column2: THOSE considering buying a used car or truck through eBay Motors can now get a free vehicle history report provided by Experian's AutoCheck. Previously such vehicle background reports were offered by some sellers, but now eBay will provide them on all used vehicles that are newer than the 1981 model year, said Nicolas Franchet, senior director for United States vehicles at eBay Motors.

On my way out of the bank after withdrawing some cash, I stopped by the customer service desk to ask about adding my new husband to my account and changing my name in their system. Are there forms to fill out? What documentation do I need? An enthusiastic ''personal banker'' practically lit up at the opportunity to help. ''No forms,'' she said. Just bring ''your marriage license, your new ID and your husband. It'll just take a minute.''

An article last Sunday about the film ''The Messenger'' misstated, at one point, the rank of the character played by Woody Harrelson. As the article noted elsewhere, he portrays a captain named Tony Stone, not a sergeant.

GRANDMA never knitted anything quite as funky as Wool and the Gang's Foxy Roxy oversize scarf or Snood Dog chunky cowl. But then, Wool and the Gang, a year-old company that includes among its creative team a former designer for Balmain and a former publicity director for Colette, is determined to bring sexy back to knitting. Aside from its collection of street-chic pieces (fingerless gloves, crop-top sweaters), it sells kits of wooden needles, vivid Peruvian yarn and easy-to-understand patterns to create and customize each design on your own. And now Wool and the Gang has opened its first shop, a nook in SoHo that offers knitting workshops. ''It's important to have this kind of craft,'' said Aurélie Nicod, a designer for the label. ''People are tired of disposable fashion.'' Wool and the Gang, 98 Thompson Street (between Prince and Spring Streets); (212) 966-9266.

CONAN O'BRIEN It's been reported that outspoken anti-immigration anchor Lou Dobbs is leaving CNN. Yeah. True story, yeah. He'll be replaced by a guy named Juan, who will do the same job for $5 an hour.

STEILMANN--Klaus, passed away on November 14th at the age of 80 after a short illness. His family was with him. Klaus was our friend and quite a remarkable man. He was one of the first young German businessmen who started working with the garment center in New York. He became the most successful women's wear manufacturer in Germany. He was a pioneer in building understanding between cultures and was admired and respected not only in the business community but in his personal life. In his later years he shifted his interest in the textile industry to the Eastern European countries and Russia and became a pioneer in building bridges internationally between these cultures and the rest of the world. At one time he was the biggest self-made industrialist devoted to women's wear in Europe. But he always made time for his soccer hobby, fine food and wine, the Club of Rome, and his friends. Klaus is survived by his wife, three daughters and two grandchildren. M & B and Zoo

The Cayman Islands aren't exactly a culinary destination like New York or Paris, but during one week in January, that's where you'll find some of the best chefs in America. Eric Ripert, above, the chef at Le Bernardin in New York, which was awarded four stars by The New York Times, has teamed up with the Ritz-Carlton, Grand Cayman, and Food & Wine magazine to host the Cayman Cookout (www.caymanislands.ky/cookout) from Jan. 14 to 18.

MINOFF--Marvin, Producer passed away Wednesday night, November 11th, at home with his family and friends. He is survived by his wife of 29 years, actress Bonnie Franklin, his daughter Julie and her husband Glenn Mar, his son Jed and his wife Madoka, his two granddaughters, Natasha MarMinoff and Maya Grace Minoff, his brother Bruce and his wife Susan. He was the much-loved uncle of Melissa Minoff, artist Edward Minoff, and the godfather of Adam Bush. Born June 26, 1931, in Brooklyn, New York, Marvin attended Lincoln High School, Syracuse University and NYU before entering the U.S. Army, where he served in intelligence during the Korean War. Returning to New York, Minoff joined the William Morris Agency. In 15 years he rose quickly at two major agencies, William Morris and International Famous Artists (today's ICM), and became vice president of the motion picture department. He represented renowned actors, writers and directors such as Cicely Tyson, Sidney Lumet, David W. Rintels and Bruce Joel Rubin while packaging such blockbusters as "The French Connection" and "Love Story." His triumphs as an agent were always featured in Variety as "Another success by Marvin Minoff, son of famed theatrical haberdasher Harry Minoff," a tip of the hat to his father, who owned a clothing store up the street. Minoff left the agency business in 1974 to become president of David Frost's David Paradine Television, Inc., where he co-produced with Frost the historic "Nixon Interviews," as well as subsequent interviews with Henry Kissinger and the Shah of Iran. While at Paradine he also produced James Michener's "Dynasty," "The Ordeal of Patty Hearst," and "Portrait of a Rebel: Margaret Sanger," starring his soon-to-be wife Bonnie Franklin. After leaving Paradine he continued as an independent producer until 1985, when he formed Farrell/Minoff Productions, a partnership with actor/writer Mike Farrell. The pair worked together for the next quarter century, producing motion pictures for television starring such luminaries as Shelley Fabares, Fred Savage, Helen Hunt, Tess Harper, Patricia Wettig, Jill Clayburgh, Missy Crider and Edward Asner, along with two features: the award-winning "Dominick and Eugene" starring Tom Hulce and Ray Liotta for Orion Pictures and Universal's "Patch Adams," starring Robin Williams. A beloved and highly respected veteran of "The show-biz wars," Minoff enjoyed the esteem of all those with whom he worked and was universally regarded as that rare thing in the business: an honest man. Services will be held Sunday at Mount Sinai Memorial Park in Hollywood Hills at 11am.
HERE are highlights of other items published in the Wheels blog last week:

When Staff Sgt. Dan Nevins was brought to Walter Reed Army Medical Center in Washington five years ago after being injured in Iraq, he was met by John Melia, who gave him a backpack filled with ''comfort stuff,'' like a CD player, shorts and T-shirts. Melia is the founder of the Wounded Warrior Project, which seeks to help wounded veterans. Today, Nevins is working for the project. On Saturday, he served as an honorary captain for South Carolina in its game against No. 1 Florida. The Gamecocks wore a jersey, designed by Under Armour, that was black with desert camouflage. Instead of names on the back, each jersey featured a word like ''Duty,'' ''Honor'' or ''Commitment.'' Maryland also wore the jerseys against Virginia Tech.
CARRIAGE HOUSE CONDO $279,000

Mourners at Abraham Lincoln National Cemetery in Elwood, Ill., at the funeral for Pfc. Michael Pearson of nearby Bolingbrook. Private Pearson was one of 13 killed in the shootings at Fort Hood, Tex., on Nov. 5.

ARMSTRONG--John Chace, died on November 4th, 2009 in Shelburne, VT from complications of aortic stenosis, a disease that robbed him of his energy and a bit of his memory, but never his analytic mind. He was delivered to the Lord peacefully, at his home, under the light of a full moon and a clear sky. John was born in 1918 in Rochester, NY, the only child of George S. and Dorothy M. Armstrong. Raised in Riverside, CT, he attended Riverside School, Brunswick School and Deerfield Academy. He graduated from Williams College and New York University. After a brief period of employment with Dupont, John went on to work with his father's firm, the George S. Armstrong Company, in New York City. He worked there as a consulting engineer until his retirement as president of the company in 1995. John married Helga Evensen in 1950 and, until her untimely death in 1974, raised their three daughters together. His unfailing and absolute devotion to his children and their wellbeing stirred his spirit until his last breath. He was married to Mary Helen Post Hurlimann from 1977 until 2001. While he held her three daughters, Mary Ann, Lily and Sandy, in the highest regard and with much affection, Sandy held a piece of his heart. Aside from the pride he took in his work and the accomplishments of his children and grandchildren, John was deeply proud of his efforts on behalf of the New York University Alumni Federation. He leaves his children: Karin and her husband, Arthur Newhouse of Stowe, Vermont; Christine of Shelburne, Vermont; and Lise of South Burlington, Vermont. Grandchildren, Bart and wife, Amy, Kirsten and husband, Ben, Matthew, Anna Christina, Brendan, Christian and Lille, and great grandsons, Chace and Liam, cherish his memory. Private services were held on November 7, 2009 at the Putnam Cemetery in Greenwich, CT. A Memorial Service will be held next summer (2010) in Greensboro, VT, John's lifelong and beloved summer home. Although John appreciated flowers, and loved both a woman who grew them and a woman who painted them, instead of flowers, he preferred that any memorials in his name be made to the John C. Armstrong Scholarship Fund at the New York University Alumni Federation, c/o Alan Shapiro, Director of Gift Planning, 25 W. 4th Street, 4th fl., NYC, NY 10012. (212.998.6960).
Art Randy Kennedy

CUTTS--Edmund A.,Sr., of Oxford, MD died on Wednesday, November 11, 2009. He was the beloved husband of the late Marguerite Cutts, loving father of Edmund A. Cutts, Jr., Linda C. Featherman and Ronnie Cutts, and devoted grandfather of five grandchildren. A graveside service will be held on Saturday, November 21, 2009 at 11am at Oxford Cemetery in Oxford, MD. Friends may call on Friday, November 20, 2009 from 68pm at Fellows, Helfenbein and Newnam Funeral Home, PA, Easton, MD. www.fhnfuneralhome.com
1960 CONTEMPORARY $1,399,000

When the Oasis of the Seas, the world's largest cruise ship, departed Finland on its maiden voyage earlier this month, it barely squeezed under Denmark's Great Belt Bridge, with less than two feet to spare. There will be no such close calls when the Oasis, owned by Royal Caribbean International, docks in its new home, Cruise Terminal 18, a huge complex that opened Nov. 8 at Port Everglades, Fla. The Oasis, above, which measures 1,187 feet long and has seven themed ''neighborhoods,'' was built over two years at a reported $1.5 billion. Its 16 decks offer capacity for more than 5,000 guests and 2,000 crew members -- as well as 12,000 plants.

''It was really Warhol's night.'' Philippe Ségalot, a Manhattan art dealer who was an unsuccessful bidder for ''200 One Dollar Bills'' by Andy Warhol, above. The silkscreen painting sold for $43.7 million, including fees, at a Sotheby's auction.

Stanley was a "force" in our lives a vibrant personality, astute businessman, wise counselor, strong leader and endless source of optimism and good humor. Our deepest sympathy goes out to his wife Gloria, his daughters and grandchildren. We will miss him dearly.

Both are great horses, and certainly deserving of horse of the year in a normal year. However, only one has an undefeated career, won a first-ever Breeders' Cup Classic for a mare, and won every race going away, rather than hanging on for dear life. Zenyatta is the 2009 horse of the year. If Rachel Alexandra can go undefeated in 2010 and win the Breeders' Cup Classic at Churchill Downs, she earns it for 2010.

ARBEENY--Theresa, passed away unexpectedly on November 13, 2009. Devoted wife of the late Daniel Arbeeny, beloved mother of Kenneth and Valerie Nemer, incredible mother-in-law to Maureen Grealish and John Nemer, and, above all, loving, caring, thoughtful and inspirational grandmother to Allison, Audrey and Andrew Arbeeny and Jessica and John Nemer and Lisa (his fiancee). We should all aspire to be just like Tessie - selfless and always giving. There was no one quite like her. Wake at McLaughlin Funeral Home, 9620 Third Avenue, Brooklyn, NY 11209 Monday 2-5 and 7-9pm. Funeral Mass: Tuesday 10am, St. Nicholas Antiochian Orthodox Cathedral, 355 State St., Brooklyn, NY 11217. www.stnicholascathedral.org. Burial following: Mt. Olivet Cemetery, Maspeth, Queens.
MIDTOWN STUDIO $395,000

COHN--Mildred. The Hunter College community is deeply saddened by the passing of our extraordinary alumna, a pioneering biochemist and research scientist. The recipient of the prestigious National Medal of Science, Dr. Cohn worked in the labs of six Nobel laureates and co-authored scientific papers with them. Her own research led to the development of magnetic resonance imaging technology. In her memory, Hunter is establishing the Mildred Cohn Scholarship Fund. Contributions may be made to The Hunter College Foundation, 695 Park Avenue, E1313, New York, NY 10065. Our sincerest condolences to her children, Nina Primakoff Rossomando, Laura Primakoff, Paul Primakoff, and their families. Jennifer J. Raab President, Hunter College

We were approached by the lobbyist, who asked if we would be willing to enter a statement in the Congressional Record. I asked him for a draft. I tweaked a couple of words. There's not much reason to reinvent the wheel on a Congressional Record entry. STANLEY V. WHITE, chief of staff for Representative Robert A. Brady of Pennsylvania, one of dozens of lawmakers who used speeches ghost-written by a biotechnology company during the health-care debate in the House. [26]
Pop Jon Pareles

William A. Thomas, 46, is a lawyer whose practice includes international investment disputes and personal injury claims. He lives alone in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, and operates out of a one-room office on Fifth Avenue, where he is ''a pure solo act -- chief cook and bottle washer and all that.'' Most days, Mr. Thomas walks to lunch at Eisenberg's Sandwich Shop, near Madison Square Park. He will often take clients there -- though not those ''who are extremely concerned about their weight or cholesterol levels!'' Originally from Philadelphia and a lifelong Phillies fan, Mr. Thomas came to New York in 1987 with ''vague ambitions of becoming a musician.'' He continues to play jazz and rock piano, for fun and in a handful of gigs. He and Josh Konecky, the owner of Eisenberg's and a musician himself, often talk about their shared love of the Beatles and other classic acts. Mr. Thomas has visited Mr. Konecky's small recording studio in Eisenberg's basement, and says he hopes to jam there one day. Probably after lunch. I'm not a foodie, I'm not a gourmet. I'm a single guy, living in New York, and my refrigerator is, well, it's pretty sparsely appointed, why don't we just leave it at that.

The Grameen Bank is best known for its microloans to women in places like Bangladesh, Cameroon and Mexico. Almost two years ago, the bank extended its principles of microfinancing to New York, where it focuses on immigrant women. To receive a low-cost loan the average loan amount is $1,625 borrowers must make a deposit into a savings account each week and attend meetings with a group of their peers. So far, Grameen America has lent money to nearly 1,400 people in New York, helping them to start businesses like clothing and jewelry stores, flower shops and food stands.

Riley Skinner, left, missed a chance to become the first quarterback to start in four victories against Bobby Bowden when Florida State beat Wake Forest, 41-28. He threw two interceptions. Texas reached 10 victories for the ninth consecutive season with a win over Baylor. That streak is second only to Florida State's 14-season run of 10-win seasons from 1987 through 2000.

CARLY MARGOLIS left Cavern, a wallpaper design house she founded in 2005, to work more with her hands. The result is All for the Mountain, a jewelry line inspired by sacred objects of the past and future. ''People joke that I should sell the collection at Star Trek conventions,'' Ms. Margolis said. ''Strangely, I take that as a compliment.'' The model Erin Wasson is a fan of the Triangle Stack, a necklace with a pendant of upside-down pyramids. We like the Shoulder Pads, a bronze collar with objects, cast from crystal, that lie on top of the shoulders. Had J. R. R. Tolkien dated Nefertiti, he'd have given her a piece like this one. Bronze Shoulder Pads, $345 at allforthemountain.com and Maryam Nassir Zadeh, 123 Norfolk Street; (212) 673-6405.
VAROUXIS--Nicholas. Former Brooklyn resident, died on November 6 in Northern Virginia. Memorial donations can be made to Broadway Cares, 165 West 46th St. #

LOMBARDI--Rosemarie Benner, age 70, died peacefully in her sleep at her home in Washington, CT on November 5, 2009 of Pancreatic cancer. Born in Germany, she came to the U.S.A. in 1962 and became a U.S. citizen in 1990. She is survived by her husband of 44 years Bonnell Lombardi, son Clark Lombardi, daughter Brita Lombardi Bishop, two granddaughters, and a sister.

THE NEWSLou Dobbs, the CNN host known for voicing strong opinions about illegal immigrants and other issues, abruptly resigned from the network. BEHIND THE NEWS Mr. Dobbs was an outlier at CNN, which generally strives for middle-of-the-road newscasts compared with the more cacophonous programs on MSNBC and Fox News. Mr. Dobbs said he wanted ''to be a leader in the national conversation'' more than he wanted to stay at the network, where Jonathan Klein, its president, had been telling him to tone down his on-air advocacy. CNN said John King would take over Mr. Dobbs's time slot.
MINOFF--Marvin. Thank you for your love, friendship, generosity and wonderful humor. We love you and we'll miss you always. With great sorrow from our families to yours, the Sultans and Gells.

BRODY--Martin, died at age 88 in West Orange, NJ on October 29, 2009. He was the Chairman and CEO of Restaurant Associates (RA) from 1963-1992. Under Martin's leadership RA became one of the premier restaurant companies in the country known for their concept restaurant and high quality food service for major institutional clients. Born in 1921 in a cold water flat in Newark, NJ, Martin started working in his father's business, Rain or Shine, at nine years old. Rain or Shine was a box lunch company that thrived during the Depression selling prepackaged lunches to factory workers throughout Essex County. He graduated from Weequahic High School and Michigan State University. He enlisted in the army during World War II. In 1946, he returned home a Captain and joined the family business. He met Florence Brody (formerly Gropper) on a blind date and they were married 6 months later. After the family business had grown from 1 to 60 trucks, Martin engineered its sale in 1961. Two years later, he became Chairman, President and CEO of RA by merging Waldorf Systems with RA. RA created and owned such renowned NYC restaurants as The Four Seasons, The Forum, Mama Leones, Tavern on the Green, Brasserie, La Fonda del Sol, and Sea Grill. The food service division included such institutions as Lincoln Center, Kennedy Center, United Nations, Metropolitan Museum, Harvard Club, Ford Foundation and the U.S. Open. Nationwide operations included Charlie Brown's and Acapulco restaurant chains, and Eastern News Stands. Born of immigrant parents, his mother was pregnant with Martin when they came to this country from Budapest. Martin literally went from Ellis Island to the boardroom. He was known among his peers and colleagues for his inspirational leadership and altruism. At an early age he was invited to join the Young Presidents Organization (YPO) and later World Presidents Organization. He served 10 years as the Chairman of the Executive Committee for Caldor, which was later purchased by Associated Dry Goods, a merger initiated by Mr. Brody. Other board positions included: Boston Celtics, Dollar Savings Bank, Leisure Technology, Jaclyn, Washington National Life Insurance Company and countless Smith Barney Mutual Funds. He also served on the American Stock Exchange Advisory Committee for eight years. Martin was a true humanitarian whose generosity and leadership in community affairs touched countless lives. His nonprofit and civic work included 14 years on the board of St. Barnabas Healthcare System, the largest healthcare system in the state of NJ. He served eight years as Chairman of St. Barnabas and in 1977 was awarded an honorary lifetime trusteeship. For 13 years he was Chairman of the Finance Committee for the NJ Transit Authority Board. A plaque at Penn Station in Newark commemorates his 20 years of outstanding service. In addition he served on the NJ State Board of Institutions and Agencies and was a Commissioner on the Governor's Management Review Commission. He served on the board of Temple B'Nai Abraham and the South Palm Beach Jewish Federation. He was Chairman of the Young Men's Division of the UJA and was actively involved in the Jewish Federation of Metro West NJ as both a volunteer and board member. Martin Brody did so much for so many. A man of honor, he had an extraordinary work ethic, integrity and personal warmth. In a world of change, no one who worked for him ever quit. A longtime resident of Short Hills, NJ, he lived in Boca Raton, FL. Mr. Brody is survived by his beloved wife and lifetime partner, Florence, brother Arthur, sister Marion, daughter and son-in-law Renee and Alan Levow, son and daughter-in-law Marc and Carleen Brody. His three grandchildren Jake Levow, Cary Levow and Justine Brody were the light of his life from the day they were born. He was fond of saying "life is not a dress rehearsal" and he lived his life with that quote in mind. Martin Brody devoted most of his life to serving his community, his country and his family. We are all better for having known him and he will be deeply missed.
CONRAD--Ira, passed on November 8th, 2008. Loving father and grandfather is missed by his family and friends.

The five most e-mailed articles from nytimes.com/sports for Nov. 7 to Nov. 13. 1. WARD HELPS BIRACIAL YOUTHS ON JOURNEY TOWARD ACCEPTANCE The plight of biracial children in South Korea was largely ignored until 2006, when Hines Ward was the most valuable player of Super Bowl XL. Koreans were quick to make the link to his Korean heritage. (Published Nov. 9)

TERENCE KOH, an artist known as much for his extraordinary wardrobe (monkey-fur coats, metal Balenciaga leggings) as his work, has lately turned his attention to fashion. Following a T-shirt collaboration with Opening Ceremony last summer, Mr. Koh (above) has now designed white leather Converse sneakers, stripped down and smoothed out for a minimalist effect. ''I wanted to design the simplest Converse shoe possible,'' he explained. ''I see it as a perfect round white pearl.'' And it is just the start of his design career: ''I want to do more things in fashion,'' Mr. Koh said, adding that he was in discussions for a fragrance. ''Fashion is more interesting than art.''
There has not been any swagger in Detroit since the Thunderbird started looking like an Escort with a spoiler, so the Vikings can walk tall for at least another week.

'Another ho-hum day for him. I don't know how many other first evers the guy can have.' Clemson Coach Dabo Swinney about running back C. J. Spiller, who threw and ran for a touchdown and caught a scoring pass, the first player in team history to do all three in one game.

PLOPPED in a white leather chair in a small office in Bloomberg L.P's Manhattan headquarters, Andrew Lack knows exactly how to articulate the aspirations of this 28-year-old media and technology company. ''We want to be the world's most influential news organization,'' says Mr. Lack, who oversees Bloomberg's television, radio and dot-com endeavors.

The Giants and The Mets will miss their number one fan. Our deepest condolences to the family and especially ML. Keystone Electronics Corp.

A UNITED STATES District Judge struck down a Christian-themed license plate that had been approved by the South Carolina legislature, the Associated Press reported. Judge Cameron Currie ruled that the plate was a violation of the First Amendment, which prohibits Congress from making a law ''respecting an establishment of religion.'' The South Carolina plate featured an image of a cross in front of a stained-glass window, accompanied by the words ''I Believe.''
Dance Jack Anderson

WINGATE--William. The Board of Trustees of the Fire Island Synagogue mourns the passing of former board member, officer and friend, Bill Wingate. Our deepest condolences to his family. Shaul Magid, Rabbi Harry Trattner, Cantor

He is survived by his beloved mother, Renate; sister, Hedda; nephew, Gregory; niece, Alexa; aunt and uncle, Irene and Henry and cousins, Morton, Ari, and Ellen. He will be dearly missed.

Word trickled out that Harvard had entered into a 10-year licensing agreement for a line of preppy clothing ... under the name Harvard Yard. [A university spokesman] disputed the idea that a preppy, Harvard-branded clothing line would diminish the university's efforts to appeal to students of diverse backgrounds. -- The Times, Sept. 6

INGLE--John Frederick, Jr.,died peacefully in his sleep at Peninsula Hospital in Burlingame, California on November 9th, 2009. He was 86 years old. Architect, yachtsman and World War II veteran, John was born in Alhambra, California. John served at the Battle of The Bulge in the Army Corp of Engineers. After WWII, John studied architecture at the London School of Architecture and University of California, Berkeley where he was a member of the Phi Delta Theta fraternity. John was a devoted husband, father, grandfather and great-grandfather. While a young architect in San Francisco, John married Barbara Schick Ingle with whom he had three children. Following Barbara's death in 1975, John married Susan Lee Smith and added three children and five grandchildren to his extended family. John and Susan's thirty-two year marriage was filled with love and happiness as they enjoyed entertaining on their sailing vessels and yacht. John was a very active member of the Saint Francis Yacht Club where he officiated as Cruise Committee Chairman in 1987. As a principal in the architectural firm Rasmussen Ingle Anderson, John was among the pioneers of Silicon Valley architecture designing clean-air rooms for the industry. John also designed medical facilities and shopping centers which were built through out the country. John was a member of the American Institute of Architects and licensed in several states. John is survived by his wife, Susan and his children, Dianne Ingle Farley (New York City), Marten Ingle (Ville d'Orsay, France), Christian Ingle (Oakland, CA), their children as well as his extensive extended family. The family will hold a private memorial service in Hillsborough, California at a future date. Donations honoring John may be sent to University of California San Francisco Foundation, attention Stanley Prusiner's Alzheimer's Research, Institute for Neurodegenerative Diseases HSE774, 513 Parnassus Avenue, San Francisco, California 94143-0518

I took my 10-year-old niece and my 8-year-old nephew to see ''Where the Wild Things Are,'' and they were neither bored nor particularly excited by the film, though both professed to have really enjoyed it when queried afterward. They couldn't articulate it all that well, but they had certainly found a connection with the movie, possibly because, like many children, they basically live on that island all the time, in the company of adults who are variously playful, loving, angry, moody, absent, funny, sad and scary; and all these modes are totally unpredictable and frequently unexplainable. -- Caelum Vatnsdal of Winnipeg, Manitoba, in response to A. O. Scott's column about the complicated themes in animated films like ''Where the Wild Things Are.''
Theater Jason Zinoman

RYAN--James Vincent, died November 12, 2009. He was born on April 7, 1927 in New York City to John and Harriet Clarke Ryan. He graduated from Fordham Preparatory School, Purdue University and Fordham University Law School. He served briefly in the U.S. Navy. He had a long and distinguished career as a litigator, retiring as a senior partner of Rogers & Wells in 1989. He appeared several times before the U.S. Supreme Court as an advocate, most notably in his successful defense of Bangor Punta versus Chris Craft, a dispute arising from the acquisition of Piper Aircraft. An enthusiastic golfer, he served on the Board of Governors at Winged Foot Golf Club. A long-time resident of Rye, NY and a former member of Sankaty Head Golf Club on Nantucket, he resided in Greenwich, CT since 1997. He was predeceased by his wife of 46 years, Anne Murray Ryan, and his daughters, Marybeth and Deirdre Ryan. He is survived by his daughter, Maureen Smith, and his sons, Kevin, Emmett and James Ryan and seven grandchildren. The memorial mass will be held Wednesday, November 18th, at 10:30am at St. Michael's Church on North Street in Greenwich. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to Swim Across America Team Didi or Fordham Prep.
BERNSTEIN--Howard A. In our hearts on your birthday and forever. Our family

JACOBY--Gaby Monet, October 31, 2009, passed away peacefully after a long illness, surrounded by family and friends that adored her. Gaby was the beloved wife of legendary comedy writer, Coleman Jacoby, for over fifty-four years and magnificent stepmother to Catherine and Antoinette Jacoby. Nee, Marilyn Lagoria in Oakland California, Gaby became a flamenco dancer as a young girl, and came to New York City at age 19. Gaby danced on Broadway in "By the Beautiful Sea" in 1954 and in "Mask and Gown" in 1956. She went on to become a choreographer of live industrial musical shows, as a partner in production company Concepts Unlimited Inc. Concepts produced the documentary film, "Norman Rockwell's World: An American Dream" winning the Academy Award for Best Short Subject Film in 1971. In addition, Gaby produced and wrote many other successful documentary films for television garnering several Emmy awards and critical acclaim. Gaby had two passions: her love of her family and her love of her work. After forming Jacoby-Monet Productions with Coleman, Gaby began a new chapter in her ever developing career, writing and producing for HBO documentaries, including the highly successful "Autopsy" series with medical examiner Michael Baden. Working closely for the last several years with friend and colleague, Sheila Nevins, President of HBO Documentary Films, Gaby additionally produced "The Iceman Interviews" and "The Iceman and the Psychiatrist". Gaby was known and loved for her kindness, generosity, humility and strong, quiet convictions. In 1963 Gaby marched on Washington with Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., and was pleased to live to see Barack Obama elected President. Despite her illness, she continued working on the HBO documentary about the Barnes art collection, currently in production. Gaby is survived by her husband Coleman Jacoby, her stepdaughter Loria Parker and husband Gerry Janssen, brother, Jack Lagoria of San Francisco, niece Kitty Dorazi, grandniece Cynthia Dorazi and grandnephews. A memorial in her honor is planned at HBO on Tuesday, December 1st at 10am. Please RSVP at HBO, 212-512-7261 if planning to attend.

GRAFF--Thomas. The Board and staff of Environmental Defense Fund extend heartfelt condolences to the family of our beloved longtime friend and colleague, Tom Graff, who passed away this Thursday. An icon within the environmental community, Tom devoted his 37 year career with EDF to finding transformative solutions to environmental challenges. His successes in restoring wetlands and estuaries, reforming energy policy and reducing air pollution are a great testament to his life's work and leave an enduring legacy. A mentor, friend and hero to us all - he will be sorely missed. Carl Ferenbach, Chairman Fred Krupp, President

WILL COTTON has spent the last decade baking the cakes and confections that appear in his paintings. Consequently, he has become a pretty good pastry chef. ''So I thought to myself, I should open a bakery,'' he said, a smudge of flour on his face. ''Or at least a temporary one.'' And for three Sundays this month, he is doing just that -- baking birthday cakes, pear frangipani tarts and an assortment of macarons (he learned from the chief pâtissier at Ladurée, Philippe Andrieu) in the back of Partners & Spade. Everything is for sale (the macarons are $2.50 each; an apple caramel cake, $7) and intended for eating, rather than admiring. ''The real art is indulging in them,'' noted Mr. Cotton (above). ''It's an experiential thing.''

Every generation has the cross-country rivalry it deserves. The early 1960s had Packers-Colts, a battle of hard-hitting teams with clean-cut-but-fiery quarterbacks representing rugged shipping towns. The early 1990s had Cowboys-49ers, a booming new economy feud pitting petrodollar-fueled bluster against Silicon Valley efficiency. The current generation gets Patriots-Colts, an Internet-ready morality tale of contrasting personalities: Peyton Manning's aw-shucks drawl and the Colts' P.T.A. picnic reputation versus the tabloid pinup Tom Brady and the shadowy Svengali Bill Belichick. The baggage rarely overwhelms the game: the American Football Conference usually hangs in the balance when these teams meet, and the close final scores (18-15, 27-20, and 24-21 in recent years) do not do justice to how dramatic the games typically are.

KENNEDY--James M.,of Manhattan, died on Thursday, November 12, 2009. He was born on December 3, 1933 son of James and Evelyn (Griffin) Kennedy of Towanda, PA. After completing his formal studies at Xavier High School, Fordham and Columbia Universities he joined the Electronics Research Laboratories and Riverside Research Institute as EVP. He retired in 1995 after 40 years of service. Mr. Kennedy is survived by his loving wife of 43 years, Mary Alice Kennedy nee McDonald. He leaves countless friends around the world. A funeral will take place on Tuesday, November 17 in Ashland, Pa. There will be a memorial service at 4pm on Friday, December 4 at Holy Trinity Roman Catholic Church, 213 West 82nd Street. In lieu of flowers, please send donations to St. Luke's Roosevelt Hospital ICU Unit East 1000 10th Avenue, NY, NY 10019.

KAUFMANN--Robert C.,art librarian, passed away November 1st. From 1985 until shortly before his death, he worked at the Metropolitan Museum of Art in the Costume Institute, Watson Library, and ESDA. Prior to that he served at the Cooper-Hewitt Museum and the Yale Art & Architecture Library. His lifelong love of Italy began in 1966 with his participation in the rescue of art damaged by the Florence floods. He was active in the Victorian Society, ARLIS, and SAGE. His sister, Catherine Tatum, wishes to acknowledge the joy and comfort these friendships brought him. Robert's greatest legacy, - an unfailing kindness and generosity of spirit, - lives on in the hearts of his numerous and cherished friends. These friendships nurtured and enriched him. A celebration of Robert's life was held November 14 in Birmingham, AL. Contributions may be made to the National Cancer Institute (Director, National Cancer Institute, 9000 Rockville Pike, Building 3, Room 11A-16, Bethesda, MD, 20892), or to a favorite charity.

The ginkgo trees are dripping in gold. Autumn's last hurrah is to be seen all over the city, as pools of leaves fall to the ground. Stylish women are wearing many points of view -- so long as it's black with a touch of white. The really daring are accessorizing with red handbags and shoes. And some women confide they have not been able to resist buying new clothes after a year and a half of resorting to their own closets. Last week started with Indian summer weather and ended with blustery winds and showers, bringing out two seasons of fashion. Wednesday was Veterans Day and the flags lining Fifth Avenue called to mind Childe Hassam's paintings. The marchers gathered at Madison Square Park, where more than 100 Vietnam veterans roared by on motorcycles, taking the colors for a spin on Fifth Avenue.

OUTPOSTS A year ago, most people were open-minded about the ground-shaking changes that came with the economic collapse. Polls found a slim majority in favor of Wall Street bailouts to save the economy. They would listen, watch, wait. By this fall, the majority were not only against the bailouts, but in favor of curbing pay on Wall Street, and tightening government regulation of same. The continuous drip of perceived unfairness continues. One day it's news that Goldman Sachs seems to have stepped ahead of the line of those waiting to receive H1N1 vaccines: why were investment bankers getting doses rather than children or pregnant women? This week, Gallup found one in five parents saying they were unable to get swine flu vaccine for their children.

KOZAK--Lillian, passed away peacefully in her home on November 11, 2009. An ardent leader in the fight for women's rights, as well as a professional accountant and auditor in the Nassau County Attorney's Office, Family Court Bureau from 1977-2002, Lillian was appointed Chair of The National Organization for Women-New York State Domestic Relations Task Force in 1975. Professional surveys show that the number one reason women contact NOW is for issues related to divorce. Lillian and the core of women she attracted to work with the NOW Task Force were fierce in their determination to end the impoverishment of women and their families once they went through the legal process of divorce. Her background as an accountant gave her the professional skills to monitor such technical issues as laws covering joint bank accounts, the hidden drawbacks in equitable division of property and poorly drafted divorce mediation agreements. Early on, she warned that alternate dispute resolution programs could put women at a disadvantage economically or in cases of child custody and support. Lillian advocated not only for making domestic violence an element in any court evaluation about the "best interests of the child" but also for ending practices that resulted in fraudulent statements about assets. Lillian was a recipient of the Susan B. Anthony award of The National Organization for Women-New York State, The National NOW Woman to Woman Award, the Long Island NOW Lifetime Achievement Award, and recently, The Award for Lifetime Service from the Coalition for Family Justice. Lillian was deeply loved by her family. Her generosity was without bounds. She is survived by her daughter Ellen Kozak and her son-in-law, Scott Miller of New York City. Her son Jeffrey Kozak is deceased. A memorial service will be announced.

Teammates have called Maurice Jones-Drew pocket Hercules, an apt description for a runner who is listed at 5 feet 7 inches, but packs 208 pounds on his frame. In his first season as the Jaguars' featured back, Jones-Drew has rushed for 737 yards and an N.F.L.-leading 11 touchdowns. If the Jets' second-ranked defense has a weakness, it has been stopping the run. The Jets are 14th in rushing yards allowed, yielding an average of 108.1. The Jets are without Kris Jenkins, their disruptive nose tackle, who had surgery earlier last week to repair a torn anterior cruciate ligament.

LONG the stuff of frumpy holiday attire, velvet has taken a cool new turn this season, re-imagined by a slew of designers in unexpected ways: Alexander Wang used it for biker jackets and brogues; Sonia Rykiel for Teddy Boy-style pantsuits. Proenza Schouler cut it into skinny jeans and technically complicated devoré dresses (if you saw the Sundance Channel series ''The Day Before,'' you understand). Chloé sent out slouchy paper-bag pieces and a louche Halston-era jumpsuit (worn rather expertly by Diane Kruger, at right, above). As for Christopher Kane, he appliquéd strips of the stuff onto organza to create a range of fantastically graphic cocktail dresses. Not since 1996, when Tom Ford sent out swanky velvet pantsuits at Gucci, has the fabric looked so good.
FICHTENHOLZ--Milton, 91, Sunny Isles, FL, on November 8, 2009. International Tax Specialist with IRS, Coopers Lybrand and Shearson Lehman. His loving family misses him.

SCHERER--Donald Henry, passed away at home on October 23, 2009 surrounded by his four children who adored him, Christopher Scherer, Priscilla Droher, Amy Scherer, and Amanda Simons. His eight grandchildren further survive Donald, and his beloved wife, Sue Ann Scherer, passed away on May 2, 2008. Born in Chicago on August 22, 1927, he traveled the world during his international career as an architect, award-winning designer, and fine artist. This extraordinary man lives on through family memories and his legacy of art. www.donschererartist.com

9 P.M. (History) WWII IN HD Drawing on diary entries, these firsthand stories of 12 Americans during World War II -- soldiers, nurses and reporters -- are told in this 10-hour mini-series across five consecutive nights, using archival film footage converted into high definition. First: ''Darkness Falls,'' which covers the attack on Pearl Harbor and the first bloody battles at Guadalcanal and in North Africa. (Above, sailors working on an engine before the North Africa campaign.) In ''Hard Way Back,'' at 10, Charles Scheffel (voiced by Ron Livingston), an Army captain from Enid, Okla., eager to carry on his family's military tradition, battles Rommel's forces in Tunisia; and Jack Werner (Justin Bartha), a Jewish émigré from Vienna who enlisted in the Army just days before Pearl Harbor, faces combat in the Pacific theater. Gary Sinise narrates. 10 A.M. (Fox) FOX NEWS SUNDAY WITH CHRIS WALLACE Former New York City Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and Senator Jack Reed, Democrat of Rhode Island, weigh in on the decision to try Khalid Shaikh Mohammed, who is accused of planning the 9/11 attacks, and four other men reportedly involved in the plot, in federal court in New York.

The price of $4,650 in January was the same as last year's price -- not higher. (The price quoted for last year, $3,875, omitted taxes and fees; with those, the cost comes to $4,650.)

SKIDMORE--Margaret Cooke, died peacefully in her home surrounded by her family in Houston, TX on Monday, November 9, 2009. She was born in New York City on September 10, 1938 to Mary Frances Adams Cooke and Rev. Maurice (Tug) Bernard Cooke. She graduated from Nightingale Bamford School in New York, NY and Chatham University in Pittsburgh, PA. She married Louis H. Skidmore, Jr., then of New York City, on September 10, 1960. Mrs. Skidmore is preceded in death by her parents. She is survived by her loving husband of 49 years, Louis H. Skidmore, Jr. of Houston, TX; brother Geoffrey Bernard Cooke of Franklin, TN; son Christopher Alexander Skidmore and his wife Anne of Houston, TX; daughter Elizabeth Park Skidmore of Boston, MA; daughter Heather Skidmore Howard and her husband Christopher Tenney Howard of San Francisco, CA, and grandchildren: Madeleine and Alexander Skidmore; and Addison and Taylor Howard. After 27 years, Mrs. Skidmore retired from the Museum of Fine Arts, Houston as Associate Director, Development. During her tenure, the MFAH's endowment grew, becoming one of the top five museum endowments in the US. Mrs. Skidmore placed tremendous value in the education she received at both Nightingale-Bamford and Chatham University. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Nightingale-Bamford School, In memory of Margaret Cooke Skidmore, 20 East 92nd St, New York, New York 10128; Chatham University, In memory of Margaret Cooke Skidmore, Woodland Road, Pittsburgh, PA 05232; or Skowhegan School of Painting & Sculpture, Ste. 1116, 200 Park Ave., New York, NY 10003-1538.

On my way out of the bank after withdrawing some cash, I stopped by the customer service desk to ask about adding my new husband to my account and changing my name in their system. Are there forms to fill out? What documentation do I need? An enthusiastic ''personal banker'' practically lit up at the opportunity to help. ''No forms,'' she said. Just bring ''your marriage license, your new ID and your husband. It'll just take a minute.''

SAUERBACH--Robert, on November 7th at age 92. Adored husband, father and grandfather. Our hearts are broken but we are blessed to have had him in our lives. He will be missed more than words can express. Survived by his beloved wife, Leila, daughters Carol and Janet, and grandchildren, Michael, Jackie, Scott and Brett. We will love and miss you forever, Daddy.

ZACHARIAS--Fred C.,Herzog Research Professor at the University of San Diego's School of Law, passed away Sunday, November 8, following a protracted battle with esophageal cancer, surrounded by his loved ones. He was 56 years old. Fred was one of the Nation's most noted and prolific scholars on matters of the law profession's ethics, focusing on diverse issues such as prosecutorial ethics, attorney-client confidentiality, ethics code drafting, judicial regulation of lawyers, and the role of advocates in the American legal system. He believed that lawyers have ethical roles beyond their duty to advance their clients' interests, that, in addition, they have countervailing obligations to the courts, the legal system, third parties, society as a whole, and general morality. Fred was a graduate of the Ethical Culture and Fieldston Schools, Johns Hopkins University and Yale Law School; before becoming a Law Professor at Cornell in 1983, he served as a public interest lawyer in Washington, DC. He moved to the University of San Diego in 1990. He was a member of the American Law Institute, a former chair of the AALS Section of Professional Responsibility and the Section on Scholarship, and has been an active member of various organizations relating to lawyers' professional ethics. His philanthropic work included support for the San Diego Shelter for Homeless Teenagers (SDYCA) and as a long-term advisor to the Legal Ethics Committee of the San Diego County Bar. Fred is survived by his loving wife, Sharon Soroko Zacharias, sons Blake and Eric, mother Laure, and brother Lawrence, brother-in-law Richard Soroko, sisters-in-law Cathy Schoen and Sherry Schoenberg, a nephew Josh and a niece Alix. He will be remembered above all as a warm, loving and humorous family man, a cherished colleague, a loyal and generous friend, and a man of the highest principles.

EDISON--Sidney J.,died peacefully at home on October 29, at age 94. Known affectionately to his intimates as "Palmer," he was a much loved and admired brother, cousin, mentor, friend, enjoyed for his whimsy, protean knowledge, ironic wit, modest authority and supportive generosity. Born in Atlanta, raised in St. Louis, a one-time resident of California and a sometime resident of Venice, Italy and Paris, he was at heart a New Yorker, and attended the theatre two or three nights a week, well into his later years. After attending the University of Wisconsin, Sidney spent a year painting in Paris. A man of high critical standards, no less when measuring his own talents, he returned to the US and settled in New York, where he was hired by Lincoln Kirstein as the first director of the MOMA Dance Archive, later to become the foundation for the Dance Collection at the New York Public Library. The 40s proved a personally eventful decade, in which he met and married the late Evelyn Brookman (the marriage ended but a friendship endured), studied painting and sculpture at the New York's Art Students' League, taught ballroom dancing at the Arthur Murray Dance Studios and extended his cultural interests in music and writing, counting among his early friends Virgil Thompson and Tennessee Williams. He moved to Los Angeles and focused on his writing skills. There he found work on films being produced to support the war effort. In 1972, through his mother's friendship with an early-grade school teacher in the UK, he encountered a child whose insatiable intellectual curiosity matched his own; he became a quiet benefactor of both the young man's cultural expansion and his continuing education, on through Oxford. Of Sidney, his protege, now a professor, has said, "It's so terribly sad to lose someone who had been such an important, inspirational and transforming figure in one's life." Sidney Edison was the son of Hannah Farbstein Edison and Harry Edison. His father founded Edison Brothers Stores, an enterprise in which he was joined by his four younger brothers. It began as a single shoe store in Atlanta and grew nationally to become the largest chain of women's shoe stores in the country. As the business grew, the family moved to St. Louis, home of the Company's corporate headquarters. Sidney was predeceased by his sister Edna. He is already missed and will be remembered and quoted often by multiple generations of his close and loving family, as well as friends and acquaintances, whom he treated with equal respect. At his request, no memorial service is planned.

There is a class of utterances that, when encountered, produces irritation, distress and, in some cases, the desire to kill. You hear or read one of these and your heart sinks. Everyone will have his or her (non)favorites. Mine is a three-word announcement on the TV screen, "To Be Continued," which says, "I know that you have become invested in this story and are eager to find out how it ends, but you're going to have to wait for a few days or a week or a month or forever." In the great order of things, it is only a minor inconvenience, but it is experienced as a deprivation; you were banking on something and now it has been taken away.

In a column in The New York Times on Sunday, Richard Thaler explored what he called the diabolical economics of Swoopo, an online auction site. Swoopo sells merchandise, typically for below its price elsewhere, but charges 60 cents for every bid. Auction prices rise in one-cent increments, which means that Swoopo ends up making a lot of money off its bidders.

What makes a photograph funny? The question can be debated endlessly, but let it suffice for this brief paragraph to note that Stephen Crowley's picture of security personnel attending the presidential visit to China is amusing; in a droll, understated, Crowlian kind of way. As your eye scans the picture, most likely from left to right, you pass over figures from two cultures that are as alike in their composure as they are different in dress. Then you reach the punchline: that last pair of hands, clasped in an ever-so-slightly anxious fashion; as who wouldn't be whose job was to protect the president of the United States? We can admire the formality of the first three figures and identify with the fourth.

The group's letter, addressed to Jeffrey Katzenberg, one of several Hollywood heavyweights who serves on the board of the Motion Picture and Television Fund, came after the fund published ads in trade publications last week playing down the impact of the proposed closing. To fail to "change the board's direction," the coalition also contends, would provide only "further evidence of the moral bankruptcy of the existing board."

The debate over the authorship and authenticity of the books and blog posts that eventually became the Showtime series "Secret Diary of a Call Girl" -- criticized for supposedly glamorizing prostitution -- seems to be over. A British scientist, Brooke Magnanti, told The Sunday Times in London that she was "Belle de Jour," the escort whose sexual experiences were recounted in the blog and in three books. Ms. Magnanti, who works as a child health researcher at the University of Bristol in England, said she started in the sex trade in 2003, when she was finishing her Ph.D, and continued for more than a year. She explained that she had decided to go public now because she feared an ex-boyfriend was about to expose her. She added on her blog that she was relieved "to be able to defend what my experience of sex work is like to all the skeptics and doubters."

Bit by bit (or byte by byte), carmakers are connecting their vehicles not only to Internet-based services but also to owners' smartphones. The latest is Mercedes-Benz, which announced a new telematics platform Monday that beefs up its navigation system with traffic and weather information and lets drivers lock or unlock their cars using an iPhone or BlackBerry.
From our colleagues at The Lede:

Balyasny Asset Management, the big Chicago hedge fund run by Dmitry Balyasny, discovered no signs of improper activity after conducting an internal review into trading records and communications of a former employee who recently surfaced in the insider trading case against the Galleon Group.

CHESHIRE, Conn. - In many ways it was just another day, another class of Wesleyan University, one of the more selective colleges in the Northeast. The topic was multiculturalism in schools. The discussion focused on methods of evaluating the rhetorical skills of various commentators, from Arthur M. Schlesinger Jr. to Dinesh D'Souza.

It may take the nation that invented Fellini to truly embrace Zaha Hadid, the whirlwind architect who is by turns sugar and spitfire. Italians stress the "z" in "Zaha" as they do in "czarina," and treated her like one during last weekend's opening festivities for the National Museum of the XXI Century Arts (MAXXI) in Rome, the patient realization of a public commission won by Hadid in 1999. At a kickoff event, Hadid warned that her Italian "was nothing" but could not dissuade a crowd of journalists from lunging at her like Anita Ekberg rushing into the Trevi Fountain. With nearly 65,000 square feet of exhibition space, however, it is the Italian Ministry of Culture and Heritage that underwent a $224 million baptism, in the hopes of refreshing the ancient fonts of western art and architecture.

During a stint on Bravo's "Top Chef" reality show, chef Ariane Duarte won raves for her Thanksgiving turkey. But while dining recently at her Montclair, N.J., restaurant, CulinAriane, it was a seasonal vegetarian dish that made the biggest impression.
The holiday season must be around the corner. A 76-foot Norway spruce arrived at Rockefeller Center on Thursday and "The Radio City Christmas Spectacular" kicked off shows the following night.
Pro wrestling will continue its long run as a staple of cable programming after World Wrestling Entertainment announced a new deal Monday to remain on the USA network for another four years.

The Food and Drug Administration has indefinitely delayed a proposed ban on the sale of raw oysters harvested on the Gulf Coast during warm months in the face of opposition from the oyster industry and legislators from the region. The ban was intended to reduce the risk from Vibrio vulnificus, a bacterium that each year kills about 15 people in the United States each year.

While some American Twitter addicts reacted with real and feigned outrage on Monday to President Obama's confession, during a forum with Chinese students in Shanghai, that he does not personally update the @BarackObama feed -- which more than two million people follow on the social network -- observers in China were more interested in what he said next: that he disagrees with China's censorship of the Internet.

At a time when many consumers are drinking tap water rather than bottled water, a high-end chocolatier is making over its marketing to better fit in with the new mood.

Amaranth Advisors, the hedge fund that closed its doors three years ago after losing more than $6.6 billion on wrong-way bets on the price of natural gas, said on Monday that it had dropped its two-month old lawsuit against the hedge fund manager Paul Touradji and his firm, Touradji Capital Management. The suit claimed that Mr. Touradji breached two separate contracts signed in September 2006 that governed the transfer and purchase of Amaranth's base metals portfolio. Mr. Touradji and his firm were accused of using confidential information about Amaranth's trading strategy and its positions to unjustly profit. Touradji Capital denied Amaranth's allegations, saying that its conduct in assuming the risk of Amaranth's base metal portfolio was professional and lawful. "Amaranth has received and evaluated additional information regarding the transaction, including trading records and other information voluntarily provided by Touradji Capital, that is consistent with Touradji Capital's position that it did not violate the agreement with Amaranth and did not misuse Amaranth's proprietary information," Amaranth said in a statement. "Accordingly, Amaranth has withdrawn its summons and notice and elected not to serve a complaint against Touradji Capital." "Amaranth's decision to withdraw its claims vindicates our position that we acted appropriately and with the utmost of professionalism," Mr. Touradji said in a statement. "It also clearly validates our previous statement that the Amaranth suit was based on the misinformation of two disgruntled former employees involved in separate litigation with T.C.M." The two former employees are Robert Vollero and Gentry Beach. The men sued Touradji Capital last December, contending that they were owed $50 million in unpaid bonuses. The hedge fund filed a countersuit against the men this month alleging that the two men had lied about their abilities, stole company secrets and defamed the firm. Touradji Capital is seeking more than $250 million as compensation for financial and reputational damage
The footsteps of Attorney General Andrew M. Cuomo are growing louder for Gov. David A. Paterson.
The bye week was going to be good news for the Giants: They couldn't lose again. It turned out they had a far better week than that.

Wow. Matthew Yglesias catches David Ignatius worrying that the Fed may not have enough political support in its efforts to raise interest rates and fight inflation. As Matt correctly notes, this is a remote issue -- unemployment is high, inflation is low, and the Fed has no business raising rates any time soon.

Updated, 5:12 p.m. | The New York City Council voted overwhelmingly on Monday to grant ticket-fatigued drivers a five-minute grace period before parking-meter regulations and alternate-side parking rules are enforced, boldly defying Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, who hours earlier vowed to veto the measure, saying it would lead to "chaos."

After devoting most of his energy in recent years to feature films and cable, the writer, director and producer Larry Charles is returning to network television. Mr. Charles, who wrote numerous episodes for the NBC hit series "Seinfeld" and "Mad About You" in the 1990s, is to write and direct the pilot of an as yet unnamed series for NBC. In this decade, Mr. Charles has directed Sacha Baron Cohen's "Borat" and "Bruno" films, and also directed, produced or written episodes for two hit HBO series, "Curb Your Enthusiasm" and "Entourage." The new NBC show is to have an ensemble cast, be set in a small town and, as Mr. Charles told The Hollywood Reporter, will aim to depict "contemporary American life through the prism of a do-it-yourself homemade aesthetic that will mix mediums."

Two events late last week predict two alternative realities for the management buyout of Landry's. The events show that the company's chief executive, Tilman J. Fertitta, may have a much rougher time - or at least have to spend more money - acquiring the shares of Landry's he does not already own.

A blog called "Eating the Road'' has an extremely detailed guide to all-you-can-eat buffets and how to get the most from them. "If you arrive just before the 'changing of the guard' or the breakfast to lunch, lunch to dinner time-frames you'll not only pay the lesser dollar amount (typically $2 to $3) but may also have a wider variety to choose from.'' And, "Allow other's the right of way, especially women, children and the elderly.''

In a last desperate cry, a technician on an Antarctic expedition yelled out a temperature measurement he made as he fell into a crevasse. The number that he shouted out (covered by the penguin ) was clearly heard, but not the units. It turned out not to make a difference. What was the temperature?(Illustration: Justin Thyme)

Update | 3:28 p.m. The Library of Congress has named Paul McCartney, prolific songwriter and former Beatle, as the third recipient of its Gershwin Prize for Popular Song. "It is hard to think of another performer and composer who has had a more indelible and transformative effect on popular song and music of several different genres," the Librarian of Congress, James H. Billington, said in announcing the award on Monday. Mr. McCartney is the first non-American to win the prize, named for the songwriters George and Ira Gershwin: the previous honorees were Paul Simon and Stevie Wonder. The Library said that an all-star tribute concert is planned for the spring of 2010. Mr. McCartney, who has a new CD/DVD called "Good Evening New York City" coming out on Tuesday, said that "as a great admirer of the Gershwins' songs" he was "highly honored" to be given the prize. The Library of Congress said that Mr. McCartney planned to perform at the tribute show.

The Sausalito businessman who has denied for years that he played any role in setting the 2005 fire that destroyed $250 million of premium wine will plead guilty to arson today in federal court.

Godwin's Law -- which says that in any sufficiently long online discussion, someone will compare his opponent to Hitler -- is often interpreted to mean that if you do, in fact, start making Nazi comparisons, you've lost the argument and can no longer be taken seriously. I'm all for that. (Does this mean that we should no longer take any significant figure in the Republican Party seriously? Yes, it does.)

Students at Stanford University can now file their dissertations with the university's registrar by uploading their dissertations and receiving approval online. Then, they can publish using Google and see their works accessible by anyone with a computer.

We had parents, high school volunteers, PTA volunteers and a bunch of school children out on a beautiful fall day yesterday, making a difference at the Tuscan Elementary School in Maplewood. We mulched and wood chipped, weeded and pruned. The school looks glamorous! The volunteers were Mary (PTA Grounds chair), Karim, Lili and Julia Meddahi; Emily and Marie Glynn; Suzette, Barnes, Teilo and Crys Evans; Shira, Ken, Valerie and Rosie Houghton; and Kaitlin, Jen and Ryan Thomas. High school students who volunteered to fill their requirement to graduate included Greg Tuttle (Tuscan alumni), John Leelik, Danielle Martin and Chris Benoit together with his sister Catherine Benoit (current Tuscan student). Thanks all.

Senator Robert C. Byrd, Democrat of West Virginia, who is already the longest-serving senator in United States history, is set to cross yet another milestone of longevity in the legislative branch. On Wednesday, he'll surpass Carl Hayden as the longest-serving member of Congress in history, combining terms in both the House and Senate.

Months of rain, cold weather and crop blight made 2009 "one of the worst, if not the worst, growing seasons in memory," Jan Ellen Spiegel writes in The New York Times. Most counties in New York and New Jersey have been declared agricultural disaster areas, and Connecticut is awaiting word from the federal government on the same declaration for nearly all of its counties.

The Institution for Mechanical Engineers, a British professional body, argues in a new report that Britain's goal of slashing emissions by 80 percent from 1990 levels by 2050 shows the government using ambitious, yet distant, targets to mask its failure to tackle the problem adequately in the near-term.

Over the course of more than 200 shows, James Lipton has interviewed actors, directors, comedians and talk show hosts, with only a couple of exceptions for nonacting musicians (Billy Joel and Elton John, as long as you don't count "Tommy"). The Insider profiles emerging tastemakers in the fields of fashion, design, food, travel and the arts. Here, the Catskills-based pastry chef Craig Thompson shares his essentials. A self-taught baker, Thompson began his career making lemon meringue pies based on the paintings of Wayne Thiebaud for the cafe at the the Kemper Contemporary Museum in Kansas City. He moved to New York and worked with high-end event-planning companies before settling in the Catskills, where he founded his bespoke bakery, Shandaken Bake.

Follow two men with very distinct, if somewhat overlapping, obsessions tonight. The music critic Robert Palmer is the subject of the new documentary “The Hand of Fatima,” which explores his drug use and his family; his pioneering work will be honored at a tribute tonight at Le Poisson Rouge that benefits the Sufi musicians he championed. Only recently have companies begun assigning smells to everyday products: frangipani-scented sewing threads, tires that smell like roses. A paper soon to be published in the Journal of Consumer Research confirms the wisdom of this tactic, finding that scented products linger in the memory. In one experiment, the researchers, posing as marketers, asked 151 college students to examine a brand-name pencil, along with a 10-point list of its selling points. Some of the pencils were unscented, and some had been dosed with pine or tea tree oil. Two weeks later, the average student could not remember a single attribute of the scentless pencil, but remembered more than three attributes of the scented pencils. Students were not provided with the scent, which could jog their memory.

What everyone has suspected for weeks has now been made more or less official by President Obama and other world leaders: no new legally binding climate treaty will emerge at discussions in Copenhagen next month. The continuing differences between industrialized and developing nations over who should bear the burden of stopping global warming mean that at best Copenhagen will be a steppingstone. This does not make the talks between President Obama and President Hu Jintao of China any less important. Even an interim agreement will be impossible without enthusiastic participation by both countries, which together account for 40 percent of greenhouse gas emissions. Denmark's prime minister, Lars Lokke Rasmussen, has sketched the outlines of a fallback position that would have all countries commit to achievable, transparent domestic targets while negotiations on a broader treaty continued. This is an honorable proposition that Mr. Obama can easily accept, but getting Mr. Hu to sign on -- and bring other developing countries with him -- may take some doing.

50 CENT ''Before I Self Destruct'' (Shady/Aftermath/Interscope) So it turns out 50 Cent only works well as a world killer, an artist who doesn't make sense divorced from unassailable power or commercial success. That's become ever clearer as popular sentiment has shifted away from him, and his bag of tricks has run low. Once he was the rough outsider; now he's a symbol of bloat. He used to start beefs effortlessly. Now when he taunts other rappers, they don't bother replying, the equivalent of an unreturned phone call.

KID SISTER ''Ultraviolet'' (Downtown) Kid Sister plays an ingénue in her raps, but it doesn't take long to figure out that she's a grown-up. Squired into the limelight a few years ago by a Kanye West mixtape, Kid Sister -- a k a Melisa Young, a 29-year-old Chicagoan -- brings the benign, level-headed fizz you heard a generation ago from female rappers rather than the dour heat you hear now from -- well, they're just about all male now, aren't they? ''Ultraviolet,'' her much-delayed first album, aims to be a constant stream of enlightened fun. This is a record girls can share with their parents, and possibly even their boyfriends. There's a lot about ''Ultraviolet'' you might want to like. But it runs more on concept rather than talent; too often it feels self-conscious and low on hooks.

MYRON WALDEN ''Momentum'' (Demi Sound) The saxophonist Myron Walden has been a regular presence on the New York modern-jazz circuit, working most visibly with Brian Blade's Fellowship, a band rooted in softly burnished gospel sonorities. But he hasn't released an album of his own since 2005, apparently for reasons other than reticence: Mr. Walden, a longtime specialist on alto, recently decided to take up the tenor, adjusting to a different voice and register. ''Momentum'' is the first in a series of albums featuring the new instrument, and on some level it lands as a fresh statement of purpose.

ECKEL--John R. Jr.,Founder, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer of Copano Energy, L.L.C., died on November 13, 2009, at age 58. Mr. Eckel was born October 22, 1951 in Houston, Texas. Mr. Eckel founded Copano Energy in 1992 and served as President and Chief Executive Officer until April 2003, when he became Chairman of the Board of Directors and Chief Executive Officer. Under Mr. Eckel's leadership, Copano grew from a single 23-mile pipeline to a successful midstream natural gas company with over 6,000 miles of pipeline and seven processing plants in Oklahoma, Texas, Wyoming and Louisiana. Mr. Eckel was also an industry innovator, as evidenced by the fact that Copano was the first midstream company to trade publicly as a limited liability company. Mr. Eckel conducted his life and his business affairs with the highest level of integrity. He had a tremendous work ethic and was a compassionate leader. His influence in the oil and gas sector is also reflected in his work at the Texas Pipeline Association, where he served on the Board and on the Executive Committee, and at Live Oak Reserves, Inc., an exploration and production company that he founded in 1986. Following graduation from Columbia University in 1973, where he received a Bachelor of Arts degree, Mr. Eckel joined the Securities Investment Department of The Mutual Life Insurance Company of New York as an Investment Analyst and subsequently served as an Assistant Director of Investments (Energy and Minerals). In 1977, Mr. Eckel joined Lehman Brothers as an Associate in Corporate Finance and in 1978, was elected Assistant Vice President in Energy Finance. After leaving the finance sector, Mr. Eckel became involved in the energy industry, founding drilling, service and exploration and production companies before founding Copano. Mr. Eckel was known for his support of a broad range of charitable organizations including the Whitney Museum of American Art, the Museum of Modern Art, the Museum of Fine Arts, Houston, the Elton John AIDS Foundation and MD Anderson Cancer Center (Physician Scientist Program Fund) and for fostering in others his ethic of purposeful giving. Mr. Eckel was a member of the Director's Counsel at the Whitney Museum of American Art. Mr. Eckel also served as a member of the Director's Circle and on the American Painting and Sculpture subcommittee for the Museum of Fine Arts, Houston. Mr. Eckel is preceded in death by his mother Margaret Fultz Eckel, grandparents O.B. and Marguerite Fultz and John Glenn and Florence Eckel. Mr. Eckel's interest in oil and gas was fostered by both of his grandfathers' involvement in the oil and gas business in Texas. Mr. Eckel is survived by his father, John R. Eckel, Sr., his brother David Eckel and wife, Sandra, his sister Anne Lowery and husband Greg and his niece Sarah Lowery. Details of a memorial service are pending. In lieu of flowers, those wishing to make a donation in Mr. Eckel's honor should direct it to the Whitney Museum of American Art or the Museum of Fine Arts, Houston (American Painting and Sculpture).

RYAN--James Vincent, died November 12, 2009. He was born on April 7, 1927 in New York City to John and Harriet Clarke Ryan. He graduated from Fordham Preparatory School, Purdue University and Fordham University Law School. He served briefly in the U.S. Navy. He had a long and distinguished career as a litigator, retiring as a senior partner of Rogers & Wells in 1989. He appeared several times before the U.S. Supreme Court as an advocate, most notably in his successful defense of Bangor Punta versus Chris Craft, a dispute arising from the acquisition of Piper Aircraft. An enthusiastic golfer, he served on the Board of Governors at Winged Foot Golf Club. A long-time resident of Rye, NY and a former member of Sankaty Head Golf Club on Nantucket, he resided in Greenwich, CT since 1997. He was predeceased by his wife of 46 years, Anne Murray Ryan, and his daughters, Marybeth and Deirdre Ryan. He is survived by his daughter, Maureen Smith, and his sons, Kevin, Emmett and James Ryan and seven grandchildren. The memorial mass will be held Wednesday, November 18th, at 10:30am at St. Michael's Church on North Street in Greenwich. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to Swim Across America Team Didi or Fordham Prep.

ARMSTRONG--John Chace, died on November 4th, 2009 in Shelburne, VT from complications of aortic stenosis, a disease that robbed him of his energy and a bit of his memory, but never his analytic mind. He was delivered to the Lord peacefully, at his home, under the light of a full moon and a clear sky. John was born in 1918 in Rochester, NY, the only child of George S. and Dorothy M. Armstrong. Raised in Riverside, CT, he attended Riverside School, Brunswick School and Deerfield Academy. He graduated from Williams College and New York University. After a brief period of employment with Dupont, John went on to work with his father's firm, the George S. Armstrong Company, in New York City. He worked there as a consulting engineer until his retirement as president of the company in 1995. John married Helga Evensen in 1950 and, until her untimely death in 1974, raised their three daughters together. His unfailing and absolute devotion to his children and their wellbeing stirred his spirit until his last breath. He was married to Mary Helen Post Hurlimann from 1977 until 2001. While he held her three daughters, Mary Ann, Lily and Sandy, in the highest regard and with much affection, Sandy held a piece of his heart. Aside from the pride he took in his work and the accomplishments of his children and grandchildren, John was deeply proud of his efforts on behalf of the New York University Alumni Federation. He leaves his children: Karin and her husband, Arthur Newhouse of Stowe, Vermont; Christine of Shelburne, Vermont; and Lise of South Burlington, Vermont. Grandchildren, Bart and wife, Amy, Kirsten and husband, Ben, Matthew, Anna Christina, Brendan, Christian and Lille, and great grandsons, Chace and Liam, cherish his memory. Private services were held on November 7, 2009 at the Putnam Cemetery in Greenwich, CT. A Memorial Service will be held next summer (2010) in Greensboro, VT, John's lifelong and beloved summer home. Although John appreciated flowers, and loved both a woman who grew them and a woman who painted them, instead of flowers, he preferred that any memorials in his name be made to the John C. Armstrong Scholarship Fund at the New York University Alumni Federation, c/o Alan Shapiro, Director of Gift Planning, 25 W. 4th Street, 4th fl., NYC, NY 10012. (212.998.6960).

Television began as an entertainment vehicle, with shows like ''Texaco Star Theater,'' hosted by Milton Berle (1948-1955), ''Gunsmoke'' (1955-1975) and ''Lassie'' (1954-1974). Still, it was an essential information highway from the introduction of nightly news shows like NBC's, which paired Chet Huntley and David Brinkley in 1956, until the growth of the Internet and the explosion of cable television. The abundance of entertainment choices, like the game consoles PlayStation (introduced in 1994) and the Wii (2006), cellphone talking and texting, and social networks like Facebook and Twitter, has not slowed the increase in dedicated TV time. In the 2008-9 season, the average person spent a record four hours and 49 minutes watching TV each day. SHELLY FREIERMAN

Labmert of Lansdowne, PA, in-laws Raymond and Amy Lambert of Strafford, PA, Joyce Curtin, Nancy and Michael Willey and niece of Franklin, MA; Gail and Glen Brown and nieces and nephews of Evans, GA, brother Richard A. Votta and brother-in-law Keith Richards of Lansdowne, mother Margaret N. Votta of Clearwater, FL, cousin Elizabeth Walker of Astron, PA. Memorial services will be held at St. Mary's Episcopal Church, Ardmore, PA, December 5th, 2009 at 11am followed by a reception. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to the New York Rugby Club in Meg's name, checks payable to: New York Rugby c/o Annie Collier 6 Scenic Dr, South Salem, NY 10590. A report in The Caucus column on Friday referred incorrectly to a statement in Sarah Palin's new book, ''Going Rogue,'' and a correction in this space on Saturday omitted the source of the erroneous information. The report, using information from The Associated Press, gave an incorrect amount in some copies for the legal costs Ms. Palin said the McCain campaign made her pay for its vetting of her as a vice presidential candidate. According to her account in the book, it was $50,000 -- not $500,000, a figure The AP later corrected in its article.

Television began as an entertainment vehicle, with shows like ''Texaco Star Theater,'' hosted by Milton Berle (1948-1955), ''Gunsmoke'' (1955-1975) and ''Lassie'' (1954-1974). Still, it was an essential information highway from the introduction of nightly news shows like NBC's, which paired Chet Huntley and David Brinkley in 1956, until the growth of the Internet and the explosion of cable television. The abundance of entertainment choices, like the game consoles PlayStation (introduced in 1994) and the Wii (2006), cellphone talking and texting, and social networks like Facebook and Twitter, has not slowed the increase in dedicated TV time. In the 2008-9 season, the average person spent a record four hours and 49 minutes watching TV each day. SHELLY FREIERMAN
MARMALSTEIN--Elizabeth. Beloved wife and mother. Liz left us November 15. She will always be remembered with so much love and affection. Morris, Melissa and Steven

By the end of the day Wednesday, the full 32-team field for the 2010 World Cup in South Africa will be set. Four European playoffs and the second leg of the South America-North/Central America playoff will be completed. And a one-game African playoff in Sudan will determine whether Algeria or Egypt will make the tournament. Players, coaches and fans endure controversy, anxiety and some disturbing violence on what should prove to be a dramatic final day of qualifying.

During a fierce thunderstorm on Aug. 18, an estimated 508 trees were either felled or broken beyond repair in Central Park, while another 500 sustained serious, but not fatal, damage. Language may change, but pedantry is forever. And as Jan Freeman demonstrates in "Ambrose Bierce's 'Write It Right': The Celebrated Cynic's Language Peeves Deciphered, Appraised, and Annotated for 21st-Century Readers," so too is the tradition of modern-day pedants' picking apart the outmoded irritants of the quibblers who came before them. In the spirit of Theodore Bernstein's funny and edifying "Miss Thistlebottom's Hobgoblins," Freeman, who writes The Boston Globe's weekly language column "The Word," has taken "Write It Right," Bierce's "Little Blacklist of Literary Faults," published in 1909, and annotated it - thoroughly, fondly and wittily - for today's usage obsessives.
