The Buffalo Bills fired Coach Dick Jauron on Tuesday, making him the first coaching casualty of the season. In-season coaching changes are unusual in the N.F.L. because the short season means even a new coach can have little impact. The timing of the firing is especially odd because the Bills had a bye two weeks ago, a more natural time to make a change. But they were routed, 41-17, by the three-win Tennessee Titans on Sunday to drop to 3-6. Jauron was apparently surprised. He was called to a meeting with the team's owner, Ralph Wilson, in Detroit and fired.

MTV Networks has acquired exclusive television rights to the Michael Jackson concert film "This Is It" for six years beginning in 2011, the company announced on Tuesday. The deal allows MTV Networks to show the film on all of its channels, including MTV and VH1, as well as on BET Networks, which like MTV is owned by Viacom. In its announcement, MTV said it would also work with Sony Pictures Entertainment to market the DVD of the film, due early next year. "This Is It" has grossed $67 million in the United States and $129 million overseas.

The overlap between two Broadway productions of David Mamet won't last very long. The Broadway revival of "Oleanna," Mr. Mamet's play about a university professor and the female student who believes he has harassed her, will end its run at the Golden Theater on Jan. 3, its publicists said Tuesday in a news release. The play, which stars Bill Pullman and Julia Stiles, was a transfer of a production that ran earlier this year at the Mark Taper Forum in Los Angeles. Directed by Doug Hughes, it opened at the Golden Theater on Oct. 11. Mr. Mamet's new play, "Race," which he is also directing, is to open at the Ethel Barrymore Theater on Dec. 6.

Metropolitan Books has acquired the North American rights to two novels by Herta Müller, the Romanian-born German novelist and essayist who was awarded the Nobel Prize last month.

If the promise of the some of the best country's best food and wine weren't enough to make you book a plane ticket to the Maremma region of Tuscany right now, then these tantalizing images from Massimo Vitali and Albrecht Tübke will certainly do the trick. This coastal strip offers all sorts of sybaritic pleasures, from sunbathing to sipping Sassicaia - the award-winning wine is produced in the town of Bolgheri. These two photographers offer a lovely glimpse into the region with their traveling show "Vintage Green," which is currently on view at the Core Club. While Vitali delivers his epic landscapes of the verdant area, the Leipzig-born Tübke offers endearing portraits of the local legends, from winemakers to hunters. The show continues until Dec. 9. Vitali has a new show opening at Bonni Benrubi Gallery starting Dec. 3.

Get licensed or get out, is the message from the New York City Department of Consumer Affairs to the city's pedicab professionals, who have until Friday to obtain business licenses and register their vehicles or else close up shop. The Nov. 20 deadline marks the end of a 60-day period in which the city invited pedicab operators to apply to become licensed, a process that entails submitting their rickshaws to a rigorous inspection, and retrofitting them with things like seat belts and turn signals to bring them up to new safety standards outlined in the law.

As we signaled to turn right into the high school parking lot, a man frantically waved his hands in the air alerting us that the lot was full. At 3:30 on a Sunday afternoon, I never expected there'd be several hundred eager parents - and students - streaming into a high school gym for a glimpse of, and perhaps a quick chat with, admissions representatives and alumni from 70 colleges and universities. But there we were, searching for a parking spot so we, too, could join the throngs of college seekers on a crisp fall day.

First, Blair Waldorf told us that Lady Gaga wrote her song "Poker Face" for her stepfather, Cyrus Rose, a revelation that we're fairly certain is true only in the fictional world of "Gossip Girl." Now comes more surprising (and authentic) news: Lady Gaga will not be eligible in the best new artist category at the Grammy Awards next year. Variety reported that although Lady Gaga (whose real name is Stefani Germanotta) has sold more than 1.5 million copies of her debut album, "The Fame," her song "Just Dance" was nominated in the best dance recording category at this year's Grammys, making her ineligible for new artist next year, according to the award's regulations. Previous winners in the best new artist category include Adele, Amy Winehouse and Carrie Underwood; nominations for the 52nd annual Grammy Awards will be announced on Dec. 2 and awards will be given out on Jan. 31.

There's little in the boxing world that isn't exploited for maximum impact - babbles, tassels and bedazzles have all made their appearance on the fingers and feet of fleet-footed pugilists. Jack Dempsey, the gentleman boxer and heavyweight champion from 1919 to 1926, was, to put it into our terms, a fashion-forward tastemaker. In our era, Paulie Malignaggi, Floyd "Money" Mayweather and Rickie "The Hitman" Hatton have paraded down the aisle in Technicolor robes. Boxing has always found a way of muscling itself into fashion.

The Mets' two biggest off-season objectives, to paraphrase Captain Obvious, are to acquire another slugger and to add a No. 2 starter behind Johan Santana. Not so obvious is how -- and if -- they will accomplish these goals and find creative ways to bring in a starting catcher, resolve issues in the bullpen and in the back end of the rotation, and decide if they should deal second baseman Luis Castillo.

Apparently the eight years that Bob Saget spent hosting "America's Funniest Home Videos," narrating clips of misbehaving kitties and people getting hit by footballs in tender areas, were simply a warm-up act. Now he's turning the camera on himself. On Tuesday, A&E announced that it had ordered a new reality series starring Mr. Saget, the comedian and former "Full House" star, that is tentatively titled "Bob Saget's Strange Days." In a news release, A&E said that the new series would follow Mr. Saget as he explores "some of America's most fascinating and mysterious worlds"; for Mr. Saget, that means an investigation of mail-order brides; meeting up with a survivalist cult that is preparing for the end of the world; and rushing a college fraternity. The show is expected to have its premiere next year; no word yet on which if any Olsen twin might be involved.

But in her mixed assessment of the Italian restaurant Quinto Quarto, did Andrea Thompson really need to say anything more once she revealed that during dinner one night she saw "the pizza-delivery guy who shows up with two large pepperoni pies for the staff''?

Every now and then, something for sale on Amazon.com seems so monumentally stupid that it inspires a spontaneous community comedy festival. One person after another leaves phony reviews, each more heartfelt and over-the-top than last, sardonically praising the Amazon item for its astonishing, life-changing abilities. Perfect strangers, entertaining each other in the comments, laughing their heads off-until Amazon gets wind of the stunt and shuts it down.
Working Mother Magazine published a package of articles on Tuesday called "Lost Custody," about the new reality of divorce and child custody for working mothers.

On Monday, Al Jazeera reported that a spokesman for the Pakistani Taliban said the group accepted responsibility for only some of the recent suicide bombings in Pakistan, laying the blame for others, including a deadly attack on a market last month that killed more than 100 civilians, on the American security firm formerly known as Blackwater. The spokesman claimed that the firm, now called Xe, was involved in an attempt to discredit the militants by staging deadly attacks.

Each day this week, the Guidance Office -- the forum on The Choice where readers ask questions of education experts -- will feature answers about community colleges by Kay M. McClenney. Dr. McClenney is the director of the Center for Community College Student Engagement, a research and service initiative of the Community College Leadership Program at the University of Texas at Austin.
Stephen Constantine, 47, a native of England, is currently the coach of the national team of Sudan. He has also coached the national teams of Nepal, India and Malawi.

Last week, when John G. Branca and John McClain were named the executors of Michael Jackson's estate by a Superior Court judge in Los Angeles, one estate expert was quoted as saying the decision would ensure "there won't be any further challenge." But now the singer's father, Joe Jackson, is planning to challenge the decision, Agence France-Presse reported. Citing legal papers filed on Friday, Agence France-Presse said that Joe Jackson plans to appeal the appointment of Mr. Branca, a lawyer, and Mr. McClain, a music executive, in the California Court of Appeals. Joe Jackson was left out of his son's will, and the Superior Court had said he had no standing to challenge it.

I've become one of those people who, by the time I walk from the couch to the kitchen, can't remember why I'm standing in front of an open fridge. Some people can laugh off these memory blips as old-timer's disease. But I'm only 37. And it doesn't feel funny staring into an abyss of cartons and containers unable to remember that I want a glass of orange juice.

Monologue | Aired Monday night on "The Late Late Show With Craig Ferguson" on CBS: I was watching "Oprah" on the TV. She had Sarah Palin on the show. Sarah was promoting her book, where she talks about her plans for the future. I think she wants to be the next leader of the free world, which is ridiculous, because no one can replace Oprah.

Monologue | Aired Monday night on NBC: President Obama was in Japan. Some people are upset that Obama bowed to the Japanese emperor. It's still better than when former President Bush high-fived the emperor and said, "Give me some skin, Mr. Miyagi."

Monologue | Aired Monday night on "Late Night With Jimmy Fallon" on NBC: Hey, during a town hall event in China, President Obama admitted that he's never used Twitter. Even John McCain was like, "Get it together, grandpa."

The latest cash prize for talent has gone to Sophie Theallet, who won the $200,000 CFDA/Vogue Fund award last night. The prize, which includes a year of mentoring from a veteran in the industry, is especially deserved in Ms. Theallet's case. Her clothes are not flashy or arty; she's not everybody's darling. But if you appreciate hand-done details like pin-tucking, if you like a certain friendliness in clothes, and if you're surprised and delighted by non-generic reds and blues, then you are surely on Sophie's side.

Now that the 40th-anniversary moon-landing specials produced by American television have come and gone, we're getting to see some of the shows made for the occasion by the BBC. They're uniformly more inventive and interesting than the clip-show history lessons churned out here. Sarah Palin’s appearance Monday on “The Oprah Winfrey Show” looked less like a celebratory comeback than a redo of the presidential campaign.

After playing the Orange Bowl and “Saturday Night Live,” Ashlee Simpson is ready to take on Broadway. Ms. Simpson, 25, announced on Monday that she would play Roxie Hart in the musical “Chicago” for 10 weeks, beginning on Nov. 30. Ms. Simpson, best known for the hit CDs “Autobiography” and “I Am Me” and a much publicized lip-synching episode on television, has played Roxie before, on the West End in London, but is to be making her Broadway debut. Most recently, she has been a regular on the revived version of “Melrose Place” on the CW network, but that show’s producers announced last month that her character would be written out of the story.

With the nursing home that has tended generations of actors, directors and crew members scheduled to close and evict many of its elderly residents at year’s end, a coalition representing entertainment industry workers has issued a public letter urging the Motion Picture & Television Fund, which underwrites the home, to reverse its decision. “We know there is enough money to fulfill” existing commitments to the current residents, the coalition, Saving the Lives of Our Own, said. The group’s letter, addressed to Jeffrey Katzenberg, one of several Hollywood heavyweights on the fund’s board, came after the fund published ads in trade publications last week minimizing the impact of the proposed closing. To fail to “change the board’s direction,” the coalition contends, would only provide “further evidence of the moral bankruptcy of the existing board.”.

They surely won’t fetch anywhere near the $43.7 million someone paid last week for one of Andy Warhol’s seminal silk-screen paintings. But illustrations that Warhol did for a children’s book series in the late 1950s are to be offered by Bloomsbury Auctions on Dec. 9, along with work by other children’s authors and illustrators, including Beatrix Potter, A. A. Milne, Maurice Sendak and Edward Gorey. The early Warhol illustrations (one is above), conventional in style and subject, accompanied the Doubleday Book Club’s Best in Children’s Books series, like a version of “The Little Red Hen” that shows the title character sowing seeds in a field as a lazy cat, dog and mouse look on. The estimated price is $500 to $600 for the four-book lot.

The Library of Congress has named Paul McCartney, below, the third recipient of its Gershwin Prize for Popular Song. “It is hard to think of another performer and composer who has had a more indelible and transformative effect on popular song and music of several different genres,” the Librarian of Congress, James H. Billington, said in announcing the award on Monday. Mr. McCartney is the first non-American to win the prize; the previous honorees were Paul Simon and Stevie Wonder. The library said an all-star tribute concert was planned for the spring. Mr. McCartney said that “as a great admirer of the Gershwins’ songs” he was “highly honored” to be given the prize, and the library said he planned to play at the tribute show.

They don't know it, but people who use Google's online maps may be getting directions from Richard Hintz. Mr. Hintz, a 62-year-old engineer who lives in Berkeley, Calif., has tweaked the locations of more than 200 business listings and points of interest in cities across the state, sliding an on-screen place marker down the block here, moving another one across the street there. Farther afield, he has mapped parts of Cambodia and Laos, where he likes to go on motorcycle trips.

Retail sales in the United States increased by a higher-than-expected 1.4 percent in October from September, helped by a strong demand for cars, the government said Monday. Prices, however, were 1.7 percent below October a year ago.

PLAYERArsenal striker Robin van Persie, 26, is expected to miss up to six weeks after he tore ligaments in his left ankle playing for the Netherlands in a friendly against Italy last weekend. Van Persie will fly to Serbia for treatment, which involves being massaged with fluid from a human placenta. CLUB Scotland fired George Burley, 53, as the manager of its national team Monday. Scotland has not qualified for the World Cup since 1998 and last played in the European Championship in 1996.

The setting for a new television commercial by supporters of abortion rights is an unexpected one: a comedy club. Cory Kahaney, a comedian who appeared on ''Last Comic Standing,'' tells the audience about two patients who are told that their insurance will cover a breast reduction and a nose job. But when a third patient asks if insurance will cover an abortion -- she is 11 weeks pregnant and has discovered that part of her child's brain and skull are missing -- she is told no.

On the White House blog, Nancy-Ann DeParle, the director of the Office of Health Reform, rebuts recent claims by the insurance industry that the proposed health care overhaul would actually increase the cost of premiums. ''Despite being roundly and thoroughly debunked,'' she wrote, ''the industry lobby continues to release these studies and push their bogus conclusion about cost increases.''

A federal court judge in Memphis has denied the request of the PGA Tour player Doug Barron for a temporary restraining order on his drug suspension that would have allowed him to compete in the PGA Tour qualifying school this week. Magistrate Judge Tu M. Pham issued the ruling Monday after a hearing on Friday. Barron, 40, was suspended for a year by the tour on Nov. 12, becoming the first player barred for violating its antidoping policy. Barron tested positive for testosterone and for propranolol, a beta-blocker, at the St. Jude Classic in June.

Senator Robert C. Byrd, Democrat of West Virginia, who is already the longest-serving senator in United States history, is set to cross another milestone of longevity in the legislative branch. On Wednesday, he will surpass Carl Hayden as the longest-serving member of Congress, combining terms in the House and Senate. Mr. Hayden, Democrat of Arizona, served in the House from 1912 to 1927 and in the Senate from 1927 to 1969, for a total of 56 years 319 days.

(13, 49) NO SUBTITLES NECESSARY: LASZLO & VILMOS As pioneers of the American New Wave, the cinematographers Vilmos Zsigmond, above left, and Laszlo Kovacs, above right, rose to prominence in Hollywood through films like ''McCabe and Mrs. Miller,'' ''Deliverance'' and ''Close Encounters of the Third Kind'' (Mr. Zsigmond's work) and ''Easy Rider,'' ''Five Easy Pieces'' and ''Frances'' (Mr. Kovacs's). This ''Independent Lens'' presentation chronicles their 50-year story, from their escape from Hungary during the 1956 Soviet invasion to their creation of a new American film aesthetic. Peter Bogdanovich, John Boorman, Richard Donner, John Williams, Jon Voight, Peter Fonda, Sandra Bullock, Karen Black, Dennis Hopper and Sharon Stone discuss the men's legacy. 9 A.M. (CBS) THE DOCTORS Brooke Burke, the show's ''mommy correspondent,'' and puppets from ''Sesame Street'' talk about building blocks for a healthier family; also a discussion of the effects of spanking.

Frank Frigo and Chuck Bower, champion backgammon players and developers of the ZEUS computer program, have huddled with N.F.L. executives and coaches over the years, including with Bill Belichick, below. They can simulate hundreds of thousands of N.F.L. outcomes in seconds, and their program can be customized to account for the strengths and weaknesses of the offensive and defensive units of each team. They examined Belichick's decision to try to convert a fourth-and-2 from the Patriots' 28 late in Sunday night's game against the Indianapolis Colts, with New England leading, 34-28. Here are three ways that ZEUS breaks down the problem. In each case, an extended simulation is performed, beginning with the exact circumstance on fourth-and-2 and finishing at the end of the game.

Allen Iverson's playing days in Memphis proved short-lived, and his next destination is unknown. Iverson and the Grizzlies mutually agreed to cut ties Monday, possibly ending his storied career. The team that may need Iverson the most, the Knicks, probably will not pursue him.
International IRANIAN NUCLEAR PLANT

International inspectors who gained access to Iran's newly revealed underground nuclear enrichment plant voiced strong suspicions in a report on Monday that the country was concealing other atomic facilities. The report was the first independent account of what was contained in the once secret plant, tunneled into the side of a mountain, and came as the Obama administration was expressing growing impatience with Iran's slow response in nuclear negotiations.

Is she or isn't she running for president in 2012? Sarah Palin, on ''The Oprah Winfrey Show,'' answered by borrowing the line her father used when she resigned as governor of Alaska in July: ''She's not retreating, she's reloading.''

European Aeronautic Defense and Space, the maker of Airbus passenger jets, on Monday reported a loss for the third quarter and warned that it could face significant charges this year for problems with its A400M military transport and the A380 superjumbo jet. The company, based in Munich and Paris, said it had a net loss of 87 million euros ($130 million), in contrast to a profit of 679 million euros in the quarter last year. Revenue fell 2 percent, to 9.53 billion euros ($14 billion) and a weaker dollar hit earnings overseas. Revenue at the Airbus unit fell 3 percent, to 6.2 billion euros.

ECKEL--John R. Jr.,Founder, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer of Copano Energy, L.L.C., died on November 13, 2009, at age 58. Mr. Eckel was born October 22, 1951 in Houston, Texas. Mr. Eckel founded Copano Energy in 1992 and served as President and Chief Executive Officer until April 2003, when he became Chairman of the Board of Directors and Chief Executive Officer. Under Mr. Eckel's leadership, Copano grew from a single 23-mile pipeline to a successful midstream natural gas company with over 6,000 miles of pipeline and seven processing plants in Oklahoma, Texas, Wyoming and Louisiana. Mr. Eckel was also an industry innovator, as evidenced by the fact that Copano was the first midstream company to trade publicly as a limited liability company. Mr. Eckel conducted his life and his business affairs with the highest level of integrity. He had a tremendous work ethic and was a compassionate leader. His influence in the oil and gas sector is also reflected in his work at the Texas Pipeline Association, where he served on the Board and on the Executive Committee, and at Live Oak Reserves, Inc., an exploration and production company that he founded in 1986. Following graduation from Columbia University in 1973, where he received a Bachelor of Arts degree, Mr. Eckel joined the Securities Investment Department of The Mutual Life Insurance Company of New York as an Investment Analyst and subsequently served as an Assistant Director of Investments (Energy and Minerals). In 1977, Mr. Eckel joined Lehman Brothers as an Associate in Corporate Finance and in 1978, was elected Assistant Vice President in Energy Finance. After leaving the finance sector, Mr. Eckel became involved in the energy industry, founding drilling, service and exploration and production companies before founding Copano. Mr. Eckel was known for his support of a broad range of charitable organizations including the Whitney Museum of American Art, the Museum of Modern Art, the Museum of Fine Arts, Houston, the Elton John AIDS Foundation and MD Anderson Cancer Center (Physician Scientist Program Fund) and for fostering in others his ethic of purposeful giving. Mr. Eckel was a member of the Director's Counsel at the Whitney Museum of American Art. Mr. Eckel also served as a member of the Director's Circle and on the American Painting and Sculpture subcommittee for the Museum of Fine Arts, Houston. Mr. Eckel is preceded in death by his mother Margaret Fultz Eckel, grandparents O.B. and Marguerite Fultz and John Glenn and Florence Eckel. Mr. Eckel's interest in oil and gas was fostered by both of his grandfathers' involvement in the oil and gas business in Texas. Mr. Eckel is survived by his father, John R. Eckel, Sr., his brother David Eckel and wife, Sandra, his sister Anne Lowery and husband Greg and his niece Sarah Lowery. Details of a memorial service are pending. In lieu of flowers, those wishing to make a donation in Mr. Eckel's honor should direct it to the Whitney Museum of American Art or the Museum of Fine Arts, Houston (American Painting and Sculpture).

A college student who bid on and won more than $1.8 million in federal oil and gas leases last year without the intent or ability to pay will not be allowed to argue in court that he acted out of necessity to protect the environment, a federal judge ruled on Monday. The student, Tim DeChristopher, 27, an economics major at the University of Utah, faces up to five years in prison and huge fines on each of two felony charges -- making false statements and interfering with an auction -- arising from the sale last December in Utah.

Consideration by the federal authorities of a plan to house Guantánamo Bay detainees at a maximum-security prison in northwest Illinois has further fueled criticism of the Obama administration from conservative bloggers who were already condemning the decision to try the accused Sept. 11 plotters in federal court. Gov. Patrick J. Quinn and Senator Richard J. Durbin, both Democrats of Illinois, say the potential sale of the almost empty Thomson Correctional Center, about 150 miles west of Chicago, could help create about 3,000 jobs. But critics, including Republican members of Congress from Illinois and conservative bloggers, are saying such a move would endanger public safety.

The Supreme Court declined to hear an appeal from Native Americans who said trademarks associated with the Washington Redskins should be canceled because they were offensive. The court denied the appeal without comment. The court's order in the case, Harjo v. Pro-Football Inc., No. 09-326, let stand a decision from a three-judge panel of the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit. The appeals court's decision did not address the trademarks' asserted offensiveness, ruling instead that the challengers had moved too slowly in seeking to cancel them.

The Senate majority leader, Harry Reid of Nevada, met on Monday night with a group of liberal Senate Democrats who urged him not to back down from his decision to put a government-run insurance plan, or public option, in the major health care legislation he is working to finalize. Mr. Reid has said he would include a public plan in the bill with a provision for states to opt out if they do not want to offer it. But Mr. Reid is still short at least 3 of the 60 votes he needs on a motion to bring the health care bill up for debate.

If I have one serious regret about my age, it is that my permanent teeth developed before New York, my hometown, got fluoridated water. I first lost a permanent molar to decay in my early 20s, and the resulting bridge has had to be replaced several times in subsequent decades, ultimately as a four-part apparatus. Now that has to go as well. Because I could not floss and clean properly under the bridge and between the supporting crowns, I developed a severe periodontal infection.

KOPS--Daniel W.,Sr. of Palm Beach, Florida, passed away on November 14, 2009 at the age of 92. He is survived by his wife of 62 years, Nancy, his sons, Daniel W. Kops, Jr. (Sandra) and Stephen R. Kops, a daughter, Cynthia Kops Merbaum, seven grandchildren, one great-granddaughter, eight nieces and one nephew. Born on August 7, 1917 in Lawrence, New York, he graduated from Cornell University in 1939, with a B.A. in journalism. After serving in the U.S. Air Corps during WWII, he became a partner and later president of what became Kops-Monahan Communications. He was a pioneer in radio broadcast journalism, known for his use of editorials. He served as a board member of the National Association of Broadcasters, Chairman of the Committee on Editorializing and board member of the National United Way Association. A graveside service will be held Wednesday, November 18, 2009 at 11:00am at the Grove Street Cemetery in New Haven, CT, followed by a reception. In lieu of flowers, donations may be sent to the Connecticut Hospice or the Greater New Haven United Way.

Jay-Z, Will Smith and Jada Pinkett Smith have signed on as producers of the new Broadway musical ''Fela!,'' right, and will attend the show's opening night at the Eugene O'Neill Theater on Monday, a publicist for the production said. Their artistic involvement is bound to be minimal, given that the show is already in previews and had a critically acclaimed run Off Broadway last year. But the presence of three high-wattage celebrities at opening night, and the likelihood that they will promote the show through television appearances and media interviews, will raise the show's public profile at a time when theatergoers have plenty of Broadway musicals to choose from. Conceived by the Tony Award-winning choreographer Bill T. Jones, ''Fela!'' centers on the life and work of the Afro-beat superstar Fela Anikulapo Kuti. There are no big stars in the cast, which makes the involvement of Jay-Z and the Smiths even more of a marketing boon. They were not immediately available for interviews, said the show's publicist, Billy Zavelson.

MULLAN--Rita Kelly, passed away on November 11, 2009 after a long battle with cancer. She is survived by her son Brendan, his wife and their three children, her daughter Bronagh, her husband and child and two brothers and three sisters. Born in Belfast, Northern Ireland in 1940, Rita spent her early professional life as a nurse at the Royal Victoria Hospital and as a government outreach nurse. After emigrating to the U.S. in 1976, Rita worked as a nurse in Little Rock, AR and a nursing consultant in Washington, DC. After leaving nursing, Rita started a nonprofit organization, The Irish National Caucus, dedicated to addressing human rights in Northern Ireland. The organization lobbied the U.S. government to recognize the Irish issue and succeeded in spotlighting the issue in the U.S. She received the Eleanor Roosevelt Award for Human Rights, was named one of the Top 100 Peacemakers by Irish America Magazine, and testified numerous times before the U.S. Congress on the issue of human rights in Northern Ireland. Rita became an American citizen in 1996 and retired shortly thereafter. Rita spent the last several years of her life living on the coast of Oregon enjoying her garden and family. In many ways it was just another day, another class of Wesleyan University, one of the more selective colleges in the Northeast. The topic was multiculturalism in schools. The discussion focused on methods of evaluating the rhetorical skills of various commentators, from Arthur M. Schlesinger Jr. to Dinesh D'Souza. One student pored over the text, his glasses perched at the tip of his nose. Another raised his hand again and again, eager to speak. A third lobbed grenades into the discussion. Several worried aloud about their homework, a research paper due in a few weeks.

GENDELL--Martin B.,76, of New York City died on November 9 of complications from endocarditis. Raised in Ossining, NY, Martin graduated from the University of Chicago in 1956. He served in the U.S. Army from 1956 to 1962. Martin earned an M.B.A. at The Wharton School of the University of Pennsylvania in 1965, after which he held a series of marketing management positions at companies including Schering Corporation and Block Drug Company. He retired from the New York State Insurance Fund in 2007. He was a past president of the New York Chapter of the University of Chicago Alumni Association. Martin will be greatly missed by his seven nieces and nephews, their spouses and children, and his extended family and friends. Interment will be held at noon on Sunday, November 15 in Athens, GA. A memorial celebration will be held on Friday, November 27 in New York City at the Frank E. Campbell Memorial Chapel. In lieu of flowers, please make charitable contributions in memory of Martin to the College Fund at the University of Chicago, 5801 South Ellis Ave., Suite 007, Chicago, IL 60637.

First, a correction. The concluding point in my earlier post is wrong: The House health care bill would not, in fact, effectively tax all 18 million of the remaining uninsured to pay for coverage for the other 36 million, because some percentage of that 18 million - in the draft of the Senate bill, it's anyone who couldn't find a health care plan costing less than 8 percent of income; in the House bill it's still unspecified - would be eligible for a "hardship waiver" exempting them from paying the fine if they can't afford coverage. And this exemption makes the House bill a better deal for the uninsured than I suggested.

On the 21st day (of October) President Obama said, "Let there be a conference." And so there was. This morning, small-business owners, their representatives, their lenders, and their lenders' representatives - some 70 people in all - gathered in the gilded and marble-clad Cash Room of the United States Treasury. The venue was appropriate, since, after all, the whole point of the exercise was to figure out how to get more capital in the hands of small business.

As my colleague Elisabeth Bumiller reported from Washington on Tuesday, it seems likely that the number of suicides by American soldiers will increase again this year. At the Pentagon, Gen. Peter Chiarelli, the Army vice chief of staff, said that as of Nov. 16, the Army had reported 140 suicides of active duty soldiers this year, the same number as in all of 2008. If that forecast proves accurate, this will be the fifth year in a row that suicides will have increased in the Army.

For me, excuse me, but it was a no brainer. If Jenson Button was offered a drive at McLaren, he had to take it - with the millions of dollars difference to that offered at Brawn or not. Brawn could not pay up what he was asking for? McLaren could? Button's manager was talking recently about how his decision hinged not so much on money as on some feeling of belonging or being wanted - unless I misunderstood his words. Think of it, though. A driver wins the title after half a decade with the same team, in a fluke year, a year no one could have predicted, a jackpot of a drive for him. Then, with his newfound freedom, he is offered a drive at one of the two greatest teams in the history of the sport. Does he refuse that?

Any parent of an autistic child will tell you that their life is forever changed by their child's condition. A recent study in The Journal of Autism and Developmental Disorders quantifies exactly how different that life can be. They were interviewed at the end of each day, and saliva samples were taken every four days.

For a city that often gets knocked for being starved for culture, Los Angeles served up an all-you-can-eat buffet this past week. For once the talk was focused on art and not on movies or on who is in rehab. The festivities began with an arty party on Thursday night for "mindthegap," the inaugural show at Prism, a new three-story gallery on Sunset Boulevard. More stars than there are in paparazzi heaven - Carine! Dasha! Peaches! - showed up to support the owners, PC Valmorbida and Jared Najjar, and the featured artists, Barry McGee and Phil Frost. The following night Miuccia Prada held court at her Beverly Hills store for the publication of her new book, simply titled "Prada," while the philanthropist's philanthropist Eli Broad hosted an A-list dinner, which was in turn followed by an after-party at Benedikt and Lauren Taschen's house. Tired yet? The bleary-eyed emerged the next day to make it to the Jeff Koons private reception and brunch at Gagosian before heading back to their hotels to get their glad rags on for MOCA's 30th anniversary gala. Over 1,000 guests - everyone from John Baldessari to Brangelina and Gore Vidal - turned out for the black-tie-soiree-as-performance-art, which raised over $4 million for the resurgent museum. The highlight of the evening was "Ballet Russes Italian Style (The Shortest Musical You Will Never See Again)," a five-minute act created by the artist Francesco Vezzoli, starring the evening's M.C., Michael York, dancers from the Bolshoi Ballet and Lady Gaga, who performed her new song, "Speechless," on a rotating pink grand piano painted with blue butterflies by Damien Hirst. (Larry Gagosian later snapped up the piano at auction to the tune of $450,000.) As if that weren't enough, what seemed like half of Los Angeles rallied for an after-party hosted by Pop magazine at Prism. By the end of the weekend, there were enough stories to fill a movie and more than one reveler looked in need of rehab.

While Studs Terkel was following around musicians, baseball players and other hardworking Americans in the course of his journalistic duties, it turns out that Mr. Terkel was being followed himself. The Chicago Tribune reported that Mr. Terkel, the prolific author, radio host and Pulitzer Prize winner, who died last year, was tracked for 45 years by the Federal Bureau of Investigation on the suspicion that he was a Communist. According to a dossier obtained by the NYCity News Service of the City University of New York, the F.B.I.'s file on Mr. Terkel began in 1945, noting that he spoke at a Paul Robeson rally and worked with the BBC on a piece about the "sordid side of life in Chicago." The last entry in the file was a 1990 article from The Wall Street Journal in which Mr. Terkel was quoted on the junk-bond scandal of the financier Michael Milken. ("We live in a corrupt, amoral moment," Mr. Terkel said.) The dossier also showed that Mr. Terkel had applied for a job in the fingerprints division of the F.B.I. in the 1930s.

The newly reorganized General Motors is exceeding the government's expectations by a large margin, Steven Rattner, the former head of the Obama administration's auto task force, said at a Fortune magazine conference on Wednesday morning.

Recipe lovers will be eager to pore over Mark Bittman's 101 make-ahead recipes today in the Dining section of The New York Times. But for those who are having a tough time choosing a favorite, Mr. Bittman has offered his top 12 picks for Eat Well's Vegetarian Thanksgiving.

You'll never look at those cute little mechanical stuffed bunnies the same way again. On Thursday, Moss unveils "Remains," an exhibition by the artist Cathy McClure, whose particular passion is taking these mass-produced, eminently disposable items and redesigning them as precious objects. McClure strips away the plush motorized creatures' furry coats and fluffy stuffing and then casts the animals' plastic bodies and limbs in bronze, while leaving most of their mechanisms intact but exposed. A rabbit's ears, for instance, are reduced to their antenna-like spring supports, while a formerly cocky rooster drags his now-heavy body around, crowing as if he were still king of the barnyard. If the movie "Mad Max" had had a toyshop, these half-whimsical, half-disturbing animals would have fit right in. But they're strictly for big kids now, with their sumptuous bronze bodies and five-figure price tags. The exhibition continues through Dec. 31 at 150 Greene Street.
It's a life-changing moment when you discover you are going to be a parent. Equally profound is when you learn you never really were.
Relations between the N.H.L. and K.H.L. may be a bit rocky, but the cultural exchange between North America and Russia continues with announcements on both sides of the divide.
Dear Prescriptions readers,
Looking for a last-minute Thanksgiving vacation? Take your pick:

Suppose you'd like to send a friend a note in a time of need -- perhaps she was recently embarrassed at a music awards show on national television? -- but you can't think of the exact right words to say to her. Taylor Swift may be able to help you out. American Greetings said that it has signed a deal with Ms. Swift, the 19-year-old country music superstar, to produce a line of greeting cards centered around her, The Associated Press reported. In a news release, American Greetings said that it planned to release cards, as well as gift wrap, stationery and online photo products and greetings whose design will be overseen by Ms. Swift in the spring. In a statement, the company's chief executive, Zev Weiss, said that Ms. Swift's "abilities as a storyteller and songwriter make her a natural at writing cards for consumers of all ages." Ms. Swift said in statement, "My idea of a great song is a song that says how I feel better than I could. I feel the same way about greeting cards." We'll see if they measure up to the Garfield product line, which we feel are the best greeting cards "of all-time -- of all-time."

I just got back from Charlotte, N.C. where independent consultants, college admissions representatives, and other experts in the field of education gathered for the Independent Educational Consultant Association bi-annual meeting. I sat in a seminar on how financial aid has changed over the past few years and will impact college admissions.

California has become the first state in the nation to institute energy standards for television sets, a move that could lead to the removal of the most power-consuming television screens from store shelves.
From our friends at the Dot Earth blog:

Hannah Smith is a senior at University Laboratory School in Baton Rouge, La., who is currently applying to colleges. Here she responds to the more than 300 comments on an essay she wrote about her interest in women's colleges, which was posted on The Choice.

"Precious: Based on the Novel 'Push' by Sapphire" took a step in the march toward Oscar recognition, as the Producers Guild of America chose to honor it with the group's Stanley Kramer Award, according to a person briefed on the decision who spoke on condition of anonymity because it had not been formally announced. Established in 2002, the Kramer award is given to a movie, program, studio, executive or entity that tackles provocative social issues in a constructive way. "Precious," about a young woman's struggles to succeed despite her troubled and impoverished family, fills the bill, and will join such past recipients as "Milk" and "Good Night, and Good Luck," both of which were nominated for best-picture Oscars.

President Obama, whose motorcade has been as long as 71 vehicles, is always at least 30 cars ahead of the four-person photo pool trailing him as he tours Asia. I really wanted a whimsical picture of the president as he walked past the "No Smoking" sign in the Forbidden City, but his Chinese police escorts blocked the shot as his entourage swept by. (Note: Lark cigarettes are very popular in Asia and the gift shop in the hotel where Mr. Obama stayed in Tokyo sells Che ashtrays). That done, we were escorted at a quick trot - with the 35 pounds of gear it takes to be a live news bureau operation - to set up at the other side of the nearly-empty complex to record the president as he signed the visitor's log. Throughout Japan, Singapore and China, I have met friendly and industrious people. The young woman at the Starbucks in Beijing took my debit card with a smile and never once mentioned the nearly $1 trillion of U.S. debt held by China. A helpful American journalist based in Beijing pointed out the spot where an unknown Chinese man heroically faced down a line of tanks during the 1989 Tiananmen Square protests. There's little down time on these trips. Sleepless nights worrying about oversleeping take their toll. My hopes of going to the famous Silk Market in Beijing to haggle for Western cowboy wear - the exact item available in Aspen at four times the amount - have been dashed.

The Seward Park branch of the New York Public Library opened 100 years ago this month, on Nov. 11, 1909, and the library will mark the centennial with a program of public events starting at 2 p.m. Thursday. Perhaps what is most remarkable about the branch, which was most recently renovated in 2004, is the continuity of the immigrant aspirations -- then largely Jewish, now mostly Asian and Hispanic -- it embodies.
Eight months older than General Motors, Virgil Coffman clearly is not whom Chevrolet had in mind when it decided to bring back the Camaro.

Two months ago, the City of Houston announced that it planned to work with NRG Energy, the big wholesale power generation company, to build a $40 million solar power plant that would be the largest in Texas. But now The Dallas Morning News is reporting that prospects for the plant are dimming fast.

Got a burning question you've wanted to pose to the Velvet Underground since that down-and-out New York art-rock band broke up in the 1970s? Want to know who's coughing on the recording of "Who Loves the Sun" or when we'll see an official CD release for "Squeeze"? You may finally have a chance to get the answers: On Dec. 8, three members of the Velvet Underground will appear at the New York Public Library to discuss the group's music and history as part of the library's "Live From the NYPL" series, Billboard reported. The musicians Maureen Tucker, Doug Yule and, of course, Lou Reed (who we understand just adores being peppered with random questions by his fans) are scheduled to appear at the event, at which they will be interviewed by the journalist David Fricke. The interview will take place at the Celeste Bartos Forum in the library's Stephen A. Schwarzman Building, and tickets are available online at nypl.org ($15 and $25). The Velvet Underground singer-guitarist Sterling Morrison died in 1995, and the co-founder John Cale left in 1968, though he reunited with Mr. Reed for a Rock and Roll Hall of Fame induction ceremony in 1996.

The Am Law Daily named Michael Ringler of Wilson Sonsini Goodrich & Rosati as deal maker of the week last week. The Web site did so based on his representation of 3Com in its $2.7 billion agreement to be acquired by Hewlett-Packard. Am Law's profile could only be described as glowing and based on his "persistent" lawyering.

Each day this week, the Guidance Office -- the forum on The Choice where readers ask questions of education experts -- will feature answers about community colleges by Kay M. McClenney. Dr. McClenney is the director of the Center for Community College Student Engagement, a research and service initiative of the Community College Leadership Program at the University of Texas at Austin.

A decade ago, the N.B.A. and its players were embroiled in a labor dispute, culminating in a lockout which nearly led to the cancellation of the 1998-99 season. With the current collective bargaining agreement set to expire in 2011, the parties once again have begun to lay the groundwork for the negotiations toward a new agreement. The Los Angeles Lakers' Derek Fisher, a veteran of the 1998-99 work stoppage and now the president of the N.B.A. Players Association, is the players' chief representative.

For the "Bad Lieutenant" star Nicolas Cage, the week just got a little worse. The Associated Press reported that Mr. Cage, the actor whose lavish spending habits have been widely discussed since he filed suit against his former business manager, is being countersued by that same manager. In October, Mr. Cage sued Samuel J. Levin for fraud, saying that Mr. Levin led him "down a path toward financial ruin." In his countersuit filed on Nov. 12, The A.P. reported, Mr. Levin said he told Mr. Cage he would need to earn $30 million a year to maintain his life style, and that he warned the actor not to buy castles in England and Bavaria. (Mr. Cage did not heed the advice.) Mr. Levin also said in his filing that he devised a fund-raising plan for Mr. Cage that included the sale of a dozen classic cars and a $1.6 million comic book collection. A lawyer for Mr. Cage said that Mr. Levin had breached Mr. Cage's privacy by releasing details about his asset sales. The A.P. said that the Internal Revenue Service has filed more than $6.6 million in tax liens against Mr. Cage this year.

They're chunky. They're clunky. They can chew your ankles when they're being broken in. And yet I'm completely feeling for brogues this fall. They're the 1960s wingtips with the heavy extended leather sole worn by businessmen in an era typified by philandering, booze and cigarettes in the workplace. They served as heavy anchors to the slender suits of the day that have been resurfacing thanks to "Mad Men" and the spinoffs hitting the floors at Brooks Brothers, J. Crew and Banana Republic. Duckie Brown's brogue collaboration with Florsheim has reinvigorated its classic Royal Imperial collection with saturated colors and artful perforations; other stateside manufacturers like Alden and Allen Edmonds have classic versions of the shoe that originated in England with brands like Trickers, Church's and Grenson. I prefer the cordovan color for the rich tone it adds to any gray suit, but black will do just fine. Best of all, brogues are not just suited for business - they are the perfect exclamation point for jeans, whether they are faded and worn, or dark and unwashed. Roll up those cuffs I'm feeling for brogues.

With the approach of the international climate talks in Copenhagen, the United Nations Development Program in conjunction with the Olympus Corporation and the Agence France-Presse Foundation created a photo competition aimed at profiling everyday Africans and their efforts to combat climate change. Below is a slide show of some of the winning photographs and the runners-up in various categories.

As you busily compile your year-end best-of lists and plan your 2010 schedule around the Grammys, the Oscars or the start of "American Idol," it may have escaped your attention that the National Book Awards, in their 60th year, are to be handed out on Wednesday night. If the National Book Awards, presented by the National Book Foundation, seem to have generated less buzz than in previous years, it might have something to do with a roster of finalists that aren't likely to be known by wide audiences: among this year's nominees for the fiction prize are Colum McCann's "Let the Great World Spin," and Marcel Theroux's "Far North"; the nonfiction finalists include David M. Carroll's "Following the Water: A Hydromancer's Notebook," and Sean B. Carroll's "Remarkable Creatures: Epic Adventures in the Search for the Origins of the Species."

A report released on Wednesday by Human Rights Watch on the human rights situation in Cuba takes the government of President Raúl Castro to task for, among other things, jailing those without jobs. The report cited the cases of dozens of people charged with "dangerousness" for being unemployed.

Monologue | Aired Tuesday night on NBC: The President of the United States is in China tonight. This is big. The Chinese president entertained President Obama by having a military band play "I Just Called To Say I Love You" and "We Are The World." What I want to know is how did the Chinese president get hold of my college record collection?

Monologue | Aired Tuesday night on "Late Night With Jimmy Fallon" on NBC: Well, the President is in China now. And he had 71 cars in his motorcade drive from the airport to Beijing. There's one car for the president, two for Secret Service and then 68 for Obama's advisers on the environment.

Monologue | Aired Tuesday night on "Jimmy Kimmel Live" on ABC: Sarah Palin's new book came out today. Well, she did "Oprah" yesterday. She did "G.M.A." this morning. Having her out on the road is a nice break, if you are a moose in Alaska.

Tonight in our towns, it's a great time to learn more about that "hardest job you'll ever love": parenting. True to the profession, you're expected to be two places at once. Or sent one parent to one session and the other parent to the other meeting. First, a description of Millburn's program, followed by words from Dr. Rob Handelman on mindful parenting.

Kumi Naidoo was appointed executive director of the environmental campaign group Greenpeace International this month after two decades leading civil society groups in Africa and internationally. Mr. Naidoo, 44, who is from South Africa, takes over the role at a time when environmentalism increasingly enjoys mainstream status, although the agenda of groups like Greenpeace remains at odds with those of many governments in critical areas like nuclear power and biotechnology. Mr. Naidoo, who is based in Amsterdam, answered questions on energy and climate policy in an e-mail exchange with Green Inc.

Update | 2:23 p.m. We've received lots of requests from business owners who want to know more about the 10,000 Small Businesses initiative. Here's a Web site dedicated to the plan. And here's an e-mail address where you can send questions: 10000SmallBusinesses@gs.com.

While the article in Tuesday's New York Times about SUNY's transition to Division I noted that the four State University of New York research universities have increased their contributions to athletics in recent years, it did not examine the role that student fees play in the athletic budgets, as Amy Perko of the Knight Commission on Intercollegiate Athletics noted in an e-mail message on Tuesday.

Jonathan Cohn gets his hands on a McKinsey & Company report analyzing what health care reform would mean for a typical employer (and thus for the medical system as a whole). The employer is called "Client X" in the report. The conclusion is that reform is indeed likely to have a significant -- and positive -- impact on health care.
Ford leads automakers in the annual list of Top Safety Picks from the Insurance Institute for Highway Safety, which released its compilation of the safest passenger vehicles Wednesday.

Highlights from Wednesday's media coverage:
American Express said Wednesday that it would buy Revolution Money, a provider of Internet-based payment services started by Steve Case, AOL's co-founder, for $300 million.

New York State would make it a felony to drive while intoxicated with a child in the vehicle and would require first-time convicted drunken drivers to buy a device that prevents them from driving their cars if they have been drinking, under a bill passed by the State Assembly on Tuesday.

Hubris will get you every time. Why did I think I could take Heston Blumenthal to lunch at Shopsin's and get away with it? The brilliant British chef behind the Fat Duck and the Hinds Head in Bray - just inked to open in the London Mandarin Oriental next fall with an Adam Tihany-designed space serving English food on a more historical scale - was in town on his way back from Venezuela, where he demonstrated his flaming sorbet. (First challenge: finding dry ice in a country with electricity shortages and an increasingly adversarial trade relationship with Colombia.) Where do you take a man known for snail porridge and bacon-and-egg ice cream? A chef so funny and articulate that you can basically print the transcript of his interview about roast chicken in the 14th century and call it a story? Duh.

What we're reading on Wednesday morning.RT @Pagliacci "Vesti la giubba": The Culture Monster blog of The Los Angeles Times reports on a project recently started by the San Diego Opera, in which that company will recount the history of opera on its Twitter feed, at the rate of two posts a day. One recent post in the series reads: "1613: Monteverdi in Venice, maestro di capella at San Marco. Writes great church music, and more operas."

Updated, 2:08 p.m. | Five young people have been arrested in a shooting that critically injured a 15-year-old Bronx girl -- a bystander struck by a bullet intended for someone else -- the New York City police announced on Wednesday morning.

Representative Paul E. Kanjorski introduced his contentious amendment to the House financial regulatory reform bill on Wednesday that would allow the government to break up financial institutions that it believed were "too big to fail," even if those firms appear well-capitalized and healthy.

Houston is America's oil capital, with its sprawling oil company headquarters and highways so densely trafficked at rush hour that they sometimes feel like endless parking lots. But Houston's city government and Reliant Energy are trying a modest new effort to green the city's image with a program called "Power of the Plug-in."

People who are closely following the health care debate might not have to wait much longer for Senate Democrats to release their bill and for the Congressional Budget Office to assess its cost.

"Ever since Natalie Portman popped headphones onto Zach Braff's head and said, 'This song will change your life,' [in the movie "Garden State"] American music has been dying a slow death," claims an essay quoted in the "Idea of the Day" blog. Andrew S. Grove, the 73-year-old former chief executive of Intel, has long brought a piercing intellect and a personal passion to the subject of health care.

Delta Air Lines offered $1 billion in aid to beleaguered Japan Airlines on Wednesday, a proposal that American Airlines quickly said it would top as the world's biggest air carriers escalated a war for influence.
Intrawest, owned by the Fortress Investment Group, has agreed to sell its Copper Mountain ski resort in Colorado to Powdr, The Associated Press reported.
MySpace, the social networking platform, is in talks to acquire struggling free music streaming site imeem, The Associated Press reported, citing two people familiar with the matter.

Charter Communications said Tuesday a bankruptcy judge has confirmed its reorganization plan, clearing the way for the nation's fourth-largest cable TV operator to emerge from Chapter 11 in a few weeks.
Xerox is a step closer to acquiring Dallas-based Affiliated Computer Services, now that the U.S. antitrust review period for the deal has expired, The Associated Press said.

Citigroup said on Tuesday it boosted the base salaries for its chief financial officer and a global markets co-head, but still plans to pay its chief executive, Vikram Pandit, $1 for the year, Reuters reported.

Congress ought to clarify if a proposed super-regulator of the U.S. financial system should be an overlapping overseer of securities and futures exchanges, the chief futures regulator said on Tuesday.

Enclosed by a dark brown fence, the weedy lot at Park Avenue and 56th Street in Midtown Manhattan is a conspicuous reminder of how ambitions were shattered in the recent real estate debacle, The New York Times's Terry Pristin writes. This vacant site, where the Drake Hotel once stood, is likely to leave a gash in the middle of the nation's costliest office submarket for years to come, real estate specialists say.

A 37-year-old Russian lawyer for an international investment fund, Hermitage Capital Management, died in a pretrial detention center on Monday, nearly a year after he was arrested in an escalating feud between the Russian authorities and the company, Russia's Interior Ministry announced on Tuesday.

This Frugal Traveler is not big on souvenirs. Too often, the postcards, T-shirts and other tchotchkes hawked to tourists are kitschy and overpriced - the kind of junk that takes up space in your suitcase and gets filed away when you return home. Rarely do those things fulfill the French root of the word "souvenir" and help you to remember your adventure. Better, I say, to save your money and return home empty-handed but full of memories.

Researchers at Princeton University recently made a remarkable discovery about the brains of rats that exercise. Some of their neurons respond differently to stress than the neurons of slothful rats. Scientists have known for some time that exercise stimulates the creation of new brain cells (neurons) but not how, precisely, these neurons might be functionally different from other brain cells.

John Quincy Adams is a preacher in Brooklyn. He founded the New Frontier Baptist Church in Bedford-Stuyvesant, where he has been a pastor for 45 of his 87 years. Mr. Adams - the father of two, grandfather of seven and great-grandfather of two - said he never gave much thought to sharing the name of a former president. "My life has been fruitful," he said. "Even though the presidents went further than I did, I think I kept pace with them."

NEW YORK.

An obituary on Monday about John J. O’Connor, a former television critic for The New York Times, referred incorrectly to his work for the Arts & Leisure section. Although he wrote essays for it under his own name, he did not also do so under the pseudonym Cyclops. That was the occasional pen name of another critic for The Times, John Leonard.
Michael R. Bennett is not a doctor. But he played one when he signed off on thousands of drug tests for aviation and transportation companies, federal officials said.

An article on Thursday about foundations that spend down their endowments and then close misstated the taxability of some foundation investment earnings. Private foundations are subject to an excise tax of 1 to 2 percent on the earnings; they are not tax exempt.

Buy your tickets now for “Brother/Sister Plays,” a trilogy by the talented young playwright Tarell Alvin McCraney, a onetime assistant to August Wilson. Set in a housing project in a Louisiana bayou, the plays, running in rep at the Public, “are pumped full of a senses-heightening oxygen that leaves you tingling,” Ben Brantley writes. “Mr. McCraney, who turned 29 in October, writes with a passion and urgency that can’t be faked and in a style that makes artifice feel like instinct, even as it invests ordinary lives with the grandeur of ancient gods.”

Once home to a Laundromat, the Bed-Stuy spot Umi Nom is now an outpost of sleek design and adventurous cooking — a destination worthy of a trip on the G train, courtesy of the pioneering chef King Phojanakong, of Kuma Inn on the Lower East Side. The menu at Uni Nom (tagalog for “to drink”) “consists of artfully composed small plates of Asian comfort food, elevated by technique but primal in appeal,” Ligaya Mishan writes. She likes the delicate crispy chicken wings, “the nearly deliquescent pork-belly adobo” and “the dizzyingly hot” papaya salad. “If you’re daring, Mr. Phojanakong can be a guide to the wild side,” she writes, offering the Filipino delicacy balut, a fertilized duck egg. Bring whatever you want to wash it down with — the restaurant is BYOB for the time being.

It’s not quite Manchester, England, England, but the Broadway cast of “Hair” will soon be making its way across the Atlantic Sea to take that musical to London. In a news release, the Public Theater, the “Hair” producers and Cameron Mackintosh said they would transfer the production to the Gielgud Theater next year, along with the cast that originated the revival, which is now playing at the Al Hirschfeld Theater. The London production is to begin previews on April 1 and open on April 14, while a new Broadway cast will come into the Hirschfeld starting on March 9. A press representative said that the London production would be an open-ended run, but that the New York cast would remain with the show only through Oct. 2. Gavin Creel, above left, and Will Swenson, above right, among others in the New York cast, were expected to be part of the London transfer, but contracts had not yet been signed, representatives said.

Readers clamoring for more work from this year’s Nobel laureate in literature will be able to get their hands on two more titles in the next three years. Metropolitan Books has acquired the North American rights to two novels by Herta Müller, above, the Romanian-born German novelist and essayist who received the Nobel Prize last month. Only 5 of Ms. Müller’s 20-some books have been published in English. Metropolitan Books, a unit of Macmillan that previously released her “Land of Green Plums” and “The Appointment,” has acquired rights to “Everything I Possess, I Carry With Me,” a finalist for the 2009 German Book Prize, and “The Fox Was Always a Hunter” (1992). Metropolitan will publish “Everything I Possess” — “Atemschaukel” in German — in September 2011 and “The Fox Was Always a Hunter” — “Der Fuchs War Damals Schon Der Jager” — in September 2012. Sara Bershtel, publisher of Metropolitan, said Philip Boehm would translate the books.

The City of Santa Monica is poised to join what is shaping up to be a high-profile contest in Los Angeles, competing with Beverly Hills and possibly another California municipality to become the home for a new museum to house the art collection of the billionaire Eli Broad, right. Several months ago Santa Monica officials approached Mr. Broad, who had already been in discussions with Beverly Hills about placing his museum there, The Los Angeles Times reported. In a report that was to be discussed Tuesday night by the Santa Monica City Council, P. Lamont Ewell, the city manager, said winning the museum, which would be built next to the Santa Monica Civic Auditorium, would “significantly advance the city’s goals of promoting the arts and enhancing cultural opportunities” in the area “with a relatively small expenditure of public funds.” Under the plan the city would lease land to Mr. Broad’s foundation for a nominal amount and contribute about $1 million for design, construction, parking and other costs. Mr. Broad’s foundation would pay the rest to build the museum, and would establish an endowment to cover its operating costs.

Off Broadway’s Vineyard Theater announced performance dates on Tuesday for the premiere production of “The Scottsboro Boys,” with music and lyrics by John Kander and Fred Ebb under Susan Stroman’s direction. The musical, about the historic rape case in Scottsboro, Ala., involving a group of black teenagers who seek to prove their innocence, will begin previews at the Vineyard on Feb. 12 and open on March 10. The book is by David Thompson, and music direction will be by David Loud. “The Scottsboro Boys,” unfinished at the time of Ebb’s death in 2004, had been slated for a development lab production in 2009-10, but instead will be given a fully staged production. Casting has not been announced.

The overlap between two Broadway productions of David Mamet won’t last very long. The Broadway revival of “Oleanna,” Mr. Mamet’s play about a university professor and the female student who believes he has harassed her, will end its run at the Golden Theater on Jan. 3, its publicists said Tuesday. The play, which stars Bill Pullman and Julia Stiles, was a transfer of a production that ran this year at the Mark Taper Forum in Los Angeles; directed by Doug Hughes, it opened at the Golden Theater on Oct. 11. Mr. Mamet’s new play, “Race,” which he is also directing, is to open at the Ethel Barrymore Theater on Dec. 6.

8 P.M. (13, 49) SECRETS OF SHANGRI-LA Two National Geographic reports present journeys to the remote kingdom of Mustang, between Nepal and Tibet, where mysterious, hand-carved caves high in the Himalayas have long shrouded glorious treasures, like hand-inked Tibetan folio pages, above, and ancient human remains. In this first entry the mountaineer Peter Athans leads an expedition of climbers, archaeologists, anthropologists and art historians on a mission to rescue valuable Tibetan texts from their deteriorating shelter before looters find them. A confrontation results, involving a political group from a nearby village, the king of Mustang and even the rights of the divinities that are believed to inhabit the area. In ''Lost Cave Temples of the Himalaya,'' at 9, Liesel Clark chronicles the 2007 expedition of Mr. Athans, who is her husband, and the big-wall climber Renan Ozturk as they maneuvered into the crumbling caves, where each vertical move was a step into a lost world unoccupied for hundreds, if not thousands, of years. 9:45 A.M. (Fox Business Network) FOX BUSINESS Jenna Lee reports on the newest products and services at the 2009 Streaming Media West show in San Jose, Calif. Marc Whitten, general manager of Xbox Live; Tim Harader, senior product manager of Microsoft Silverlight; and Anthony Wood, founder and chief executive of Roku, are interviewed.

While Congress searches for ways to slow the growth of health care spending, a new study suggests that its efforts may be overwhelmed by the surging prevalence of obesity. The report, issued Tuesday, projects that if current trends continue, 103 million American adults will be considered obese by 2018. That would be 43 percent of adults, compared with 31 percent in 2008, according to the research by Kenneth E. Thorpe, a professor of public health at Emory University and an authority on the cost of treating chronic disease.

Somali pirates released 36 crew members and their Spanish fishing vessel on Tuesday, the government here said, even as authorities said pirates had seized a tanker with a crew of 28 North Koreans. Prime Minister José Luis Rodríguez Zapatero told reporters that the Spanish tuna boat, the Alakrana, captured on Oct. 2, was steaming toward ''safer waters'' and that its crew was ''safe and sound.'' But officials declined to comment on reports that Spain had paid nearly $3.5 million in ransom. Asked about a ransom, Mr. Zapatero said, ''The government did what it had to do.''

MARTIN--Jean Jacobs. Weeks from her 93rd birthday, Jean Jacobs Martin left us on June 23, 2009. Her life will be celebrated by friends and family in Central Park on November 22nd at a Conservancy bench adopted in her memory. Born of Russian parentage in New York City on July 18, 1916, Jean was always an elegant, proud, and generous New Yorker; a loving, caring, loyal friend to many; a devoted wife to the late Charles Jacobs and the late Herman Martin; and the greatest fan of her "perfect" sons, Alan and Jim Jacobs, her daughters-in-law, Lynn Goodpasture and Kathleen Craig, and her granddaughters, Keelia Goodpasture Jacobs, the late Halley Canyon Rose Jacobs, and Wesley Lynn Willow Jacobs. Memorial donations may be made in her name to the Central Park Conservancy.

Officially, a player needs 6.25 carries per team game to qualify for the league leaders in yards per carry. Michael Vick is the single-season leader; he averaged 8.45 yards per carry in his final season in Atlanta. Among players with at least 200 carries in a season, Jim Brown's 6.40 yards per carry in 1963 is the best in league history. The Tennessee Titans' Chris Johnson has a chance to catch him; he is averaging 6.42 yards per carry this season. Johnson's average through nine games is the third highest by any player (with 100 carries) since 1960: only Brown (1963) and Mercury Morris (1973) were better.

Professor Emeritus in the Political Science Department of Drew University and author of eleven books, passed away at the age of sixty-seven from melanoma. Dr. Wice died peacefully on Sunday, November 15th, in the embrace of his three loving children. A wake is scheduled for Thursday, November 20 from 5-9pm at Burroughs, Kohr and Dangler Homes at 106 Main Street in Madison, New Jersey. Funeral services will begin at 11am the following morning at the same location.

AMES--Lucia Millham, 98, of Lexington, MA died on Thursday, November 12. Mrs. Ames, a resident of Locust Valley NY from 1939-1996, served on the American Hospital Association's Council on Volunteer Services from 1966-1968. She was a member of AHA's National Advisory Council on Health in 1971-1972. Mrs. Ames was the widow of Newton Millham and later Amyas Ames. She is survived by her children, Peter Millham, Lucia Michielli, Kate Latimer, Clodagh Lee, and Tony Millham. Contributions may be made in her name to Amyas Ames Nature Path at Brookhaven. A memorial service will be held at First Parish Church, Lincoln, MA, Saturday, November 21 at 11am. Services by Douglass Funeral Home, Lexington, MA.

Staying away from first-round picks like JaMarcus Russell and Darrius Heyward-Bey will be important to the Oakland Raiders' long-term success, but they could do themselves a favor in the short term by figuring out how to beat the Chiefs. Kansas City's 16-10 victory on Sunday was its seventh in a row at Oakland Coliseum. Since the Raiders played in the Super Bowl after the 2002 season, they are 3-11 against the Chiefs, a streak that includes losses to forgettable starting quarterbacks like Damon Huard and Tyler Thigpen. The streak is even more galling for Raiders fans when one considers that almost a quarter of Kansas City's 47 wins over the past seven seasons have come against Oakland. In the wake of the latest loss, Oakland Coach Tom Cable is contemplating a quarterback switch, but a change in buildings might be a better idea: the Raiders were much closer to .500 (12-14) against the Chiefs during the 13 years they called Los Angeles home. ANDREW DAS

REDLER--Angelika Marta (nee Hausman), of Manhattan, died Monday, November 16, 2009 just short of her 99th birthday. Familiarly known as Aga, she lived a storied life that began in privilege, was torn apart by extreme loss and suffering, and eventually ended in comfort and security. Her life story epitomizes the historic events that befell European Jews during the rise and fall of Nazism. Aga was born in Krakow, then part of Austria Hungary, now Poland, on November 28th 1910, into a well to do and cultured Jewish family. Her father and uncle were the owners of a multi city block shopping complex known as "Passage Hausman" in Lwow (Lemberg), Poland, now part of Ukraine. Highly educated, Aga studied art and literature; spoke French, Italian and English as well as Polish and German, which were her native tongues. She married Dr. Irvine Redler in 1934. At the start of the Second World War, Dr. Redler was able to leave the country because he played soccer for a team that represented Poland in an international league. Eventually, Mrs. Redler was also able to escape Poland and was reunited with her husband in Scotland, where both worked in a hospital as members of the Polish Army in exile under the leadership of General Anders. Mrs. Redler's parents and her brother Bruno were unable to leave and were exiled to Siberia by the Russians when the Nazis declared war on Soviet Russia. Mrs. Redler's father and brother, then 18, died in captivity as a result of malnutrition and lack of medical care. Her mother, Alicia Glatzer-Hausman survived the war and was reunited with her daughter and son-in-law in England. The three immigrated to the US in 1947 and made their home in New York City. Dr. Redler was professor of orthopedics at New York University Hospital until his death in 1981. Mrs. Redler worked as a volunteer translator at the hospital and at the Guggenheim Museum for many years. She loved New York, and its cultural events, especially the Opera. There are no immediate family members.

Last season's Super Bowl pitted the N.F.L.'s 23rd-ranked rushing offense (Pittsburgh) against the 32nd-ranked rushing offense (Arizona). If that didn't convince fans that the importance of the running game is a distant second to the passing game, then here is more evidence: This season, the teams with the top eight passing offenses, in terms of yards per game, all have winning records. Seven of them are 6-3 or better: 1. Indianapolis (9-0); 2. New England (6-3); 3. Houston (5-4); 4. New Orleans (9-0); 5. Arizona (6-3); 6. Dallas (6-3); 7. San Diego (6-3); and 8. Pittsburgh (6-3).

LARSON--Robert W.,beloved husband of Margo, passed away on November 12, 2009. He was the father of 10 children, 14 grandchildren and one great-grandson. Born in Dover, NJ on January 28, 1922, Larson was a graduate of Cornell University. He was a Major in the U.S. Army serving in WWII as an Artillery Battery Commander and was captain and coach of the U.S. Army Touring Track Team. He founded Larson Mortgage Company, growing it into a diverse company of 650 employees in six states, which later became Cenlar Capital Corp. He was a leader in national mortgage banking for 30 years and was President of the Board of Governors of the New Jersey Mortgage Bankers Assn. and worked with the U.S. Senate and House Banking Committees developing legislation and testifying on housing-related matters. Larson was a member of Cornell's Tower and Founders Clubs, sponsoring foreign students and renowned artist Muli Tang. He was married to Margo Mayr Larson for 23 years; they were close and affectionate companions. Service is at 11am Friday, November 20, 2009 at Liberty Corner Presbyterian Church, 45 Church St., Basking Ridge, NJ 07920. Friends may call Friday from 9am to 11am. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made in the name of Robert W. Larson to Cornell Track & Field Team payable to "Cornell University" and with "Track Development Fund" on memo line. Attn: S. Caraher, CU Athletics, Teagle Hall, Ithaca, NY 14853.

Brian Burke of Advanced NFL Stats assessed the Jaguars' strategy of instructing Maurice Jones-Drew to take a knee at the Jets' 1-yard line rather than scoring late in Jacksonville's victory Sunday: ''It improved the Jaguars' chances of winning by 17 percentage points. Smart, selfless player and smart coaching.

Osborne, in an interview yesterday. The cost of the upgrades was not immediately available. -- Tina Kelley

I'm preheating the oven up here in the Dining kitchen, getting ready for the Thanksgiving holiday, getting ready to man the battle stations for The New York Times Thanksgiving Help Desk. I will be with you through most of the big day itself. Need help with the bird, the stuffing, the sides, the gravy, the wine, how to say grace (whether to say grace!), the timing, the desserts, the fact that you said you'd make butternut squash and now you're looking at the things and realize you have no idea how to make butternut squash? The New York Times Thanksgiving Help Desk is here to help. Post a question below. I'll answer it, until 3 p.m next Thursday. Watch for the later postings on Diner's Journal for my responses.

A gas station attendant was Tasered and beaten up this morning in a robbery on Springfield Avenue, the Maplewood police said. Soon after, officers apprehended a suspect, who was charged with aggravated assault, robbery, resisting arrest and weapons charges. According to the police, at about 6:30 a.m. a man entered the office of the Denco Gas Station, Tasered the attendant, hit him in the face and knocked him to the ground. He then took a large amount of cash from the attendant's jacket pocket and left. A customer reported a description of the suspect to the police, and Patrolman Kevin Graham found someone answering that description behind a home on Russell Street in Union. After a brief chase, Michael Terry, 22, of Union, was arrested with the help of Patrolman Kraig Hunken and Sgt. Joe Guglielmo. Patrolman Graham suffered a minor knee injury, and the victim was taken to St. Barnabas Medical Center, where he was treated and released. Mr. Terry was being held at the Essex County Jail, with bail set at $100,000. -- Tina Kelley

In what is surely one of the more interesting convergences of economics and design in recent memory, the multiethnic, small-business-dominated London neighborhood of Brixton recently started printing its own currency. The idea for the Brixton pound was cooked up by Tim Nichols, who wanted to stimulate local commerce and study how wealth circulates when bank notes are confined to single districts. Transition Town Brixton, a community organization that addresses energy issues and climate change, also pitched in on the project, with the intention of encouraging local consumption and helping shrink carbon footprints.

LOST PINES, Texas - This has not been the easiest year for Mark Sanford, the governor of South Carolina. Mr. Sanford found himself entangled in a public tale about an affair. His wife ditched him. He is facing an ethics investigations back home. He has withstood calls to step down at home, instead deciding to wait out the end of his term (he is barred from seeing reelection by term limits). And he arguably has not been particularly good for the Republican brand.
