Kate Whoriskey's first season as an artistic director of the Intiman Theater in Seattle will include a production of "Ruined," the Pulitzer Prize-winning Lynn Nottage play that Ms. Whoriskey also directed in New York and Chicago. On Thursday, the Intiman announced that its 2010 season would open with a production of Clifford Odets's "Paradise Lost," directed by Dámaso Rodriguez, which will begin previews on March 19 and open on March 26. The season will also feature "Ruined" (July 2 through Aug. 8) as the first play in a five-year International Cycle and Hawthorne's "Scarlet Letter" adapted by Naomi Iizuka and directed by Lear deBessonet (Oct. 22 through Dec. 5) as the latest play in its American Cycle. Other productions include Molière's "A Doctor in Spite of Himself" (Sept. 3-Oct. 10), adapted by Christopher Bayes and Steven Epp, and starring Daniel Breaker, a star of "Shrek the Musical" and "Passing Strange" (as well as Ms. Whoriskey's husband). Ms. Whoriskey is currently sharing artistic directing duties with Bartlett Sher, who is departing after this season.
The usual preholiday hiring by stores did not happen in October as the city's unemployment rate held at 10.3 percent, its highest level in 16 years, the State Labor Department said on Thursday.

Investors can now receive email reminders -- quarterly, annually, or another period -- which will outline how much of each fund or security they need to buy or sell to rebalance back to their their original allocation.

The A/V team at the Philadelphia Museum of Art has been working double-overtime, installing "Marcel Wanders: Daydreams," a multimedia exhibition that opens on Sunday. The exhibition, a retrospective of sorts of the Dutch design star's career, is Wanders's first solo show in the United States. Why Philadelphia? "We asked him," said Kathy Hiesinger, the museum's curator of European decorative arts. And to sweeten the deal, the museum's modern design collaborative, Collab, will present Wanders with its Design Excellence Award on Saturday night.

In June, the once-downtrodden mess of a company called Palm shocked the world by thrusting its arm from the grave, holding a gleaming, compact capsule called the Palm Pre. The Pre, of course, is an app phone like the iPhone, in fact designed by many of the same ex-Apple engineers, but with a slide-out keyboard, removable battery, and joyous touch screen software all its own.

This week, Palm released a follow up to the Pre, a cheaper, thinner, lesser phone called the Pixi. The official price is $100 with a two-year Sprint contract, but Amazon is selling the thing for — are you sitting down? — $25.

Phillips de Pury is an esteemed auction house dating back to 1796. Its clientele includes Napoleon and Beau Brummell. A different ilk of bidders, however, will be raising their paddles this Saturday as the firm holds its inaugural Music sale.

Ethan Hawke has assembled an estimable gathering of downtown denizens and fellow actors to star in a coming revival of "A Lie of the Mind," the Sam Shepard play that he will be directing for the New Group. The cast of the play, about a man who believes he may have murdered his wife, will feature Josh Hamilton (who starred in Jonathan Marc Sherman's "Things We Want" for Mr. Hawke), as well as Marin Ireland (Broadway's "Reasons to Be Pretty"), Deirdre O'Connell ("Circle Mirror Transformation"), Alessandro Nivola, Maggie Siff and Frank Whaley. The production is to begin previews on Jan. 29 with an official opening planned for February, its publicists said in a news release.

The Public Theater said on Thursday that it was extending its run of Tarell Alvin McCraney's "Brother/Sister Plays." The production will continue through Dec. 20, with all three plays running on Saturdays and Sundays.

On City Room, Mike Reicher writes about a new exhibition, "Only in New York: Photographs From Look Magazine," at the Museum of the City of New York. "Based on a book with the same title, it is a compilation of the photojournalism magazine's images published between 1938 and 1971," he writes. "Editors and photographers at Look, which had its offices in New York, drew many of their subjects from the city's streets, stages and back rooms." Read more on City Room . . .

Will Ferrell may have had a lucrative season on Broadway in his George W. Bush show, but that comic actor is being called the most overpaid film star in a Forbes.com study, Reuters reported. In ranking the Top 10 movie stars who cost more than they deliver, Forbes.com looked at actors' estimated salaries on their films, including DVD and television sales, and compared them to the revenues grossed by those films. According to this methodology, Mr. Ferrell's films earned an average of $3.29 for every dollar he was paid. (The tally was dragged down by his 2009 release "Land of the Lost," which cost $100 million to make and grossed $65 million worldwide.) The Forbes list of overpaid stars was rounded out by Ewan McGregor, Billy Bob Thornton, Eddie Murphy, Ice Cube, Tom Cruise, Drew Barrymore, Leonardo DiCaprio, Samuel L. Jackson and Jim Carrey.

Among the National Book Awards winners named on Wednesday night whose names may elude you, one honoree you've almost certainly heard of is Flannery O'Connor. In an online poll conducted by the National Book Foundation, her collection "The Complete Stories" was named the best work to have won the National Book Award for fiction in the contest's 60-year history. The competition was steep: other finalists in the poll were "The Stories of John Cheever," William Faulkner's "Collected Stories," "The Collected Stories of Eudora Welty," Ralph Ellison's "Invisible Man" and Thomas Pynchon's "Gravity's Rainbow." (Then again, the O'Connor book bested some formidable contenders when it won the fiction prize in 1972, including John Updike's "Rabbit Redux," Walker Percy's "Love in the Ruins" and E. L. Doctorow's "Book of Daniel.") This year's National Book Award for fiction was won by Colum McCann's "Let the Great World Spin."

Lani Hay, daughter of Vietnamese immigrants, retired from the Navy as an intelligence officer, and then with her American Express card and some savings, opened a technology consulting business serving the federal government. By 2007, just four years after it opened its doors, Lanmark Technology had grown to bring in $12 million in annual revenue and employ 100 people.* Then the recession hit. "Along with L.M.T.'s annual revenues dropping, L.M.T.'s line of credit was also dropped, by a bank that bought out the bank that I was working with," Ms. Hay said Wednesday in a conference in Washington, convened by the Obama administration to address the problems small businesses have had finding capital during the recession. Worse, she said, the bank canceled the credit line just before she was to receive a $500,000 contract from the Defense Department - and she had needed the credit to tide her firm over until the government paid its bills.

Should the United States and China be teaming up on clean urban transportation systems instead of clean cars? After the announcement of a suite of new energy partnerships between China and the United States, I sought feedback on the electric vehicle project from Lee Schipper, an energy and transportation specialist who splits his time between the University of California, Berkeley, and Stanford. He's quite worried that the program is looking at cars mainly from an energy-efficiency context, instead of how they will shape and affect China's fast-expanding cities in a larger sense. "Creating a zero-carbon car for China tomorrow won't solve the much bigger problems of urban congestion, traffic fatalities and the paving over of once-beautiful cities to make room for more cars," Dr. Schipper said. "The discussions should back up. Energy is only a means to an end. What are the ends, urban access and mobility, or cars for a small minority?"

Stanley Kubrick wanted the grit. Still in his teens, the future director photographed New York City's underbelly in the 1940s and '50s, shooting boxers and showgirls with stark shadows evocative of the city's shady side. First as a freelancer and then as a staff photographer for Look magazine, his images were a dark counterpoint to the work of others who depicted New York as a gleaming world capital.

Opium Magazine’s Literary Death Match drives another stake into the notion of bookish politesse tonight at the Bowery Poetry Club. Watch as comedy writers — including Jon Friedman of Jimmy Fallon and “The Rejection Show” and Edith Zimmerman, of these hilarious “Letters to the Editors of Women’s Magazines” — duke it out in the reading arena, which is a lot louder than you might think.

Girl? Boy? Boi? Gurl? It no longer matters, at least as long as style is concerned. Androgyny is in, according to Ruth La Ferla. Outfit your new gender-neutral wardrobe at the Steven Alan sample sale (at the showroom, 87 Franklin Street, TriBeCa), where you can get striped sweaters, leather jackets, slouchy T-shirts and printed scarves for more than 50 percent off, along with a decent sampling of the people you’d want to attract while wearing them.

“The Cuban band Septeto Nacional de Ignacio Piñeiro can legitimately claim to have invented salsa,” Larry Rohter writes. But though their music has flourished, because of political machinations, they’ve had a hard time reaching our shores: the group last performed in the United States at the Chicago World’s Fair in 1933. Tonight the musicians — fourth-generation descendents of the original line-up, including the sole female member of the Buena Vista Social Club — will play what may be a once-in-a-lifetime gig at SOBs. Don’t miss it, or risk waiting another 76 years.

An article last Thursday about foundations that spend down their endowments and then close misstated the percentage of the New York City Anti-Violence Project’s budget that comes from the Paul Rapoport Foundation. It is 1 percent, not “more than one-tenth.” The article also paraphrased incorrectly from comments by Sharon Stapel, the executive director of the Anti-Violence Project, about the project’s possible efforts to attract new donors. She said it might seek to broaden its base of donors, not to serve a broader audience.
The government will apply high technology to H. R. Haldeman’s handwritten notes in an effort to fill in the 18 ½-minute gap in the Watergate tapes.
The Basics column on Nov. 10, about recent discoveries from the study of pig cognition, misstated the species of a wild boar. It is Sus scrofa, not Sus scrofus.
A report found that universities often do not disclose faculty members’ conflicts of interest in government-financed studies.

A picture caption on Saturday with an article about a decline in Champagne sales misstated the relationship between two of the people shown shopping for wine. Brenda Terris, at the left, is single; Ed Weltman is not her husband. (They were shown with Tamara Wick.).

An article on Monday about “virtual wallets” and other ways to avoid carrying money and credit cards, misstated the billing procedure used by Boku, a start-up company that lets people purchase goods online using their 10-digit cellphone numbers. Boku applies charges to its customers’ cellphone bills, not to their credit cards.

The Religion Journal on Saturday, about a church for young people in Queens, misstated the chapter of a biblical passage that was the subject of the first sermon by Din Tolbert, now the church’s youth pastor. The passage, which says that nothing will separate Christians from the love of God, is Romans 8, verses 35-39 — not Romans 35. (Romans has only 16 chapters.).

An article on Saturday about the new White House counsel, Robert F. Bauer, misstated the relationship between President Richard M. Nixon and his third counsel, Leonard Garment. Mr. Garment had known Nixon for nearly a decade and had been an aide and adviser to him before taking the White House job; it was not the case that he and Nixon were not close.

A map on Saturday with an article about the decriminalization of possession of small amounts of marijuana in Breckenridge, Colo., labeled a neighboring state incorrectly. The state directly south of Colorado is New Mexico, not Texas.

A headline on Friday with an article about the tracing of an E. coli outbreak to AFA Foods, a large producer of ground beef, described the company’s testing procedures incorrectly. It tests its finished ground beef, but stopped testing the beef trimmings that are mixed into the beef; it has not “halted testing of ground beef.”.

An article on Tuesday about revised guidelines on breast cancer screening misstated a statistic from the United States Preventive Services Task Force, which released the recommendations. The task force concluded that one cancer death was prevented for every 1,339 women aged 50 to 59 who were screened for 10 years — not 50 to 74.

“Precious: Based on the Novel ‘Push’ by Sapphire,” starring Gabourey Sidibe, above, took a step in the march toward Oscar recognition, as the Producers Guild of America has chosen to honor it with the group’s Stanley Kramer Award. Established in 2002, the Kramer award is given to a movie, program, studio, executive or entity that tackles provocative social issues in a constructive way. “Precious,” about a young woman’s struggles to succeed despite her troubled and impoverished family, fills the bill, and will join past recipients like “Milk” and “Good Night, and Good Luck,” both of which were nominated for best picture Oscars.

Have a burning question you’ve wanted to pose to the Velvet Underground since that down-and-out New York art-rock band broke up in the 1970s? Want to know who’s coughing on the recording of “Who Loves the Sun” or when we’ll see an official CD release for “Squeeze”? You may finally have a chance to get the answers. On Dec. 8 three members of the Velvet Underground will appear at the New York Public Library to discuss the group’s music and history as part of the library’s “Live From the NYPL” series, Billboard reported. The musicians Maureen Tucker, Doug Yule and, of course, Lou Reed, above, are scheduled to appear. The Velvet Underground singer-guitarist Sterling Morrison died in 1995, and the band’s co-founder John Cale left in 1968, though he reunited with Mr. Reed for a Rock and Roll Hall of Fame induction ceremony in 1996.

Bon Jovi has scored its second No. 1 album in a row — and the fourth of its career — with “The Circle” (Island), which sold 163,000 copies in the United States, according to Nielsen SoundScan. Carrie Underwood’s “Play On” (19/Arista Nashville), last week’s top seller, fell to No. 3 with 128,000 sales, a 60 percent drop, and Andrea Bocelli’s “My Christmas” (Sugar/Decca) climbed one spot to No. 2 with 136,000. The soundtrack to Michael Jackson’s “This Is It” (Epic) fell two spots to No. 4 with 117,000 sales, and Taylor Swift’s “Fearless” (Big Machine) was No. 5 with 91,000 sales. Besides “The Circle,” the only other new album on the Top 10 this week was “Memento Mori” (A&M/Octone) by the young Texas metal band Flyleaf, which bowed at No. 8 with 56,000.

The design for the George W. Bush Presidential Center at Southern Methodist University, created by Robert A. M. Stern Architects, was officially unveiled in a ceremony Wednesday, The Dallas Morning News reported. In an interview Laura Bush told The Morning News that a year was spent discussing and planning the design for a 225,000-square-foot building that will be home to Mr. Bush’s presidential papers, as well as a museum and a policy institute. “We did not want this to be monumental like some other libraries are,” Mrs. Bush said. “We’re very aware that the presidents are men. They are people. We wanted it to be human in scale.” Mr. Stern said the building, which is scheduled to have its groundbreaking next year, was not designed to reflect on Mr. Bush personally. “It’s not a portrait or a defense of his policies,” Mr. Stern told The Morning News. “It is about the presidency, the dignity of the office.”.

For the “Bad Lieutenant” star Nicolas Cage, right, the week just got a little worse. The Associated Press reported that Mr. Cage, whose spending habits have been widely discussed since he filed suit against his former business manager, was being countersued by that manager. In October Mr. Cage sued Samuel J. Levin for fraud, accusing Mr. Levin of leading him “down a path toward financial ruin.” In the countersuit filed on Nov. 12, The A.P. reported, Mr. Levin said he had told Mr. Cage that he would need to earn $30 million a year to maintain his lifestyle, and that he warned the actor not to buy castles in England and Bavaria. (Mr. Cage did not heed the advice.) Mr. Levin also said that he devised a fund-raising plan that included the sale of classic cars and a $1.6 million comic book collection. A lawyer for Mr. Cage said Mr. Levin had breached Mr. Cage’s privacy by releasing details about his asset sales.

Senator Charles E. Schumer, Democrat of New York, has thrown his support behind an effort to keep the Pool Parties summer concert series at its latest home on the Brooklyn waterfront. Jelly, the group that began putting on the free shows at McCarren Park Pool in Williamsburg in 2006 and moved to the East River State Park in Williamsburg this year, wants to stay at the park but announced on Wednesday that state parks officials said it might not be able to return next year. Senator Schumer, who attended two Pool Party concerts this year, said he would work with state authorities to allow the concerts to stay. “When I heard that the concerts might be canceled, I couldn’t understand why, given that this is exactly what our parks are supposed to be for, and I am going to do everything I can to see that they continue,” he said. Not everything went perfectly smoothly at the Pool Parties this year. For a show in August featuring Girl Talk, an extension to the stage collapsed.

TEICHER--Rabbi Isaac Jacob, lovingly referred to as "Zeidi," died peacefully in his sleep early Sunday morning, November 15, 2009, two months shy of his 104th birthday. Renowned Rabbinic scholar, he immigrated to New York from Galicia passing through the gates of Ellis Island in 1920. His lengthy career had numerous stopping points and milestones, culminating with a span of 27 years in Montreal, Canada where, in addition to his pulpit position, he served for many years as President of the Board of Jewish Ministers. Following the death of his beloved wife Chiennie, he lived the last 31 years of his life in the community of Hillcrest, Queens. He is survived by his children Soshy and Chaim, their spouses Sol and Marni, six grandchildren and six great-grandchildren. Zeidi was graced with an effusive personality and presence. He was a dynamic orator and legendary teller of tales. He was an integral force in our lives for so long, it is hard to conceive of life without him. Baruch Adoshem yom yom. Blessed be God for every day.

SYMS--Sy. The Columbia University International Family AIDS Program mourns the loss of our dear friend and founding philanthropic partner, Sy Syms, who together with Lynn, his wife; David and Gerry Pincus; and Harold and Lynne Honickman, provided in 1999 the moral and financial support to introduce AIDS care and treatment for pregnant women, children, adolescents and adults in the Dominican Republic and other resource-poor countries. Hundreds of babies have been born AIDS-free; thousands of lives have been saved. Sy's friendship, humor, quiet generosity, humility, and deep compassion for those in need will be deeply missed. We send our sincere condolences to his family. Stephen Nicholas, M.D., Founder and Director

Petschek, Judith Resnick, Lauren Veronis, Vice-Presidents Suzanne K. Ponsot, Exec. Dir.

SYMS--Sy. The Yeshiva University family is profoundly saddened at the death of our Vice Chairman and cherished friend. Entrepreneur, philanthropist, and consummate gentleman --this was Sy Syms. Beloved husband of Lynn Tamarkin Syms, he is survived by his daughters, Marcy, member of YU's Sy Syms School of Business Board of Overseers, and Laura, sons, Robert and Richard, two stepchildren, Cary Tamarkin and Leslie Tamarkin, eleven grandchildren, and three sisters. He had two children who predeceased him, Stephen and Adrienne, of blessed memory. In 1983 he was presented with an Honorary Doctor of Humane Letters degree, conferred by then President Norman Lamm. Mr. Syms was a Benefactor of Yeshiva University whose visionary gift in 1986 established the Sy Syms School of Business. The school has launched men and women in highly successful careers in many business disciplines. He founded the Syms Board of Overseers, was a dynamic Co-Chair of the university's 2001 capital campaign, and significantly supported the undergraduate and graduate schools, the YU Museum, the affiliated Rabbi Isaac Elchanan Theological Seminary and the High School Enrichment Fund. He had served as treasurer of the Yeshiva University Board of Trustees, and was Vice Chairman at the time of his passing. Mr. Syms was an accomplished business leader and generous and visionary philanthropist. President Richard M. Joel noted, ''Sy Syms embodied excellence in education, ethics, decency, humor and humility-he represented the best in us. He will be sorely missed.'' May the family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Yeshiva University Richard M. Joel, President Dr. Norman Lamm, Chancellor Sy Syms School of Business Josh S. The onslaught of television commercials opposing health care legislation has prompted a liberal advocacy group and two labor unions to begin a $1.7 million advertising campaign in favor of the overhaul. The commercials, being shown on both cable and broadcast stations in 13 Congressional districts, try to buck up 12 Democrats and the lone Republican who voted in favor of health care legislation when it passed the House on Nov. 7.

IT was a cut-and-paste operation as aspiring designers gathered last week to show off creations improvised, literally, with tape and shears. Their efforts, unveiled at Don Hill's, a downtown club, were part of Style Wars, a competition produced by the House of Diehl, a New York design firm. The point, Mary Jo Diehl said, was to give the young a chance to shine under pressure. ''In a dream world you've got six months and a bolt of Italian silk to make a dress,'' she said. ''In the real world your resources and deadlines are tighter than Shrek in a Speedo.'' Two of the judges, the models Elettra Wiedemann (top right) and Jenny Shimizu (near right), tried to keep open minds. Ms. Shimizu hoped she could spot talent at a glance. ''I'm watching for the energy,'' she said. ''That's what's most attractive.''

Revised guidelines from an influential panel of medical experts suggest that women under age 50 forgo annual mammograms. Conservatives were quick to cite the new recommendations as an example of hazardous government intrusion into health care, and many readers agreed. Following are a sampling of comments: Here in a single capsule-sized dose is the reason health care costs are skyrocketing: No one is willing to accept anything short of the Cadillac standard of health care, even when a Ford is perfectly adequate to get you where you want to go. Donnolo Their agenda at the outset was one of cost-cutting, making more money for the insurance companies in the short term, and not patient care. They totally ignored a large body of evidence that contradicts their position. Marco77 It's all about cost first, quality second. In this health care debate, you get to pick your poison, but both pills are bitter. Bill My first mammogram, at the age of 40, showed I had ductal carcinoma in situ. Surgery followed. Five years later, I had invasive cancer, a far more aggressive and dangerous disease. It is unthinkable that mammograms should be withheld until the age of 50. It is also unforgivable that a remote task force could propose such a disturbing and alarming suggestion. cjm What about screening for prostate cancer? Oh, of course, men are better able to deal with the trauma of false positives. Fragile women must be shielded from this awful fate, even at the risk of their lives. Silly me. Robinson

NBC's ''Sunday Night Football'' has achieved what ABC's ''Monday Night Football'' never did, even in the 1970s: it is the No. 1 program in prime time. For now. It will almost certainly lose the race after the season ends and Fox's ''American Idol'' returns to the air in January. Through 10 weeks, ''Sunday Night'' viewership (19.8 million), household rating (12.0) and all key demographic ratings placed it at No. 1. The numbers are slightly less dominating for the TV season, which began on Sept. 21 and excluded NBC's first three games. By that calculation, ''Sunday Night'' is No. 1 in the critical adult 18-49 demographic but second to CBS's ''NCIS'' in ratings and viewership. RICHARD SANDOMIR

THERE are 2.3 million people in the United States who hunt migratory birds, according to the Fish and Wildlife Service. And in many parts of the country it is duck hunting season. Waterfowl guns are now more versatile than ever, with features that let hunters use shells of various sizes and keep a tighter pattern to their shots at longer ranges. ''Today's shotguns come dipped in camo colors to help prevent rust on the barrels,'' said Bill Lyons, the state chairman of Massachusetts Ducks Unlimited, a group that favors wetlands conservation and supports hunting. ''They're also made lighter than guns from the past,'' Mr. Lyons said by e-mail.

WENTZ--Earl, 71, of New York and Charlotte passed away in Charlotte on Sunday, November 15, following an extended illness. He was a noted teacher of vocal performance and technique and performed as both an actor and musician. Earl Wentz was also a composer of both numerous sacred and secular works. He created the American Composer Series, an ongoing cabaret series paying tribute to the greatest composers of popular American music, particularly those associated with Tin Pan Alley, presenting 15 original musical revues from 2000 to 2009. He is survived by his partner of 27 years, William B. Watkins of New York, and an extended family. For more information on the life and career of Earl Wentz, please see the web site at www.earlwentz.com. For currently in print and soon to be released CDs and other works, please see www.sixpenceinc.com. Details of the services scheduled for New York and Charlotte as well as memorial fund information can also be found at www.earlwentz.com.

Raiders in a high-speed skiff tried again on Wednesday to commandeer the Maersk Alabama, the American-flagged ship seized by pirates in April, the United States Navy said. The United States Naval Forces Central Command said four men in a skiff came within 300 yards of the Maersk Alabama about 600 miles off the northeast coast of Somalia. But a security team on the Maersk Alabama responded with small-arms fire and evasive maneuvers to help thwart the attack, the Navy said in a statement. No injuries or damage were reported, the Navy said.

It's late in the season, but you would not be able to tell by looking at the schedule. Top-ranked Florida is taking on Florida International, No. 2 Alabama plays Chattanooga and no top 25 teams play each other. It seems like a lineup fit for the first or second week. But even in this seeming desert of decent games, there are a few matchups worth watching. Two of them -- Oregon at Arizona and California at Stanford -- are in the wide-open Pac-10, which has defied expectations throughout the season. Mississippi State at Arkansas may not mean much in the larger context of the SEC, but it does give two programs which seem to be improving under relatively new coaches a chance to show where they stand. Kansas State's game against Nebraska does matter in the Big 12, though the prize for winning this game will be a date with powerful Texas in the conference title game. And to round things out and keep the A.C.C. fans interested, we'll be keeping an eye on North Carolina and Boston College. Our band of prognosticators have made their picks, and now it's time to hear from you. If you agree, disagree or merely find the predictions laughable, feel free to chime in with a comment.

Almost every account of bloodshed necessarily focuses on death and mortal injury. In that way, though, important stories are lost: those of survivors whose lives are forever changed in one traumatic instant. More than a dozen people were killed by a suicide bomber in Afghanistan on Friday. Others, like this boy, were "merely" injured (Slide 4). We do not know his prognosis - or even his name, for that matter - but we can see in that tender face just how high a price violence exacts. Reuters credited the photograph simply to a stringer.

But Performa 09, which runs through this weekend, has given us a breed of less self-indulgent artists for whom audience pleasure is paramount. Witness the exhilarating, back-to-back appearances last night by Mike Kelley and Terence Koh. Though the title of his work, "Extracurricular Activity Projective #32, Plus," suggested more of the same-old-same, Kelley brought nudity, horseplay and a Bourbon Street-style marching band to the basketball court at Judson Church, the epicenter of postmodern dance.

"Enter Laughing," the semi-autobiographical novel by Carl Reiner about a funny young actor juggling his girlfriends, career dreams and difficult parents, was turned into a play that was a hit on Broadway in the mid-1960s and then a musical that flopped in 1976 with the title "So Long, 174th Street."

Critics have accused President Obama of kowtowing to Chinese leaders, by failing to meet dissidents, toning down his criticisms and delaying a meeting with the Dalai Lama. On balance, I think that criticism is premature: Confrontation doesn't help with China and can hurt, and so engagement becomes a fine line to navigate. The Obama visit wasn't a ringing success, but neither was it a craven embarrassment.

Though they get together now only for Transcendental Meditation-themed concerts and Beatles Rock Band promotional events, Ringo Starr and Paul McCartney have recently reunited for an actual new piece of recorded music. Mr. Starr told The Guardian that Mr. McCartney, his long-ago band mate, provided bass and backing vocals for a song called "Walk With Me" that appears on Mr. Starr's coming solo album, "Y Not." When Mr. McCartney visited his home around the time of the Grammy Awards, Mr. Starr said, "I played him this other track and Paul said: 'Give me the headphones. Give me a pair of cans.' And he went to the mike, and he just invented that part where he follows on my vocal. That was all Paul McCartney, and there could be nothing better." The song was written by Van Dyke Parks and Mr. Starr, who added that Mr. McCartney's contribution "makes the song like a conversation between us, and that was Paul's idea to do his part one beat behind me." The two surviving Beatles previously recorded together on Mr. Starr's 1998 album, "Vertical Man," which also featured contributions from George Harrison and George Martin.

The Department of City Planning has proposed regulations that would restrict certain homeowners from paving over their front yards to create parking spaces, a move that could alter the residential streetscape, especially in boroughs like Queens and Brooklyn. Responding to residents' complaints of unsightly concrete driveways and lost street parking, the new rules would restrict so-called curb cuts -- the sidewalk indentations created to allow cars to move from the street onto the front yards of houses -- and tighten front-yard "planting" requirements. They would also require certain residential building owners to add parking if they modify their buildings. These changes are "key to fostering inviting, walkable blocks," the city planning commissioner, Amanda M. Burden, said when she announced the proposed new rules on Monday. Like the PlaNYC and other recent Bloomberg administration initiatives, the rules hold the potential for making the city more pedestrian friendly and create more green spaces. But if approved, they would inhibit homeowners who want to carve out parking spaces on their own properties.

Pastry-loving Upper East Siders who have been bereft since François Payard closed his patisserie and restaurant in June can satisfy their sweet tooth once more. Many of his specialties, including macarons, cookies and chocolates are available at Butterfield Market. His büche de Noël, a Christmas mainstay for years, will reappear in December. (Mr. Payard started selling a more limited line of sweets in the Mauboussin jewelry boutique on Madison Avenue a few weeks ago.)Butterfield Market: 1114 Lexington Avenue (78th Street); (212)-288-7800.

Because hockey does not receive anywhere near equal attention from most of the established media in the United States when compared to other major sports, it has consistently found a home in new and emerging media. When network TV lost its interest in the N.H.L., the league pioneered bringing major league sports to cable TV in the early '80s (and the teams followed on regional sports cable networks). If fans found that their local newspaper sports sections contained little news of hockey, they increasingly sought that news on the Internet, beginning on Web sites and then blogs.

The chief executive of the Gibson Guitar company will take a leave of absence from an environmental group after a federal raid on the company's factory in Nashville, The Tennessean reported. On Tuesday, The Tennessean reported, agents of the United States Fish and Wildlife Service served a search warrant on company officials at a Gibson manufacturing plant where its acoustic and electric guitars are made. The agents did not say what they were searching for or if anything was removed from the plant. But some hardwoods used in making premium guitars, like rosewood from the rain forests of Madagascar and Brazil, have recently been banned under a federal law called the Lacey Act because of environmental concerns. In a statement to The Tennessean, Gibson said that it was "fully cooperating with agents of the United States Fish and Wildlife Service as it pertains to an issue with harvested wood." The Rainforest Alliance, a conservation group, said the Gibson chief executive, Henry Juszkiewicz, would not rejoin its board until the federal investigation ends.

I hate making analogies between selling a business and selling a house. It offends me on many levels, but nevertheless, here I go. I was watching an episode of "The Property Ladder" on the Learning Channel, and it got me thinking about preparing for sale. I watched home owners spend months filled with 16-hour days of hard labor, ripping out walls, installing cabinets and laying tile. Every decision -- from paint color to countertops to flooring -- was made with a buyer and an asking price in mind.

James Levine has relinquished the remaining performances of "Der Rosenkavalier" at the Metropolitan Opera. Mr. Levine, the Met's music director, canceled the first half of the run in October while recovering from back surgery. He is currently rehearsing "Tales of Hoffman," which opens on Dec. 3, but the Met said he did not have time to rehearse properly for "Der Rosenkavalier," which re-emerges Jan. 1, 6, 9 and 15. Edo de Waart, who took over for Mr. Levine in the October "Rosenkavaliers," will conduct those performances.

In the new winter issue of T: Travel, our sights are set on the beach. (It's winter, where else?) First we head to Tobago for a fashion cover shoot and a glimpse of the slow (and sustainable) life on one of the Caribbean's least known islands. Then we go to Miami for sand and surf with a heavy side of scene, before heading way south of the border for a look at the real Buenos Aires through its food. But don't think we've forgotten the season's cooler pleasures: we make a trip to the booming and beautiful ski town of Geilo, Norway, as well as to the tiny winter wonderland of Holland's Friesland, before we end up closer to home amid the lovable wackiness of Baltimore.

The latest phase of Reed Seifer's Project Optimism may not solve world hunger, or add much to the history of Conceptual Art. But it could brighten the mood of some New York City commuters - if they happen to look at the back of their MetroCards. This is a rarer occurrence than you might imagine, but give it a try. You may find the word "optimism" printed in sturdy black sans-serif lowercase letters, along with tinier blocks of type that say "Arts for Transit" and "Reed Seifer, Artist." The Metropolitan Transportation Authority has put seven million such cards in circulation since September, with another seven million to come.

The international style crowd recently descended upon Istanbul for a three-day fashion extravaganza. Powerhouse labels like Roberto Cavalli, Salavatore Ferragamo, Vivienne Westwood and Missoni staged shows with A-list models like Jessica Stam and Lily Donaldson, and there was even the requisite celebrity appearance - Bruce Willis at Missoni. Still, one of the highlights was a student show by young Turkish designers from the ISMEK and LaSalle fashion academies, including up-and-coming stars like like Sule Simsek Yalcin and Rabia Koyun.

The Virginia State Police said a tour bus belonging to Miley Cyrus overturned on Friday morning, killing one person, but that Ms. Cyrus had not been on board, The Associated Press reported. Sgt. Thomas Molnar told The A.P. that the bus overturned around 8:15 a.m. Friday on Interstate 85 about 40 miles south of Richmond. The police did not identify those aboard; one of the other nine passengers had minor injuries. Ms. Cyrus is scheduled to perform on Sunday in Greensboro, N.C.

Having friends over for dinner used to involve a minimal and fairly unremarkable to-do list: There were groceries to buy, along with flowers and a couple of bottles of semi-respectable wine. I would put out some guest towels and a collection of fancy soaps that were off limits to blood relatives, and then -- voilà! -- dinner was served. Preparing for a dinner party these days is far more complex, thanks to a vast and bewildering array of dietary needs that seem to have suddenly overtaken everyone I know.

Senator Harry Reid, the majority leader, having unveiled the Senate health care bill now needs 60 votes to stave off a Republican filibuster and begin formal floor debate. That means getting all 58 Senate Democrats and the two independents on board for a vote set for Saturday evening. But even among the Democrats, Senators Blanche Lincoln of Arkansas, Ben Nelson of Nebraska and Mary Landrieu of Louisiana have been cagey about whether they will support the bill.

The University of California system has long been one of the gems of American education -- a first-rate research university that was one of the most affordable in the country. But it's future is uncertain, my colleague Tamar Lewin reports.

If there is one thing that pop-culture aficionados have learned over the past year, it's that young women like stories about vampires. A lot. In that vein, the latest volume of "Vampire Knight," a series aimed at female readers, tops our manga list this week. Created by Matsuri Hino, Vampire Knight follows the goings-on at Cross Academy, a school where the day class is composed of humans, and the night class is -- yup -- vampires. The series has always enjoyed a certain popularity, but with the fervor for "Twilight" now rivaling Beatlemania, more and more readers are discovering Ms. Hino's take on undead teenage drama. (Speaking of which, how long will it be before there's a graphic-novel adaptation of "Twilight"? Oh, wait -- it's already been announced. Whew!)

Her legislation would repeal the program immediately, and return the unobligated balance of the original $255 million appropriation - as of Tuesday, $153 million, according to the Small Business Administration - back to the Treasury.

In this week's Automobiles section, Lindsay Brooke writes about his experience driving a prototype version of the Chevrolet Volt. The hybrid Volt, which General Motors plans to begin selling in 2010, has been the focus of a great deal of interest as G.M. shifts its strategy to vehicles that are not primarily powered by internal combustion engines. The Volt can run on electricity alone for about 40 miles, according to the company. After that, it relies upon a gasoline engine to run a generator that provides electrical power to the batteries.

Among the wonders of Mumbai are the dabbawallas, deliverymen who ferry home-cooked meals -- contained in multicompartment metal lunch boxes called tiffins -- from residences to offices (and back) every day. It used to be that the meals would originate only with a mother, a grandmother or, perhaps, a wife. But with the startup of a handful of businesses catering to the tiffin crowd, the options have expanded.

You can literally put your money where your mouth is with these enamel, silver and gold Seven Sins earrings by the Rome-based jeweler Delfina Delettrez, who must have accessories in her blood. (She's a fourth-generation Fendi.) Her work, with its gothic bent and unusual combinations of colors and materials, is often inspired by the human body, especially as it's depicted in paintings by Giorgio de Chirico and the work of Andreas van Vessel, the 16th-century anatomist. The earrings are about $1,600 at Opening Ceremony, 35 Howard Street, or go to openingceremony.us.

“Tim Burton’s career is the ultimate revenge of the art nerd,” Ken Johnson writes. The animator of Pee-Wee and Beetlejuice, Edward Scissorhands and Jack Skellington, is the subject of a major retrospective at MoMA, which showcases the art — including drawings, sculptures and photos — that he has been making throughout his career. Freaks, of course, are his main subject (keep your eye out for Stainboy, “a superhero whose only power is leaving stains”); the exhibit also includes screenings of his films, from “Batman” to early shorts like “Frankenweenie.”

“The Bad Lieutenant: Port of Call New Orleans,” Werner Herzog’s sorta remake of the 1992 Abel Ferrara film, “is a pulpy, glorious mess,” writes A.O. Scott. And he means it in a good way: “Its maniacal unpredictability is such a blast that it reminds you just how tidy and dull most crime thrillers are these days.” The star, Nicolas Cage, is at the height of ravaged oddball: “Sometimes his loose-limbed shuffle and sibilant drawl suggest Jimmy Stewart as a crackhead,” Scott writes. Other times, he just freestyle-raps (“to the break of dawn!”). “What may seem like random, dissociated bursts of energy are in fact the brilliant syncopations of a player with a sure, if unorthodox, sense of rhythm,” Scott writes. Ditto for the movie itself. “It has a warped sincerity, and an energy that keeps going and going. To the break of dawn!”

An article in some editions on Nov. 12 about the Sotheby’s auction of contemporary art in New York misstated Sotheby’s high estimate of sales before the auction. It was $97.7 million — not $67.9 million, which was the low estimate. (Actual sales totaled $134.4 million.).

An art review last Friday about “Victorious Ones: Jain Images of Perfection,” at the Rubin Museum of Art, and “Peaceful Conquerors: Jain Manuscript Painting,” at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, misspelled the Sanskrit term for the Jains’ commitment to nonviolence. It is ahimsa, not ahmisa.

A chart in some editions on Wednesday with an article about Kansas City Royals pitcher Zack Greinke’s winning the American League Cy Young Award misspelled the surname of the Detroit Tigers pitcher who had 31 victories in 1968, nearly twice as many as Greinke’s 16 in 2009. He is Denny McLain, not McClain.

An article on Tuesday about the upgrading of sports programs in the State University of New York system omitted two state university systems that did not have athletics programs in Division I of the National Collegiate Athletic Association in the 1980s. Besides Alaska and New York, North Dakota and South Dakota also did not have any state universities or colleges in Division I during that period. The article also misstated the title once held by the person who is investigating the Binghamton University sports program. Judith S. Kaye, who was not identified by name in the article, was New York State’s former chief judge; there is no “chief justice” in New York.

An article on the Square Feet pages on Wednesday about an initiative to offer mortgages to landlords who fix wasteful energy and water systems misstated the frequency of energy audits for older apartment buildings under proposed New York City regulations. The Patient Money column on Saturday, about ways to pay for alternative medical procedures and nutritional supplements, misquoted Dr. David Riley, a medical doctor who is editor of the journal Alternative Therapies in Health and Medicine. Dr. Riley said he was not aware of any mislabeling problems involving the nutritional supplement glucosamine. He did not say that a supplement promoted as supplying 100 percent of a daily dose of glucosamine might actually contain only a microscopic amount of the ingredient. The article also referred incorrectly to the Food and Drug Administration’s jurisdiction over nutritional supplements. The F.D.A. does in fact regulate nutritional supplements, although it does not oversee the supplements as extensively as it does prescription drugs.

FRANCIS--Charles G.,85, died peacefully at his home at The Osborn in Rye, NY on November 18, 2009. Born in Murdo, South Dakota, he had a wonderful boyhood that he cherished all his life. After serving in the Signal Corps of the U.S. Army from 1943-46, he attended U.C.L.A., where he was editor-in-chief of the Daily Bruin newspaper. It was there that he met his beloved wife Barbara, to whom he was happily married for 60 years. After working for a number of years in journalism, he joined IBM in 1957 in Los Angeles. In 1961, he moved to Chappaqua, NY where he lived happily until 2001. He had a distinguished career at IBM for 30 years working both in communications and advertising. Beginning in 1971 until his retirement in 1987, he was the worldwide Director of Advertising where he developed numerous memorable campaigns and oversaw the IBM sponsorship of over 40 television specials, many of which were seen around the world. After retiring from IBM, he spent 20 years as the creator and editor of IdeaBank, a subscription internet service whose collection of quotations, anecdotes and humor were used by subscribers in a multitude of professions from over 14 countries. Shortly before his death, he published a book, "Wisdom Well Said", that includes many of the anecdotes and stories from IdeaBank. He was the proud father of two children, Abby Francis Kohnstamm and Paul Francis, and the proud grandfather of Sarah and Paul Kohnstamm and Charles and Eleanor Francis. A memorial service in celebration of his life will be held at The Osborn in Rye, NY at 11am on December 5, 2009. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that donations be given to The Osborn Retirement Community, Rye, NY 10580 and Hospice of Westchester, 311 North Street, White Plains, NY 10605.

FRISA--Maria Suzanna, playwright, medical professional, good friend, died November 16, 2009 after a protracted illness. She will be deeply missed by many people.

DENAT DE GUILLEBON--Jeanne-Claude. Dear Christo, Jeanne-Claude was a force of nature. You two combined were the best duo that we've known as artists. We really loved Jeanne-Claude's generosity to our individual lives as well as to the rest of the world's. She was truly a dynamo. We always, always, always loved seeing her and being with her. We will miss Jeanne-Claude so much, it is hard to put into words. Our deepest sympathy to you, Cyril, and your extended family. Love, Aggie and Daniel

KIEV--Ari, 75, passed away on November 18th, 2009. Beloved husband to Phyllis, father to Jon (Karin) and Marshall (Johanna), and grandfather to Will, Drew, Eddie and Chloe, Ari enjoyed coaching, learning, teaching, tennis, travel, sailing and skiing. He grew up in Washington Heights; attended Stuyvesant High School; Harvard class of 1954; Cornell Medical School class of 1958, psychiatry residency at John Hopkins; specialty training at Maudsley Hospital in London; graduate of New York Law School; was in the process of getting his Executive Healthcare MBA at George Washington University. Ari played basketball at Harvard; was a Captain in the U.S. Air Force at Lackland Air Force base in San Antonio, TX; was an associate professor of psychiatry at Cornell Medical School; hosted WBCS TV popular Sunrise Semester; founded the Life Strategy Workshops in New York City; founded and directed the Suicide Prevention Clinic at New York Hospital/Cornell. He became the first psychiatrist to be appointed to the U.S. Olympic Sports Medicine Committee, and has worked with Olympic and professional athletes in peak performance coaching, including the U.S. bobsled team and the U.S. basketball team at the Pan Am Games in Puerto Rico. Founder of the Kiev Foundation, which donated over 15,000 rare books on Jewish theology to the George Washington University; Founder and President of the Social Psychiatry Research Institute, a leader in international clinical drug studies. Renowned and sought after lecturer; best-selling author of over 20 books, including A Strategy for Daily Living and Trading to Win: The Psychology of Mastering the Markets, which he wrote in collaboration with SAC Capital, where he acted as trading coach for 16 years. We will miss your strength, kindness and wisdom. Funeral will be private. Shiva at our home on Saturday 5:30-8, Sunday 2:30-6 and Monday 4:30-8. For details, email mkiev1@gmail.com. Memorial ceremony will follow in January. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Kiev Foundation at PO Box 381, Westport, CT 06881.

Among the National Book Awards winners named on Wednesday night whose names may elude you, one honoree you've almost certainly heard of is Flannery O'Connor. In an online vote conducted by the National Book Foundation, her collection ''The Complete Stories'' was named the best work to have won the National Book Award for fiction in the contest's 60-year history. The competition was steep: other finalists were ''The Stories of John Cheever,'' William Faulkner's ''Collected Stories,'' ''The Collected Stories of Eudora Welty,'' Ralph Ellison's ''Invisible Man'' and Thomas Pynchon's ''Gravity's Rainbow.'' (Then again, the O'Connor book bested some formidable contenders when it won the fiction prize in 1972, including John Updike's ''Rabbit Redux,'' Walker Percy's ''Love in the Ruins'' and E. L. Doctorow's ''Book of Daniel.'') This year's National Book Award for fiction was won by Colum McCann's ''Let the Great World Spin.''

Even as it faces a $4.1 billion budget deficit, service cuts and possible layoffs, the Bloomberg administration is preparing to spend several million dollars to hire a private testing firm to give construction industry licensing exams that are currently overseen by city employees. The city has long administered most of the tests in-house, but recently sought proposals from outside firms to give the written and practical examinations for 16 construction and building maintenance trade licenses, from crane operator and master electrician to welder and elevator inspector.

Flights over much of the eastern United States were delayed Thursday by a predawn failure in a fairly new communications system, which led to the shutdown of a computer that accepts flight plans from the airlines and feeds them to air traffic controllers. It was the fourth major disruption attributed to the communications system, which the Federal Aviation Administration began putting into service earlier in this decade as a way to cut costs and assure reliability. But the F.A.A. said late Thursday that it had not yet determined the cause of the failure, that the failure might not be related to the relative newness of the system, and that it did not see a pattern.

Seeking justice and a spot in the World Cup for its national team, the Football Association of Ireland has demanded a replay of the playoff game that ended in France's favor after Thierry Henry handled the ball before passing to William Gallas for a score. The teams played to a 1-1 draw Wednesday, but France advanced to next year's World Cup in South Africa, 2-1, on total goals in the two-game playoff. ''The blatantly incorrect decision by the referee to award the goal has damaged the integrity of the sport,'' the association said in a statement. ''We now call on FIFA, as the world governing body for our sport, to organize for this match to be replayed.''

The National Football League Players Association is calling for the removal of Dr. Ira Casson as co-chairman of the league's committee on concussions, saying that he is too biased to lead the research and policy group. When Stuart Kipnis, a 45-year-old Lincoln Square father, decided to become the primary caregiver for his infant son, Liam, both above, he expected to face the usual parenting challenges, like Muppet overload and a marked lack of intelligible conversation. But Mr. Kipnis never dreamed he would be rejected by a play group because he was a father. It all started when Mr. Kipnis, a genial personal trainer, spotted a flier for Little Lincoln Logs, a local play group intended for parents with children from newborns to age 5. He sent an e-mail message, figuring he fit both criteria. The response: Not so fast. Apparently in this case ''parents'' meant ''mothers'' -- several of whom were not thrilled by the idea of a strange man coming to their homes for group-sponsored play dates.

LOOMIS--Frank, 67. Hill, Betts & Nash LLP notes with sorrow the passing of our retired partner, who resided in Tampa, Florida. He was a graduate of the University of Florida and Emory Law School and received a Masters degree in Taxation from NYU Law School. Born of a distinguished family and sparked by an early and successful career as an Aviation and Insurance Defense lawyer, he led a remarkable and interesting life. He traveled the world and was able to realize his dream of spending retirement years in the Florida Keys. He was a loving and generous son, father, brother and friend. We express our condolences to his extensive family and friends.

RAGSDALE--Duane William, who was Vice Chairman of Ted Bates Worldwide, Inc. when it was the second largest advertising agency in the world, died of Alzheimer's Disease November 17th. He was 85 years of age. Mr. Ragsdale was a resident of New York City for 58 years and spent summers in Mattapoisett, MA for 47 years. Known as Rags, he was born in Baker City, Oregon and attended schools there. During World War II, he attended the University of Colorado in the Naval V12 program and upon graduation he served on the William B. Langfitt troop transport in the Pacific. After the service he attended the Harvard Business School on an academic scholarship and graduated in 1951. Rags' first venture into advertising was in the advertising department of Paramount Pictures in 1951 researching the impact - if any - that the newly developed television might have upon the movie industry. He went on to Compton Advertising, now Satchi & Satchi, where he helped to launch Gleem Toothpaste "for people who can't brush after every meal". His next position was at William Esty. Once at Ted Bates Worldwide, Rags was instrumental in bringing William Esty into the Ted Bates Worldwide Organization. He is a past member of the new York Athletic Club, The Harvard Club of New York, and the American Advertising Federation. He was appreciated for giving full credit to those who worked with him for their contributions to advertising campaigns. He was also known for a wonderful sense of humor. His coworkers refer to the period of time that they worked with him as their "Camelot". He is survived by Mimi his loving wife for 57 years and dear daughter Martha, his niece Dana and nephews Richard and Norman. He was preceded in death by his brothers Lee, Norman and Orville. Rags will be deeply missed by all who knew him. A memorial service will be held at a later date. Please make remembrances to your favorite charity.

'THE ART OF ARCHIE COMICS' This is proving to be a banner year for Archie Andrews, the redhead from Riverdale. In May it was announced he would marry longtime love interest Veronica Lodge. That was followed in October with the twist that he would marry the girl next door, Betty Cooper. (Don't worry. He's not a bigamist. It was all part of a possible alternative-futures story line concocted to commemorate the August publication of Archie No. 600.) Now Archie, who first appeared in December 1941, is being honored in an exhibition of artwork, vintage house ads, toys and more at the Museum of Comic and Cartoon Art. Included is ''Smack!'' (right), by Harry Lucey, from the late 1950s.

SAFER--David. With profound sorrow we mourn the passing of our mentor and leader, the one person who set the standards of excellence that have guided us for over half a century. David Safer taught us to practice with fairness and decency, and always with our clients' best interests at heart. He earned, and richly deserved, the respect, even love, of all who knew him. David kept us all on an even keel, never permitting us to overly exult when things went well, nor letting us despair when they went otherwise. Though retired for over two years, his presence is still felt, and we still address problems with one simple question, "what would Dave do?" Our thoughts are with his beloved children, Laura and Ron, whose remarkable achievements in Law made him so very proud, and with their wonderful families. We will miss him more than we can ever express. The Partners and Staff of Joel E. Sammet and Company LLP

Tim Burton's career is the ultimate revenge of the art nerd. Mr. Burton, the self-professed alienated child of a dysfunctional family in Burbank, Calif., who funneled his loneliness, pain and grief into drawing cartoons, has found fame, fortune and a beautiful companion (Helena Bonham Carter) by telling cinematic tales of sensitive misfits triumphing over, or succumbing to, a world of repressive mediocrity. His recurring theme has near-universal resonance. Who has not dreamed of proving that he or she was underestimated by the forces of ignorance and venality? But it is Mr. Burton's extraordinarily inventive and adventurous way with the languages of popular film that accounts mainly for his success. Without the confectionery beauty and technical ingenuity of his movies -- and performances by charismatic actors like Paul Reubens, Michael Keaton and Johnny Depp in films as diverse as ''Pee-wee's Big Adventure,'' ''Beetlejuice'' and ''Sweeney Todd'' -- his Oedipal pathos would not be enough.

8 P.M. (The Documentary Channel) DAMNED TO HEAVEN On May 2006 Warren S. Jeffs -- the leader of the Fundamentalist Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints, which believes that plural marriage is a requirement for entering heaven -- was put on the F.B.I.'s most-wanted list. His crime: acting as an accomplice to rape for his role in the ceremonial marriage of a teenage girl to an older cousin. In September of the following year, having already renounced his role as prophet, Mr. Jeffs, above, was convicted and is serving a prison term of 10 years to life. This documentary from Thomas Elliott and Pawel Gula explores the emotional and physical effects of polygamy on women and girls. In ''Banished: The Lost Boys of Polygamy,'' at 9:45, Stacey Butler examines the lives of boys 13 to 21 who have been pressured to leave the fundamentalist Mormon sect to reduce competition for wives. 8 P.M. (CBS) GHOST WHISPERER Melinda (Jennifer Love Hewitt) worries about the safety of her son, Aiden (Connor Gibbs), when the ghost of a girl who died from leukemia (Madison Leisle) befriends him -- and warns Melinda to stay out of her way.

The Tanglewood Music Festival in Lenox, Mass., has announced that it will celebrate its 70th anniversary next summer by featuring performances or works by more than a dozen alumni who have made their mark at the musical redoubt in the Berkshires. The names include the soprano Dawn Upshaw; the mezzo-soprano Stephanie Blythe; the composers Michael Gandolfi, John Harbison and Osvaldo Golijov; and the conductors Charles Dutoit, Christoph von Dohnanyi and Seiji Ozawa, above. The festival also said that James Levine would conduct the Boston Symphony Orchestra in Mahler's Symphony No. 2 (''Resurrection'') and lead a concert version of Mozart's opera ''The Abduction From the Seraglio.'' Susanna Malkki, a young Finnish conductor, will make her Tanglewood debut conducting the Boston Symphony in a program that includes the violinist Joshua Bell and the pianist Jeremy Denk as soloists. The Mark Morris Dance Group also returns. The season runs from July 9 to Aug. 29.

Re "The Archbishop's Blog" (Nov. 8):The explanation for The Times's refusal to publish Archbishop Timothy Dolan's letter is lame and defensive, as is the rest of your column. Your argument seems to be that because The Times gave the archbishop a lot of coverage and said some nice things about him when he first came to New York that it can with impunity publish imbalanced and biased articles about the Catholic Church.Likewise, you seem to argue that because some of the religion writers for The Times sometimes write articles that are not considered offensive, this makes the offensive ones O.K. With respect to Maureen Dowd, it's difficult to see how The Times sponsors her vitriolic diatribes in general. Her work is short on reason and logic but long on venom and distortion, hardly a contribution to serious public discussion. It's no secret that The Times is steadily losing readership. Remaining in denial about its skewed coverage of the Catholic Church is just the latest example of how badly out of touch with reality the editors and writers for The Times continue to be. I suspect many will find your attempt to defend The Times's record on this matter to be thoroughly unpersuasive.MSGR. MICHAEL FITZGERALDPhiladelphia, Nov. 8, 2009 ●I write as a Catholic nun who is a daily reader of The Times, and I agree with your conclusion that The Times does not have a pattern of anti-Catholicism. Maureen Dowd's column on nuns and the Vatican was compatible with my "anger and anguish about the moral crisis" in the church. If any group in the U.S. Catholic Church should be investigated, it is the bishops who presided over the pattern of moving "troubled" priests from parish to parish without disclosure - to parishioners or legal authorities - of actions that potentially constituted sexual abuse and required investigation. In January 2006, The Times wrote an editorial praising a Detroit auxiliary bishop, Thomas Gumbleton, for his advocacy of improved public policies to deal with sexual abuse by priests and others. Subsequent to the publication of this editorial, local church leaders remarked that the supportive editorial was proof that The Times had an anti-Catholic bias. This reactionary critique causes me to infer that the accusation of anti-Catholic bias on the part of The Times is an example of the Catholic Church's being defensive and protective of itself, not an objective assessment of the attitude of the newspaper. SISTER SUE SATTLER, I.H.M.Detroit, Nov. 8, 2009 ●The New York Times has no sympathy toward the Roman Catholic Church and, in fact, is institutionally predisposed to find fault with the church wherever and whenever it may be found.The Times does not value churchgoing Roman Catholics as part of its constituency; as a result, we are fair game. The core audience of The Times -- secularists, atheists, members of certain politically left-leaning Christian and non-Christian denominations, all enjoy it immensely when The Times uses its pages to kick the church. Archbishop Dolan is correct -- other faiths (and, I might add, certain other favored segments of society) -- get a "bye" from the writers and editors of The Times. Who knows? Maybe the Times and its Catholic-baiting political and cultural allies will eventually hound us into shutting down our charities, closing our hospitals, ending our school system and walking away from our colleges. But life in New York and this nation would be much poorer for it.THOMAS J. RICE Manhattan, Nov. 10, 2009 ● I see nothing in Archbishop Dolan's screed that claims the facts of the reporting were wrong. He's just upset that the wrongs were reported. It is asked: "What is fair to report and criticize about the leadership of a religion?" Everything is fair to be reported - the good, the bad, and the ugly, as long as the reporting is accurate. Dolan says that Dowd dug "deep into the nativist handbook to use every anti-Catholic caricature possible." Virtually every Catholic in the country opposed the nativist anti-Catholic assault of the 19th century, but today's Catholics, on the other hand, support and praise the secular press coverage of the crimes and cover-up of the crimes of Catholic clergy - coverage that is almost totally absent in the Catholic press. Nothing is being reported today that the clergy has not brought on itself. For centuries the Catholic clergy has impressed on the laity the image of a clergy so superior that there slowly emerged the perception of a real ontological difference between the two. Accurate reporting in the secular press about sexual abuse, larcenous pastors stealing millions from their parishes, and now a Vatican investigation of our nuns is rightly tearing down this myth. B.M. BYRNEVienna, Va., Nov. 9, 2009 ● It is not surprising to me that the Catholic archbishop would see anti-Catholicism in the article by Maureen Dowd, coverage of the pedophilia scandal and other stories that didn't reflect well on Catholics or the Catholic Church. The church is and always has been an authoritarian hierarchy. As such, it is able to prohibit dissent or criticism from members of its hierarchy and, to a great degree, members of its congregations. It is reasonable for an archbishop to conclude that if he can't criticize, no one else should be allowed to either.In a secular, liberal democratic state, the cherished right of freedom of speech includes the right to criticize anybody and everybody. I hope these values persist for a long time to come. I have little hope that religions that depend on blind obedience will embrace them anytime soon.STEPHEN JONESVenice, Fla., Nov. 10, 2009 ● I'm an 84-year-old Catholic who has been reading The Times since I was 17. I cannot agree with Archbishop Dolan's outrage over Maureen Dowd's column on the attitude of the church toward nuns. Women are just as intelligent and responsible as men. Many of them occupy the top positions in American business and serve in growing numbers in both houses of Congress as well as presidential cabinets. Indeed, one female recently almost achieved the office of president. What's next - ordained female priests?TERRY ROEWarminster, Pa., Nov. 9, 2009 ● ● Re "Recession, Revolution and a Leaner Times" (Nov. 1):Doubtless the decision about charging online readers is an important one, but seldom are important business decisions arrived at by following a clear consensus. More often, when one finds a clear business consensus, it is often proved wrong and/or late, like American auto companies' decision to play down smaller, fuel-efficient cars. No, this is a tough decision that will accurately be made by leadership choosing a path or paths that may appear questionable at the outset, but may be recognized as visionary later.GARY SWAYZEManchester, Mass., Nov. 1, 2009 ●Come on, throw us a bone here - give those of us who care about The New York Times an opportunity to support it. How about a "We Love the NYT" coffee mug, an "All the News That's Fit to Print" umbrella, an "Honorary Times Cub Reporter" T-shirt, a "Members Only" spot on the Web site - you name it, we'll probably donate to get it.Like many Times supporters, my home page is The New York Times, and I read it (for free) every day. I send articles (for free) to friends and family by e-mail probably once a week. I get the Sunday Times delivered to my Toronto home but I can't justify getting the paper (or any newspaper) every day. But I rely on the kind of reporting that no one but The New York Times is doing, and I'd be willing, even thrilled, to support it in the same way I support Minnesota Public Radio, which I listen to (for free) online. Just give me a premium or two and a convenient way to send a hundred bucks or so to keep this kind of journalism alive while it finds a new economic basis for survival.GERSHON SILINSToronto, Nov. 2, 2009 ● I am among those who hate seeing new organizations die by a thousand self-imposed cuts. At 39, I am on the younger end of the cohort that can't live without newspapers. But my wife and I have already dropped our subscription to The Atlanta Journal-Constitution, our local daily, because it has so deconstructed itself that there's no point in paying for it.After the last price increase by The Times, I reluctantly gave up the print edition for Times Reader. It was a difficult decision and a hard adjustment; I'd still prefer to handle an actual newspaper, but it made no sense to pay over $800 per year when I can pay $15 per month for the same content. It seems to me that there ought to be something in between. I'd obviously be willing to pay far more than $15 per month.I continue to believe that in the long run, the best model for a news organization will be that of a nonprofit, public-service organization. There will always be a readership, an increasingly small and specialized niche for newspapers, but the old business model will not last. In my opinion, The Times should essentially junk its junky free site and develop more along the polished, clean subscription service represented by Times Reader.DAVID TALLMANAtlanta, Nov. 2, 2009 ●Like other dedicated readers, I am worried. There is so much talk of newsroom cuts and elimination of bureaus and newspaper sections, I open the Sunday Times fearful that some section will be missing, or there will be some subtle change in the quality of the articles. Yesterday I was reminded that change and technological innovation will not necessarily lead to the demise of newspapers. I read The Times using the Times Reader for the first time and I was impressed by how easily I could work my way through in an efficient yet leisurely way - as a Sunday read ought to be. While nytimes.com is useful and a site I'll continue to use, it's very different from the experience of actually reading the (print-version) paper. I tend to jump about, depending on what grabs my attention, and I rarely get through the day's news. And I find pop-up ads irritating. But why is there no advertising in the Times Reader version of the paper? Wouldn't this be a perfect vehicle for print-style ads (NOT pop-ups!!)? The beauty of in-paper advertising is that it is seen, but if it is of no interest the reader can skip over and ignore it. It does not detract from the pleasure of reading the paper. Old-fashioned, perhaps, but effective. Surely there remain some advertisers out there who would see value in placing their messages here.CHERISSE BANDY Foster, R.I., Nov. 2, 2009 ●This morning, like every Sunday morning, I went out to the little coffee shop that charges $1 per cup for any size coffee, and picked up my New York Times. Five dollars for the paper is a lot of money for me at the moment - I am 69 years old, have been unemployed for almost a year, and things are very tight. However, not having the Sunday Times is like giving up a part of my history (I grew up in New York, and along with bagels and lox, The Times is Sunday morning), and giving up on the great tradition of print news. So, I pay my $5, buy cheaper food for the cat (just kidding) and enjoy the luxury of Sunday with the Times.Weekdays I mostly catch you online - and for the past few months I have been wondering why you do not charge at least a nominal fee for this service. I would be happy to pay it (I'll tell the cat to eat cake) if that fee would guarantee that the print version of The Times would stay with us. Our country needs real journalists - those guys that hold the governments feet to the fire and protect our interests. I hope you do go ahead with charging for online service, and I hope again to see reporters playing bridge and working crossword puzzles.SHARON RESNICKPrinceton, N.J., Nov. 1, 2009 ●Why don't you ask for voluntary contributions from online readers? I would be very glad to pay $300 per year. It is wonderful to read the paper here in Edmonton at the same time that someone in New York can. And many of your readers understand well how important investigative journalism is in keeping governments honest.BILL KELLY Edmonton, Alberta, Nov. 1, 2009 ●I am a faithful reader of The New York Times online, but if it were not free, I would not have become so faithful. I used to go to many different sites to get all the news. Now I start at your site and believe it is by far the best in the United States. My recommendation is to allow a one-year free subscription to new users. Then try to keep the yearly charge as low as possible to encourage the widest readership. Like the woman in your column, I have my credit card ready. STEVE MARTIN Seattle, Nov. 1, 2009 ●I encourage the debate on charging for The Times online, which The Wall Street Journal and The Economist are doing. But I have a problem if a subscription Web presence will still involve cookies and the related spying on my Web activity. I have debated this with people at The Times and The Economist.The Times suggests that the cookies make the Web "easier to use." But there is nothing in the cookies I found that improves my Web experience; many of them are tracking cookies that allow someone to build a marketable profile of me.The argument in your column is that millions of online advertising dollars are at stake if charging for access reduces the number of viewers. That may be, but the advertisers should be aware that many Web users, like myself, do not allow cookies and work diligently to avoid any tracking. And a growing number of Web users are learning about tracking and how to block the intrusion into personal privacy.The decision to charge or not is, in my view, a decision on the long-term survival of The Times. I am concerned that in time the loss of print revenue will force the online version to support more and more of the paper's operations. My larger concern is that the work of powerful newspapers - in keeping our governments and corporations in line with investigative reporting - will disappear without a decent revenue stream to pay the costs of such reporting. So I am willing to pay for access to a robust online New York Times, but I am not willing to surrender my privacy to get it.RAYMOND C. GRAYEaston, Pa., Nov. 1, 2009 ● ●Re "About That Bloomberg Runaway" (Nov. 15): Your column suggests the correct and inescapable point that polls can serve as self-fulfilling prophecies, discouraging those who would otherwise vote if the polls were more promising for their candidates. The important point left out, however, is that pollsters should ask directly regarding the intensity of support for candidates, rather than relying on whether respondents may "change their minds." That is a good question, but it is no substitute for also inquiring about how strongly poll respondents support specific candidates. If all polls asked about both the strength of support and the likelihood of voters' changing their minds, fewer large disparities between poll support and election support would occur.RICHARD E. VATZTowson, Md., Nov. 15, 2009 The writer is a professor of political rhetoric at Towson University.

Frankly, I'm not sure I'd like it too much there, but here, I find it to be a bit of intellectual icing on the cake.

Monologue | Aired Friday night on CBS: On Friday, President Obama pardons the White House turkey. Dick Cheney didn't miss an opportunity. This proves that Obama is soft on poultry.

I have an essay in the NY Times Sunday Book Review about fighting poverty and some of the literature that has arisen. Nobody fights like humanitarians, so there have been battles among the Jeff Sachs camp on the one hand and the Bill Easterly/Dambisa Moyo camp on the other. My take is that the critics have some valid points -- money often is wasted, projects fail, and helping people is far harder than it looks -- but that we're also getting better at figuring out what interventions work, and more money definitely is useful for those. I love the work of the Poverty Action Lab at MIT in bringing rigorous evaluation to development, and I think that also helps in figuring out how to get the most bang for the buck. In any case, read the essay and post any comments here.

I recently lost a longtime client, who was also a dear friend and valuable mentor, to prostate cancer. He was 52 years old and left behind his wife and two children. The other day I learned that another good friend was found to have skin cancer that had progressed to the point where he had to have glands removed. He was so busy running his company, he didn't notice the moles that had started to look different. My friend is only 38 years old.
