A television review on Nov. 13 about a new version of “The Prisoner,” on AMC, misspelled a star’s surname at one point. As the review noted elsewhere, the actor who plays Six is Jim Caviezel, not Cazievel.
Mike Cammalleri’s goal in the third period Friday night turned out to be the winner for the visiting Canadiens, who withstood a furious comeback to beat the Washington Capitals, 3-2.

A classical music entry in the Listings pages on Friday about a recital by the pianist Nareh Arghamanyan scheduled for Sunday at the Frick Collection misstated the time. It will be at 5 p.m., not 6:45.

A Spare Times for Children entry on Friday about a performance by Mama Doni & the Mama Doni Band scheduled for Sunday at the Museum of Jewish Heritage — a Living Memorial to the Holocaust, in Lower Manhattan, misstated the ticket prices. They are $15 for adults and $7 for children 12 and younger; for members of the museum or the Jewish Community Project they are $12 for adults and $5 for children 12 and younger.
The junior transfer Wes Johnson and the freshman Brandon Triche helped lead the unranked Orange to an 87-71 victory over No. 6 North Carolina in Madsion Square Garden.

A music review on Wednesday about a production of “Peter and the Wolf,” at the New Victory Theater, misidentified the conductor. The conductor is Craig Barna — not Keith Levenson, who is the music supervisor. (His surname was also misspelled as Levinson.).

An article on Nov. 11 about recordings from the Newport Jazz Festival and Newport Folk Festival being made available at wolfgangsvault.com referred incompletely to the founding of the jazz festival. George Wein was a founder, along with Elaine and Louis Lorillard. Mr. Wein was not the sole founder.
LeBron James scored a season-high 40 points as the Cleveland Cavaliers rallied on the road to beat the Indiana Pacers, 105-95, on Friday night.

An article last Saturday about President Obama’s visit to Japan, where he announced creation of a group to study the contentious issue of the Marine base on Okinawa, misstated, in some editions, the year in which a Japanese 12-year-old was raped on Okinawa by three American servicemen. It was 1995, not 1996.

An article on Friday about Oprah Winfrey’s decision to end her daily talk show in 2011 to concentrate on her own cable channel misstated, in some editions, part of the name of the firm of Larry Gerbrandt, an analyst who commented on the potential effect of the move on broadcast networks. It is Media Valuation Partners, not Media Evaluation Partners.

An article last Saturday about the increased use of vulgar language on prime-time broadcast television misidentified the court that struck down in 1976 the imposition of a “family hour” policy by the Federal Communications Commission. It was a United States District Court in California, not the United States Supreme Court.

A news analysis article on Friday about recommendations that women should delay screenings for breast and cervical cancer misstated a statistic from the United States Preventive Services Task Force, which released the breast cancer recommendations. The task force concluded that one cancer death was prevented for every 1,339 women aged 50 to 59 who were screened for 10 years — not 50 to 74.

As Broadway waits to see if a new play about Vince Lombardi takes flight next season, the McCarter Theater Center is announcing a world premiere production of a play about another sports legend, Muhammad Ali, starring Ben Vereen, below, and Evan Parke. Set in the mid-1960s as Mr. Ali, formerly Cassius Clay, began cementing his heavyweight champion status, “Fetch Clay, Make Man,” by Will Power, centers on the young boxer’s friendship with Stepin Fetchit, the stage name of the actor Lincoln Perry. The play deals with creating personas, a point of controversy for Mr. Perry, who, as Fetchit, came across as a lazy and foolish black man — an image that proved lucrative for him. Mr. Parke has been cast as Mr. Ali and Mr. Vereen as Fetchit in the production, which is scheduled to begin performances on Jan. 8, and to open on Jan. 15 and run through Feb. 14. The Tony Award-winning director Des McAnuff (“Jersey Boys,” “700 Sundays”) is to direct. The cast also includes Richard Masur (“Democracy,” “The Burning Bed”), John Earl Jelks (“Radio Golf”), and Sonequa Martin (“Loss of Shadows”).
Summit Entertainment said its supernatural heartthrob thriller “The Twilight Saga: New Moon” took in an estimated $26.3 million at midnight shows on Thursday night.

“Enter Laughing,” the semiautobiographical novel by Carl Reiner about a funny young actor juggling his girlfriends, career dreams and difficult parents, was turned into a play that was a hit on Broadway in the mid-1960s, and then a musical that flopped in 1976 with the title, “So Long, 174th Street.” That musical was renamed with the original Reiner title and revived Off Broadway by the York Theater Company last season, earning strong reviews and warm endorsements from the likes of Jerry Seinfeld. Now the producer Dan Whitten plans to transfer the York show to Broadway during the 2010-11 season, according to an e-mail message he recently sent to investors. A spokesman for Mr. Whitten said that the transfer was about a year off and that no Broadway house had been lined up. The York production was directed by Stuart Ross (“Forever Plaid”) and starred Josh Grisetti, above, who had been on deck to star as Eugene Jerome in a revival of Neil Simon’s “Broadway Bound.” That show was canceled last month because of a weak advance and poor ticket sales for its companion production, “Brighton Beach Memoirs.”.

PARONETTO--Fiorenzo. The Department of Pathology of the Mount Sinai School of Medicine mourns the loss of Fiorenzo Paronetto, M.D., Professor of Pathology at The Mount Sinai School of Medicine, New York, NY, Chief of Pathology and Laboratory Medicine at the Bronx Veterans Affairs Medical Center and Distinguished Liver Pathologist. Dr. Paronetto expired on November 19th in his Rockland home. The author and coauthor of over 190 scientific publications, Dr. Paronetto's contribution to the study of liver disease has been immense. After obtaining his Medical Degree from the University of Padua, Italy, Dr. Paronetto began his lifetime affiliation with the Mount Sinai School of Medicine in 1957 as a Resident in Pathology under the guidance of Dr. Hans Popper. He will be greatly missed by his co-workers, scholars and trainees. Alan Schiller, M.D., Chairman

Soccer's governing body, FIFA, on Friday denied Ireland's request for a replay of its World Cup qualifying match against France, in which Thierry Henry handled the ball seconds before William Gallas scored the winning goal. The play sparked an outcry across the world but failed to move FIFA. In a statement, FIFA said, ''the result of the match cannot be changed and the match cannot be replayed. As is clearly mentioned in the Laws of the Game, during matches, decisions are taken by the referee and these decisions are final.''

SAFER--David. With profound sorrow we mourn the passing of our mentor and leader, the one person who set the standards of excellence that have guided us for over half a century. David Safer taught us to practice with fairness and decency, and always with our clients' best interests at heart. He earned, and richly deserved, the respect, even love, of all who knew him. David kept us all on an even keel, never permitting us to overly exult when things went well, nor letting us despair when they went otherwise. Though retired for over two years, his presence is still felt, and we still address problems with one simple question, "what would Dave do?" Our thoughts are with his beloved children, Laura and Ron, whose remarkable achievements in Law made him so very proud, and with their wonderful families. We will miss him more than we can ever express. The Partners and Staff of Joel E. Sammet and Company LLP

Omar Vizquel and Ozzie Guillen each wear No. 13 as a tribute to another slick-fielding shortstop from Venezuela, Dave Concepcion. One of them will have to change his number next season if the Chicago White Sox follow through on their plans to sign Vizquel as a reserve infielder and unite him with Guillen, their tempestuous manager, to form one of the more intriguing pairings in baseball. Guillen and Vizquel, born three years apart, are longtime friends and grew up not far from each other near Caracas. As contemporaries, they played against each other in the American League for more than a decade. Guillen, now 45, came first, winning the Rookie of the Year award with Chicago in 1985 and compiling a solid 16-year career highlighted by a .264 average, a Gold Glove award and three All-Star appearances.

SANDHU--Robert (Bobby). Born in Glen Ridge, NJ on November 21, 1968 he was the beloved son of Randhir S. and Kuldip K. Sandhu and loving brother of Sandy Sandhu and Teena Sandhu Pollock. During his high school years he met Sherwin Pollock, who became one of his closest friends and who later joined the Sandhu family when he married Teena. A lover of books and knowledge, he did his undergraduate work at Rutgers University and went on to law school at St. John's University. After obtaining his law degree he was fortunate to join the firm of MacKenzie Partners in Manhattan as a proxy solicitor, becoming a senior vice president in the firm-a job he loved and a position he retained throughout his life. He relished living in NYC-connecting with its history and people. Along with his passion for reading, playing with his three nieces (Kyrin, Maya, and Tara), good food, fine beer, he loved being with his friends of whom he was fortunate to have many. He was a very strong believer in giving back to the community and to those who supported him-generous in giving of his time and money. In 2006 he was diagnosed with an aggressive form of Hodgkins lymphoma. Despite his courage, the rallying of family and friends to his side and the limitless love and support of his colleagues at MacKenzie Partners-his second family, he passed away in his sleep on November 18th, 2009, 3 days shy of his 41st birthday at his home in Manhattan. He will be deeply missed and always remembered.

Manny Pacquiao's 12th-round technical knockout of Miguel Cotto in their welterweight title fight last Saturday night generated 1.25 million pay-per-view buys, with gross revenue of $70 million, HBO said Friday. Of the total, 650,000 came from cable subscribers and 600,000 from satellite homes. An estimated 110,000 purchases came from Puerto Rico, Cotto's homeland.

Why are health insurance premiums increasing so fast for so many small employers? Some Democratic members of Congress want to know. In a strongly worded letter to the trade association representing the nation's health insurers, 31 senators and 88 representatives wrote, ''Small businesses and hard-working Americans deserve to know why they will be subjected to such unusual and significant increases in health premiums, and we ask you to submit to Congress a detailed explanation of the planned rate hikes.''

Even before the recession, more than one in five Americans could not pay for basic needs without help from family, friends or outsiders, according to a survey by the Census Bureau. Fourteen percent of all Americans and 26 percent of blacks who responded to the 2005 survey reported that at sometime in the preceding year they were not able to meet essential expenses on their own, like paying bills for basic needs, avoiding foreclosure and buying sufficient food.

PARONETTO--Dr. Fiorenzo, passed away in his home in Sparkill, NY on November 19, 2009. He was 80 years old. The cause was cancer. He received his medical degree from the University of Padua, Italy in 1952. In 1954, he won a NATO fellowship to study immunology and liver disease at the University of Utah in Salt Lake City and at The Mount Sinai Hospital in New York where he where he completed an internship, residency and research fellowship in Pathology, under the direction of Dr. Hans Popper. In 1971 he became full Professor of Pathology at Mount Sinai where he has been teaching for more than 50 years. In 1973 he became Chief of the Department of Pathology and Laboratory Medicine at the Veterans Affairs Medical Center, Bronx, New York. He spent the last 36 years directing the Department of Pathology and has been involved in research investigations in immunopathology. His survivors include his wife, Dr. Nijole Brazenas, two daughters, Dr. Lucia Caruana and Dr. Laura Murphy, sons-in-law Dr. Salvatore Caruana and Brian Murphy and five grandchildren, Francesco and Charles Caruana, Kimberly, Emily and Daniel Murphy. He also leaves behind a sister, Bianca Paronetto of Treviso, Italy and many nieces and nephews. The Family will receive visitors at Hanneman Funeral Home, 88 S. Broadway, Nyack, New York, on Sun., November 22 from 2:00pm to 4:00pm and from 7:00pm to 9:00pm. A Mass of Christian Burial will be celebrated on Monday, November 30 at 10:00am, St. John's Church, 895 Piermont Avenue, Piermont, NY. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to Maryknoll, P.O. Box 345, Maryknoll, NY 10545, www.maryknollsociety.org.

Just when it seemed as if the Giants would field a healthy team on Sunday, they announced that middle linebacker Antonio Pierce would be out indefinitely with a bulging disk in his neck. Pierce learned of the injury after a magnetic resonance imaging exam after practice on Friday.

Britain may finally be emerging from recession, but many analysts warn that it is a false dawn. In fact, they argue, the economy here is so ravaged by growing debts and ruined banks that it could well be following in the steps of Japan's lost decade of the 1990s. The parallels are eerie: Like Japan, Britain enjoyed more than a decade of booming growth, fed by aggressive bank lending and real estate investments. Haunted by the comparison, policy makers have been extra aggressive in using fiscal and monetary levers in hope of preventing the stagnation and banking stasis that plagued Japan for so many years.

9 P.M. (Starz) DOUBT (2008) Meryl Streep, above, plays Sister Aloysius, the principal of a Roman Catholic school in the Bronx who comes to believe that her supervisor, Father Flynn (Philip Seymour Hoffman), has developed an erotic interest in one of their charges -- and may have acted on it -- in John Patrick Shanley's adaptation of his stage play. Amy Adams is the younger nun who fuels her suspicions. Writing in The New York Times, Manohla Dargis said, ''Despite its theological asides and weighty moral stakes, 'Doubt' essentially boils down to a shell game: you think you see the pea under this or that shell, but the prize (answer) remains tauntingly out of reach.'' She added that Mr. Shanley's ''words are good, solid, at times touching'' but ''it's a mystery what he thought Ms. Streep, with her wild eyes and an accent as wide as the Grand Concourse, was doing.'' Still, of the role that earned Ms. Streep yet another Oscar nomination, Ms. Dargis wrote, ''She's a hoot, but she's also a relief, because, for some of us, worshiping Our Lady of Accents is easier on the soul than doing time in church.'' 10:30 A.M. (13) RELIGION & ETHICS NEWSWEEKLY Kim Lawton looks at Eid al-Adha, the three-day Muslim festival of prayer and feasts that commemorates the prophet Abraham's willingness to sacrifice his son in obedience to God. Also, a profile of Flannery O'Connor and an investigation into how religious leaders in Washington's black churches are helping to combat AIDS.

Hundreds of private e-mail messages and documents hacked from a computer server at a British university are causing a stir among global warming skeptics, who say they show that climate scientists conspired to overstate the case for a human influence on climate change. The e-mail messages, attributed to prominent American and British climate researchers, include discussions of scientific data and whether it should be released, exchanges about how best to combat the arguments of skeptics, and casual comments -- in some cases derisive -- about specific people known for their skeptical views. Drafts of scientific papers and a photo collage that portrays climate skeptics on an ice floe were also among the hacked data, some of which dates back 13 years.

The guy she’s with laughs and says, “Don’t mess up his face!” before snapping a picture. I’m at the National Great Blacks in Wax Museum in Baltimore, where Obama recently joined figures like Colin Powell, Zora Neale Hurston and Malcolm X, amid three floors of displays.

Value/ (val´ y) /n. / A principle or quality that someone holds dear. In the world of travel, “value” is often used in its monetary sense (i.e., a good experience at the right price), but increasingly it speaks to an even more important trend: people choosing trips that tie into their personal value systems, as in,‘We went to Tobago for our beach vacation because it reflects our values — local ownership, ecological preservation, sustainable development.

When Charles Darwin landed on the Galápagos Islands in 1835, the 19 islands had a few hundred settlers. Today, the 30,000 people who live there pose a threat to its fragile biodiversity. In an effort to help pause time, if not reverse it, the Swiss watchmaker IWC Schaffhausen has pledged $500,000 per year to the Galápagos conservation group the Charles Darwin Foundation, and to raise awareness has created the Aquatimer Chronograph Edition Galápagos Islands ($6,500). It’s one of six new diver’s watches in the Aquatimer family, which was born in 1967 — the same year tour groups first visited the islands. [?][?][?] JOSEPH PLAMBECK.

ALLEN Those in the know call Franklin, Tenn., just outside Nashville, the “Malibu of Tennessee.” A small city with a lot of spending power — thanks to locals with names like Keith, Nicole and Wynonna — Franklin recently got a boost with the arrival of Will Woods’s men’s-wear shop F. M. Allen. (He also has a New York store.) Woods calls the brand “rugged yet elegant,” just right for the genteel country life. RIMA SUQI.

Artists have toyed with maps before — there’s Salvador Dalí’s Surrealist “Map of the World” and Jasper Johns’s splotchy sendup of the Lower 48, for starters. But “The Map as Art” (Princeton Architectural Press; $45), a new coffee table curiosity by Katharine Harmon, shows how much traction the idea has with artists today. “There’s been an exponential increase in map-related art in gallery and museum shows.” Harmon says. “The reason, I think, is that this is a time when we’re all disoriented.” Instead of collecting real maps, she compiled more than 350 works that deal with representations of place: Maya Lin’s Baltic birch plywood sculpture of the Caspian Sea, Ruth Watson’s globe made of animal tissue (with Antarctica done in brains), Vik Muniz’s six continents forged from old computer parts. Rand McNally seems a world away. [?][?][?] STEPHEN HEYMAN.

Camden Passage, a narrow, stone-paved street in London’s Islington neighborhood, was once one of the city’s main antiques hubs, home to more than 350 shops. But in 2001, “trading in antiques hit a wall,” as one local proprietor put it, and businesses shut down or moved away. Then slowly the street came back to life, with a restaurant here, a chocolate shop there. (And not without controversy, as many Passage settlers feared that newcomers would mean higher rents.) Now Camden Passage has fully diversified, with a mix of stylish new shops and restaurants snug against the handful of antiques stores that held on.

The East Antarctic Ice Sheet, long seen as the stable side of Antarctica's vast lode of ice, appears to have been losing mass, particularly in coastal regions, over the past three years, according to a new analysis using gravity measurements. The finding is preliminary and comes with substantial uncertainty, the researchers reported in Nature Geoscience. But the research is generally consistent with other recent studies on ice loss in Antarctica and Greenland using surface and satellite measurements. What this portends for sea levels remains somewhat murky in the short run (by 2100) but very clear over the long haul, polar specialists largely agree.

Watching the gymnast Nastia Liukin dismount the uneven bars, you're almost too busy counting the flips - was that five ? - to notice her daintily perfect landing. Raised in Texas by two Soviet gymnasts, Liukin, 20, dominated Beijing last year, where she won the all-around gold. She's been cooling her pummeled heels lately, which doesn't mean she's traveling any less. This fall she visited London to blog from the world championships for USA Today, and she was in Copenhagen to promote Chicago's Olympic bid. Despite her past successes, Liukin is already dreaming about victory in the 2012 London games. ''Not that many people have really competed after they won their Olympic gold,'' she says. ''I want to achieve something that nobody's ever done.''

To the Editor: The Ridgeway Trail (“Hiking Into History,” Nov. 1) in England has the mixture of nature, history, geology and village life that makes for extraordinary hiking and that seems to be missing in the trails in the United States. The United States seems to excel in wilderness trails that don’t have a hint of the domesticity described by Henry Shukman. However, it’s the contrast between the exertion needed to hike and the luxury of a village inn that brings the greatest pleasure.

To the Editor: I enjoyed the article “Rare Books Don’t Always Live in Glass Cases” (Nov. 1) on lesser-known libraries with extraordinary collections. I was reminded of the detour-worthy art collection housed in the library of my hometown, Charles City, Iowa, population about 7,500. The public library was bequeathed an important collection of works on paper in 1941.

An article on Oct. 25 about the recent governor’s race in New Jersey misidentified the illegal activity that some Sephardic rabbis had been accused of and that the article characterized as part of the state’s infamous corruption. The rabbis were charged with money laundering, not with selling body parts and then using the money to bribe politicians. (There was a Brooklyn man accused of conspiring to broker the sale of a kidney, and several New Jersey politicians accused of corruption, all of whom were arrested the same day as the rabbis.).

GERLI--David, ninety-eight young, died reluctantly on November 19th. Survived by his devoted wife, Anne Gerli, loving children: David Gerli, Joan Hempstead, Carol Pfeuti, Eden Ljungberd as well as his stepchildren Coco Shean, Mary Clarke, Carol Deane and plethora of grandchildren and great-grandchildren. David served his country in the Coast Guard and the Navy during World War II. Family will hold a memorial celebration on Monday, November 23rd, at 4pm at the Colony Club, 564 Park Ave. In lieu of flowers send donations to The Village Preservation, 44 Cosdrew Ln., East Hampton, NY 11937.

Dr. Armellini is survived by his wife Nina, a sister Alda Neuman, two children, Marina Janus and Richard Armellini, three stepchildren and four grandchildren.

Mets fans had a lot to complain about during their team's first season at Citi Field, the sloppy play on the field and the high prices in the stands most prominently. Some fans were especially angry that more was not done to commemorate the team's past in its new home. The team addressed some of these concerns in August when giant images of Darryl Strawberry, Keith Hernandez, Dwight Gooden, Gil Hodges and Tom Seaver and of Jerry Koosman jumping into the arms of Jerry Grote in 1969 were installed around the inside of the stadium. The Mets also put their playoff banners on the left-field wall.

ROSS--Raymond. We mourn the loss of the best friend you could ever have. It was a privilege to know him for over 60 years. He will stay in our hearts forever. Our deepest condolences to the entire Ross family. Judy, George, Bobbe, Ben, Billy, Fran, Ann, Marty, Ruth and Harry

TEICHER--Rabbi Isaac Jacob, lovingly referred to as "Zeidi," died peacefully in his sleep early Sunday morning, November 15, 2009, two months shy of his 104th birthday. Renowned Rabbinic scholar, he immigrated to New York from Galicia passing through the gates of Ellis Island in 1920. His lengthy career had numerous stopping points and milestones, culminating with a span of 27 years in Montreal, Canada where, in addition to his pulpit position, he served for many years as President of the Board of Jewish Ministers. Following the death of his beloved wife Chiennie, he lived the last 31 years of his life in the community of Hillcrest, Queens. He is survived by his children Soshy and Chaim, their spouses Sol and Marni, six grandchildren and six great-grandchildren. Zeidi was graced with an effusive personality and presence. He was a dynamic orator and legendary teller of tales. He was an integral force in our lives for so long, it is hard to conceive of life without him. Baruch Adoshem yom yom. Blessed be God for every day.

OLSEN--David A. The Board of Directors and staff of Manhattan Theatre Club mourn the loss of our friend, David Olsen, and extend our deepest sympathy to our long-time Board member, Bobbie, and the entire Olsen family.

In public life, you are your comparison -- another Lincoln, another Garbo, another Pacino. Pity those who struggled last week to capture the essence of Oprah Winfrey. Perhaps Robert Thompson, a professor of television at Syracuse, broke ground when he said: ''We have come to use the term 'Oprahfication' in almost same way we use a term like the 'Hellenization.' And it's not completely inappropriate. She was able to colonize cultural territory the way Alexander was able to colonize physical territory.'' Ms. Winfrey announced that her TV talk show would end in September 2011. She will now focus her colonization efforts on a cable channel that will bear her name. Modern-day Thracians beware.

The Senate debate on health care, set to begin the week after Thanksgiving, is now on course to collide with the holiday season. One question for advocacy groups on all sides will be whether to keep up their barrage of pointed commercials, even as chestnuts roast and stockings are hung. The presidential primary candidates faced this same dilemma two years ago, when the Iowa caucuses were moved up to Jan. 3. The campaigns had to figure out how to stay visible during the crucial weeks before the vote, which overlapped with Christmas and New Year's, when the public was not really up for a political brawl.

HAVING friends over for dinner used to involve a minimal and fairly unremarkable to-do list: There were groceries to buy, along with flowers and a couple of bottles of semi-respectable wine. I would put out some guest towels and a collection of fancy soaps that were off-limits to blood relatives, and then -- voilà! -- dinner was served. Preparing for a dinner party these days is far more complex, thanks to a vast and bewildering array of dietary needs that seem to have suddenly overtaken everyone I know. An unscientific survey of family and friends turns up one acquaintance who is kosher, two who are more like kosher-style, in addition to two vegans, a smattering of lacto-vegetarians and a couple who cannot digest gluten of any kind. Accommodations must be made for my mother-in-law, who is lactose intolerant, and a friend who is dangerously and inconveniently allergic to peanuts. I must know at least a dozen women who have declared lifelong war on complex carbohydrates. And then there's my daughter, a wispy and tender-hearted flower child who prefers not to eat ''anything with a face'' (although she will sometimes make random and completely unreasonable exceptions for hot dogs and pepperoni).

Last week, Central Park was a blaze of red. Patience, the southernmost library lion, stood guard on Fifth Avenue against a background of golden leaves. And autumn's splendor appeared on the backs of a few imaginative women in a city known for dressing in black. Among the welcome minority was a woman in the surprise fall color, amethyst, left center; and Franca Sozzani, the editor of Italian Vogue, near left top, in a refined mix of amethyst, aubergine and forest green. Louise Doktor, left center, was recently spotted in amethyst on Park Avenue at 7:40 a.m. An administrative assistant, she has a gift for color and pattern, choosing pieces with no regard for size and wearing them in an uninhibited way: a skirt as a cape; a huge plaid shirt as a shawl.

WATT--David Henderson. Husband of Karen Houseman Watt, loving father, died November 17, in Mystic, CT. Born July 25, 1935 in New York, NY, David grew up in Riverdale. He graduated from Ohio Wesleyan University in 1959, Air Force ROTC, and served the Air Force until 1962. David worked as a marketing executive, his success due to a gregarious nature and scrupulous attention to detail. In addition to his wife, he is survived by his brother Richard, of Greensboro, NC; his children Melinda Watt, Andrew Watt, Meredith Trant; and four grandchildren, Amelia, Cassandra, Miles and Elizabeth.

EVEN for an artist who trades in the glamorously ephemeral, Francesco Vezzoli created a spectacle -- ''Ballets Russes Italian Style (The Shortest Musical You Will Never See Again)'' -- that was dazzlingly short. The performance featured Lady Gaga, who played her song ''Speechless'' on a rotating pink Steinway grand piano, with butterflies painted by Damien Hirst, all the while flanked by Prada-clad dancers from the Bolshoi Ballet. Conceived for last weekend's 30th anniversary gala at the Los Angeles Museum of Contemporary Art, Mr. Vezzoli's work may have been brief, but that was his intention. ''My work offers a moment of magic that is hard to capture,'' he said. For fans of Mr. Vezzoli's celebrity-obsessed ephemera, he has two exhibitions -- one in Stockholm mixing Dalí's work with his own imagery, starring Princess Caroline of Monaco as Queen Christina; the other, in Paris, an homage to Fellini, starring Eva Mendes as Anita Ekberg. Both run through the middle of January 2010. Fans of Ms. Gaga (above) are now able to buy the Frank Gehry-designed hat she wore that night at moca.org/mocanewauction. Or there's always the pirated video of the MoCA performance on YouTube. HORACIO SILVA

IF your 7-year-old design addict is already disdainful of rugs with storybook characters (and if money is no object), here's a less saccharine alternative: four witty, whimsical offerings that the London designers Edward Barber and Jay Osgerby have done for the Rug Company. Colorful and graphic, each design depicts a different member of the animal kingdom and reflects its nature, from the solitary owl against its night-sky background to an acid-green snake that seems to slither off the edge of its rug. A pair of butterflies and an adorable school of fish, above, round out the designs, which cost $3,285 or $4,725, depending on size. Barber Osgerby's creations have the playful simplicity of children's-book illustrations, but they're so sophisticated that you'll likely be seeing them in grown-up rooms, too. www.therugcompany.info. BERISH--Andrew, M.D. March 22, 1939 to November 1, 2009. Loving father of Adam (Alissa) and Josh (Liz). Devoted grandfather to Matthew and Jack. He leaves behind many friends and colleagues. Andy was a true character who brought smiles to those who knew him. He will be greatly missed.
FRISA--Maria Suzanna, playwright, medical professional, good friend, died November 16, 2009 after a protracted illness. She will be deeply missed by many people.

Smack in the middle of eastern Berlin is a grassy lawn measuring nearly five acres. Near it is a huge billboard showing a castle. What gives? It's an example of Zwischennutzung, or interim use, a word that gets bandied around a lot in a city that still has plenty of history to consider and lots of space to reconfigure.

To the Sports Editor: Re ''After the Tailgate, the Breathalyzer,'' Nov. 19: Boolah, boolah to the universities of Wisconsin and Minnesota for taking steps to limit student alcohol consumption at least on days of football games. Hopefully other colleges -- including the Ivies -- will follow suit because what good is going to costly classes during the week, then wiping one's brain out with a weekend binge?

WALBORSKY--Hyman, 78, passed away October 21, 2009 at home surrounded with much love in West Palm Beach, Florida. He served our Country honorably in Korea and worked for an American company for over 30 years in Cuba, Venezuela and Mexico City. He is survived by his beloved wife of 48 years, Aura Walborsky, daughter Aileen Josephs; son-in-law Dr. Mitchell Josephs; grandson Jonathan Josephs; son Paul Walborsky; daughter-in-law Liann Walborsky and granddaughters Maya and Ellie Walborsky. He was uncle to Edwin, Eric, Lisa and Irene Walborsky. A Shabbat Service in his honor will be held in Congregation L'Dor Va D'or, December 18, 2009 in Lake Worth, Florida.

THERE is a small gem of a show at Danziger Projects, featuring a little-known trove of Polaroids shot by Andy Warhol in the late 1970s and early '80s. Commissioned by a collector, they are portraits of famous athletes taken with a Big Shot camera. The simplicity of Mr. Warhol's method gives the tiny images (4 1/4 by 3 3/8) a purity and sincerity that belies the radiance and aura of greatness of the sitters. Even today, there is something tingle-inducing about seeing O. J. Simpson, Muhammad Ali, Chris Evert and Wayne Gretzky at the height of their ability. The show runs to Dec. 12 at 534 West 24th Street. KATHY RYAN

BERNSOHN--Lorin, deeply loved and deeply mourned by his wife of thirty years, Alison Jarvis, his daughter, Amanda, his son, Lucas, his daughter-in-law Nancy, and his brother, Paulus. Lorin Bernsohn died on November 20th at his home in Manhattan. Born in Brooklyn, Lorin was a lifetime New Yorker and started his career in music at the age of 19 as first cellist in the Buffalo Philharmonic Orchestra. He was a cellist with the New York Philharmonic for 42 years and a member of many chamber ensembles, including the Philharmonia Virtuosi of New York. A life member of the Art Students League, he was also an accomplished painter. A man of enormous integrity, Lorin was the truest of gentlemen, known for his intellect, wit, kindness and culture. He inspired us all with his uncommon courage. We will miss him profoundly. Gifts in memory of Lorin may be made to the Michael J. Fox Foundation (attn: Tribute Gifts, Church Street Station, P.O. Box 780, New York, NY 10008-0780) or WQXR, the public classical music station (attn: Development, WQXR, 160 Varick Street, New York, NY 10023). A funeral service will be held at 2pm on Tuesday November 24th at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 West 76th Street, New York NY 10023. Telephone 212 362 6600. Viewing precedes.
SAYERS--Theodore R. We mourn the death of our member and extend deepest sympathy to his family. Congregation Emanu-El of the City of New York

DENAT DE GUILLEBON--Jeanne-Claude. The staff and Board of Trustees of iCI (Independent Curators International) mourn the death of the extraordinary artist and visionary Jeanne-Claude, who, with her husband and artistic partner Christo, was a longtime and very generous supporter of iCI and a member of the Board of Trustees. Drinking and dining with a water view is a basic right of all Miamians -- whether it's at haute cuisine hideaways or hole-in-the-wall saloons. Il Gabbiano The founders of New York's Il Mulino co-own this modern Italian spot in a primo space tucked behind a downtown high-rise. The delightfully overwhelming menu is heavy on dishes from the Abruzzo region. 335 South Biscayne Boulevard; (305) 373-0063; ilgabbianomiami.com; entrees $29 to $65.

YOUDELMAN--Myrna R.,at home in Hartsdale, NY on November 14. Survived by her children, Taran, Jane and Ben (Jill), her mother, Pauline Kopell and granddaughter Olivia Louise, brother Bernie Kopell and nephews Adam and Josh Kopell. Cremation was private. Family and friends will be gathering at her home on Saturday, November 21 from Noon-5pm.

The five men the Justice Department has said will be charged in the attacks of Sept. 11 intend to plead not guilty so they can express their political and religious views during a trial, the lawyer for one of the men said on Saturday. The lawyer, Scott L. Fenstermaker, said that during a meeting at the Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, prison on Tuesday, his client, Ali Abd al-Aziz Ali, expressed the desire for a trial despite his intention to admit his role in the attacks and seek ''martyrdom'' through execution.

BERG--James F. As President of the RAB, Realty Advisory Board, he was the finest person imaginable. The Board of Directors and the membership of NYARM extend their most heartfelt sympathies to his wife Nancy and all those who loved and admired Jim. Margie Russell, Executive Director Greg Carlson, President NYARM, The New York Association of Realty Managers

Change out west Southern California's seven-year reign atop the Pac-10 ended quietly. The idle Trojans were eliminated when No. 20 Oregon State beat Washington State. Narrow Escape Florida State scored a touchdown in the final minute to beat Maryland and become bowl eligible for the 28th consecutive year, the longest active streak in the nation.

The former Seattle and Green Bay coach Mike Holmgren said he would be interested in working for the Cleveland Browns. Holmgren said in his weekly radio show on KJR in Seattle that he had not yet spoken to the Browns' owner, Randy Lerner, who is looking for a ''serious, credible leader'' to run his struggling team.

BROOKMAN--Jerome J.,devoted husband of 70 years to Rhoda Fixell, father to Bill (Joanne) and Jill, grandfather to Andrew Lapidus, Noah and Hannah Brookman. Founding publisher and editor of Sound Publishing Co. passed away November 20th. We will miss his prodigious memory. Born January 11, 1911 in New York City, graduated from City College 1928, attended Fordham Law. World War II Pacific Veteran, awarded the Purple Heart. Services November 22, 11:30am at Riverside Nassau North Chapel, opposite Railroad Station, Great Neck, NY.

BARRY--Eftimia M. (nee Chelales) on November 20, 2009. Beloved wife of the late Lewis Barry. Also survived by her sister-in-law, nieces and nephews. Visiting Monday, 9am at Clavin Funeral Home, 7722 4th Ave., Brooklyn. Funeral service to follow, 10:30am at Holy Cross G.O. Church.

SCHEFFEL--Richard L.,of Briarcliff Manor, NY. Born on December 15, 1935, passed away unexpectedly on June 7, 2009. He spent his non-retirement years as a freelance writer editing at MacGraw Hill, then as a senior editor-in-chief at Readers Digest. He was an avid naturalist and gardener. His love of life and his family will be remembered by all of those who survive him.

To the Sports Editor: Re ''Losing a Chess Match, and a Game,'' Nov. 16: Jacksonville's Maurice Jones-Drew got a lot of positive attention for saying, ''Tell my fantasy owners I'm sorry,'' after he eschewed a sure touchdown by taking a knee on the 1-yard line in the Jaguars' victory last Sunday against the Jets.

An article last Sunday about China's economic growth described the trade relationship between China and the United States incorrectly. China is America's biggest source of imports, not its biggest trading partner. (America's biggest trading partner, a category that takes account of American exports as well as imports, is Canada.)

OLSEN--David A.,died on November 14, 2009 of bladder cancer. He lived in Salisbury, CT and also had homes in Vero Beach, FL and New York. He was born on November 29, 1937, attended the Bronxville, NY Schools and graduated from Bowdoin College. He served as a 1st Lt. in the U.S. Army and Army Reserves. David began his extraordinary career in the insurance business with the Great American Insurance Company in New York City and Chicago. He joined the insurance brokerage firm of Johnson & Higgins in 1966 in the San Francisco office Marine Dept. He also worked in the J&H Chicago and Houston offices before transferring to the New York office in 1985 as Executive Vice President. He became President and COO in 1987, CEO in 1990 and Chairman in 1991. When J&H merged with Marsh & McLellan Companies in 1997, David became Vice-Chair and a Board member. David's expertise was sought by the governance of organizations large and small, including the Business Council for the U.N., U.S. Trust Corp., the American Institute for Chartered Property and Casualty Underwriters, the College of Insurance, the South Street Seaport Museum, the United Way of NYC, the Salisbury Vounteer Ambulance Service, Salisibury Visiting Nurses, Salisbury Congregational Church, Northwest CT Center for Family Services, and Salisbury Housing Trust. David served Bowdoin College as an Overseer from 1986-1996 and Trustee from 1996 to 2003. On the occasion of his 50th Reunion at Bowdoin, David and his wife Bobbie and their children established the Olsen Family Fund - Center for the Common Good. He leaves a remarkable legacy in the worlds of business, philanthropy and public service. David is survived by his wife Roberta whom he married on May 11, 1963; a son Brad and his wife Jeanine; a daughter Amy Hess, her husband Stephen and their three children Daniel, Sarah and Laura. He was predeceased by his parents Alexander and Mabel Olsen and a sister Barbara Olsen Rockefeller. A memorial service will be held on Monday, December 14 at 11:00am at the Salisbury CT Congregational Church. No flowers, please. Memorial gifts may be made to Bowdoin College, Olsen Family Fund, 4100 College Station, Brunswick, ME 04011-8432.

LANDAU--Sheldon M. Beloved husband of Emily Fisher Landau. Loving father of Ellen (Marty), Donald (Leslie), Richard (Julia). Devoted grandfather of Ben, Jack, Jake, Dylan, Jared and Caity. He is also survived by a stepdaughter, Candia and grandchildren Hadley, Winston, Eric, Alexandra, Miasha, Tora, Madeline, William, Noah, and Cole. Sheldon was a Lieutenant in World War II serving as a fighter pilot. Until his retirement, he was a Partner and President of Jerry Silverman Inc. Two of the best players in the N.F.L. at their respective positions meet again Sunday. In Week 2, Darrelle Revis blanketed Randy Moss, below, allowing four catches for 24 yards. Afterward, Moss said Revis often had help over the top, which when revisited last week, started a minor controversy. The Jets contended that Revis covered Moss by himself for most of that game. The Patriots said the opposite. The drama adds to the intrigue of this choice matchup.
BESSO--Victor, 23 Nov. 2006 . Still and always together. With love your wife, Nidia. We all miss you every day.

I didn't want to be famous, but the Norwegians insisted. The smiling weatherwoman, the thumbs-up cameraman standing in the snow, even the delighted caterer, who really should not have cared one way or the other, each wanted me to sit on a half log draped in reindeer fur and say things in English to their morning TV audience. To be honest, I felt ashamed. And a little embarrassed. I had only come to Norway to ski, and maybe write some words about it, not to make a fuss or have makeup put on me in front of little skiing children. But here I was, seated next to a beautiful Norwegian Katie Couric, at the base of a little Hobbit hill, a frozen valley beneath us, a staged cooking fire at my back, unsure of what these people wanted from me. I considered running off but wondered how that might look.

Nate Robinson found the basket only once Saturday -- after the buzzer and at the wrong end of the court. With 0.5 seconds left in the first quarter of the Knicks' game against the Nets, Robinson received an inbounds pass, then turned and heaved a 3-pointer at his own basket. The referee Steve Javie waved off the shot before it swished. But Knicks Coach Mike D'Antoni was livid, and he bellowed at Robinson on the bench. It was a low point in an otherwise successful afternoon for the Knicks, who won by 98-91.

An article on Oct. 25 about the recent governor's race in New Jersey misidentified the illegal activity that some Sephardic rabbis had been accused of and that the article characterized as part of the state's infamous corruption. The rabbis were charged with money laundering, not with selling body parts and then using the money to bribe politicians. (There was a Brooklyn man accused of conspiring to broker the sale of a kidney, and several New Jersey politicians accused of corruption, all of whom were arrested the same day as the rabbis.)

The North African country of Tunisia is known for its golden beaches, sunny weather and affordable luxuries. The new 260-room Radisson hotel, in the former French colonial port city of Monastir, is no exception. The Radisson Blu Resort & Thalasso, Monastir (www.radissonblu.com/resort-monastir), above, sits on 12 acres along the Mediterranean and has three restaurants, five bars and an indoor and two outdoor swimming pools, including one just for children. At the beach, there's water-skiing, Jet-Skiing or sand volleyball.

Joe Rosa placed first and his twin, Jim, was second at the New Jersey State Meet of Champions. Joe covered the five-kilometer course at Holmdel Park in 14 minutes 56 seconds to break the course record of 15:04 he set Oct. 3. Jim was timed in 15:15. The Rosas run for West Windsor-Plainsboro High School North.

A RARE assortment of vintage Oliver Peoples frames, dating as far back as 1987, is the calling card at A. Kinney Court, a boutique that opened recently in Venice, Calif. The owner, Garrett Leight, 25, is following in the footsteps of his dad, Larry, who founded Oliver Peoples more than 20 years ago. Classic clip-on sunglasses, with tinted vintage lenses, as well as the famous '50s-style O'Malley frame (above), are just some of the offerings father and son found in multiple storage units. The store carries other trendy optical lines like Mykita, Thierry Lasry and KBL Eyewear, as well as shoes and clothing for men and women. A. Kinney Court, 1423 Abbot Kinney Boulevard, Venice, Calif. BRUCE PASK
Television Mike Hale

GRAVES--Zoe R.,Ph.D. Born April 28, 1946 died November 11, 2009. Dr. Graves began her career as a supervisor in the Cytogenetics Laboratory at Letchworth Village Developmental Center from 1969-1982, while completing her undergraduate studies at Columbia University. After graduating Suma Cum Laude in 1974, Zoe went on to earn M.A. and Ph.D. degrees at the City University Graduate Center in Developmental Psychology. In 1981 Zoe began agency work in medical communications, serving as VP/Associate Creative Director at GTFH. She founded and led Creative Medical Communications, Inc. for 10 years, ultimately returning to her passion as a psychologist in 2001. Zoe also wrote, directed and performed with an off-off Broadway theatrical company for over a decade. Forced into early retirement in 2003 by an advanced cancer, Zoe continued her rich and diverse cultural pursuits, including horseback riding, photography, horticulture and music and the arts. To her last days, Zoe delighted in the company of family and lifelong friends. Zoe leaves behind the two loves of her life - her adopted daughter Corina and husband Rob Kearney. She is also survived by her mother and stepfather, Devora and Al Karp, sister Amy Hunter and two brothers Hank and Bill Sharp and their beloved families. Zoe urged all to share in her zest for life. A memorial service will be held at The New York Society for Ethical Culture, 2 West 64th St., New York, NY on Saturday, January 9, 2010 at noon.
VOLASKI--Ben, 85, of Sunrise, Florida, beloved husband to the late Rosalyn, father to Maurice, brother to Herman, Frances, and Victor, died of lung cancer, on Wednesday, November, 18th.

McNIVEN--Mary Mortimer, passed away on November 2, at age 93. Mary was born in Sharon, Wisconsin and graduated cum laude from Lawrence University. She married Robert Rusch in 1938 and was widowed in 1959. Known for her spirit and determination, Mary then moved her young family to Delray Beach, FL. She later married Charles "Buster" McNiven and lived in New York City where Buster was the Executive Director of Kips Bay Boys Club before retiring to Falmouth, MA. Mary and Buster enjoyed great times with their friends at Woods Hole Golf Club. She was predeceased by her beloved husband Charles McNiven and her brother, Robert Mortimer. She is survived by her loving children: Robert, Katherine, Elizabeth, Anne, and Patricia. Known as "Mimi" to her eight grandchildren, she will be missed by Robert, Robyn, Kim, Kristen, Alexis, Daphne, Shannon, and Adam and four great-grandchildren. All who have known Mary (aka Mimi) were touched by her warmth, intelligence, wit, and spark; we will miss her and treasure many wonderful memories as she would want us to do. In lieu of flowers donations may be sent to Kips Bay Boys & Girls Club, 1930 Randall Ave., Bronx, NY 10473.

Last week, Central Park was a blaze of red. Patience, the southernmost library lion, stood guard on Fifth Avenue against a background of golden leaves. And autumn's splendor appeared on the backs of a few imaginative women in a city known for dressing in black. Among the welcome minority was a woman in the surprise fall color, amethyst, left center; and Franca Sozzani, the editor of Italian Vogue, near left top, in a refined mix of amethyst, aubergine and forest green. Louise Doktor, left center, was recently spotted in amethyst on Park Avenue at 7:40 a.m. An administrative assistant, she has a gift for color and pattern, choosing pieces with no regard for size and wearing them in an uninhibited way: a skirt as a cape; a huge plaid shirt as a shawl.

Flying during the holidays is never fun. But a couple of airlines are trying to brighten up the process with a gift of free Wi-Fi access at 10,000 feet. Through Jan. 15, Virgin America, in a promotion with Google, will offer its Gogo Inflight Internet free on all flights. The service is normally $5.95 for very short flights to $12.95 for flights over three hours.

After 20 years, the dossier on Norv Turner is complete. He is a great teacher of quarterbacks and receivers whose offenses generate impressive statistics, if slightly less impressive point totals. He is a good planner but a poor in-game strategist. As a disciplinarian and motivator, he ranks somewhere between Dick Jauron and a substitute gym teacher. Turner's players must provide their own leadership, and every losing streak sparks questions about the team's character and commitment, as well as Turner's command fitness. The San Diego Chargers (6-3) invariably rally after each losing streak, because they have too much talent to do otherwise. That is why it was foolish to write them off when they started the season 2-3. The Chargers were not a bad team, they were just getting a jump on their disappointment.

DISARM the Patek Philippe. Park the Bugatti. Drain the last drops of Cristal. The party's over. That, at least, is what Ford's futurists are thinking. ''Our view is, the era of excess has reached a tipping point,'' George Pipas, the company's sales analyst, told journalists last week in Manhattan. ''People are moving from conspicuous consumption to more careful consumption.''

KEVIN GRAY ''I do a lot of jailhouse interviews,'' says the journalist Kevin Gray, who took time off from grilling psychopaths and serial killers to explore the small Norwegian ski town of Geilo (''Cold Rush,'' Page 98). ''I don't consider myself somebody who writes about landscape a lot, or food, or amenities,'' says Gray, a frequent contributor to Details and New York magazine. ''So I figured the best thing for me to do was populate this story with a lot of people.'' A former CNN producer, Gray lives in the East Village, where he plays guitar in an amateur prog-rock band and, more regularly, walks Hank Williams, his year-old Boston terrier.

Both men earned trips to the Grand Prix Final, which will serve as the final showdown for the sport's elite ahead of the Vancouver Olympics.

IF your 7-year-old design addict is already disdainful of rugs with storybook characters (and if money is no object), here's a less saccharine alternative: four witty, whimsical offerings that the London designers Edward Barber and Jay Osgerby have done for the Rug Company. Colorful and graphic, each design depicts a different member of the animal kingdom and reflects its nature, from the solitary owl against its night-sky background to an acid-green snake that seems to slither off the edge of its rug. A pair of butterflies and an adorable school of fish, above, round out the designs, which cost $3,285 or $4,725, depending on size. Barber Osgerby's creations have the playful simplicity of children's-book illustrations, but they're so sophisticated that you'll likely be seeing them in grown-up rooms, too. www.therugcompany.info. PILAR VILADAS

Since the late 1980s, Lolita Wolf has been an active participant in New York's B.D.S.M. scene. (B.D.S.M., she explained, stands for ''bondage and discipline, dominance and submission, sadism and masochism.'') Ms. Wolf, 53, gives private lessons and leads workshops with titles like ''Power Flogging'' and ''Let's Play With Needles,'' and has made instructional books and videos. She runs a small printing business and works part time at Purple Passion, a fetish and adult toy shop in Chelsea. Although she describes her childhood in Queens as normal and middle-class, Ms. Wolf -- who was born Peggy but, after becoming more open about her sexual preferences, adopted her role-play name, Lolita -- said she has always had bondage fantasies. ''When I was 6 years old, I would be the captive princess, and I had to do things just to stay alive until I could be rescued,'' she recalled. ''Funny enough, it's still my No. 1 fantasy.'' Ms. Wolf, who is bisexual and describes herself as polyamorous, lives alone on the Upper West Side.

ANDRE 3000 must have taken a page or two out of ''Gentlemen of the Bacongo'' (Trolley Books, $39.95), a new tome by Daniele Tamagni that celebrates dandies in an unlikely style capital -- the Congo Republic. The culture of La SAPE, or La Société des Ambianceurs et des Personnes Élégantes (Society of Funlovers and Elegant People), began when the country was a French protectorate and the local men adopted a little European flair. The sapeurs, as they are known, spiff themselves up with brightly colored suits, fedoras and the occasional cigar -- more English aristo than Iceberg Slim. They also believe in cultivating the mind and spirit (''We respect other people, we don't like war, we like peace, and we have a moral code that is very Christian,'' says one sapeur) and are minor celebrities in their hometowns, appearing at funerals and weddings. While they look fabulously natty with their pressed pocket squares and razor-sharp blazers, their images are all the more compelling set against a background of abject poverty -- in streets crowded with trash and half-dressed children, the peacocks strut. MAURA EGAN

The first person I asked about life in Phnom Penh, the Cambodian capital, was Julia Fesenberg, then an executive with Raffles Hotels. Driving from the airport on a muggy, dark gray afternoon, we passed through miles of grim, crude, cinder block construction. Fesenberg waxed in a winsome German accent about her enthusiasm for the city. After years in Angkor Wat, she'd had the option of transferring to a hotel in Europe or the United States. But all of those places were too built up and boring, she said. Cooked. Done. ''My mother's having a hard time understanding my vision,'' Fesenberg said with a shrug. ''But when am I ever going to get the chance to be somewhere less developed?'' I'd been hearing about Phnom Penh since at least the early 1990s, when a group of journalists from New York were hired to staff the just-introduced Cambodia Daily. Dispatches they sent to acquaintances sounded hellish and exciting, in that young-man-meets-failed-state sort of way, with reports of land mines, military checkpoints, handguns, machine guns, coup attempts, cratered streets, opiates and amputee teen prostitutes.

SAYERS--Theodore R. After a full and vibrant life, he fought a courageous battle with cancer and passed away peacefully in his home in New York, NY on November 21, 2009 at age 88. He was predeceased by his beloved wife, Lillian and cherished son Mark. He is survived by a daughter, and his two devoted granddaughters, Lauren Braun Costello and Nicole Braun Carrasco, as well as a great-grandson, Jonathan Costello. He is also survived by his sister, Charlotte Feinsten and many treasured nieces and nephews as well an abundance of valued friends. Mr. Sayers graduated from Brooklyn College and received a Masters degree in business from NYU, he served in the US Coast Guard during WWII. Successful in real estate development in the US and abroad, he concluded his career as President of EMES Management Corporation. Mr. Sayers was also involved in numerous charitable organizations, including serving as Chairman of the Board of Circle in the Square Theater. Services Monday November 23, 11am at Temple Emanu-El 5th Ave at 65th St. In lieu of flowers, the family asks that donations be made to the Central Park Conservancy in honor of Lillian Sayers. He will be deeply missed and always remembered.

Climate Change THE NEWS After meeting on the sidelines of the Asian-Pacific Economic Cooperation conference in Singapore,President Obama and other leaders announced that a binding climate-change agreement could not be negotiated in time for a major world summit meeting next month in Copenhagen.

This past week The Times introduced a new version of its online opinion section, called Opinionator. So, what is Opinionator?It's most of what readers used to find under Op-Extra -- exclusive online opinion journalism from The Times. But it's now all in one place, with easy-to-use navigation. Opinionator includes regular online columnists (Stanley Fish, Olivia Judson, Timothy Egan, Judith Warner and Dick Cavett); contributing columnists (like Allison Arieff and Errol Morris); thematic series like Home Fires and Happy Days; and Op-Ed page columnists writing specially for the Web (The Conversation with Gail Collins and David Brooks).

GAR--Nicholas, 64, a resident of Chatham Twp.,NJ, passed away on November 7 after a long and courageous struggle with chronic illness associated with exposure to Agent Orange. Nick began his professional career as a commercial and artistic photographer in New York City, publishing stirring photos of local scenery, landmarks, and people he encountered in walks through the city streets. Later, Nick was drafted into the military and served honorably with the US Army as a Private First Class in ground combat, in country, during the Vietnam War, 1965-1967. During his service, he kept his focus on preserving the lives of his fellow soldiers and local civilians. After his discharge, Nick studied art at Silvermine College and later in New York City's environs. His modern paintings and sculptures were available in private showings. His work was viewed as innovative and exceptionally beautiful in color, subject and composition. In 2001, Nick earned a Master of Letters in politics and international finance from Drew University. He supported humanitarian principles in public and private life, personally extending compassion and friendship to all he met. At the time of his death, he had authored a scholarly text and was preparing it for publication. Nick had also begun a memoir about his travels and war experiences in Vietnam. He is survived by his mother, a brother and sister-in law, and his younger sister.

Among the wonders of Mumbai are the dabbawallas, deliverymen who ferry home-cooked meals -- in multicompartment metal lunch boxes called tiffins -- from residences to offices (and back) every day. It used to be that the meals would originate only with a mother, a grandmother or perhaps a wife. But with the startup of a handful of businesses catering to the tiffin crowd, the options have expanded. LoveLunch (lovelunch@gmail.com) is one such operation, created for those who prefer to sample Continental and pan-Asian cuisine rather than sticking to the basics. LoveLunch has transformed the tiffin into art, bringing gourmet meals to expatriates and foodies across Mumbai each day. On occasion, LoveLunch participants receive e-mail previewing the day's menu, which might include dishes like green Thai fish curry or Japanese teriyaki chicken.

RAGSDALE--Duane William, who was Vice Chairman of Ted Bates Worldwide, Inc. when it was the second largest advertising agency in the world, died of Alzheimer's Disease November 17th. He was 85 years of age. Mr. Ragsdale was a resident of New York City for 58 years and spent summers in Mattapoisett, MA for 47 years. Known as Rags, he was born in Baker City, Oregon and attended schools there. During World War II, he attended the University of Colorado in the Naval V12 program and upon graduation he served on the William B. Langfitt troop transport in the Pacific. After the service he attended the Harvard Business School on an academic scholarship and graduated in 1951. Rags' first venture into advertising was in the advertising department of Paramount Pictures in 1951 researching the impact - if any - that the newly developed television might have upon the movie industry. He went on to Compton Advertising, now Satchi & Satchi, where he helped to launch Gleem Toothpaste "for people who can't brush after every meal". His next position was at William Esty. Once at Ted Bates Worldwide, Rags was instrumental in bringing William Esty into the Ted Bates Worldwide Organization. He is a past member of the new York Athletic Club, The Harvard Club of New York, and the American Advertising Federation. He was appreciated for giving full credit to those who worked with him for their contributions to advertising campaigns. He was also known for a wonderful sense of humor. His coworkers refer to the period of time that they worked with him as their "Camelot". He is survived by Mimi his loving wife for 57 years and dear daughter Martha, his niece Dana and nephews Richard and Norman. He was preceded in death by his brothers Lee, Norman and Orville. Rags will be deeply missed by all who knew him. A memorial service will be held at a later date. Please make remembrances to your favorite charity.

Bernanke, the Federal Reserve chairman, who warned last week that high unemployment and a continued reluctance by banks to make loans were likely to slow the economic recovery for the next year.

YOU can literally put your money where your mouth is with these enamel, silver and gold Seven Sins earrings by the Rome-based jeweler Delfina Delettrez (who, as a fourth-generation Fendi, must have accessories in her blood). Her work, with its gothic bent and unusual combinations of colors and materials, is often inspired by the human body, especially as it's depicted in the work of Andreas van Vessel, the 16th-century anatomist. The earrings are about $1,600 at Opening Ceremony, 35 Howard Street, or go to openingceremony.us. SANDRA BALLENTINE

A Queens man was charged with killing his wife and 14-year-old son on Saturday after their bodies were found with their throats cut in a closet of the family's three-room apartment, the authorities said. ''They were wrapped in black plastic,'' said Richard A. Brown, the Queens district attorney, who visited the building, at 39-02 111th Street in Corona.

EHRET--Walter, passed away on November 16th, 2009 at the age of 91, after a long, happy, and productive life. He left a great legacy as a teacher who touched many students' lives. He was the beloved husband and best friend of Beverly, his wife of 62 years, adored father of David Ehret and Christine Marver, and daughter-in-law Pamela Ehret, and the proud grandfather of Jeffrey, Julia, and Sarah Marver. Mr. Ehret was born in New York City in 1918 to Adele Tonies and her husband who tragically died in the flu epidemic of that year. He was later adopted by a kind stepfather, Charles Ehret. Walter Ehret was a graduate of the Julliard School of Music and Teachers College, Columbia University. He has served as an adjunct faculty member of Hofstra University, Manhattanville College, and Teachers College, Columbia University. In addition, he taught instrumental and choral music in several New Jersey and New York school systems for over 40 years. In 1984 he retired as District Coordinator of Music for the Scarsdale, NY Public Schools. Choral groups under his direction have performed with distinction at contests and at other award-winning occasions. They have performed in Carnegie Hall and Madison Square Garden, as well as on radio and television. His organizations have been invited to sing at New Jersey and New York State School Music Association conventions, divisional meetings of the Music Educators National Conference, and the first American Choral Directors Association National Conference. He was a past president of the Music Educators Associations for Bergen, Nassau, and Westchester Counties. He was a former Vice President of Choirs for the New York State School Music Association, a former State Chairman of Junior High School Music of the New York State School Music Association, and a past member of several MENC committees. He was a founding member and first New York State president of the American Choral Directors Association. He is well known as a clinician, conductor, and choral literature specialist, and has functioned in these various capacities at over 300 workshops in some 30 states. He is one of the nation's most prolific and respected choral editors and arrangers, and has over 2000 publications in print. In addition, he is co-author of Growing with Music, a basic music series for grades K-8, co-author of Functional Lessons in Singing, a class voice textbook, author of The Choral Conductor's Handbook, and co-author of The International Book of Christmas Carols. As per his wishes, his body was donated to medical science. His family and friends will gather to celebrate his life at a future date. Contributions to his memory may be made to the Eye Research Institute, 20 Staniford Street, Boston, MA 02114.

Want to find Mickey Mouse for an autograph? Want to know the wait time for Space Mountain? Well, there's an app for that -- sort of. Disney Parks has released a mobile app, Mobile Magic, which delivers real-time updates of wait times, where to find characters and GPS-enabled maps for both Disneyland and Walt Disney World. But the app, $9.99 for a 180-day subscription, works only on Verizon Wireless phones.

LEVINE--Sanford H.,71, of Schenectady, NY, November 18, 2009. An attorney, devoted his career to the State University of New York, serving as University Counsel and Vice Chancellor for Legal Affairs from 1978-97, and then for a decade as Professor of Educational Administration and Policy Studies at the University at Albany. Former president National Assn of College and University Attorneys. Survived by wife Margaret, daughters Jessica DeHaemer and Abby Shallom; granddaughters Rachel and Leah DeHaemer; sister Janet L. Schiff. Funeral Sunday, November 22 at 10am at Congregation Gates of Heaven, 852 Ashmore Ave., Schenectady, NY. levinememorialchapel.com.

ROSEN--Mitchell B.,passed away peacefully on November 20th at the age of 84. Beloved husband of Lila (nee Herzfeld) for 56 years. Devoted father of Bruce and Kathy, kind father-in-law to Jill and Ethan. Cherished grandfather of Allison and Grant. He is also survived by his sister Enid Nash and brother-in-law Stephen Herzfeld. He was a caring and humble man who took great pride in having been a long-time member of the New York Stock Exchange. He honorably served in the U.S. Marines during World War II. Researchers at Princeton University recently made a remarkable discovery about the brains of rats that exercise. Some of their neurons respond differently to stress than the neurons of slothful rats. Scientists have known for some time that exercise stimulates the creation of new brain cells (neurons) but not how, precisely, these neurons might be functionally different from other brain cells. In the experiment, preliminary results of which were presented last month at the annual meeting of the Society for Neuroscience in Chicago, scientists allowed one group of rats to run. Another set of rodents were not allowed to exercise. Then all of the rats swam in cold water, which they don't like to do. Afterward, the scientists examined the animals' brains. They found that the stress of the swimming activated neurons in all of the animals' brains. (The researchers could tell which neurons were activated because the cells expressed specific genes in response to the stress.) But the youngest brain cells in the running rats, the cells that the scientists assumed were created by running, were less likely to express the genes. They generally remained quiet. The ''cells born from running,'' the researchers concluded, appeared to have been ''specifically buffered from exposure to a stressful experience.'' The rats had created, through running, a brain that seemed biochemically, molecularly, calm. For years, both in popular imagination and in scientific circles, it has been a given that exercise enhances mood. But how exercise, a physiological activity, might directly affect mood and anxiety, psychological states, was unclear. Now, thanks in no small part to improved research techniques and a growing understanding of the biochemistry and the genetics of thought itself, scientists are beginning to tease out how exercise remodels the brain, making it more stress-resistant. In work undertaken at the University of Colorado, Boulder, for instance, scientists have examined the role of serotonin, a neurotransmitter often considered to be the ''happy'' brain chemical. That simplistic view of serotonin has been undermined by other researchers, and the University of Colorado work further dilutes the idea. In those experiments, rats taught to feel helpless and anxious (by being exposed to a laboratory stressor) showed increased serotonin activity in their brains. But rats that had run for several weeks before being stressed showed less serotonin activity and were less anxious and helpless despite the stress.

Whether Roger Federer wins or loses in London next week, the tennis year will still be his. No matter how big the buzz at the tour championships, which start Sunday in their new digs by the River Thames, the truth is that the most significant trophies have been handed over. By reaching the finals of all four Grand Slam tournaments, winning his first French Open and securing his record 15th major singles title, at Wimbledon, Federer has already become the indispensable man of 2009.

MAHONEY--Evelyn B. Age 97. A resident of Delray Beach, FL. Formerly of Great Neck, NY and Atlantis, FL. Died peacefully at her home on November 16th. Widow of Louis Eugene Marx and Waldron Mahoney. Mother of Linda and Peter Bermas, the late Pennie Bellard, and Mary Ellen Marx, and "Mother Lynn" of Helga and Sergio Palacios. Loving grandmother of Margot Goldberg, Laura Van Sise, Jason Bellard, and Anna Bellard, and their spouses, and great-grandmother of Tamir, Rachel and Jack, Gabriella and Owen, and Willem and Olivia and grateful friend of Evelyn Brown, her caring companion for many years. Following cremation, a memorial service will be held in Florida. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to Great Neck Student Aid Fund, Inc., P.O. Box 1067, Great Neck, NY 11023, or a charity of your choice. For further information contact Boynton Memorial Chapel (561-734-5600).

SYMS--Sy. Boys Town Jerusalem mourns the passing of a cherished member of its extended family. Sy identified with the plight of disadvantaged youth and generously supported Boys Town's mission of helping turn young boys from limited backgrounds into young men with limitless futures. He was a philanthropist and a true humanitarian who not only educated consumers, but as a role model par excellence, educated others in the art of giving and helping the less fortunate. His legacy will endure as a blessing and inspiration for all. We extend heartfelt condolences to his entire family. Rabbie Moshe Linchner, Dean Josh S. Weston, Honorary Chairman Raphael Benaroya, Chairman Michael J. Scharf, President Rabbie Ronald Gray, Ex VP

IF one wanted to encapsulate everything that defines Queens into a single neighborhood -- and who wouldn't, really -- the result might very well be Astoria. Ensconced in the northwest corner of the borough and bigger than some small towns, it used to be dominated by immigrants from southern Europe but has morphed into a broader mix. The message to every newcomer couldn't be clearer: the united nations of Astoria welcomes you, too.
BERNSTEIN--Linda. June 19, 1944 - November 16, 2009. In loving memory of a beloved wife, mom, sister, aunt, sister-in-law, cousin and friend.

These include hundreds of independent book retailers (statistically weighted to represent all such outlets); national, regional and local chains; online and multimedia entertainment retailers; university, gift, supermarket, discount department stores and newsstands. An asterisk (*) indicates that a book’s sales are barely distinguishable from those of the book above. A dagger (†) indicates that some bookstores report receiving bulk orders. Among those categories not actively tracked are: perennial sellers; required classroom reading; text, reference and test preparation guides; journals and workbooks; calorie counters; shopping guides; comics and crossword puzzles. HOFSTETTER--Neil. The members of the Department of Surgery mourn the loss of Neil Hofstetter, beloved brother of Dr. Steven Hofstetter. We extend our deepest condolences to Dr. Hofstetter and his family on their loss. Donations in memory of Neil Hofstetter can be made to NYU Institute for Surgical Research and mailed to 530 First Avenue - HCC 6C, New York, NY 10016. H. Leon Pachter M.D. F.A.C.S The George David Stewart Professor and Chair Department of Surgery NYU School of Medicine

Watching the gymnast Nastia Liukin dismount the uneven bars, you're almost too busy counting the flips -- was that five? -- to notice her daintily perfect landing. Raised in Texas by two Soviet gymnasts, Liukin, 20, dominated Beijing last year, where she won the all-around gold. She's been cooling her pummeled heels lately, which doesn't mean she's traveling any less. This fall she visited London to blog from the world championships for USA Today, and she was in Copenhagen to promote Chicago's Olympic bid. Despite her past successes, Liukin is already dreaming about victory in the 2012 London games. ''Not that many people have really competed after they won their Olympic gold,'' she says. ''I want to achieve something that nobody's ever done.'' STEPHEN HEYMAN

MARK--Jack, March 18th, 1923 -- November 19th, 2009, passed away at home with his wife of 60 years, Amy, and his daughter Deborah, at his bedside. He was an adored father, grandfather, and husband. Among all his life's accomplishments, he was most proud of his service as a paratrooper and member of the O.S.S. in WWII. He was generous to a fault, had an amazing sense of humor, and he loved his family above everything else. He is also survived by his grandson Roger, and his daughter Linda.

A study by SquareTrade, an online vendor of extended warranties, says 20.4 percent of laptops fail over three years. The study found evidence that netbooks fail at a higher rate, 5.4 percent in the first year of use compared with 4.2 percent for a premium-level laptop. But netbooks haven't been around long enough to provide solid three-year data.

It stars Mr. Herzog's frequent collaborator Klaus Kinski. Foliage fills the frames of Slide 10, Slide 11 and Slide 12; playing a somber, ceremonial role in two of the pictures and a delightfully recreational role in the third. Much outrage has been spent and many brows furrowed over Nate Robinson's bizarre decision to shoot at the wrong basket during the Knicks game against the Nets on Saturday. But it appears that the Knicks' greatest concern -- that he might have scored 3 points for the Nets -- is misplaced.

As executives of General Motors met Monday with European officials to ask for financial help in restructuring its struggling auto operations on the Continent, Germany reopened a bitter public debate over state aid and job protections that has sharply divided its government, Judy Dempsey of The New York Times reports from Berlin.

Peter Mueller, who won a gold medal in the 1976 Olympics and went on to coach American skaters like Bonnie Blair and Dan Jansen to Olympic medals, was fired by Norway as its national speedskating coach on Monday after one of its skaters accused him of sexual harassment. It was startling for the timing -- the Games begin in less than three months -- and because Mueller was widely hailed for resurrecting a slumping program over the past six years.

Uptowners have Bemelmans. Marie's Crisis, in the West Village, caters to a gay crowd. But what about the Brooklyn hipsters? Now they have the Manhattan Inn, a new old-timey piano bar on Manhattan Avenue opened by Brooke Baxter and Rolyn Hu, the ladies who started Glasslands Gallery on Kent Avenue in 2006. But the Manhattan Inn is different. "It's a little older crowd," says Hu, "maybe looking to have a quieter night." Instead of a massive art loft rocked by guitars and gritty marching bands, an intimate front bar opens to a larger back room, where, under a skylight and a chandelier, a lily-white baby grand - courtesy of Craigslist - awaits its player.

(Ed makes a pizzocheri like dish -- starting with the noodles. --MB)Buckwheat noodles with cabbage have been no stranger to The Times (see here, for instance), and when my wife, Jackie, recently remembered that a Savoy cabbage and some leeks were languishing in the refrigerator, that was what came to mind. It was a chilly, rainy day. We'd walked through a pleasant drizzle for an hour and a half and had just climbed into a taxi with our shopping bags when the drizzle turned to a downpour and finding a cab suddenly became impossible for other people - cause for smug triumphalism and hearty appetite.

Tuesday is the deadline for European domestic leagues to inform the International Ice Hockey Federation whether they will participate in the 2010-11 Champions Hockey League, the revived competition featuring regular-season and playoff victors from the continent's "Top 7" hockey-playing nations.

If the coming Academy Awards show turns out to be teeming with original musical numbers or dirty sexual puns, now you'll know who to thank or vilify.
