The on-again, off-again Cadillac CTS Coupe is back on again. Cadillac officially announced the 2011 model Monday morning, promising to show the car publicly -- for sure, this time -- next week at the Los Angeles auto show.

The role of newspapers and journalists is evolving as technologies and media markets change. Along with providing conventional coverage of the news, blogging, video reports and the like, media outlets are increasingly providing basic background on important enduring issues. The Times has put more effort recently into enriching and updating what are called topics pages -- basic backgrounders on issues in the news. I recently had a go at our page on global warming. Here's the introduction and a link to the full page. It's followed by the steady feed of news articles and accompanied by links to other background. Henceforth, it'll be a "living document," with more features, links and content added as needed. I encourage you to identify any gaps and glitches. Our editors will keep track of the comments.

Hope you got your shopping in this weekend, friends. We're coming up to the big event now. I'll be on hand on Thursday morning for all your last-minute freak-outs and emergencies. In the meantime, let's take a quick couple of questions from the in-box, dispatch them as if they were heritage birds. Later today, I'll be back with some more: "On the Question of Pies" and the like. Keep hitting "refresh."

The cover story in the latest issue of Time magazine is titled "The Case Against Over-Parenting. Why Mom and Dad need to cut the strings." Its target is helicopter parents. In it, the author, Nancy Gibbs, argues for laissez-faire parenting - a "let them grow by letting go" method - while acknowledging that over-involvement can feel irresistible.

Two very different pieces of travel writing loom large in "Cocina Confidential," Stephen Metcalf's foodie adventure story from our winter travel issue. The first, "The Return of Eva Perón" by V.S. Naipaul, was written more than 30 years ago, but it's still talked about in more introspective quarters of the Argentine capital - and not always with affection. "To Naipaul," Metcalf writes, "Argentina was less a country than a staging ground for absurdist public traumas that never add up to an actual history. From dictatorship to hyperinflation to, more recently, the currency crisis, which plunged the economy into chaos in 2001, cataclysm seems to come naturally to Argentines."

President Obama devotes a fair amount of time to sports. He plays golf most weekends. He filled out his N.C.A.A. championship bracket for all ESPN viewers to see. And he carefully follows his hometown Chicago teams: the White Sox, the Bulls and the Bears.

Susan Goldberg's Complaint Box on the vast and bewildering array of dietary needs drew a deluge of more than 300 comments (the most ever for a Complaint Box). Some commiserated with her frustration, but others tsk-tsked her for being a less than gracious host. Many people with dietary restrictions explained how they tried not to impose; others offered strategies, whether through buffets or very simple recipes.

Royal KPN of the Netherlands and iBasis have kissed and made up. The two parties announced Monday that they had settled their litigation in Delaware Chancery Court. KPN will now raise its offer to $3 a share, from $2.25, and the iBasis board will recommend the offer.

Though we've been misled by them in the past, we're fairly certain that Michael Feinstein and Dame Edna Everage are telling the truth when they say they have found a Broadway theater for their coming stage collaboration, "All About Me." On Monday, publicists for the production said that it would be performed at the Golden Theater, with previews to begin on Feb. 19 and an opening night set for March 18. That theater has recently been home to the revival of David Mamet's "Oleanna" (as well as "Avenue Q"), and was also where Mr. Feinstein performed his show "Michael Feinstein in Concert - Piano and Voice." "All About Me" will be written by Christopher Durang and directed by Jerry Zaks.

Louis Armstrong, "Dinah," filmed on a sound stage in Denmark, 1933: a very early item in his filmography. This is a short and efficient answer for why he was and is important. You sense he's building his brand - the stuff with the handkerchief, getting up in the viewer's grill, popping his eyes at .55 -- but it's still pretty extreme, and exciting. Look at how he felt music, and moved to it. (Especially .10-.20, that davening kind of thing: James Brown did that too.) Listen to the way he chopped up rhythm, sailing his phrases over the beat. You want to say he's imitating a trumpet when he sings, but then you want to say vice versa, so neither can be true. He's continuous, playing or singing something nearly all the way through, making his body part of the performance.

The Fall Classic is done, the Yankees are World Champs, Thanksgiving's round the corner, the Babe's in His Heaven and all's right with the world! So for this short working week, we're going to do some whimsical problems that require no deep mathematical concepts. After all, it's not fair to tax our brains too heavily, when all our blood supply is being diverted to our turkey-laden stomachs, turning us too, temporarily, into turkeys. Whimsical though these problems are, when you do solve them, you'll nevertheless experience the absolute certainty that is characteristic of the aha! experience we've discussed recently. "Of course that is the answer," you'll say. "There can be no doubt." Like Helen Keller discovering language, or Einstein discovering relativity, you'll need no external authority to validate your answer: you'll just know it is right.

My column today uses Sarah Palin and Mike Huckabee as a springboard to talk about how the Republican Party's biggest problem, increasingly, is less a dearth of creative conservative policy ideas than a dearth of politicians interested in embracing them and selling them. And by "sensible policy ideas," I don't mean idiosyncratic notions cooked up by a couple of twentysomething journalists working at non-conservative publications; I mean politically plausible ideas being proposed by economists and think tankers with impeccable right-wing bona fides. If the Republicans were associated with, say, Michael Boskin's stimulus ideas, Nicole Gelinas's proposals for handling Wall Street, and some combination of the Miller-Capretta and Troy-Anderson health care plans, they would be a party worth taking seriously on domestic policy. But they aren't, so they aren't. And on this front, the wonks can only do so much: In the end, you need politicians capable of picking up policy ideas and running with them. That's what the G.O.P. is waiting for. Hopefully it won't have to wait forever.

Another way to get ahead (see this week's Minimalist for 101 others) on Thanksgiving dinner is to make the gravy the night before. Start with a good strong stock, one you have made well in advance, preferably with roasted meat, a few aromatic vegetables and a bay leaf or two. Then make a roux, heating butter and flour together until they darken. Whisk the stock into the roux until it's thick, then refrigerate. When you are ready to serve, just reheat it. Presto! Gravy without hassle.

The Royal Hideaway Playacar, an adults-only all-inclusive resort in Playa del Carmen, on the Yucatán Peninsula of Mexico, is offering 50 percent off stays through Dec. 22. Stay four nights and pay for two; stay six and pay for three.

Shooting on a new film starring Tom Cruise and Cameron Diaz was halted by a stampede -- not of paparazzi, autograph seekers or moviegoers who want their "Vanilla Sky" tickets refunded, but of bulls that accidentally got loose on the set. The Associated Press reported that seven bulls broke free on Sunday during rehearsals in the Spanish city of Cadiz for a film called "Knight & Day." Mr. Cruise and Ms. Diaz were not on the set at the time, but two women, whose names were not given, were injured as the bulls ran through the city's streets to a nearby beach. The film's director, Jose Luis Escolar, said that he did not know how the bulls escaped. A spokesman for the local government told The A.P. that production on "Knight & Day" has been suspended until further notice.

Second Stage Theater said on Monday that it is extending its production of "Let Me Down Easy," a one-woman show written and performed by Anna Deavere Smith, in which various characters deal with medical care and end-of-life issues in the United States. The play, which was scheduled to run through Dec. 6, has been extended by three weeks. It will not, however, be performed from Dec. 14 through 20 so that Ms. Smith can perform "Hymn" with the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater at New York City Center as she had previously planned. The run of "Let Me Down Easy" is now scheduled to run through Jan. 3.

The restaurant synonymous with leafy hippie cooking has a new cookbook: "The Moosewood Restaurant Cooking for Health." Those who remember the original "Moosewood Cookbook," by the onetime collective member Mollie Katzen, will recall the charming hand lettering, whimsical illustrations and casual instructions ("Ok, so, you take four modest slices of good rye bread. "). The new book, published by the Moosewood Collective (members run the famous vegetarian eatery in Ithaca, N.Y.), is slicker, more comprehensive and, true to its title, healthier. That means more kale and less cheese.

Now that water has been found on the moon, it seems even more fitting that 2009 has officially been designated the International Year of Astronomy (who knew?). But let's be honest: space's heyday was the summer of '69, when Buzz Aldrin and Neil Armstrong brought a rugged, clean-cut appeal to the final frontier. It was perhaps with this in mind that Simon Page, a self-taught graphic designer, created a series of posters for the Year of Astronomy that are modeled on textbook covers of the '60s and '70s. The result is a beautiful exercise in conceptual minimalism, with a clear geometric bent that betrays Page's math-nerd origins. (He has a degree in applied mathematics and took up graphic design as a hobby two years ago.) It's hard to choose which to like best, but I'm particularly fond of the deep blue poster, below, in which Page uses diagonal lines to create interstellar objects in relief - and calls to mind the gentle descent of a meteor shower.

Even if you saw the pioneering indie band at one of their last reunion tours , this one, writes Ben Sisario, is different: they’ll be playing Doolittle in its entirety. “Released 20 years ago, it’s a spiky and allusive thing that packs anxious, violent, erotic, religious and silly ideas — visions of the surrealist horror-comedy “Un Chien Andalou,” Old Testament vengeance, sexy girls — into tight, short blasts of pop,” he writes. Hit Craigslist if you have to.

Brazil's ambitions to be a more important player on the global diplomatic stage are crashing headlong into the efforts of the United States and other Western powers to rein in Iran's nuclear arms program. Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva, Brazil's president, is set to receive Iran's president, Mahmoud Ahmadinejad, here on Monday in his first state visit to Brazil. The visit is part of a larger push by Mr. da Silva to wade into the seemingly intractable world of Middle East politics, and follows visits in the last two weeks by Israel's president, Shimon Peres, and Mahmoud Abbas, president of the Palestinian Authority.

SUSAN BOYLE ''I Dreamed a Dream'' (Syco Music/Columbia) All 12 cuts on Susan Boyle's debut album offer variations on the same aural concept: Ms. Boyle's impressively clear, steady voice with barely a catch in the throat and plain, unadorned phrasing seems to emanate from the center of a large cathedral. Most of the arrangements feature piano and hovering strings, and have no backbeats; some are flecked with guitar. Now and then a gospel chorus swells discreetly from behind, and distant drum rolls add gravity.

GOTTLIEB--Ann, passed away peacefully and with dignity at her home on November 20, 2009 after a long battle with cancer. Loving and devoted mother of Lawrence Gottlieb, Lisa Senter (Michael), Lynne Blumenstock (Steve) and Jon Gottlieb (Janet) and cherished grandmother of Andrew Senter, Victoria Senter, Alexa Blumenstock, Sarah Gottlieb, Sophie Gottlieb, Hannah Blumenstock, Joshua Gottlieb and Rosie Gottlieb, Mrs. Gottlieb (nee Lowenstein) was the beloved wife of Jules A. Gottlieb for 51 years until he predeceased her in 2000. Together Mr. and Mrs. Gottlieb founded ABCO Refrigeration Supply Corp. in 1949 and today their family continues to operate the multi-state air conditioning and refrigeration wholesale distribution company. Mrs. Gottlieb was a valued member of the Board of Directors of ABCO at the time of her death. Philanthropic and socially concerned, Mrs. Gottlieb for many years also served actively and enthusiastically on the Boards of Long Island Jewish Hospital Medical Center, the Samuel Field Y in Queens, and Temple Beth Israel of Port Washington, NY. With her husband, she was instrumental in the creation of the Ann and Jules Gottlieb Women's Comprehensive Health Center of Long Island Jewish Hospital Medical Center in 1996, which was one of the first centers in the New York City area dedicated to the multi-faceted medical treatment of women, and also founded the Ann and Jules Gottlieb Family Violence Center at the Samuel Field Y. Mrs. Gottlieb, a past president of the Service Guild of Long Island Jewish Hospital Medical Center, also was actively involved with AIPAC and its Long Island Council, the United Jewish Appeal, and the Planned Parenthood of Nassau County to which she recently donated a "PlanVan" mobile resource center to help the organization expand accessibility in poorer communities. A resident of Floral Park when she died at the age of 82, Mrs. Gottlieb also had a home in Boca Raton, FLA and for many years had lived with her family in Manhasset, NY. Services Tuesday, November 24, 11:30am at Riverside-Nassau North Chapels, 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck, NY.

David served his country in the Coast Guard and the Navy during World War II. When a daughter of South Korea's top financial regulator was married last June, one tradition was notably absent: cash-filled gift envelopes. Before entering a Korean wedding hall, guests normally line up to hand their offerings to a cashier, who opens the envelopes and registers the givers' names, and the amounts of the gifts, in a velvet-covered ledger. The practice is such a given that wedding invitations sometimes include bank account numbers so people who cannot attend can still send money.

Warner Home Video released ''Tom & Jerry Greatest Chases,'' a collection of the classic cartoons made as theatrical shorts in the 1940s and '50s by William Hanna and Joseph Barbera, in March 2000. This year, Warner released ''Chases'' Volume 2 in June and ''Chases'' Volume 3 (above) on Oct. 13. Most of this year's top DVDs are series with a devoted fan base, like ''Dexter'' from Showtime and ''24'' from Fox. In the kids/family category, Tom and Jerry are joined by two Scooby-Doo movies, along with titles aimed at the under-5 set, like those featuring Elmo and Barney. SHELLY FREIERMAN

HARGADON--Brother Kevin, FSC, Ph.D. Clinical Psychology, died peacefully on Thursday evening, November 19th. Brother Kevin, a De La Salle Christian Brother for 62 years, was a member of the Christian Brothers Community at Manhattan College before going to De La Salle Hall, a skilled nursing facility in Lincroft, NJ in August 2009. Brother Kevin, retired at Manhattan College, had been an Associate Professor of Psychology from 1981-1995 and an adjunct lecturer 1996-2000. Earlier in his professional career, Brother Kevin taught chemistry at La Salle Academy, Providence, RI and the Christian Brother Scholasticate in Troy, NY and Washington, DC. Brother Kevin also served as Executive Director at Lincoln Hall and as President of Christian Brother Academy, Syracuse, NY where he also served as Director of the Brothers' Community. Viewing will be at Christian Brothers Center, 4415 Post Road, Bronx, NY on Monday, November 23rd 2pm -5pm; 7pm9pm. There will be a vigil prayer service at 8:30pm. Mass of the Resurrection will be celebrated in the Chapel of De La Salle and His Brothers at Manhattan College on Tuesday, November 24th at 10am. There will be a viewing at the Chapel 9:15am 9:45am. Burial will follow at Gate of Heaven, Valhalla, NY. Predeceased by his parents, Mary (Houlihan) and Michael Hargadon, and a sister, Barbara Kepesky, Brother Kevin Hargadon is survived by his two devoted sisters, Margaret Conway of Rutherford, NJ and Eileen Jones of Scarsdale, NY and by many loving nieces and nephews. In lieu of flowers, donations to: DeLaSalle Christian Brothers District of Eastern North America 444A Route 35 South Eatontown, New Jersey 07724 would be appreciated.

Schoolchildren are taught to try, try again. Maybe teachers should just show a weekly N.F.L. highlight reel to get the message across. The nine teams that entered Week 11 as the division leaders (Denver and San Diego were tied for first in the American Football Conference West) were a combined 63-18 (.778). That record was 22 wins better than the same nine teams' records from a year ago at this time. THIS IS DISCIPLINE? Cleveland Coach Eric Mangini insisted last week that the Browns were making progress, and that one of the signs was that they had committed the fewest penalties in the league, after being near the bottom of the league last season. Discipline, Mangini said, would eventually pay off. The Browns are still waiting.

Elisabeth Soderstrom, the Swedish soprano acclaimed for the plangent richness and intelligence of her singing and for her wide-ranging repertory, including influential portrayals of leading roles in the operas of Janacek, died on Friday in Stockholm, her native city. She was 82. Her death came after several years of complications from a stroke, said the Swedish mezzo-soprano Kerstin Meyer, her friend and colleague, speaking by phone from Stockholm.

GEORGAS--John William, on November 21, 2009. Born in Freeport, Long Island on January 14, 1928 to William John Georgas and Helen J. Laricos-Georgas. John received a B.S. degree in Business Administration from Syracuse University, an M.B.A. from Hofstra University and completed the Harvard Business School Executive Program. In 1951, he began his career at General Foods Corporation, progressing through a variety of marketing assignments. In 1955, John married Tarsi Babis. In 1962, he joined J. Walter Thompson Company, an advertising agency; he left as Senior Vice President of the company. In 1974, John joined The Coca-Cola Company as Vice President Coca-Cola USA and Manager of Market Planning and shortly became Director of Corporate Marketing for USA and International. He was later named Senior Vice President of The Coca-Cola Company, followed by President and Chief Executive Officer of Coca-Cola (Japan) Company, based in Tokyo, and later President of Pacific Group. Mr. Georgas was an active member of the USA-China Business Council and officiated the opening of several Coca-Cola bottling plants in China. In 1984, he returned to Atlanta and named Senior Vice President of The Coca-Cola Company and President of Coca-Cola International. In 1992, he retired from The Coca-Cola Company and continued as a consultant until 1994. He served on numerous international boards and organizations. Mr. Georgas was a large philanthropist with many endowments involving the Greek Orthodox Church, hospitals, education and the Arts, most notably The Metropolitan Museum of Art in NYC. Family came first for John. He will be greatly missed by his wife, Tarsi Georgas, and children, William Georgas, Gregory Georgas and Laura Georgas-Carr. Seven grandchildren mourn their Papou: John and Sophia; Tatiana, John and Gigi; Caroline and Alexis. Family will receive friends on Monday, 4-8pm at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81st St. Funeral services will be Tuesday, 11am at The Greek Orthodox Cathedral of the Holy Trinity, 319 E. 74th St.

LEONA LEWIS Echo (J/Syco) Did it occur to no one in the Leona Lewis camp that ''Echo'' might be an awkward title for her sophomore album? Ms. Lewis, a former winner of ''X Factor,'' Simon Cowell's British music talent show, had last year's biggest-selling single in the United States in ''Bleeding Love,'' a full-throated cry of wounded resolve. The desire to repeat that success is natural, but an echo tends to be weaker than the original signal: more diffuse, less defined. Ms. Lewis, already facing the pressures of a sequel, surely could have used a more promising theme.

SHAKIRA She Wolf (Epic) You shouldn't listen to ''She Wolf,'' the first song on Shakira's album of the same name. You should flatten out its essence and put it on your fridge door, or some other graveyard of kitsch. A stilted piece of your-good-girl's-gonna-go-bad songwriting, it grasps at Eurodisco and robotic affects promising hot blood and offering cold consommé. It's so undercooked and overwritten -- with wan wolf howls and lines about being treated like a coffee machine in an office -- that it reaches a special class of fascinating-awful.

Games that were decided on Sunday late in the fourth quarter or in overtime. Baltimore's Joe Flacco threw an interception deep in Indianapolis territory that sealed the Colts' 17-15 win over the Ravens. Tony Romo's TD pass to Patrick Crayton gave Dallas a 7-6 win. David Garrard's TD pass to Mike Sims-Walker gave the Jaguars an 18-15 win over Buffalo. Matt Ryan's TD pass to Tony Gonzalez tied the score for Atlanta, but Lawrence Tynes kicked a 36-yard field goal in overtime to give the Giants a 34-31 victory over Atlanta. Sebastian Janikowski's field goal gave Oakland a 20-17 win over Cincinnati. Brandon Pettigrew's TD reception with no time left gave Detroit a 38-37 victory over Cleveland. Ryan Succop's 22-yard field goal in overtime gave Kansas City a 27-24 victory over Pittsburgh.

In a shift in the National Football League's approach to handling concussions, the league will soon require teams to receive advice from independent neurologists while treating players with brain injuries, several people with knowledge of the plan confirmed Sunday. For generations, decisions on when players who sustain concussions should return to play have been made by doctors and trainers employed by the team, raising questions of possible conflicts of interest when coaches and owners want players to return more quickly than proper care would suggest.

Warner Home Video released ''Tom & Jerry Greatest Chases,'' a collection of the classic cartoons made as theatrical shorts in the 1940s and '50s by William Hanna and Joseph Barbera, in March 2000. This year, Warner released ''Chases'' Volume 2 in June and ''Chases'' Volume 3 (above) on Oct. 13. Most of this year's top DVDs are series with a devoted fan base, like ''Dexter'' from Showtime and ''24'' from Fox. In the kids/family category, Tom and Jerry are joined by two Scooby-Doo movies, along with titles aimed at the under-5 set, like those featuring Elmo and Barney. SHELLY FREIERMAN

RIHANNA ''Rated R'' (Def Jam) Rihanna glares from the cover of ''Rated R,'' concealing one eye with a hand. ''Rated R,'' her fourth album, arrives nine months after Chris Brown, her boyfriend at the time, blackened her eye in a beating as they were driving back from a post-Grammy party. The aftermath -- his sentence to community service and a restraining order, her condemnation of domestic violence -- has filled the airwaves and Internet.

It has been a perplexing, exhausting, ultimately encouraging year to be Novak Djokovic. There was a racket change along with all the usual time changes; 76 singles victories but no major tournament titles; tactical progress but no ranking progress, at least not yet.

BERNSOHN--Lorin, deeply loved and deeply mourned by his wife of thirty years, Alison Jarvis, his daughter, Amanda, his son, Lucas, his daughter-in-law Nancy, and his brother, Paulus. Lorin Bernsohn died on November 20th at his home in Manhattan. Born in Brooklyn, Lorin was a lifetime New Yorker and started his career in music at the age of 19 as first cellist in the Buffalo Philharmonic Orchestra. He was a cellist with the New York Philharmonic for 42 years and a member of many chamber ensembles, including the Philharmonia Virtuosi of New York. A life member of the Art Students League, he was also an accomplished painter. A man of enormous integrity, Lorin was the truest of gentlemen, known for his intellect, wit, kindness and culture. He inspired us all with his uncommon courage. We will miss him profoundly. Gifts in memory of Lorin may be made to the Michael J. Fox Foundation (attn: Tribute Gifts, Church Street Station, P.O. Box 780, New York, NY 10008-0780) or WQXR, the public classical music station (attn: Development, WQXR, 160 Varick Street, New York, NY 10023). A funeral service will be held at 2pm on Tuesday November 24th at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 West 76th Street, New York NY 10023. Telephone 212 362 6600. Viewing precedes.

8 P.M. (History) SURVIVING THE HOLIDAYS WITH LEWIS BLACK The acerbic Mr. Black, right, who never met a holiday he truly liked, puts his comedy skills to use in this primer on how to live through what he calls the ''monthlong festival of consumption'' -- without losing your mind. Consulting experts on holiday history, anxiety and gift giving, and other comedians, he explores the meaning of Kwanzaa, the history of Hanukkah and the real St. Nicholas as well as why the Detroit Lions play on Thanksgiving Day and why we pop Champagne corks on New Year's Eve. He even interviews turkeys on a turkey farm and dresses up in white and red for a gig as a department store Santa. 7 A.M. (NBC) TODAY Susan Boyle sings on the plaza at Rockefeller Center to promote her new album, ''I Dreamed a Dream.''

A gas explosion at a northeast Chinacoal mine on Saturday killed at least 104 people, Chinese news media said Monday. It was China's worst mine disaster in nearly two years. Since an announcement on Saturday that 42 were dead and 66 were missing, no more survivors have been found, the official Xinhua news agency said.
BESSO--Victor, 23 Nov. 2006 . Still and always together. With love your wife, Nidia. We all miss you every day.

Union-backed groups are pressuring a handful of renegade House Democrats from New York and New Jersey to back the party's efforts to overhaul the health care system. The organizations -- including the Communications Workers of America and the Working Families Party -- say they are disappointed that these lawmakers voted against the bill approved by the House this month and left open the possibility that they could withhold political support from them or even actively oppose them in next year's elections unless they back final legislation.

It was drizzling lightly in late October when the midnight shift started at the Owls Head Water Pollution Control Plant, where much of Brooklyn's sewage is treated. A few miles away, people were walking home without umbrellas from late dinners. But at Owls Head, a swimming pool's worth of sewage and wastewater was soon rushing in every second. Warning horns began to blare. A little after 1 a.m., with a harder rain falling, Owls Head reached its capacity and workers started shutting the intake gates.

Bored with the buttons on your current phone and their limited functions? Sony Ericsson says its new cellphones will feature an Infinite Button that can connect you to friends, photos, music, videos and more. Well, the company will do this if it can deliver the phones with the buttons next year.

Anxious that Saturday's party-line Senate vote to open debate on a health care overhaul gives them little maneuvering room, Obama administration officials and their Congressional allies are stepping up overtures to select Senate Republicans in hopes of winning their ultimate support. The two moderate Republican senators from Maine, Susan Collins and Olympia J. Snowe, say Senator Harry Reid, the majority leader, reached out to them after he unveiled the Senate measure, encouraging them to bring forward their ideas and concerns.

Darkness chased Lorena Ochoa off the golf course Sunday before she was through, but she was not done. After making a bogey on the penultimate hole of a second round she had waited two days to start, Ochoa headed straight to the practice green and putted for several minutes. She did not have enough light to see the line, but that was beside the point. The top-ranked Ochoa needed time to regain her composure after another long and frustrating day at the L.P.G.A. Tour Championship at the Houstonian Golf & Country Club.

SODERSTROM--Elisabeth. The Metropolitan Opera mourns the death of soprano Elisabeth Soderstrom, who sang many memorable performances with our company over the course of 40 years. We offer our sincere condolences to her family and friends. Peter Gelb, General Manager James Levine, Music Director

So far, the United States has negotiated privately to sell back to banks the warrants it received in exchange for injected funds. Now it is starting an auction process to bring in a market price for a handful of companies' warrants, including JPMorgan's. It's sensible, but the Treasury will probably still be criticized. The government typically took warrants over shares worth 15 percent of the amount of its injection when it invested in banks under the Troubled Asset Relief Program. JPMorgan Chase, for instance, received $25 billion from the taxpayer, and the warrants gave the government the right to buy $3.75 billion worth of stock. That right, lasting 10 years, has option value. Determining it, though, has been tricky.

Last week, Skype became a newly independent company, formally separating from its parent of the last four years, eBay. Now the Internet phone company, with major offices in Luxembourg and London, is set for a significant reorganization of its management team.

WEDNESDAY'S PUZZLE - There was a recent discussion among some crossword constructors about how to clue the word NURSE. Past descriptions have included "Surgeon's assistant" or "M*A*S*H extra." The former clue seems to relegate the nurse to a mere supporting role. The latter is particularly troublesome because in both the movie and the TV show, some of the main characters were nurses and extras could be found with any job description. The implication was that all this was borderline demeaning to a noble profession and perhaps even sexist. (Constructors are overwhelmingly male. Solvers, as far as I can tell, split more or less evenly.)
First minor league coaches, then planters with orange and blue flowers, and now new old uniforms: The Mets haven't signed any players this off-season, but they are busy nonetheless.

A fire, deliberately set, at Hope for the Future Ministries in East Farmingdale, N.Y., took away a reliable source of food for the needy in Manhattan and on Long Island. But word of the fire brought in a host of donations.

Yesterday, Tuesday, Nov. 24, was The Big Day: it was exactly 150 years since Charles Darwin's "On the Origin of Species" was first published. In this book, Darwin described how evolution by natural selection works - and presented a huge body of evidence, drawn from every field of biology then known, that evolution can account for the patterns we see in nature.

A busy day in Mets-land on Tuesday. No, they didn't make any trades or sign any free agents. Rather, they announced a new retro pinstripe home uniform and completed the coaching staff that will assist Jerry Manuel in 2010.

Chase Utley, the Philadelphia Phillies second baseman, might very well be considered the National League's best player but for the presence of Albert Pujols. Utley, who hit five home runs in the World Series, finished eighth in the voting for this year's N.L. Most Valuable Player award, won by Pujols, and that is nothing new. He and Pujols are the only two players who have finished in the top 15 of the N.L. voting in each of the past five seasons. Pujols has three awards, Utley none.

Remember restaurants? I review them for a living, when I'm not answering readers' questions about cooking for the forthcoming Thanksgiving holiday. This week I write about A Voce Columbus. It's an Italian place on the third floor of the Time Warner Center, an uptown version of the A Voce off Madison Square Park where Andrew Carmellini was chef. Mr. Carmellini left before the new restaurant opened (he's now at Locanda Verde); the chef at both A Voce restaurants is Missy Robbins. She's very good -- better perhaps than the stage upon which she cooks. Have you been to either A Voce? To both of them? Which do you prefer? Let's talk about food this week, restaurant locations and the culture of dining out. Post a comment below.

A team of climate scientists, seeking to remind the negotiators who will hammer out a new climate treaty of what is at stake, has produced The Copenhagen Diagnosis, a summary of the latest peer-reviewed science on the anticipated impacts of human-driven global warming. In an interview, Richard Somerville, a climatologist at the University of California, San Diego, and a past contributor to the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change, said the case for climate change as a serious risk to human affairs was clear, despite recent firestorms over some data sets and scientists' actions.

Kelsey Grammer, best known as the star of the former NBC hit "Frasier," is in talks to play Georges in the coming Broadway revival of "La Cage aux Folles," according to two executives involved in the production. The executives, who spoke on condition of anonymity because no contract had been signed, said they were optimistic that Mr. Grammer would be on board in the role, which was played by Robin Williams in the 1996 movie adaptation, "The Birdcage."

It is disappointing that Good Morning America did not give Adam Lambert the opportunity to tailor his performance to their audience, as he did on their show in August 2009. The reign of "The Emperor Jones" continues. The Irish Repertory Theater's production of that Eugene O'Neill play will transfer Off Broadway to the Soho Playhouse next month, its press representatives said on Tuesday. The play, which stars John Douglas Thompson as Brutus Jones, the prison convict turned island autocrat, will have a seven-week run at the Soho Playhouse, with previews scheduled to begin on Dec. 15 and an opening night set for Dec. 22. For his latest exhibition, the abstract painter John Zinsser has turned to representation. Gallery representation, that is. "Art Dealer Archipelagoes," at James Graham & Sons Gallery through Jan. 5, is an installation of finely detailed drawings of maps that viewed together form an atlas of the artist's 25-year love affair with the New York gallery scene. Several of the dealer "states" included in the installation are now defunct - including Holly Solomon and John Good - but Zinsser's geographical juxtapositions remind viewers of their place in the pantheon. "There is something inherently funny about the whole undertaking," Zinsser says about the exhibit. "The groupings, the borders and implied territories, and a sense of the larger triumph and pathos - those artists who made it, and those who didn't." Also in the show: a series of "Auction Lot" drawings that trace the paths of iconic artworks into the market and, for better or worse, highlight the influence of auction houses and collectors on contemporary art history.

The folks over at College Confidential are engaging their readership today on the question, "What if you pester an admissions counselor?'' The thread began with someone who identifies herself as "Wendy aka sometimes-hyper-mom'' asking, "Is it possible to negatively impact a college's impression of my daughter by sending too many emails to the admissions counselor.''

Matt Yglesias and Isaac Chotiner both suggest that if a Republican politician were to embrace serious domestic policy ideas, Republican voters wouldn't want anything to do with him. The conservative movement tends to "fetishize stupidity," Yglesias writes, and believes that there's "something actually un-American about being thoughtful, having respect for scholarship, or incorporating any kind of nuance into your discussion." If Sarah Palin and Mike Huckabee "were interested in policy, then they would not be so appealing to the GOP base," Chotiner argues, adding that since movement conservatism "sneers at intellectuals and elites," a conservative candidate "who was interested in learning the ins and outs of the welfare state and health care policy is unlikely to ever achieve Palin/Huckabee levels of popularity with the grassroots."

Let's say you're an investor who has been following Hewlett-Packard for ages. The company's slowing printer sales concerns you, largely because you think this may be a long-term issue rather than a short-term blip. Meanwhile, you're bullish as all get out about H.P.'s services business.

Readers may remember my longtime friend Brian Nelson as the moon-faced man in the kilt - his photo and an accompanying essay appeared on the Well blog in August. Cancer treatment had changed his appearance, leaving his face and eyes swollen and unrecognizable, his voice muffled and sometimes unintelligible.

Last spring, I invaded these columns to tell about a local autism awareness music project, SingSOS!, that had been invited to perform at the United Nations. That was a high point on a long and winding road that has now led -- at last! -- to the release of the "Songs of the Spectrum" album in time for the holidays.

A train that is supposed to go nowhere seems to be going nowhere, at least for the time being. Plans by the artist Jeff Koons and the Los Angeles County Museum of Art to create an eye-popping piece of public art -- a 70-foot replica of a 1943 locomotive engine designed to dangle nose down from a 161-foot crane -- are in limbo because the museum cannot pay for it, Bloomberg reported.

Maplewood police said today that Willie Odom Jr., 41, of Freehold Borough, turned himself in to Freehold Police on Sunday in connection with the early morning armed robbery on Oct. 31 of an Irvington woman at a Bank of America ATM machine at Springfield Avenue and Jacoby Street. The police have also charged Mr. Odom with committing several other robberies in Orange and West Orange, since the Maplewood hold-up. Boston is one of those cities that can't seem to shake its reputation: forget all the cutting-edge biotech and the newfound fashion consciousness and the burgeoning food culture - for many this will always be America's capital of the buttoned-up, where kicking it old school trumps looking to the future. Yet in the space of less than a month two important new hotels have arrived here, the W and the Ames, and between them they've injected a healthy dose of the kind of modernity and style that typifies the new Boston.

Andreas Schmitz, president of the Federal Association of German Banks, said in a statement Monday in Frankfurt that a central problem of the financial crisis, in Europe at least, was not that certain banks were "too big to fail," but that they were "too connected to fail," or simply "too risky."

The London Philharmonic Orchestra said Tuesday that its former finance director embezzled $928,000 over four years. The executive, Cameron Poole, who also held the title of general manager, is accused of using the money for antiques, vacations and renovations to his London townhouse, according to British newspapers.

Even as the conventional wisdom seems to have converged on the view that despite the continuing willingness of bond investors to buy US debt at low interest rates, the deficit is terrible, scary, awful -- you know we're in herd behavior mode when phrases like "time bomb" start appearing in news stories -- a weird complacency has settled in on the state of the actual economy. We're recovering, everyone says -- no need to do anything more.

There's something disturbingly familiar about the current deficit hysteria. There's the way that fear, and a demand for action against a supposed threat, has spread despite the lack of any solid evidence to support it. There's the way that many news stories seem to present only one side of the argument, and suppress or neglect contrary evidence (e.g., writing articles about how nervous investors are turning on Japan while never mentioning that the current interest rate on Japanese long-term debt is, um, 1.3 percent).

Riccardo Muti will be making his first conducting foray into China, which has become a major destination for Western musicians and orchestras in recent years. He will conduct the Shanghai Symphony Orchestra on Dec. 31 in what is billed as a New Year's Eve concert (27 days before the Chinese New Year), an orchestra spokeswoman said. The program will consist of Verdi's overture to "La Forza del Destino," the ballet music from his "Vêpres Siciliennes," Martucci's "Notturno" and Respighi's "Pines of Rome." The concert will take place at the Shanghai Grand Theater.

Boy, if life were only like this. Woody Allen has landed another, shall we say, vivacious young actress to appear in one of his movies -- in this case, the first lady of France. Bloomberg News reported that Carla Sarkozy, the model, singer, actress and wife of the French president Nicolas Sarkozy, said in a television interview that she had agreed to appear in Mr. Allen's next film. "He offered me a role in his next movie," Mrs. Sarkozy said in the interview with Canal Plus television. "I don't know for what character, but I said yes. I'm not an actress at all," she said, according to Bloomberg News. "Maybe I will be terrible. But, in my life, I cannot let such a chance go." Under her maiden name, Bruni, Ms. Sarkozy has recorded three albums of music and contributed songs to the soundtracks of films including "(500) Days of Summer."

Joost, the struggling video Web site, said on Tuesday that it was selling most of the company to the Adconion Media Group, an online advertising and marketing company, for an undisclosed amount. The acquisition ends a long sales process that at one point was thought to involve possible interest from the cable television operators like Time Warner Cable and Comcast.

The American Symphony Orchestra is headed back to Carnegie Hall, its longtime home. Beginning with its 2010-11 season, the orchestra, led by the conductor Leon Botstein, will resume playing its concerts at Carnegie Hall, a press representative for the orchestra said. At its founding in 1962 by the conductor Leopold Stokowski, the orchestra performed its concerts at Carnegie Hall. But in 1992, the orchestra moved to Lincoln Center, where it was invited by Nathan Leventhal, Lincoln Center's president at the time, to participate in the Great Performers series. In a news release, the orchestra said that all tickets to its 2010-11 season at Carnegie Hall will cost $25. The orchestra will also remain in residence at the Richard B. Fisher Center for the Performing Arts at Bard College, where Mr. Botstein is president.

There's a perception that grunge emerged in the early 1990s. But with his photos in the new book "Grunge," Michael Lavine shows us that the '90s wasn't the beginning of grunge; it was the end. That's when Seattle's best cultural brew was watered down, piped out to the masses and sold at a steep profit. Marc Jacobs appropriated flannel. The music of the Pacific Northwest commingled with So-Cal skate culture. And you could don the ready-made trappings of this amorphous "alternative" movement simply by slinking into the nearest Pacific Sunwear.

One thing never changed about "Jon & Kate Plus 8": the kids were always a good time. Only the steeliest misanthrope could fail to be charmed by their squeals and romps. How you felt about the show, though, depended on how you felt about Jon and Kate Gosselin. If you found them boring, except for when they were irritating -- what I like to think of as the silent majority position -- then the show ran the gamut from vaguely embarrassing to borderline unwatchable.

Update | 1:02 p.m. The fallout from Adam Lambert's provocative act on the American Music Awards continues: on Tuesday, ABC said that it had canceled a performance by Mr. Lambert scheduled for Wednesday on "Good Morning America." An ABC spokeswoman said, "Given his controversial American Music Awards performance, we were concerned about airing a similar concert so early in the morning." Mr. Lambert previously appeared on "Good Morning America" in August, when he performed the Muse song "Starlight," and discussed his sexuality in an interview with "20/20" in June. The American Music Awards show was broadcast on ABC on Sunday night.

The argument to stay in school and finish that college degree just got a whole lot harder to make: the 23-year-old British playwright Polly Stenham, who was just 19 years old when she dropped out of University College London to finish her critically acclaimed play "That Face," will soon see the drama performed in New York, in a production staged by Manhattan Theater Club. In a news release, publicists for Manhattan Theater Club said that its production of "That Face," about a family struggling with drugs, alcohol and dissolution, will star Elizabeth Marvel (above, of Broadway's "Top Girls") as the family matriarch, Martha, and will be directed by Sarah Benson (who directed "Blasted" for the Soho Rep, where she is artistic director). The play is scheduled to begin previews at New York City Center - Stage I on April 29, with an opening night planned for May 18. Additional casting is expected to be announced shortly.

Denise Grady, a science writer for The New York Times, recently explored the link between a recently discovered virus called XMRV and chronic fatigue syndrome, in "Is a Virus the Cause of Fatigue Syndrome?" Here, Dr. Nancy G. Klimas, who serves on the board of the International Association for Chronic Fatigue Syndrome, responds to readers' questions. Dr. Klimas is a director of the department of immunology of the University of Miami School of Medicine and director of research for clinical AIDS/H.I.V. research at the Miami Veterans Affairs Medical Center. Donny Osmond will dance for the honor of middle-aged men everywhere in the season finale of "Dancing With the Stars" (ABC, 9 p.m.). The International Violence Against Women Act, IVAWA, is a fairly obscure piece of legislation that never gets anywhere. A turkey dinner might be just the thing for a pilgrim celebration, but if you happen to be in Madrid this Thanksgiving why not dine like a queen on stuffed partridge instead? The Westin Palace Hotel (Plaza de las Cortes 7; 34-91-360-8000; www.westinpalacemadrid.com) is offering a special celebratory menu in honor of the 200th anniversary of the peseta, which was first minted in 1809, only to be replaced by the euro in 2002. The seven-course menu, which is available through Dec. 19, is based on a banquet offered in 1866 by Queen Isabel II, the Spanish monarch whose paid mercenaries became known as "peseteros."

“Wonder Woman” may flaunt her own jewelry, but she didn’t do her own stunts. The documentary “Double Dare” traces the lives of a pair of stuntwomen, Jeannie Epper, 64 and still kickin’, who filled in for Lynda Carter, and her colleague Zoe Bell, who landed “Xena, Warrior Princess” at just 19. “This preternaturally cheerful daredevil crashes through a plate-glass window like some Tinker Bell turned Ninja assassin,” Manohla Dargis wrote. And you’ll see it all in the film, “a story about women who like to roll cars, throw punches and jump from gaspingly tall heights,” while battling the Hollywood’s greatest opponents: sexism, agism and thin-ism. It screens tonight only at the IFC Center.

Julian Plenti is the alter-ego solo project of Paul Banks, the frontman of the dapper downtown band Interpol. “But Julian Plenti is a darker, brasher and more sinister,” writes Amanda Petrusich. He “bears more resemblance — vocally, at least — to a heavy-metal frontman than to a tailored-suit-wearing art star.” Otherwise, expect some of the post-punk sounds and adoring girls. Tonight at the Bowery Ballroom with I’m In You.

Set in the 1880s, when doctors treated women’s “hysteria” by giving them orgasms, “In the Next Room, or the vibrator play” is “insightful, fresh and funny,” writes Charles Isherwood. Set in the office of a doctor who administers sexual cures, Sarah Ruhl, “one of the most gifted and adventurous American playwrights to emerge in recent years” illuminates “with a light touch — a soft, flickering light rather than a moralizing glare — how much control men had over women’s lives, bodies and thoughts, even their most intimate sensations,” he writes. It’s “a true novelty: a sex comedy,” not for teens, but “for adults with open hearts and minds.” Get your tickets now.

The Critics’ Choice column on Monday about new CDs misstated the title of Adam Lambert’s album. It is “For Your Entertainment,” not “For Your Consideration.” The column, which included a review of Rihanna’s album “Rated R,” also misstated the timing of her beating by her former boyfriend, Chris Brown. It was after a pre-Grammy Awards party, not a post-Grammy party.

A picture caption in some copies on Nov. 14 with an article about Penn’s football program in the years after a popular player killed himself misidentified the team’s opponent. The photograph showed the player, Kyle Ambrogi, being congratulated after scoring in a game against Villanova, not against Bucknell. (Ambrogi killed himself on Oct. 10, 2005, two days after a game against Bucknell.).

An article on Nov. 13 about Atavia Wilson of the Bronx, a part-time health care aide who received rent assistance through The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund, referred imprecisely to the change in benefits that will take place once she returns to full-time work, and referred incorrectly to her current allotment of food stamps. She will no longer be eligible for Medicaid and unemployment benefits once her work hours increase, but she will in fact still qualify for food stamps. And she now gets $100 in food stamps per month, not per week.

An article in some editions on Thursday about the National Book Award ceremonies, where the novelist Dave Eggers received an award for outstanding service to the American literary community, misstated his role in the founding of the independent publishing house McSweeney’s. He was the sole founder, not a co-founder.

An article on Saturday about a report that the Washington school chancellor intervened on behalf of her fiancé, now the mayor of Sacramento, who was under investigation by a government watchdog, referred incompletely to a complaint filed against that watchdog, Gerald Walpin, the inspector general of AmeriCorps. Although the acting United States attorney for Sacramento sent a complaint last April to a federal panel, saying that Mr. Walpin had withheld information when conducting his investigation, the panel found in October that there was no merit to the complaint.
A listing of American military deaths on Saturday misstated the number of confirmed dead in the war in Afghanistan as of then. It was 910, not 909. An updated list appears on Page A12 today.

An article on Monday about ballooning debt payments for the federal government misspelled, in some copies, the surname of an economist who noted that the bill for debt service would be even higher were it not for current low interest rates. He is Alan Levenson, not Levinson. And a chart with the continuation of the article misstated, in some editions, the size of debt payments due within a year that are currently paying no more than 1 percent in interest. It is $1.9 trillion, not $2.5 trillion.

The National Public Radio newscast anchor Carl Kasell, right, will retire from the job at the end of the year, NPR said Monday. But Mr. Kasell will continue to keep score for NPR’s weekly quiz show “Wait Wait ... Don’t Tell Me!” as that program’s official judge. A familiar voice for millions of morning listeners, Mr. Kassell has read the news on “Morning Edition” for 30 years. “After 30 years of waking up at 1:05 a.m.” to prepare for the newscasts, NPR said in a memo to employees, Mr. Kasell “has decided the time has come to sleep in.” He will anchor a final newscast on Dec. 30.

Carnage indeed. The new replacement cast of the Broadway hit play “God of Carnage” was off to a slow start at the box office last week, the first performances without the all-star lineup led by James Gandolfini and Marcia Gay Harden, who won the Tony Award for best actress for the production (which itself won best play). This new incarnation of “Carnage” grossed $497,779 last week, compared with $1,107,302 the previous week. The audience attendance last week was only 63 percent of capacity. Still, last week’s gross was among the largest for a play on Broadway (and bigger than grosses for some musicals last week). But by comparison, the play’s former cast had helped catapult “Carnage” into the million-dollar club of top-grossing Broadway shows. The new cast — Christine Lahti, Annie Potts, Jimmy Smits and Ken Stott — has not had the benefit of major new reviews, or anything like the rush of pre-opening media publicity that greeted the original cast. A spokesman for the production, Chris Boneau, said on Monday that the producers had expected the fall-off and noted that the new cast had higher grosses last week than the original “Carnage” cast had in its first full week of previews ($396,470) in March. He added that the producers had a “very healthy advance” in ticket sales and were “more than pleased.”.

The Museum at Eldridge Street has commissioned the artist Kiki Smith and the architect Deborah Gans to create a new east window for its 1887 synagogue, right, a National Historic Landmark on the Lower East Side of Manhattan. “We were interested to make a piece that integrated into the building but would not mimic the structure,” Ms. Smith said in an interview. The synagogue reopened in 2007 after a 20-year restoration, but there were no available records of the original window. “We decided not to try to recreate something when we did not know what that something really looked like,” said Bonnie Dimun, executive director of the museum. Instead Ms. Smith and Ms. Gans will reimagine the window, due to be completed by spring. While the design has yet to be released, Ms. Smith said it would feature the Star of David at the center “in a field of blue five-pointed stars.”.

Jez Butterworth’s play “Jerusalem,” a three-hour-plus dark comedy, won two London Evening Standard Theater Awards, which were announced on Monday, Reuters reported. “Jerusalem,” which opened at the Royal Court Theater under Ian Rickson’s direction, was named best play, and Mark Rylance, who portrayed a tax-evading stoner nicknamed Rooster, received the best actor award. The New York Times critic Ben Brantley called “Jerusalem” a “great sprawling brawl of a play,” and praised Mr. Rylance, right, for his “astonishing performance.” Mr. Rylance won a Tony Award last year for his performance in the Broadway revival of “Boeing-Boeing.” Rachel Weisz was named best actress for her performance in the Donmar Warehouse’s revival of “A Streetcar Named Desire.” The award was named after the actress Natasha Richardson, who died in March, and was presented by Ms. Richardson’s mother, the actress Vanessa Redgrave.

GIMBEL--R. Nicholas, age 58, of Bryn Mawr, PA, died in Bryn Mawr on November 19, 2009 of complications of pneumonia. Nick was a partner at the law firm of McCarter & English in Philadelphia, and a graduate of The Groton School, Yale University, and the University of Chicago Law School, where he was a member of the Law Review. After graduation from law school, he clerked for the U.S. Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit. A former editor of Litigation Magazine and Coverage, Nick was a Fellow of the American College of Trial Lawyers and a member of the American Law Institute, where he was an advisor to the Restatement of the Law Third, Restitution. He had been an Assistant US Attorney for the Southern District of NY and taught as an adjunct professor at Rutgers University School of Law, Camden. In addition to his enthusiastic tenure as a trustee of the Agnes Irwin School, Nick served as a trustee of the Committee of 70, a board member of the Philadelphia Chapter of the American Foundation for Suicide Prevention and as Chair of the Independence Hall Association. He is survived by his wife, Martha Morse, his children Martha and Anne Gimbel, his sisters Elizabeth Kitzinger and Victoria Lubin, and his uncles S Stinor Gimbel and Louis S. Gimbel 3rd. A memorial service will be held on November 29 at 4pm at the Merion Cricket Club in Haverford, PA on Sunday, November 29, 2009. Donations in his memory may be made, payable to the Philadelphia Bar Foundation, to the R. Nicholas Gimbel Fund for Legal Excellence, Philadelphia Bar Foundation, 1101 Market Street, 11th Fl, Philadelphia, PA 19107.

SONDHEIMER--Joan Charlotte (nee Salomon), beloved wife of Eric, sister-in-law of Fred, Linda, and Ruth Sondheimer, Marion and Robert Couturier, most cherished aunt of three generations of nieces and nephews from the Sondheimer, Couturier, Klein and Pick families. Born 1912 in Berlin, resettled in Ecuador and immigrated in 1946 to New York City. Lottie Joan had great empathy for all, especially her family and friends. Her great beauty, both outer and inner, will be forever remembered and sorely missed. Services: 10am Wednesday at Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 91 Street and Amsterdam Avenue. Family will receive friends at 118 W. 79th Street, on Sunday, November 29, 3-7pm. Donations in her memory may be made to Self-Help Community Services, 520 Eighth Avenue, New York, NY 10018

MALAVE--Ernesto. The City University of New York mourns the untimely passing of Vice Chancellor for Budget and Finance Ernesto Malave, our extraordinarily gifted colleague and friend, so deeply devoted to his family and the University. For over a quarter of a century, CUNY and all of its constituent colleges benefited enormously from his creativity and dedication and his deep and abiding passion to advance the best educational interests of our student body. A student leader at Borough of Manhattan Community College/CUNY, he earned his B.A. at the College of New Rochelle. He joined the CUNY staff in 1983 as an admissions advisor and was later appointed Assistant Director of Governmental Relations. He transferred to the University Budget Office in 1989, eventually being appointed Budget Director in 1998. He was named Interim Vice Chancellor for Budget and Finance in 2002 and full Vice Chancellor in 2003. He managed and communicated the most complex University budget issues with exemplary integrity, ability and success. He will be sorely missed. We extend our deepest condolences and sympathies to his beloved family. Benno Schmidt, Chairperson Matthew Goldstein, Chancellor

Anschutz Trophy after a dramatic penalty shootout victory over the Los Angeles Galaxy in Major League Soccer's championship game. Bernard L. Madoff's enormous Ponzi scheme ended on Dec. 11, 2008, when he was arrested at his Manhattan penthouse. But for some early victims, the date his crime started could matter much more than when it stopped. A motion pending in federal bankruptcy court in Manhattan contends that Mr. Madoff's long-term investors cannot accurately calculate their losses until they know whether any of their original profits were legitimate. And to determine that, the motion continues, they must know when the Ponzi scheme began.

MARKS--Linda, on November 22nd, 2009. Beloved mother of Stephanie and Emily Marks. Dear sister of Larry Appelbaum. Cherished bubby. Services Tuesday, 9:30am, at "The Riverside", 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

SYMS--Sy. The Trustees and staff of WNET.ORG, parent company of THIRTEEN and WLIW21, are deeply saddened by the passing of Sy Syms. His commitment to education drove his philanthropic dedication to many vital institutions across the nation and around the world. Sy was the first retailer to underwrite public television, and through SYMS Corp.'s generous longstanding commitment to presenting quality cinema on THIRTEEN every Saturday night, Sy encouraged art, culture and creativity throughout our region. We extend our sincere condolences to Sy's wife, Lynn Tamarkin Syms, his children, Marcy, Robert, Richard and Laura, and his grandchildren, and sisters as we mourn a wonderful humanitarian and revered member of our community. James S. Tisch, Chairman Neal Shapiro, President & CEO

From a development perspective, this town has a few problems. It is 60 miles from the nearest airport, a three-hour drive on roads so bad the trip can be nauseating. Electricity is erratic, drinking water is contaminated, the beach in town is littered with trash and nearby rivers are either clogged with an invasive weed or plagued by silty agricultural runoff that threatens the fish on offshore reefs.

EFRON--Miriam, of Queens, on November 21, 2009. Beloved daughter of her late parents, Jacob and Ida Efron, and late sister, Sylvia Miller. She is survived by her loving nephew, Dr. Leslie Miller and his wife, Debi Benoit. She was the incomparable law secretary to Royal E. Blakeman for over 50 years and was renowned for having greater knowledge of the law than incoming law graduates. GOTTLIEB--Ann. The staff and trustees of the North Shore-Long Island Jewish (LIJ) Health System are greatly saddened by the death of trustee Ann Gottlieb, a long-time friend and benefactor of LIJ Medical Center. Her long association with LIJ Medical Center began in 1958, when she became a hospital volunteer. Ann helped create the LIJ Friends Campaign, which raised funds for innovative hospital programs. With her late husband Jules, Ann established a legacy of excellence in women's healthcare. The Ann and Jules Gottlieb Women's Comprehensive Health Center in Manhasset, NY addresses women's healthcare needs through all stages of life, providing an array of resources at a single, state-of-the-art facility. The Schlanger, Gottlieb, Partners Council Breast Imaging Center in Lake Success, NY is dedicated to detecting and diagnosing breast cancer. As part of its Women's Health Conference, North Shore-LIJ created the Ann Gottlieb Award for Excellence in Teaching to honor physicians who exemplify the highest qualities of an educator. Ann's hard work, dedication and generosity will always be remembered. We extend our heartfelt sympathy to her family. Michael Dowling, President and CEO Saul Katz, Chairman North Shore-LIJ Health System

When Senate Democratic leaders first went behind closed doors to complete the health care legislation, the only women in the room were either committee staff members or officials from the White House. The senators there -- Harry Reid of Nevada, Max Baucus of Montana and Christopher J. Dodd of Connecticut -- reflected the Senate's predominant history as an old-boys' club. But to move the bill forward for full debate, the Democrats' last two crucial votes came from women: Senators Mary L. Landrieu of Louisiana and Blanche Lincoln of Arkansas.

BRODY--Frances Lasker, died at home on November 12 at the age of 93. She lived in Los Angeles, California, and had been in ill health for several years. She was born in Chicago, Illinois, and attended Chicago Latin, the Madeira School, and graduated from Vassar College in 1937. During World War II, she was serving in the Ambulance Corp when she met Sidney Brody, whom she married in 1942. She then moved to New York while her husband, a much decorated Lieutenant Colonel in the Army Air Corp, flew missions in Europe and the Pacific. After the war, they moved to Los Angeles in 1949. She was prominent in the Los Angeles community as a long-time advocate and activator of the arts, education and health. She was a Board member of Center Theatre Group, American Red Cross Southern California Chapter, former President of the UCLA Art Council, the UCLA Council of the Humanities, and Advisory Council of UCLA, a board member of The Museum Association of the Los Angeles County Museum of History, Science and Art, and, until a few years ago, served as an Overseer of The Huntington Library, Art Collections and Gardens. She organized and Chaired a number of major exhibitions for the public, including a major Picasso exhibition at UCLA to celebrate his 80th Birthday and the "Henri Matisse Retrospective of 1966", which was exhibited at the UCLA Art Galleries and The Boston Museum of Fine Arts. She was an organizer and director of a pilot program for elementary grade children, supported by the Los Angeles Recreation and Parks Department and UCLA School of Education. For her work, she received numerous Awards including the Boy Scouts of America Annual Award, the UCLA Distinguished Service Award, the Los Angeles Times Best Dressed for Her Life, and the Los Angeles Times Woman of the Year. Mr. Brody, a real estate developer, was also active in community affairs, having served as Chairman of the California Community Foundation and the Los Angeles County Art Museum. Mr. Brody passed away in 1983. Brody is survived by her son, Christopher Brody, and daughter Susan Lasker Brody, a daughter-in-law, two grandchildren, and a great-grandchild. Services will be private. Gifts may be made in her memory to the Lasker Medical Foundation, 110 42nd Street, New York, NY, 10017.

DENAT DE GUILLEBON--Jeanne-Claude. The Pratt Institute Board of Trustees and entire Pratt community are deeply saddened by the death of legendary environmental artist and Pratt friend Jeanne-Claude. Along with her husband Christo, Jeanne-Claude received an honorary doctorate degree from Pratt Institute, spoke as part of the Institute's annual President's Lecture Series, and was recognized with Pratt's prestigious Legends award. Our sincere condolences to Christo and Cyril. Pratt Institute Board Chair Mike Pratt and President Thomas F. Schutte

GOTTLIEB--Ann. The staff and Board of the Samuel Field YM & YWHA mourn the loss of our wonderful friend, colleague and Board member. She will always be remembered for her caring for others, her commitment to those in need and her dignity and leadership. She was an unwavering supporter of our programs and services, most especially our Partner Abuse Counseling Program that has helped countless individuals in abusive family situations. Ann will always be remembered with gratitude and love. We extend our thoughts and condolences to her family. Richard Tanenbaum, President Steven Goodman, Exec. Vice President & CEO

MALAVE--Ernesto. The CUNY Faculty Senate expresses its deep sorrow at the untimely death of Vice Chancellor Ernesto Malave. He was an open, attentive, and sincere colleague. We will miss his wit, intelligence, generosity, and charm. Manfred Philipp, Chair

LEVITT--Philip. Beloved Husband of the late Tillie. Devoted father of Paul and Nancy Levitt. Adored grandfather of Sarah, Elise and Julie. Services Tuesday, 10am, at "Boulevard-Riverside" Chapels, 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, L.I.

As President Obama nears a decision on a troop increase for the war in Afghanistan, he is facing increasingly vocal criticism from senior Congressional Democrats over the war's cost, the size of the United States troop commitment and the reliability of America's allies. Mr. Obama met with his war council for two hours on Monday night -- his ninth such session and, aides said, perhaps the final meeting before Mr. Obama announces his decision, which is expected next week. Administration officials are already working on the big, and potentially contentious, rollout of Mr. Obama's Afghanistan strategy.

After last summer's disputed presidential election, Iran's government relied largely on brute force -- beatings, arrests and show trials -- to stifle the country's embattled opposition movement. Now, stung by the force and persistence of the protests, the government appears to be starting a far more ambitious effort to discredit its opponents and re-educate Iran's mostly young and restive population. In recent weeks, the government has announced a variety of new ideological offensives.

GEORGAS--John William, on November 21, 2009. Born in Freeport, Long Island on January 14, 1928 to William John Georgas and Helen J. Laricos-Georgas. John received a B.S. degree in Business Administration from Syracuse University, an M.B.A. from Hofstra University and completed the Harvard Business School Executive Program. In 1951, he began his career at General Foods Corporation, progressing through a variety of marketing assignments. In 1955, John married Tarsi Babis. In 1962, he joined J. Walter Thompson Company, an advertising agency; he left as Senior Vice President of the company. In 1974, John joined The Coca-Cola Company as Vice President Coca-Cola USA and Manager of Market Planning and shortly became Director of Corporate Marketing for USA and International. He was later named Senior Vice President of The Coca-Cola Company, followed by President and Chief Executive Officer of Coca-Cola (Japan) Company, based in Tokyo, and later President of Pacific Group. Mr. Georgas was an active member of the USA-China Business Council and officiated the opening of several Coca-Cola bottling plants in China. In 1984, he returned to Atlanta and named Senior Vice President of The Coca-Cola Company and President of Coca-Cola International. In 1992, he retired from The Coca-Cola Company and continued as a consultant until 1994. He served on numerous international boards and organizations. Mr. Georgas was a large philanthropist with many endowments involving the Greek Orthodox Church, hospitals, education and the Arts, most notably The Metropolitan Museum of Art in NYC. Family came first for John. He will be greatly missed by his wife, Tarsi Georgas, and children, William Georgas, Gregory Georgas and Laura Georgas-Carr. Seven grandchildren mourn their Papou: John and Sophia; Tatiana, John and Gigi; Caroline and Alexis. Family will receive friends on Monday, 4-8pm at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81st St. Funeral services will be Tuesday, 11am at The Greek Orthodox Cathedral of the Holy Trinity, 319 E. 74th St.

Science has never given much credence to claims that you can learn Chinese or French by having the instruction CDs play while you sleep. If any learning happens that way, most scientists say, the language lesson is probably waking the sleeper up, not causing nouns and verbs to seep into a sound-asleep mind. But a new study about a different kind of audio approach during sleep gives insight into how the sleeping brain works, and may eventually come in handy to people studying a language, cramming for a test or memorizing lines in a play.

Citing cases of infants being trapped and suffocated, the Consumer Product Safety Commissionon Monday announced a voluntary recall of more than 2.1 million Stork Craft drop-side cribs. The recall comes amid growing concern about the safety of drop-side cribs, in which the cribs' side gate slides up and down. Four infants, including one in the Bronx and one in Gouverneur, N.Y., have died from being trapped in the side gates, the agency reported. It recommended that parents ''immediately stop using the recalled cribs, wait for the free repair kit, and do not attempt to fix the cribs without the kit.''

SCLATER-BOOTH--Patricia, died peacefully on November 19, 2009. Trish will be remembered for her inquisitive mind, vitality and generosity. Trish worked at the Metropolitan Museum of Art's Islamic Art department for the past 17 years and previously ran the catering company Ala Carte. She was predeceased by her beloved husband, Neil. Trish was the loving mother of two sons, Stuart and Andrew, and adoring grandmother of Eliza, Luke and Charles. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Visiting Nurse Service of New York/Hospice Care.

Some lawmakers are staking their support for a health care overhaul on whether or not it creates a government-run health insurance plan -- the so-called public option -- to compete with private insurers. But a new poll by the Kaiser Family Foundation suggests that even though the public supports a public option, most people have other, higher priorities for the health legislation. Respondents to the poll were given a list of features of a hypothetical health care proposal and asked to name which were extremely or very important to them. Among Democratic respondents, 87 percent picked ''making sure affordable health insurance plans are available'' as their top priority.

During the Giants' recent four-game losing streak, Coach Tom Coughlin did not exchange trash talk with opposing teams. His players were not seen arguing among themselves on the bench. But Coughlin, whose team broke out of its slump Sunday with a 34-31 victory over Atlanta, is a 63-year-old veteran and mature to a fault. His team reflects his personality.

The shot that Nate Robinson, bottom right, swished into the Nets' basket Saturday would not have counted even if it did come before the buzzer, although it did count as another reason Knicks Coach Mike D'Antoni, bottom left, has concerns over Robinson's maturity. Robinson's shot was immediately irrelevant because he released it after the buzzer sounded to end the first quarter. D'Antoni screamed at Robinson during the timeout and criticized him after the game when he met with the news media.

A few weeks into the holiday shopping season, consumers are still not reaching for their wallets. After a fairly robust October, retail sales slowed in November as the nation's stores entered their critical time of year. Major sectors like apparel, luxury goods and jewelry experienced slight sales declines.

Closing arguments began Monday in the trial of the former Khmer Rouge prison chief who is accused of crimes against humanity in the deaths of more than 14,000 people in the Tuol Sleng prison and torture house. One of the prosecutors, Karim Khan, said that despite what he called ''crocodile tears'' of contrition, the defendant, Kaing Guek Eav, commonly known as Duch, had ''sought to evade or minimize his role'' during nine months of hearings. Duch, 67, who is also charged with war crimes, murder and torture, faces a maximum penalty of life in prison. His is the first trial in a United Nations-backed tribunal on the crimes of the Khmer Rouge. Duch, who has admitted directing the torture and killings, is expected to speak before the trial closes this week.

BERNSOHN--Lorin. The New York Philharmonic mourns the passing, on November 20, 2009, of Lorin Bernsohn, 83, a cellist with the Orchestra from 1958 to 2000 and an active chamber musician. Our deepest condolences to his wife Alison, daughter Amanda, son Lucas, and family.

Scott Rothstein, the Fort Lauderdale lawyer accused of a $1 billion Ponzi scheme, certainly spread the money around. On Monday, federal authorities filed court documents seeking to seize his 87-foot yacht, more than a dozen properties and 20 luxury cars, including a 2009 Bugatti Veyron that sells for $1.5 million. The court filing showed as well that he had stakes in dozens of companies, $12 million in Moroccan banks and about $80,000 in American Express gift cards, all of which the government also wants, for the benefit of any defrauded investors.

The administrator for Lehman Brothers said on Monday that it planned to seek support to remove claims against the investment bank from British courts and distribute assets directly to creditors by the first quarter of next year, provided that enough hedge funds that are Lehman's creditors agree with the plan. PricewaterhouseCoopers, the accounting firm overseeing the liquidation of the London-based unit, called Lehman Brothers International Europe, plans to give out the details of the distribution plan on Tuesday.

In honoring Zimbabwe's tenacious female protesters at the White House on Monday, President Obama gave his sharpest critique yet of President Robert Mugabe, who has ruled the southern African country with repressive zeal since 1980. Mr. Obama bluntly referred to him as a dictator. ''In the end, history has a clear direction, and it is not the way of those who arrest women and babies for singing in the streets,'' he said. ''It is not the way of those who starve and silence their own people, who cling to power by the threat of force.''

Racked with guilt and cloistered in private after his blatant hand ball helped send France to the 2010 World Cup, striker Thierry Henry said he considered ending his career with the national team. ''Oh yes,'' he told the French sports daily L'Equipe. ''Friday, when it all went too far, I was very worked up.''

President Dmitri A. Medvedev called Monday for tax incentives and other measures to assist Russia's beleaguered nonprofit groups, which have come under government pressure in recent years. Under his predecessor, Vladimir V. Putin, now the prime minister, the groups were subjected to new regulations, as well as increased scrutiny that they sometimes characterized as harassment. In addition, charities and nonprofit groups have not prospered in Russia because under communism, in which the government was to take care of society's needs, there was no tradition of private philanthropy. Mr. Medvedev, above, said new laws would not alleviate all the problems the groups faced but would certainly help. ''Our main goal is the support of the authority of nonprofit groups in society, and the attraction to this sector of more talented people and philanthropic resources,'' he said. ''We need to stimulate philanthropy and create a stimulus or a motivation for volunteers who toil for such organizations.''

RIPS--Ervine, 88, of Dayton, NJ, died on November 11. He is survived by his wife, Cathy Black; his sons Ethan, Avram, and Darius; and his former wife, Gladys Nadler. A memorial service will be held at the Raritan Yacht Club, Perth Amboy, on November 29.
