President Obama returned from his trip to Asia facing some unsettling news: two new polls showed that his approval rating had dipped below 50 percent for the first time. To many of his critics, who had chafed as he enjoyed broad support among Americans even as many were critical of his handling of specific issues like the economy, this erosion is a tipping point, the end of Mr. Obama's perceived near-invulnerability.

RAUCHENBERGER--Louis J.,passed away on Sunday, November 22, 2009 at the age of 79. He is survived by his wife Elaine, and their six children Mary, Louis, Rich, John Stephen and Catherine as well as ten beautiful grandchildren. Lou served in the Navy during the Korean War. He was the Treasurer of CBS when he retired after 35 years of service. Louis and Elaine had recently celebrated their 50th wedding anniversary. Reposing will be at the Doyle B. Shaffer Inc. Funeral Home, Little Neck Pkwy. at Northern Blvd., Little Neck, NY on Tuesday 2-5pm and 7-9pm. Mass of Christian Burial on Wednesday, 9:45am at St. Anastasia Church, Douglaston, NY. Interment at St. Charles Cemetery, Farmingdale, NY.

GORDON--Adlynn Hartley, passed away on November 14, 2009, in Ulster Park, New York. She was 84 years old. Adlynn is survived and will be deeply missed by a large devoted family: her beloved husband of 61 years, Donald Lloyd Gordon, a general surgeon who practiced in New York City; five children and their spouses: Don Jr. and his wife, Lisa Cantrell; Lynn and her husband, Fred Lepore; Doug and his wife, Kim Weller; Wendy and her husband, Larry Rockefeller, and Derek and his wife, Julie Helm; eleven grandchildren and three great-grandchildren. A Phi Beta Kappa graduate of Vassar College with a passion for the theatre arts, Adlynn was a successful children's theatre producer. She founded her own company, Creative Theatre for Children, in the 70s, serving as executive producer and chair for its full fifteen years. Her productions of such children's classics as Peter Pan, Hansel and Gretel, Oliver and Annie, were some of the more popular events on the calendar for the John Harms Theatre in Englewood, New Jersey. In prior years, she produced shows for a number of volunteer organizations on whose boards she served as president, including the Auxiliaries of the Mayo Clinic in Rochester, Minnesota and Roosevelt Hospital in New York City and the Junior League of Northern New Jersey. Adlynn also taught children drama. Born in Nutley, New Jersey, Adlynn grew up in Englewood, New Jersey, graduating from Dwight Morrow High School, and returning with her husband and three children in the 1950s. She served on both the city's Board of Education and the board of the Dwight-Englewood School. After retiring in the early '90s to their home on the Hudson, Adlynn and her husband pursued a shared commitment to conservation. She served as Treasurer for Save the Esopus Meadowlands Lighthouse, near Port Ewen, New York; as Trustee for Friends of Mills Mansion, now a museum in Staatsburg, NY, and Corresponding Secretary and Treasurer for the Garden Club of Kingston, New York. Funeral Service will be at 1:00 pm Friday, November 27th, 2009, at Ascension Holy Trinity Church, 1585 US Hwy 9W, West Park NY, 12493. Gifts may be made in Memory of Adlynn H. Gordon '46 and sent to: Vassar College Office of Development, Box #

Official Defense Ministry documents leaked to a British newspaper have revealed a climate of stark animosity among senior British officers toward American military commanders after the 2003 invasion of Iraq, when Britain, as the second-largest troop provider, was cast as the United States' principal ally among about 30 nations constituting the occupation force. Confidential interviews with British officers returning from Iraq in the first year after the invasion were emblazoned across the front page of The Daily Telegraph on Monday. Partial transcripts of the interviews that appeared in the paper suggested that strains between the two allies, though known to some degree at the time, were more severe than previously acknowledged.

In his inaugural address last week, President Hamid Karzai proudly touted his country's achievements in creating an Afghanistan with a ''rehabilitated economic infrastructure'' and ''budding free-market economy.'' For the six families who live in a damaged warehouse on the southwest side of the capital, Kabul, the president might as well have been talking about another country.

The statement, on its surface, seemed like any other bland missive released at the end of a polite visit by a head of state. It was put out by the United States and China after President Obama's visit there, and said that the two countries would ''work together to promote peace, stability and development'' in South Asia. But on the eve of a visit by the Indian prime minister, Manmohan Singh, to the White House, where on Tuesday he will be the guest of honor at Mr. Obama's first state dinner, the words rank as one of several perceived slights that have dampened hopes for a new chapter in the sometimes rocky relationship between the United States and India.
President Obama and his wife, Michelle, hosted their first state dinner for their guests of honor, Prime Minister Manmohan Singh of India and his wife, Gursharan Kaur.

The Pontiac Silverdome, built three decades ago for $56 million, is being practically given away — sold at auction for $583,000. It is a fire sale that has reduced the once-proud arena to another sad symbol of the Detroit area’s economic collapse. Under the Silverdome’s air-inflated, cross-hatched silver roof, the Rolling Stones and Elvis Presley have played. So have the Detroit Lions and the Detroit Pistons. In 1987, Pope John Paul II drew more than 90,000 for a Mass there, and in 1983 Super Bowl XVI was played there.

My Thursday column looks at the literary battles over God in recent years, focusing on recent books such as Karen Armstrong's "The Case for God" and Robert Wright's "The Evolution of God." I found Wright's particularly provocative, although it's more popular than scholarly. Then my colleague Nicholas Wade's new book, "The Faith Instinct," doesn't focus on God so much as on the evolutionary advantages conferred by faith, creating a genetic predisposition to believe in divinity -- but it's just as fascinating.
Timothy Noah, left, of Slate and Byron York of The Washington Examiner debate the Senate filibuster.

Update | 7 a.m. The New York Times Thanksgiving Help Desk is open for business on Thanksgiving. I am sitting at it, armed with coffee, reference books, source lists, phone lists and all that the World Wide Web provides, prepared to answer your emergency questions about the bird, the stuffing, the sides, the gravy, the wine, how to say grace (whether to say grace!), the timing, the desserts, the fact that you said you'd make butternut squash and now you're looking at the things and realize you have no idea how to make butternut squash, whatever you need.

The Cortlandt Street station on the R and W lines, which was closed for one year after the 9/11 attack and then shut again in August 2005 to accommodate construction of the Fulton Street transit complex in Lower Manhattan, was partly reopened on Wednesday. For now, the station will only accommodate northbound service on the R and W lines, which travel to Midtown and then Queens. (The W runs only on weekdays, and the N makes stops at the station late at night.)

On the Bucks blog, a question of ethics in a restaurant: After dinner with her husband and his aunt "at a well-known restaurant in the San Francisco Bay area,'' Jennifer Saranow Schultz writes, "we realized that the restaurant had undercharged us for wine by somewhere between $10 and $30. But we also felt the food had been underwhelming.'' The aunt, who was paying, "opted to add about half the difference to the tip.'' In the end, she said, "I don't think we should have equated disappointment with the meal as a right to take half the undercharge in silence.''

For Gucci's fifth annual holiday campaign to benefit Unicef, the creative director Frida Giannini commissioned the author and illustrator Michael Roberts to create "Snowman in Africa," a sequel to his 2004 children's book "Snowman in Paradise." Filled with Roberts's signature "cutout" drawings, the book costs $25, with 100 percent of proceeds going to the charity. Roberts (wearing a winsome Santa beard) signed copies of the book last night at Gucci's Fifth Avenue flagship, while adult guests sipped Champagne and their tots munched on colorful cookies and drank milky peppermint punch. Stylish mommies cooed over Giannini's coordinating accessories, including a logo bag appliquéd with a snake-wrapped snowman ($2,250), a sporty bag printed with elephants and snowmen ($695) and cute key chains ($195 to $245). The pieces will be sold through Dec. 31 at Gucci stores and Gucci.com, with 25 percent of proceeds donated to Unicef.

Torah Bright takes the resume of your typical Olympic snowboarder and turns it on its head. First, she is from Australia, hardly a winter sports mecca, which also means she had to leave home at age 14 to pursue a snow-based career. She says she actually prefers skiing to snowboarding. Bright is unabashed about the importance of the Olympics in a sport that worships the X-Games first and foremost. And she is a devout Mormon, which means she forgoes drinking, caffeine and premarital sex.

Update | 3:34 p.m. "Going Rogue," the newly released memoir by Sarah Palin, the former Alaskan governor and Republican nominee for vice president, sold 469,000 copies in its first week of release, according to sales figures released Wednesday by Nielsen BookScan. That made "Going Rogue" the top-selling book of the week on Nielsen BookScan's chart, putting it ahead of new releases from authors like James Patterson (whose novel "I, Alex Cross" was No. 2) and Stephen King (whose novel "Under the Dome" placed at No. 3), as well as Dan Brown's best-selling potboiler "The Lost Symbol." The book will also make its debut at No. 1 on the New York Times best-seller list for nonfiction on Dec. 6.

When my editor asked me to go to Norway to write about skiing for T's winter travel issue, I figured, Why bother? I had just returned from a 10-day trip to Kitzbühel, in the Austrian Alps, and I was still tingly from the steep alpine runs and fast-paced night life. How could I top that? Then I looked up the little resort town of Geilo, in Norway, and saw how stupid I was. Geilo is a charming and gentle place. It serves as an entry to the Hardangervidda, the largest eroded plain in Europe and one of the most alien worlds I have ever encountered. Combine that with a stay in Bergen (the country's former fishing capital and its second-largest city), a corkscrew train ride past storybook Hobbit villages to the mouth of a magical-looking fjord, and a ferry ride along mountains plunging into the sea, and here's what I told my editor when I got back: Thank you. That was one of the best trips of my life.

The Environmental Protection Agency has some good news to share: Between the 2007 and 2008 model years, auto fleet fuel efficiency improved [pdf] (and average carbon dioxide emissions retreated) for the fifth consecutive year. That's not surprising, especially considering the $4 per gallon consumers paid for gasoline last year. But what is rather startling is the small size of the fuel economy gain: just 0.4 miles per gallon.

President Obama ended speculation on whether he would visit Copenhagen to help in talks on a new climate treaty with an announcement describing his plan to stop at the talks on Dec. 9 with a pledged near-term reduction in emissions, the day before he receives the Nobel Peace Prize in Oslo. Clearly, the political risk of attending the talks was greatly reduced by the recent announcement, during an Asian summit, that the talks would not produce a legally binding deal. There's little chance he could be blamed for failure, and every chance he could be credited for any breakthroughs. The announcement follows word that the United States will also unveil a near-term target for emissions reductions. The news release below lays out a list of activities planned by the United States during the talks: [UPDATE 11/26: China has anted up a Copenhagen target slowing growth in emissions relative to growth in the economy.]

Eat your heart out, Patti LuPone: a British theater actor who was irked by an impolite audience member not only halted his performance but also stepped off the stage to confront the theatergoer in question. The Guardian reported that Ian Hart, an actor whose credits include the first "Harry Potter" movie, climbed off the stage of the Duke of York's Theater in the West End at the curtain call of "Speaking in Tongues," the Andrew Bovell play, to run up to Gerard Earley, an audience member he believed had been talking during the performance. Mr. Earley told The Evening Standard of London that Mr. Hart had been swinging his arms and shouting as he came after him, but may not have made physical contact with him. Mr. Hart, who is continuing to appear in the play, told The Evening Standard that the incident was "just a lot of silliness."

Update | 3:54 p.m. Staff members on strike at the Georges Pompidou Center in Paris decided on Tuesday to extend their protest as that modern art museum weighs job cuts, Agence France-Presse reported. On Monday, museum employees and security guards walked off the job, amid fears that more than 400 jobs will be cut at the museum's Beaubourg building over the next 10 years. The French government could reduce the museum's payroll by not replacing retiring staff members; more than 40 percent of the staff at the Pompidou Center is over the age of 50, and the legal retirement age in France is 70. On Tuesday, representatives of the museum staff met with aides to Frédéric Mitterrand, the French culture minister, but a union official told Agence France-Presse that the meeting "did not go well."

The cherry-red interior of the Cappellini flagship store in SoHo has always reminded me of candy - it's the color of Red Vines, Swedish Fish, Atomic Fireballs, Hot Tamales, Abracabubbles, Cinnamon Discs, Red Hots and candy apples. So it seems fitting that from now until Jan. 3, the Italian furnishings shop will also be in the sweets business. "The Candy Shoppe: Papabubble x Cappellini" is this year's holiday installation by the curators Tobias Wong and Josee Lepage, who asked the artisanal candy makers Papabubble to create what they call a "shoppe-in-shop" just inside Cappellini's front doors. At an opening party last weekend, filled with fashionably dressed tots and their design-loving parents, limited-edition confections were stored in jars and honey pots on Cappellini's Passepartout shelves and piled high in the polished acrylic drawers of a staircase-like cabinet by Shrio Kuramata.

For research published earlier this year, physiologists at Nebraska Wesleyan University had distance-running members of the school's track and field team sit on the ground, legs stretched before them, feet pressed firmly up against a box; then the runners, both men and women, bent forward, reaching as far as they could past their toes. This is the classic sit-and-reach test, a well-established measurement of hamstring flexibility. The runners, as a group, didn't have exceptional elasticity, although this varied from person to person.

“There has never been anything on Broadway,” writes Ben Brantley, like “Fela!” about the Nigerian musical revolutionary Fela Anikulapo-Kuti. Choreographed and conceived by Bill T. Jones, produced by Jay-Z and Jada Pinkett Smith, this musical “throbs with a stirring newness that is not to be confused with novelty,” Mr. Brantley writes. In transferring from Off Broadway, it “acquired greater focus, clarity and intensity,” but its Afrobeat sound, as performed by Antibalas still makes you want to dance in the street. Get your tickets now.

“Me and Orson Welles,” the story of a teenager (Zac Efron, avec hair) who encounters Welles at work in a theater in 1937, “is necessary viewing for anyone whose imagination has been seduced by the charms of art,” writes A.O. Scott. Directed by Richard Linklater, the movie deals with some classic scenarios: boy meets girl, the vagaries of backstage life and the fun of having an oversize ego. “Art is a fairy tale we choose to believe in,” Mr. Scott writes, “and this movie, a fiction confected about real people, is too good not to be true.”

Michael Cohl, the new lead producer of the Broadway musical project “Spider-Man, Turn Off the Dark,” has approached Kevin McCollum and Jeffrey Seller, the Tony Award-winning producers of Broadway musicals and revivals including “Avenue Q,” “La Bohème” and “Rent,” about becoming producers of the show, according to three Broadway producers with knowledge of the conversations. The producers, who spoke on condition of anonymity because the conversations were private, said Mr. Cohl’s communications were in an initial phase and that Mr. McCollum and Mr. Seller did not have full financial details of the show. They have expertise in mounting large-cast shows (including Mr. McCollum’s new revival of “Ragtime”) and entertainment spectacles like “Avenue Q,” which features puppets. “Spider-Man,” which has had work stoppages this fall because of cash-flow problems that preceded Mr. Cohl, has been conceived as an extravaganza, complete with the S-Man himself swinging above the audience. Mr. Cohl, asked about Mr. McCollum and Mr. Seller in a telephone interview, said he was talking to “a lot of people,” and hoped to have news in December.

A train that is supposed to go nowhere seems to be going nowhere, at least for now. Plans by the artist Jeff Koons and the Los Angeles County Museum of Art to create an eye-popping piece of public art, a 70-foot replica of a 1943 locomotive engine designed to dangle nose-down from a 161-foot crane — are in limbo because the museum cannot pay for it, Bloomberg reported. The sculpture, estimated at $25 million, shown at right in a model, was expected to be completed in 2011 or 2012 in the museum’s entrance plaza. But the museum said the project had been pushed to 2014-15 because of the damage the economic downturn had done to its finances. Figures recently released show that its investment portfolio lost nearly a quarter of its value during the 2008-9 fiscal year, shrinking to $196 million from $254 million the previous year. Barbara Pflaumer, the museum’s associate vice president for communications and marketing, speaking of Mr. Koons’s engine project, told Bloomberg: “We wouldn’t do it unless someone funds it. Someone has to write us a check.” She added: “This is a very tough economy. Everyone has revised timetables.”.

SONDHEIMER--Joan Charlotte (nee Salomon), beloved wife of Eric, sister-in-law of Fred, Linda, and Ruth Sondheimer, Marion and Robert Couturier, most cherished aunt of three generations of nieces and nephews from the Sondheimer, Couturier, Klein and Pick families. Born 1912 in Berlin, resettled in Ecuador and immigrated in 1946 to New York City. Lottie Joan had great empathy for all, especially her family and friends. Her great beauty, both outer and inner, will be forever remembered and sorely missed. Services: 10am Wednesday at Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 91 Street and Amsterdam Avenue. Family will receive friends at 118 W. 79th Street, on Sunday, November 29, 3-7pm. Donations in her memory may be made to Self-Help Community Services, 520 Eighth Avenue, New York, NY 10018

The Nets have lost their first 14 games in a start that is threatening to make their season irrelevant before the calendar turns to 2010. The long-term future, however, looks a lot brighter. The final challenge to their plans to build an arena in Brooklyn was denied Tuesday, increasing the likelihood of the Nets' opening the 2012-13 season there. No matter where they play that season, their two budding stars -- Brook Lopez and Devin Harris -- give them the building blocks for an improved on-court product.

GORI-MONTANELLI--Riccardo. All of us at Pavia & Harcourt join in mourning Riccardo's death and in expressing our love for our longtime friend and partner. He will be sorely missed. They just don't make them like Riccardo anymore: a true gentleman, a gifted author and artist in addition to being a trusted counselor to an infinite number of clients on both sides of the ocean. Riccardo was a true Renaissance man. Our thoughts and deepest sympathy are with Margery, their children, Alessandra, Picchi and Lorenzo, and their grandchildren. We all share in your loss and sorrow.

SPERLING--Donald A. Husband of Margaret Keller Sperling. Loving father of John (Kathleen), Donald, Jim (Ginny) and Ann (Craig). He is also survived by his sister, Zoe Walsh, stepson James Holmes, grandchildren Jason, Brian, Joshua, Adam, Matthew, Kate and Eric and great-grandchildren Jessa, Peyton and Nyla. He is also survived by Jean Claudio (Ashley) and Alli Grace Sperling. He was predeceased by his first wife, Joan Runkel Sperling. Donald served as an Ensign in the United States Navy during World War II and graduated from Cornell University. He had served as President of Sprague and Rhodes Commodity Corporation and prior to his retirement, as President of Para-gon Coffee. He also served as a member of the Board of Managers of the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange and Director of the National Coffee Association. His love for fly fishing and upland bird hunting was legendary. He had been an active member of Trout Unlimited, the Anglers Club of New York, Clove Valley Rod and Gun Club, the DeBruce Fly Fishing Club and the Big Bend Club. His exuberance for life and love for his friends and family was felt by all. He will be deeply missed and always remembered. Donations in Donald's memory may be sent either to Burke Medical Research Institute, Donald A. Sperling Stroke Research Fund, 785 Mamaroneck Avenue, White Plains, NY 10605 or Trout Unlimited, 1300 North 17th Street, Suite 500, Arlington, VA 22209. Memorial to be announced for January.

SCLATER-BOOTH--Patricia, died peacefully on November 19, 2009. Trish will be remembered for her inquisitive mind, vitality and generosity. Trish worked at the Metropolitan Museum of Art's Islamic Art department for the past 17 years and previously ran the catering company Ala Carte. She was predeceased by her beloved husband, Neil. Trish was the loving mother of two sons, Stuart and Andrew, and adoring grandmother of Eliza, Luke and Charles. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Visiting Nurse Service of New York/Hospice Care.

BERNSTEIN--Leon, died November 9 at age 92. Son of the late Sarah and William Bernstein. Beloved husband of the late Harriet Bernstein. A devoted father, grandfather, and great-grandfather, he is survived by daughter Sally Germain and son-in-law Allan Beinhorn, son Iver Bernstein and daughter-in-law Kay Sherman; grandchildren Benjamin Bernstein and Nina Bernstein, Paul Germain and wife Jennifer Germain; and great-grandchildren Sophie Germain and Eli Germain. An institutional food distributor and broker for nearly 70 years, he was a unique entrepreneur. Having successfully sold and rebuilt his food brokerage company Bernco Sales three times rather than retire, he was looking forward to starting it yet again at the age of 90. He will be missed. Donations in his name may be made to Great Neck Public Library, 516-466-8055.

NELSON--Brian Anthony, of Brooklyn, NY, died November 22. Born in Bronxville, NY on December 13, 1958, he moved with his father and brother Craig to London in 1962. He was educated at Edge Grove and Sherborne in England, and graduated from the University of Vermont in 1980. Suffering from kidney failure because of diabetes and nephritis, he was unable to pursue a career in his first love, the theater. For twelve years he was a successful insurance agent, then took an MBA in theater management at Columbia University. In spite of deteriorating health, he subsequently worked both on and off Broadway. Brian was long a member of the Amateur Comedy Club, where he both acted and directed with distinction. The club became his extended family and he was made an honorary life member in 2008. Brian contracted cancer in 2004 and was faced with impossible odds, which he fought, as always, with unfailing bravery and humor. His recent blog posts about his struggle can be seen at briananelson.blogspot.com or by searching well.blogs.nytimes.com. He is mourned and greatly missed by his wife, Diane, his parents Merlin and Janet, his brothers Craig and Rolf and his sister Claudia. A service will be held at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine in December on a date to be announced.

Kelsey Grammer, best known as the star of the former NBC hit ''Frasier,'' is in talks to play Georges in the coming Broadway revival of ''La Cage Aux Folles,'' according to two executives involved in the production. The British actor Douglas Hodge is set to reprise his role as Albin from the current London production of the show. The executives, who spoke on condition of anonymity because no contract had been signed, said they were optimistic that Mr. Grammer would be on board in the role, which was played by Robin Williams in the 1996 movie adaptation, ''The Birdcage.''

With the Colts at 10-0, it's hard to imagine that anyone on their team would be underrated. But did you know that defensive ends Dwight Freeney, below, and Robert Mathis have combined for 18 sacks this season? There have been 11 pairs of defensive ends who have combined for 28 or more official sacks in a season. Freeney and Mathis could join them. The two also need 15.5 sacks over their last six games to set the season record for most sacks by a team's top two defensive ends. Additionally, Freeney (9.5) and Mathis (8.5) could become the first pair of defensive ends on the same team to each record 15 sacks in a season. CHASE STUART

On the Diner's Journal blog, Sam Sifton has been answering readers' questions about cooking for Thanksgiving. He will offer advice until 3 p.m. on Thursday at nytimes.com/dinersjournal. Q. I am having 32 people for the holiday. Usually I prepare one turkey and my sister-in-law brings another. Last night she told me she cannot do it -- oh my. Everyone else is from out of town. We eat at about 3 or 4 p.m. I have only one oven! Suggestions on timing and keeping the second turkey warm, when to start it, carve, etc? (I usually follow the high heat cooking.) -- Denise K., Piermont, N.Y.

Turnover or Not? On the final play of the Bengals' loss Sunday at Oakland -- which seemingly took place in front of more seagulls than people -- Carson Palmer heaved a desperation pass that was intercepted on the 7-yard line by Nnamdi Asomugha. The CBS play-by-play announcer Kevin Harlan described it as ''another turnover for the Bengals.''

How good was Patriots receiver Wes Welker against the Jets on Sunday? By posting career highs for catches (15) and yards (192), he got Bill Belichick to do something that he had steadfastly refused to do for more than a week: admit he was wrong. Belichick had watched miles of film of Welker, then a Texas Tech junior, before the Patriots drafted his Red Raiders teammate Kliff Kingsbury in 2003. On Monday, Belichick acknowledged, ''We got the wrong guy.''

KANOKOGI--Rusty. Tripp Lake Camp mourns the death of our dear friend. Rusty touched the lives of thousands during her 43 summers with us. She was revered by all as a woman of compassion, dedication and courage. Our heartfelt condolences to her family.

Rusty Kanokogi, considered the mother of women's judo after fighting for more than two decades to make it an Olympic sport, died Saturday in Brooklyn. She was 74. The cause was complications of multiple myeloma, a cancer of the plasma cells, her daughter, Jean, said.

A report in the Prescriptions column on Monday about the Senate health care debate misstated the proportion of the population, including Medicare beneficiaries age 65 and over, that would be covered by 2019 if proposed legislation is adopted. It would be about 94 percent, according to the Congressional Budget Office; counting people age 65 and older would not make the projected total 98 percent.

All of us at Columbia extend our condolences to his daughters, Sarah Rath and Marjorie Curtsinger, and the rest of the Hatch family. Lee Goldman, M.D. Dean of the Faculties of Health Sciences and Medicine Executive Vice President, Columbia University

How does a team as offensively challenged as the Browns (five offensive touchdowns in their first nine games) end up playing in one of the highest-scoring games of the season? One reason was their defensively challenged opponent, the Lions, who won, 38-37, on the final play. But another was that they ran the no-huddle offense on more than half of their offensive plays.

One of the bright lights on the political horizon for Republicans in 2010 is the United States Senate seat that opened up in Delaware when Joseph R. Biden Jr. became vice president. Party leaders recruited Representative Michael N. Castle, a former governor and a member of Congress since 1993, a candidate who Democrats and Republicans believe would have a strong chance to take the seat from Democrats. Democrats are looking to Mr. Biden's son, Joseph R. Biden III, the attorney general, as their possible candidate. (The Democrat appointed to replace Vice President Biden, Ted Kaufman, has said he will not run for a full term.)

On a holiday rivalry weekend like this one, one game seems to stand out above the rest: Alabama at Auburn. But, since the No. 2 Crimson Tide are favored and a victory by the Tigers, while possible, would be a major upset, we're staying away from that matchup in this week's picks. Besides, there are plenty of other intriguing games this weekend, beginning with Friday's Backyard Brawl between Pittsburgh and West Virginia. Oklahoma and Oklahoma State, and B.Y.U. and Utah will face off in tense in-state rivalry games, while Les Miles will try to put his last-minute time mismanagement debacle behind him when Louisiana State faces Arkansas. But the coach whose seat is at the highest temperature right now is Charlie Weis. Notre Dame faces Stanford on Saturday, and has a chance to get a victory for Weis in what may be his last game as the Irish's coach. Will Jimmy Clausen and crew come through for Weis? Our prognosticators have made their selections, and you can let us know what you think of them. If you agree, disagree or merely find the picks laughable, feel free to drop a comment below.

FRIDAY'S PUZZLE - Ed Sessa's fine previous puzzle was about dropping letters from theme clues (Across Lite, Solution). This seems to be a personal theme for him as well. In his debut puzzle, a Monday I also enjoyed (Across Lite, Solution), he billed himself as Edward M. Sessa. By puzzle No. 2 he was down to Edward Sessa, and today he's a mere Ed Sessa. Letters are starting to get critical at this point, so who knows what he'll be next. In any case, you now have links to all his puzzles and you can solve his entire oeuvre. And remember, you can find the entire New York Times daily and Sunday puzzle archive organized by constructor here, so look up your favorite and print out a set of puzzles for a rainy weekend.

For some reason, a couple of pro football games on Thanksgiving Day get all the credit. That's what people think of when they think of football and Thanksgiving. I would argue that Thanksgiving pro football is like turkey. It's good enough, but needs some accoutrement to go with it. Maybe some cranberry sauce, or at the very least some stuffing and sweet potatoes. A weekend of rivalry games like this one coming up? That's something a little more nuanced for a more delicate and refined palate. I would argue that this weekend of college games is more like the turducken, a complex and multi-layered Russian doll of food, that never fails to surprise with it's confusing flavor juxtapositions and horrific caloric implications.

Among the hundreds of things I miss about home during my year in Iraq is the Turkey Day bike race in Lancaster County, Penn. This unofficial final race of every season draws 50 or more racers from around the county, and it shows which cyclists kept up with their fitness routines since the end of the season in September. So when I finally got a chance to organize a bike race on Tallil Ali Air Base after six months here, I wanted it to be on Thanksgiving Day.

Volvo's sensuously styled XC60 is a far cry from the company's old boxy station wagons, right down to its writhing, wriggling taillights. With their LEDs positioned in a pattern so the car is easily recognizable from the rear at night, the XC60's taillights shun the straight edges or smooth circles of traditional taillights in favor of a wavy shape -- a distinction that is now being honored in a design exhibition at the Serpentine Gallery in London.

Today's idea: Cancer, not the presumed hypertension, caused the brain hemorrhage that killed President Franklin D. Roosevelt, a new book argues. If widely known at the time, cancer might have prevented F.D.R. from seeking a fourth term, shifting the course of postwar history.History | Writing in Slate, Barron H. Lerner lays out the case set forth in "F.D.R.'s Deadly Secret," a book due out in January by Steven Lomazow, a neurologist, and Eric Fettman, a journalist. Looking at the president's secretive medical history, the two theorize that a skin lesion above Roosevelt's left eye, which disappeared in photographs after 1940, was in fact a melanoma, the deadliest of skin cancers, and that the disease eventually spread to Roosevelt's abdomen and brain:

The British author Simon Kuper was born in Uganda in 1969 and grew up in London and Leiden, the Netherlands. He is currently a Paris-based sports columnist for The Financial Times. His book "Football Against the Enemy" won the William Hill Sports Book of the Year award for 1994. He is also the author of "Ajax, the Dutch, the War." His most recent book, "Soccernomics: Why England Loses, Why Germany and Brazil Win, and Why the U.S., Japan, Australia, Turkey - Even Iraq - Are Destined to Become the Kings of the World's Most Popular Sport," written with the economist Stefan Syzmanski, was published in the United States in early November.

Among those in the theater industry who were surprised on Tuesday by the announcement that the Irish Repertory Theater’s production of “The Emperor Jones” would be transferring to the SoHo Playhouse were the producers of “Made in Heaven,” the show that is playing at that Off-Broadway theater. On Wednesday the producers of “Made in Heaven,” a comedy that opened at the SoHo Playhouse on Nov. 2, said that they had no intention of vacating the theater to accommodate “The Emperor Jones,” starring John Douglas Thompson, above, which is supposed to begin previews there on Dec. 15. The “Made in Heaven” producers said that their contract with the playhouse stated that they must give the theater four weeks’ notice before closing the show. In a statement, Barbara Ligeti, the show’s lead producer, said, “I am bemused at the image of the cast of ‘Emperor Jones’ sitting in the laps of the company of ‘Made in Heaven’ on that small stage. The (conjoined) twins will love it.” It was unclear whether the show’s contract with the SoHo Playhouse included an out clause that permitted the theater to close the show if its grosses dipped below a certain dollar amount. Representatives for Darren Lee Cole, the plahouse’s general manager, and Ciarán O’Reilly, the producing director of the Irish Rep, said that both men were traveling and could not be reached for comment.

BONDS--William "Scott" Shepherd, passed away on November 20, 2009 of liver cancer. Born in Bayside, Queens, New York on June 13, 1927. Scott leaves behind his sons, Michael S. Bonds, Peter J. Bonds, Jonathan M. and Michelle Bonds, and daughter Cindy M. Bonds. Scott also leaves behind extended family in Alabama, Georgia and Florida. Scott served in the Navy during WWII. Scott received a bachelor's degree from Columbia University and a law degree from the University of Michigan. Scott worked on Wall Street as a lawyer and investment advisor until he formed his own investment firm, William Scott Bonds & Associates. Any gifts in Scott's name should be directed to the Jansen Memorial Hospice, 69 Main Street, Tuckahoe, NY 10707.

Dennis Cole, a chiseled former model whose face became familiar to television viewers in the 1960s when he played the first of his panoply of roles in more than a dozen prime-time series, died on Nov. 15 in Fort Lauderdale, Fla. He was 69 and lived in Fort Lauderdale. The cause was renal failure, said Mr. Cole's publicist, Edward Lozzi.

SANDELMAN--Sanford, of Boca Raton, Florida, formerly of Scarsdale, New York, died on November 25 at age 84. Sandy was the devoted son of the late Esther and Nathan Sandelman, adored husband of over 59 years of Susan, loving father of Jeffrey and Alison (Andrew), cherished grandfather of Brooke (Scott), Nicole (fiancee of Matthew), Grant, Steven and Elyse, and great-grandfather of Evan. A graduate of New York University School of Commerce (undergraduate and graduate), he served as a navigator in the United States Air Force during World War II, was a certified public accountant, a partner in a New York Stock Exchange member firm, and then founded and served until his death as Chairman of Kin Properties, Inc. of Boca Raton, Florida. He was a philanthropic supporter of numerous Jewish charities locally and in Israel. His wisdom, generosity, warmth and devotion to his family and friends will be forever missed by all. Services will be held at Gutterman Warheit Memorial Chapel in Boca Raton, Florida on Thursday, November 26 at 10am; funeral at Sharon Gardens in Valhalla, New York on Friday, November 27 at 1:30pm.

9 A.M. (NBC) 2009 MACY'S THANKSGIVING DAY PARADE Look, up in the sky! It's the Pillsbury Doughboy! It's Spider-Man! It's Ronald McDonald! And they're not the only additions to this 83rd near-annual parade (it missed a few years during World War II), which breaks with tradition to sidestep Broadway in favor of Seventh Avenue and the Avenue of the Americas. The lineup features the first new Santa float in almost a half-century, an appearance by the Speed Racer Mach 5 and a Sailor Mickey Mouse giant helium balloon. Scheduled performers include the casts of ''Yo Gabba Gabba!'' and the Big Apple Circus, Andrea Bocelli, Boys Like Girls, D J Lance Rock, Gloria Gaynor, Jane Krakowski, Ziggy and Judah Marley, Katharine McPhee, Jimmy Fallon, Keke Palmer, Carly Simon and Miss America 2009, Katie Stam. Meredith Vieira, Matt Lauer and Al Roker are the hosts. NOON (NBC) THE NATIONAL DOG SHOW PRESENTED BY PURINA More than 2,000 dogs in 150 breeds -- including Uli, the top-ranked bulldog in the country and one of five dogs from the New York area -- congregate for this annual show hosted by the Kennel Club of Philadelphia. John O'Hurley (''Dancing With the Stars,'' ''Seinfeld'') and the dog expert David Frei are the hosts. The show will help raise money for the University of Pennsylvania School of Veterinary Medicine.

COSTELLO--Timothy, age 65, of New York City and Shelter Island, NY on November 25th, 2009, beloved husband of Kathryn. The family and friends salute the extraordinary care he received from Dr. Byron Thomashow, Columbia Presbyterian Hospital Lung Transplant Team, and CTICU. SIMMONS--Warren H.,Jr., 82, of Princeton, New Jersey, on Sunday, November 15th, 2009. A graduate of Princeton University, class of 1948, he served as Senior Corporate Vice President for Personnel and Industrial Relations for R. H. Macy & Co. and traveled throughout the states and abroad implementing the establishment of each store in its new retail location. Father of the late Warren H. For a few fleeting moments in its 81-55 victory over Louisiana State on Wednesday night, Connecticut looked as if it had not skipped a beat since the Final Four. Seconds after tip-off at Madison Square Garden, L.S.U.'s Bo Spencer tore away for the simplest of layups. But as he rose under the basket, a hand appeared above him from nowhere, smacking the ball onto the glass and leaving Spencer wondering how he had missed the hulking presence of Charles Okwandu behind him.

This much is known: About 7:15 Tuesday night, a glittering blonde, decked out in a red and gold sari, holding the hand of her black-tuxedoed escort, swept past the camera crews and reporters camped out to catch the red-carpet arrivals for the first state dinner given by President Obama. ''Hey, that's a Desperate Housewife!'' one reporter yelled out, alluding to the TV series named for a collection of them.

Italian prosecutors on Wednesday asked a judge to give prison sentences to three Google executives and one former executive accused of defamation and failure to comply with privacy laws. The prosecutors contend that Google was negligent because it allowed a video of high school students bullying a disabled classmate to remain on its Italian-language video service for two months in 2006. The company, which is based in Mountain View, Calif., says it removed the video several hours after being alerted of its existence.

In 10 games this season, safety Kerry Rhodes has recorded an equal number of interceptions, sacks, forced fumbles and fumble recoveries -- zero. Because of that, and because the Jets are 4-6, Coach Rex Ryan has demoted Rhodes for their game Sunday against Carolina. Safety Eric Smith will replace Rhodes in the Jets' base defense, but Rhodes will continue to play in nickel and dime personnel groups.

Senator Ben Nelson, Democrat of Nebraska, has offered up an interesting explanation for his vote to move forward with debate of major health care legislation: he stopped his fellow Democrats from playing parliamentary hardball that he said would have led to a fast-tracked bill and ''sidelined'' centrists like himself. In an op-ed article in The Omaha World-Herald, Mr. Nelson suggested that if he had not agreed last Saturday to start formal debate on the health care bill, Senate Democratic leaders would have employed a tactic known as reconciliation to pass the legislation with a simple majority of 51 votes.

The governing body of European soccer, known by the acronym UEFA, said Wednesday that it was investigating the possible involvement of three referees and one ''other official connected to UEFA,'' in what the organization called the biggest match-fixing scandal in Europe. After a meeting at its headquarters in Nyon, Switzerland, with officials of soccer associations from nine countries involved in the case, UEFA said it suspected five clubs, all in Eastern Europe, of involvement in efforts to manipulate the outcome of games for gambling purposes. UEFA said it had questions about seven matches under its jurisdiction, including one in the Champions League, the prestigious competition for elite European clubs.

ZUCKER--Del. 97. A charming man of great intellect and wit, with a large repertoire of amusing anecdotes and poetry; worldly yet unpretentious, the truest of gentlemen. Graduate of Columbia College and Law School. Beloved and cherished husband of Frieda, and loving and adored brother, father, grandfather, great-grandfather, uncle, granduncle and great-granduncle. He inspired all with his uncommon courage. In our hearts forever. Services: Friday, 11:30am at Riverside, 76th and Amsterdam.

GORI-MONTANELLI--Riccardo. All of us at Pavia & Harcourt join in mourning Riccardo's death and in expressing our love for our longtime friend and partner. He will be sorely missed. They just don't make them like Riccardo anymore: a true gentleman, a gifted author and artist in addition to being a trusted counselor to an infinite number of clients on both sides of the ocean. Riccardo was a true Renaissance man. Our thoughts and deepest sympathy are with Margery, their children, Francesca, Alessandra and Lorenzo, and their grandchildren. We all share in your loss and sorrow.

There has been plenty of blame to go around in the nearly three years since the housing bubble popped. Some fault the homeowners who failed to heed the fine print; some say that the banks, pushing mortgages to unqualified, financially unstable borrowers, deserve the blame. A report published last week by the Furman Center for Real Estate and Urban Policy at New York University found that those who lived in predominantly nonwhite neighborhoods were more likely to obtain high-cost subprime loans. Nationally, more than eight million homes have been foreclosed on since the housing boom first gave way to widespread mortgage delinquencies in early 2007; in New York City, at least 15,000 properties have been foreclosed on this year, according to RealtyTrac, which collects foreclosure data. When Nassau and Suffolk Counties are added, the number jumps to roughly 25,000.

As New England Patriots Coach Bill Belichick labored over his infamous fourth-and-2 decision against the Indianapolis Colts on Nov. 15, little did he know that he was about to set off one of the season's great debates. Of course, if Belichick had succeeded -- if the Patriots had gotten a first down from their 28-yard line with two minutes remaining while nursing a 6-point lead -- the postgame discussion would be quite different. When a choice results in success, we attribute brilliance. When it fails? That is another matter altogether.

THOMPSON--David William, 95. Retired executive, business educator, and college professor. Dearly beloved and adored husband of Shirley "Sybil". Born September 3, 1914, in Fort Wayne, Indiana, a son of William Byron and Georgia Louise (Davis) Thompson. Died November 19, 2009 in New York City. David was a quiet and dignified gentleman who brought strength, wisdom, love and a sense of humor to those who knew him. He lived his life with joy, and a generosity that affected everyone around him. He and his famous smile will be greatly missed. Visitation Sunday, November 29, Frank Campbell Funeral Home, 1076 Madison Avenue, New York City, from 2 to 5 and 7 to 9pm. Funeral Service Monday, November 30, 2009, at 11:00am, Park Avenue United Methodist Church, 106 East 86th Street. Burial will be in the family cemetery in Indiana.

UNTIL recently, any pants could be considered biking pants: all you had to do was roll up the cuffs or wrap some Velcro bands around your calves. But for people who commute by bicycle, those were not ideal solutions. Spending too long on a bike in regular trousers can wear out the seat of the pants. The rear pockets may rip from too many miles carrying a U-lock and the cuffs may get scarred with grease or shredded from encounters with the chain.

In summer, the Grand Canyon is the Disney World of national parks, with crowds and traffic jams. But as Henry Shukman discovers in this week's cover story, it's a different word in the winter, a peaceful retreat with a small smattering of visitors hiking down to the canyon floor to spend the night in a rustic lodge. It's a place where the ranch bell rings for dinner and where guests while away the evening playing card games, swapping life stories and congratulating themselves for being here in December and not July.
After many false starts, the cabin's generator is now operating -­ or so I'm told by the electrician who drove out this week to have a look.

To eke out a narrow re-election victory over the city's understated comptroller, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg spent $102 million of his own money, or about $183 per vote, according to data released on Friday, making his bid for a third term the most expensive campaign in municipal history.

For loyal fans of the Norwegian pop star Annie, it's been a long four years since the electro-songstress won critical acclaim and achieved cult status with her debut album, "Anniemal." But the dry spell is over: Annie is back with "Don't Stop," a record that manages to move her into more musically complicated territory while still keeping her firmly planted on the dance floor. As she juggled D.J. gigs and rehearsals for her spring tour ("Maybe in March or April," she says. "I'm not sure if I'm starting in Europe or the U.S., but I'm definitely coming back to the U.S. for some shows"), The Moment sat down with the Scandinavian chanteuse to talk about inspirations in and out of the studio.

The online holiday shopping season officially begins Monday. So in this week's Your Money column, I explored different ways to get cash back on your online purchases, earn extra credit-card rewards, or land other discounts.

This past Sunday I stopped by the Pop-Up Flea, a temporary men's-wear-centric collection of clothing and accessories stands curated by the guys at the blog A Continuous Lean. The vibe was decidedly vintage Americana, with temporary "stores" by brands like Gitman Brothers, Jack Spade, Rogues Gallery, Schott, J. Crew, Bill Amberg and Alexander Olch. The wares were cool and the shoppers even cooler: off the charts in hip per square inch. Tucked away in a corner among all the old favorites was a booth whose name I didn't recognize. I went in for a closer look after spotting some camel toggle coats from Gloverall and heavy knit cardigans from the obscure Danish seafaring knitting company SNS Herning. The stand belonged to a brand new online-only men's-wear shop called C'H'C'M', which stands for Clinton Hill Classic Menswear. It was started in March 2009 by Sweetu Patel, a former furniture designer whose selection is skewed heavily toward classic brands like Borsalino, Saint James, Mackintosh and Drakes, as well as other finds like Northern Waters, a Canadian-based knitwear company, and Individualized Shirts. Look for a pop-up shop of its own in January at Audiovisual Arts on First Street in the East Village, where it will break out new spring merchandise. Kick off your shoes because I'm feeling for online shopping at C'H'C'M'.

Inwood, the northernmost neighborhood in Manhattan, is a place of hills and history. Inwood Hill Park, 196 acres of tree-filled landscape, dominates the scene, and traces of Lenape Indians and Dutch settlers abound. But there are relative newcomers, too, including opera singers and others who are attracted to Inwood's growing arts community. One artist who lives there - and grew up there - is Lin-Manuel Miranda, the Grammy- and Tony-winning creator of the Broadway musical "In the Heights." The expedition begins at the 207th Street station, the terminus of the A train.

This morning's post on Lincoln University's fitness requirement, one linked to a student's body mass index, has drawn more than 40 comments. Some readers are outraged by what they see as a discriminatory policy; others are heartened by the university's efforts to promote healthy habits.

A wide variety of consumer-focused stories appears in various sections of The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them all up here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.
Chile has saved its spot in the 2010 World Cup in South Africa after a domestic relegation dispute threatened FIFA action.

In a ruling (PDF) issued on Wednesday, California Superior Court Judge Peter Busch gave San Francisco the go-ahead to proceed with several aspects of the city's proposed bike plan to make its streets more hospitable to bicyclists.

To you football fans who were hoping that Super Bowl XLIV would be headlined by Lady Gaga: better luck in 2011. The National Football League announced that The Who, the long-lived British rock act led by Roger Daltrey and Pete Townshend, will perform at the halftime show, that annual occasion for bathroom breaks and (hopefully) not ripping off anyone's clothes. The Who's booking had been reported on Sports Illustrated's Extra Mustard blog, but the N.F.L. did not officially confirm it until Thursday, during a game between the Oakland Raiders and the Dallas Cowboys. Super Bowl XLIV is scheduled for Feb. 7 in suburban Miami; previous halftime performers have included Bruce Springsteen and the E Street Band, and Tom Petty and the Heartbreakers, though the only ones you probably remember are Janet Jackson and Justin Timberlake.

Last week, Ferrari issued a recall on about 2,400 1995-99 355 and 355F1s in the United States. The reason? A nonfactory mechanic improperly installed "certain screw clamps that are located in close proximity to the fuel lines and that fasten the water sleeve to the thermostat connection."

The Louisville-based literary magazine The Lumberyard, the most physically beautiful new journal I've seen this year, is a brother-and-sister operation. It's the product of Jen and Eric Woods, collaborators who describe themselves on the magazine's Web site as rural kids --- their father was a carpenter - who grew up "climbing the rafters and rolling in the sawdust of a lumber supply shed in the 1970s."

Instead, the booking has led to further complaints from those who say Mr. Lambert has been subjected to a double standard.

Gathering around a warm hearth did not happen in many Bay Area homes on Thanksgiving Day, due to a Spare the Air warning that banned wood burning both inside and outside the home. The ban applied to the 1.4 million fireplaces and wood burning devices in the Bay Area; violators risked receiving a warning (for first-time offenders) and a fine of up to $400 for subsequent violations.

Recently, while scheduling a doctor's visit for my daughter, the receptionist asked for a credit card to secure the appointment. The specialist didn't take insurance, charged $600 a visit and would charge my credit card if I canceled with less than 48 hours notice.
This weekend, co-vocabularists are invited to devise new eponyms - words named after people.

The announcement today that BMW has decided to sell the team back to Peter Sauber is good news for anyone concerned about the direction the buying of new teams may be going in F1. It's also reassuring to see a car manufacturer behaving a little more responsibly than we have begun to expect. BMW has dropped the deal with the previous somewhat shady buyer, and has decided to accept a sale of the team back to Peter Sauber, the original owner.

As a student filmmaker, Fred Guerrier usually sees what he does through the camera's tiny viewfinder or the editor's smallish screen -- or on YouTube. But for the last couple of weeks, a short film he made has been showing on a screen bigger than the ones in most movie theaters.

How much would you pay for two sweaty vests that have been worn out by weeks of use in a Broadway play? Wait, don't answer yet: How much would you pay if those two sweaty vests had been worn for weeks by Daniel Craig and Hugh Jackman, the stars of "A Steady Rain"? Audiences got their answer on Wednesday when Mr. Craig and Mr. Jackman sold their apparel (and any lingering pheromones they might contain) at a post-performance auction at the Gerald Schoenfeld Theater. BBC News reported that the vests were sold for $3,500 each; originally only one vest was going to made available, until a female audience member shouted at Mr. Jackman, "How much for the pants?" (Mr. Jackman offered up a second vest instead of his trousers.) The clothing and other items, including autographed posters and programs, were sold to raise money for Broadway Cares/Equity Fights AIDS.

Jim Hamilton has a post challenging my optimistic view about current deficits. I won't go through it in detail, except to notice that Jim seems to be slightly rewriting history about his earlier analysis, which I critiqued back in August. What was then a seeming demonstration of the impossibility of servicing the debt -- but in fact demonstrated no such thing -- has now become just an effort to "personalize" the issue. OK, I guess.

"Green Lantern: Agent Orange," written by Geoff Johns and illustrated by Philip Tan, is the top-ranking new hardcover on our list this week. It arrives at No. 2 and tells the story of Agent Orange, the latest light-based warrior to encounter Green Lantern. The story can be enjoyed on its own merits, but it also serves as a tie in to "Blackest Night," the latest event mini-series from DC Comics, in which many of its long dead superheroes mysteriously (and unpleasantly) rise from the dead. Though some comic-book fans say they are coming down with "event fatigue," that eight-issue mini-series, also written by Mr. Johns, is proving popular. The first issue, which went on sale in July, sold over 175,000 copies. It's also proving to be the gift the keeps giving: other titles connected to the storyline have also received a boost in sales.

Dubai or not Dubai -- that is the question. Dubai's sorta-kinda default (a state-owned enterprise seeking a rescheduling of its debts) is, by itself, not that big of a deal. But who else looks like Dubai? What kind of omen is this for the next stage in the financial crisis?

If you have to be a little crazy to be an entrepreneur, going into business with your spouse must represent a special kind of lunacy. My husband, Chris, and I have been business partners for more than six years. In that time we've started two businesses, sold one of them, had two kids and gotten more or less used to the daily roller coaster ride of entrepreneurial life.

What we're reading on Friday morning.No Release Yet for Polanski: A spokesman for Switzerland's Justice Ministry said that the director Roman Polanski will not be released from a prison near Zurich until at least Monday because the jailed filmmaker has not yet met all the conditions of his bail, The Associated Press reports. Under the bail agreement that was accepted on Wednesday, Mr. Polanski must post $4.5 million, which he has not yet paid; the director must also surrender his identity papers and be fitted with a monitoring bracelet.Not Ready for Prime Time: If an American television presentation can be edited for showing two men kissing, what does it take for a British television broadcast to provoke the scissors of the censors? The BBC reports that BBC4 has dropped its plans to show the ballet "Eternal Damnation to Sancho and Sanchez" by the Venezuelan choreographer Javier de Frutos because it depicted, among other things, a hunchback Pope strangling a pregnant nun with rosary beads. (The ballet also features nude scenes.) "When we announced we were showing it, at the time we weren't fully aware of the details of the ballet," a BBC spokesman said.Snowin' in the Wind: In an interview in a British magazine called The Big Issue, Bob Dylan explained his motivation for recording his first holiday-themed album, "Christmas in the Heart," Reuters reports. Though Mr. Dylan was raised Jewish in Minnesota, Christmas was one of his favorite holidays -- a time, he recalled, of "plenty of snow, jingle bells, Christmas carolers going from house to house, sleighs in the streets, town bells ringing, nativity plays." Asked what faith he practices now, Mr. Dylan told the magazine, "I am a true believer."Had Your Fill of Turkey Yet? On this day after Turkey Day, it seems only appropriate for The Guardian to recount the tale of "Divine Rapture," a notorious 1995 film project that never got off the ground. The movie was to star Johnny Depp, Marlon Brando and Debra Winger in the story of a woman who is hailed as a saint in her village when she miraculously rises from her coffin during her own funeral. (It turns out she had a rare disorder that slowed her heart-rate.) After six weeks of preparation in the Irish town of Ballycotton, the production ran out of money; Mr. Brando was nonetheless paid $1 million for his time.

PARIS | Examining music in a museum space is no simple task; exhibitions about musicians tend to downplay the music itself. But "We Want Miles," an ambitious show about the life and music of the jazz great Miles Davis, at Cité de la Musique through Jan. 17, is a remarkable exception. In this exhibition, the music is central.

The first time I met the bookmaker Jon Beacham, he was living in Beacon, N.Y., with a woman who was then his girlfriend, in a century-old house on the wrong side of the tracks from Dia/Beacon. The pair ran the Hermitage, a combination bookstore, press and gallery specializing in small-press American poetry from the 1950s through the 1970s. But Beacham recently moved back to the city to reopen the Hermitage in a desolate stretch of Bushwick, Brooklyn. "It was too hard to be doing something so esoteric and to be stuck in a small town on the Hudson," he explained. Oh well. Beacon's loss is Brooklyn's gain.

Swiss officials said on Thursday that they would not challenge a court ruling permitting Roman Polanski to be freed on bail as he fights extradition to the United States to face sentencing for having sex with a 13-year-old girl. On Wednesday the Swiss Federal Criminal Court granted Mr. Polanski’s appeal against detention in exchange for $4.5 million, along with other guarantees like the surrender of his identity papers to ensure he does not leave the country. Still, Interpol issued an advisory to its 188 member countries saying that Mr. Polanski should be arrested if he tried to travel. He fled the United States in 1978 before being sentenced. The Justice Ministry had 10 days to submit an appeal to the Swiss Federal Supreme Court, but said on Thursday that it had decided not to. The development means that Mr. Polanski may leave his jail cell and remain under house arrest and electronic monitoring at his holiday chalet, above, in Gstaad, a Swiss resort town.
