Sized for coffee tables but more serious than the average book in that category, BURTYNSKY: OIL, the companion to a current show at the Corcoran Gallery in Washington (through Dec. 13), chronicles the Canadian photographer's decade-long look at the fuel industry. Moving from Alberta oil fields to the Talladega Speedway to the ship-breaking yards of Bangladesh, Edward Burtynsky works on a global scale without preaching, and with an eye to sublime landscape paintings. His prints reveal epic waste and irreversible degradation, but carry a whiff of fantasy; the essayist Paul Roth refers to the world therein as ''Petrolia.'' Also worth reading is the down-to-earth travelogue by the Toronto writer Michael Mitchell, who accompanied Mr. Burtynsky to auto shows, tire dumps and bike rallies. (Steidl/Corcoran, $125.)

There's a good reason why the three daily book critics for The New York Times don't make 10-best lists at the end of the year: we can't. None of us has read everything. Our reviewing assignments don't overlap. None of us has an objective overview of the year's best and most important books, but this is what we do have: favorites. They are books we have not only admired in the abstract but also enjoyed, recommended and given to friends. The selections on our 10-book lists winnow down a wide array of possibilities. Of the tens of thousands of books published each year, the daily Times reviews only about 250. Each of us chose his or her share of those titles for review. Now Michiko Kakutani, Dwight Garner and I further narrow down those choices, and each of us can tell you which 10 books we'll remember best.

The decline in DVD sales has left its mark on this season's holiday offerings, which seem lighter on lavish packaging and adventurous titles than those of the last few years. The good news is that the industry's push to Blu-ray has occasioned some substantial upgrades of evergreen titles, and with the price of Blu-ray players dropping further into the comfort zone, many film lovers may decide that this is the year to make the transition. Below are some of the most notable releases of the last few months. Prices given are the manufacturers' suggested retail, which can often be cut in half with a little shopping around.

TITO RODRíGUEZ EL INOLVIDABLE: A MAN AND HIS MUSIC The recently revived Fania Records has started reaching outside itself, giving new life to the catalogs of artists it never recorded. Here's Tito Rodríguez, a singer and bandleader who lighted up Afro-Latin music from the mid-'40s to the mid-'60s. (At which point he finally lost his drawn-out battle for mambo dominance to Tito Puente, then relocated to his native Puerto Rico and died in 1973.) This exemplary set -- taken from long-out-of-print records made during the '60s -- includes luxe big-band tracks and smaller, more intense conjunto jam sessions, as well as live recordings from the Palladium, the locus of New York's mambo mania. There's also a fascinating 1960 cut called ''Esta Es Mi Orquesta'' -- possibly modeled after an earlier Stan Kenton piece called ''Prologue'' -- in which Rodríguez delivers a spoken lecture in mambo dynamics, introducing musicians one by one, letting them take their licks. (Fania, two discs, $18.98.) BEN RATLIFF

JOHN WESLEY. One of the most talked about exhibitions that happened in conjunction with this year's Venice Biennale was an extensive survey of the five-decade career of the painter John Wesley at the Fondazione Prada. The mammoth, 557-page catalog for that show is a visual and informational delight. It includes a profusely illustrated essay by the show's curator, Germano Celant, and a wealth of other textual materials. But the main pleasure is delivered by the hundreds of crisp, color reproductions of Mr. Wesley's oddly comical, formally scrupulous, often erotic, cartoon-style images. Including drawings, studies and source materials relating to many particular paintings, it sheds light on the creative processes of a great American original. (Fondazione Prada, $130.) HEAT WAVES IN A SWAMP: THE PAINTINGS OF CHARLES BURCHFIELD. If you have ever wondered what the world looked like to Ralph Waldo Emerson when he was having an attack of transcendentalist ecstasy, you could do worse than to consult one of the glowing, shimmering landscape paintings that Charles Burchfield produced in the early and late phases of his career. They are among the highlights of a traveling exhibition now at the Hammer Museum and scheduled to open at the Whitney Museum of American Art in June. Surprisingly, that show was organized not by a museum curator but by the sculptor Robert Gober, whose simple, fragmentary notes in this excellent catalog provide an illuminating biographical background to Mr. Burchfield's pantheistic visions. (Hammer Museum and DelMonico Books-Prestel, $49.95.)

Adrienne Schroeder recently moved to Richmond, Va., from Bozeman, Mont., to care for her aging father. Medical expenses -- not his, but hers -- are a concern. Ms. Schroeder had four pregnancies in the last six years, two ending in miscarriages. She still owes money from those medical costs, despite having had health insurance the whole time.

The season's liveliest books about antiques cover stolen luxuries, unsung dead designers and the details of detecting fakes. The texts are full of did-you-knows that will no doubt impress your gift recipients or maybe even set off deep discussions about how history's vagaries shape what we own. Since at least the first century collectors have been tricked by forgeries: Pliny wrote about pervasive ''glass counterfeits'' in the gemstone trade, as the Swiss historian Jean-Jacques Fiechter points out in EGYPTIAN FAKES: MASTERPIECES THAT DUPED THE ART WORLD AND THE EXPERTS WHO UNCOVERED THEM (Flammarion, $45). The book is a paranoiac's dream, telling of new carvings that were bathed in acid, boiled in tobacco and rolled in bitumen dust to look and even smell old. Once a scam had been detected -- perhaps because the pharaoh statuette wig looked a little too Art Deco, or the scarab inscriptions had basic grammatical errors -- embarrassed owners sometimes just swept the problem under the rug by quietly selling it off.

NAGLER--Frances "Faye". Adored mother, grandmother, great-grandmother, sister and aunt passed away on November 26, 2009 at age 84. Faye was an extraordinary woman full of sweetness and warmth. She began her journey in Brooklyn, marrying Nat in 1944. They had 47 wonderful years together, making their mark in causes supporting Israel, B'nai B'rith and Soviet Jewry. Faye continued their legacy after Nat's death with her tireless work at the B'nai B'rith House named after Nat. Faye was beloved by her children Steve, Mitch, Eve, Jo, Michael, Kathi and Louisa, and her grandchildren Dana, Mele, Eden, Leah, Matti, Emmy, Ben, Nikki, Nomi, James, Tim, Rodney and Marissa and her great-grandchildren Nua, Luna and Iva, and her sister Shirley Towers. Donations in her memory may be sent to: Nathan I. Nagler, Queens B'Nai B'rith House 138-49 Elder Ave., Flushing, NY 11355. Funeral service Friday, 12:30pm at "Gutterman's Inc.", 175 Long Beach Rd., Rockville Centre, NY.

The theater book of the season is unquestionably FREE FOR ALL: JOE PAPP, THE PUBLIC AND THE GREATEST THEATER STORY EVER TOLD (Doubleday, $39.95). Compiled by Kenneth Turan more than 20 years ago, with Papp's cooperation and input, the book was shelved when the ailing Papp expressed displeasure with the first draft. Emerging from the time capsule today, it is a juicy, exciting read, particularly the first half, which concentrates on Papp's life and career and the founding of the New York Shakespeare Festival and the Public Theater. The voices of more than 100 artists and administrators tell the story as they recall it. Papp emerges as a volatile and mercurial but always energetic figure, driven by a passion both for art and for the idea that theater should not be a pastime for the privileged but a source of joy and inspiration for everybody.

How do you sell beer in a country where about 60 percent of the population is Muslim and forbidden by the government to buy it? Very carefully. Guinness Anchor, which has the largest market share of the three brewers in Malaysia, recently celebrated Guinness's 250th anniversary with a concert near Kuala Lumpur featuring the Black Eyed Peas. The company had to create a separate area where alcohol could be served and agreed not to use the word ''Guinness'' at the concert or in advertising promoting the event.

PIXIES MINOTAUR You smell ''Minotaur'' first, faintly, a light musk wafting off the box. And what a box: a mottled brown, almost two feet long by more than a foot wide, with a pelt-like texture that's surprisingly soft, for a box, not at all unpleasant. It's heavy, too, at 25 pounds. The required heavy lifting (and spending) has a Darwinian effect; it selects its owners in a Herculean fashion, so brute in its presence that it demands attention. All five albums are here -- ''Come On Pilgrim,'' ''Surfer Rosa,'' ''Doolittle,'' ''Bossanova,'' ''Trompe Le Monde'' -- on 24-karat gold-plated CD and 180-gram vinyl and in Blu-ray audio. Let's face it, though: you have the music already (and if you don't, there are far more efficient ways to get it). Which is fine, because ''Minotaur'' isn't about music: it's about dedication, obsession, sense activation, one-upmanship, indie-rock consumer porn. Each copy is signed by the band and individually numbered, one of 3,000 made. The package was compiled by the graphic designer Vaughan Oliver and the photographer Simon Larbalestier, who collaborated on all of the original Pixies' album art. Their work is ghoulish and stark and tactile, captured here in an oversize book and a giclée print, rough to the touch. This doorstopper of a set is called the ''limited'' edition: a ''deluxe'' version is available too, at one-quarter the weight and one-third the price, and with only half of the good stuff. But what sort of commitment is that? (Artist In Residence, five CDs, five records, two DVDs, one Blu-ray disc, two books and two posters, $495.) JON CARAMANICA
MORRIS--Wayne J. 11/27/08 You & me, Me & you - Always.
'COLD WATER' La MaMa Galleria

Art books and books about art may be two different things. Those in the first category show, with ample size and masses of pictures; those in the second tell, with writing on the subject outweighing reproductions of it. PAINTING ABSTRACTION: NEW ELEMENTS IN ABSTRACT PAINTING, a lively survey by the independent curator and critic Bob Nickas, is big and bright (six and a half pounds and cadmium red). Each of the 80 artists included in the book is represented by three or four full-page color images and a short essay (balancing show with tell). It is weighted toward young talent from New York, and not surprisingly peppered with artists Mr. Nickas has included in gallery group shows he has organized over the years. But it is great to have some order brought to ''the persistence of abstraction,'' as Mr. Nickas calls it. Think of this as a giant survey exhibition that didn't -- probably couldn't, maybe shouldn't -- happen, and a useful tool in forming a sharper, broader sense of what is going on in the world of abstract painting. (Phaidon, $75.) Also recommended from the same Phaidon series: PAINTING TODAY, by Tony Godfrey, which goes back to the 1980s for its nearly eye-bogglingly global view of the medium in all styles. ($75.)

BIG STAR KEEP AN EYE ON THE SKY Big Star started out as a Memphis band that merely sought to outdo the Beatles, the Beach Boys, the Rolling Stones, the Kinks and the Byrds, adding some Memphis rock and soul. Big Star was already a slight throwback in the early 1970s but was also bursting with possibilities. It had open-ended studio time and some pop experience; one of its songwriters, Alex Chilton, had sung the Box Tops hit ''The Letter.'' But Big Star's fate was a perfectly disastrous combination of talent, musical ambition, personal temperament and bad luck. For Big Star's 1972 debut, ''#1 Record,'' it was led by Chris Bell and Mr. Chilton, a pairing that mixed lapidary, melodic songwriting and studio embellishments with a brash willingness to reveal every hope, fear and yearning. Mr. Bell left after ''#1 Record'' flopped, fumbled by its label. That left Mr. Chilton to lead a three-man band on the rawer, guitar-centered but still pop-minded ''Radio City.'' Then came ''3d,'' essentially a Chilton solo album assisted by Big Star's drummer, Jody Stephens. It held eerie, bereft songs in a paradoxically pretty orchestral haze: ''Nothing can hurt me,'' Mr. Chilton sang. ''Nothing can touch me.'' Latter-day fans reclaimed Big Star's albums as foundations of both crafty power-pop and disheveled indie-rock. This loving collection is virtually the complete 1970s Big Star: demos, a video clip, a 20-song live disc by the three-man band and the solo single Mr. Bell made before he died in a car accident. Alternate mixes, usually more cluttered, replace some original album tracks, but no matter: the fans already have those. (Rhino, four CDs, $69.98.) JON PARELES
AUDIO AND PHOTOS At State Supreme Court in Manhattan, Louise Nicholas, a jury clerk, helps tens of thousands of sometimes reluctant New Yorkers perform their civic duty. nytimes.com/nyregion

Video games provide as diverse a variety of experience as any form of mass entertainment. That diversity is a strength, but it can also lead to confusion for gift buyers. With top titles often costing $60 or more, buying a game that ends up unplayed can be a costly waste. Even worse, buying a violent video game meant for adults and giving it to a child just because it happens to be a video game is nothing less than negligent and irresponsible. So it is important to suit the game to the player. That said, the game industry in 2009 has something to offer just about everyone. Here are some of the best games of the year, and whom they may best suit.

The next time it will be a far worse reality than a reality TV show. REPRESENTATIVE PETER T. KING, who called for a Congressional investigation into how two uninvited guests appeared at the White House for a state dinner while aspiring to be featured on ''The Real Housewives of Washington'' [A21]

The global hotel business is in a deep funk, but that has not kept the industry from betting on Asia, the one region of the world where growth is strong. In October, two major upscale hotels opened in Hong Kong, each with views of the skyscrapers huddled between the city's mountains and harbor. One is a 381-room Hyatt Regency, on top of a shopping mall in the Kowloon district.
ALGER--Ian E.,M.D. Memorial Service for Dr. Ian Alger. Wed, Dec. 2, 2009 at 5:30pm. The Metropolitan Club, 1 East 60th St., New York City
OLAF BREUNING Small Brain Big Stomach

CONTENT may want to be free, but when it is, it doesn't make much of a gift. For the holidays most people still appreciate certain trappings: a beautiful binding, a deluxe box with a souvenir book, rich color photographs on heavy paper, two seats on the aisle. This week the critics of The Times offer suggested gifts of song, film, television, theater, art, reading and more.

Advocates of health care legislation are facing many challenges in getting their messages across to the public over the holidays. So one advocacy group is essentially moving its campaign to where the consumers are: stores and shopping malls. The group, Health Care for America Now, a coalition of labor and liberal activists, plans to drop leaflets at stores and malls Friday in Arizona, Missouri, Nevada and Texas. It says it hopes to ''educate'' shoppers about popular brands like Wrangler, the North Face and Nautica.

Whatever shape the Dow is in, the holidays are traditionally the time to spend big, and art and architecture books are a relatively guilt-free gift choice. They may cost a bundle, but they are built to last, often gorgeous and almost always edifying, designed to be revisited, for pleasure and instruction, over the years. With that in mind, the art and architecture critics of The New York Times have chosen these as the most notable books published this year. HOLLAND COTTER

Handing someone a couple of rectangular slivers of cardboard may sound a bit impersonal, as gift giving goes. But that cardboard could well bear the promise of a very personal experience, of a night that might turn out to be as reflective and intimate as a closely held hand mirror. What follows is a shopping list of theater tickets, which has been annotated according to character, matching the sensibilities of shows with personality types. (One small warning: It is probably best to avoid saying, ''I thought this show was so you,'' until after the recipient has used the tickets. To do so earlier would engender an irritating and prejudicial self-consciousness that no playgoer -- or play -- should ever be burdened with.)

REO SPEEDWAGON NOT SO SILENT NIGHT (Sony Special Products, $6.98) Big-gestured and easygoing, sweetened by Kevin Cronin's ever-enthusiastic voice, ''Not So Silent Night'' is pretty much the ideal pop Christmas album for early-1980s sentimentalists: double-guitar leads, a little bit of blues, a little bit of country, a lush ballad (''The White Snows of Winter''), a rock shuffle (''Winter Wonderland'') and some moral high ground (John Lennon's ''Happy Xmas''). (Above, the group: from left, Neal Doughty, Mr. Cronin, Bruce Hall, Dave Amato and Bryan Hitt.) It's a record trading on styles so old and codified that it's incredible that it was made in 2009. But man, is it efficient. BEN RATLIFF
PAUL--Robert D. Nov. 1, 1928-Nov. 27, 2003. In loving memory. Eve, Jeremy and Sarah

Perhaps the Giants were disoriented by the change of time zones or by the thin air of the Mile High City or by their rare appearance on Thanksgiving. Their problems -- not all of them their fault -- began early when quarterback Eli Manning called timeout because of to transmission problems with the helmet headset on which he hears the plays.

The frantic pace of urbanization in China has made conventional urban planning strategies seem pointless. How, after all, do you plan cities that grow by a few million inhabitants in less than a decade? LEARNING FROM HANGZHOU is a delirious effort to make sense of this historic urban phenomenon. The book, whose title is a witty reference to Robert Venturi, Denise Scott Brown and Steven Izenour's 1972 book, ''Learning From Las Vegas,'' examines everything from the Chinese city's rampant commercialization to the poor quality of housing for its migrant workers and the constant, 24-hour cycles of demolition and construction. This may be as close as you can get to seeing the future, and it's both euphoric and terrifying. (timezone8, $45.) Although women formed the majority of the Bauhaus's student body in its early years, the role they played in shaping the school's radical agenda has been largely ignored. Now BAUHAUS WOMEN comes along to correct the historical record. The book touches on how women's ideas about sexual liberation -- refusing to wear corsets, exercising bare-legged in city parks -- challenged the rigid class boundaries and sexual prudery of post-World War I Germany. But it was the spirit of creative collaboration they fostered -- mostly working in the school's textile, weaving, ceramics and industrial design workshops -- that helped define the Bauhaus's greatness. (Flammarion, $39.95.)

POLLIN--Abe. We are deeply saddened by the passing of our dear friend Abe Pollin. An outstanding leader and universally loved human being, Abe worked tirelessly to revitalize the Washington, DC, community and support the health of people across the country and around the world. Together with his beloved wife, Irene, he established the Pollin Prize in Pediatric Research, a unique honor awarded each year at NewYork-Presbyterian to biomedical and public health research scientists whose insights have made important improvements to children's health. Longstanding and enthusiastic supporters of our Hospital, they helped create the NewYork-Presbyterian Morgan Stanley Children's Hospital pediatric cardiac intensive care unit, which was named in loving memory of their children Linda Joy and Kenneth Jay. They contributed to our Milstein Family Heart Center, which is due to open next year. And they supported research into progressive supranuclear palsy, a rare neurological disorder. The Pollins are an extraordinary and exemplary family, whose generosity and concern has touched the entire community. Motivated by a deep commitment to improve the public good, Abe leaves an enormous legacy of good works. We offer our heartfelt condolences to Irene; his sons Robert and James; and the entire Pollin family. Herbert Pardes, M.D., President and CEO NewYork-Presbyterian Hospital

BODO--Bernard S. January 20, 1923 -- November 24, 2009. Bronx boy, exuberant owner Le Figaro Cafe, Italophile, gustatory enthusiast, New York sports fan, lifelong learner, cellist, world traveler, WWII veteran, loyal friend to many. Devoted husband to Naomi; exceptional father to Jennifer, Margaret, and Anthony; cherished grandfather to Luke, Meghan, Daniel, David, Ryker, and Sophie. You lived your extraordinary life to the fullest. We will miss you truly and will forever hold you in our hearts. The family will gather at the Bodo home on Saturday from 4-6pm and Sunday from 1-3pm. Donations in Bernie's name to Alaria Music will be very much appreciated.

Graphic books have been plentiful in 2009, with diverse approaches: memoir (''Stitches''), reportage (''A.D.: New Orleans After the Deluge''), fiction (''Asterios Polyp''), adaptation (Richard Stark's ''Hunter'') and superhero (''Batman: Whatever Happened to the Caped Crusader?''). There are many more. Whether you're already a fan or want to dip your toe into the medium, consider the following books. Dorothy's journey to Oz may seem a well-trod path, but THE WONDERFUL WIZARD OF OZ (Marvel Entertainment, $29.99), a retelling of the L. Frank Baum novel, feels delightfully new. It is filled with characters (the queen of fieldmice) and concepts (Emerald City visitors must don special spectacles or risk blindness) from the original text, which the writer, Eric Shanower, has used to maximum effect. The illustrations, by Skottie Young, are often stunning, especially his depictions of what Dorothy and friends see when gazing upon Oz.

THERE are numerous ways to invent history, as seen in this year's assortment of boxed sets. Some prefer the full-catalog purge, and others the rarities and remixes. Some celebrate received wisdom; others, alternate stories. And when all that's done, some start over, taking another look with fresh eyes. That there would be only one way to go about the task is a folly fading more with each passing year. Here the pop and jazz critics of The New York Times review the notable boxed sets and anthologies of 2009. JON CARAMANICA AC/DC: 'BACKTRACKS' A set of B sides, Australia-only album tracks, live recordings and video from the full career of one of the most reliable bands in the world. Perhaps you don't know the studio songs -- like ''Crabsody in Blue,'' a slow shuffle about a sexually transmitted disease, bounced from most editions of the ''Let There Be Rock'' album on grounds of raciness -- but you know what you're getting. Unison guitar riffs, that comfortable stomp, up-front songs of domination and teasing. The DVD is almost worthless -- cheesy promo clips for commercials, mostly -- but the live disc, with good sound, is where it's at. From 1977 to 2000, from ''T.N.T.'' to ''Back in Black,'' through the lustiest crowd roars you've ever heard, the band is loud, steady and endlessly entertaining. (Sony Legacy, two CDs and one DVD, $39.98; a deluxe collector's edition, with an extra CD of live rarities, an extra DVD of a 2003 concert in Munich, an illustrated book and a vinyl LP of some of the studio material, is available only at acdcbacktracks.com for $199.) BEN RATLIFF TITE CURET ALONSO: ALMA DE POETA A court ruling in a copyright dispute early this year made it possible for disk jockeys and performers to play the songs of Tite Curet Alonso, probably the greatest composer of salsa. The reaction was immediate: a stadium concert in San Juan, P.R., celebrating his music, and this two-disc selection of his greatest songs, as performed by various artists. If you're like me, you're used to listening to salsa by group or singer, not by songwriter, but here are some of the sharpest and most moving songs the genre produced in the 1960s and '70s: ''La Tirana,'' by La Lupe; ''Periódico de Ayer,'' by Héctor Lavoe; ''La Esencia del Guaguancó,'' by Willie Rosario; ''Anacaona,'' by Cheo Feliciano. (Strangely missing: Willie Colón and Lavoe's ''Calle Luna, Calle Sol'' and Rubén Blades's ''Plantación Adentro.'') (Emusica, two CDs, $19.49.) BEN RATLIFF JOHN COLTRANE: SIDE STEPS Before he cleaned up his life, got his own band and made some of the best jazz records ever, John Coltrane worked as a sideman over and over again in ad hoc bands for Prestige Records, a label that pumped out product with loose quality control. ''Side Steps'' collects albums released under the leadership of Elmo Hope, Tadd Dameron, Red Garland, Sonny Rollins, Gene Ammons, Mal Waldron and the tuba player Ray Draper. On average, they're ... average. (Rollins's ''Tenor Madness,'' with its famous Rollins-Coltrane duel, and Garland's elegant ''Soul Junction'' constitute its peaks.) You can hear a great musician rising to his feet: especially by late 1957, Coltrane's sound is unmistakable. Still, these are records best understood as day work. (Prestige, five discs, $59.98.) BEN RATLIFF MILES DAVIS: THE COMPLETE COLUMBIA ALBUM COLLECTION What's not here? His beginnings as a New York bebopper; his ''Birth of the Cool'' period; a few great sessions from 1954; the beginnings of his 1950s quintet with John Coltrane; the worst of his late-period fusion. What's here? Absolutely everything else from 1957 to 1985, one new live recording (from the Isle of Wight, 1970) and a superb concert DVD of his quintet with Wayne Shorter and Herbie Hancock in 1967. The albums are mostly presented here in original form, without outtakes, as you might have known them when they first came out, but a lot crisper than they sounded back then. It's a story of an artist changing his music every year or so, remarkably uninterested in jazz as a genre but rather as a process, constructing one mountain after another and charging up it: ''Milestones,'' ''Miles Ahead,'' ''Kind of Blue,'' ''Nefertiti,'' ''In a Silent Way,'' ''Get Up With It.'' What, you don't like ''Get Up With It?'' You're among those who think he lost it after ''Filles de Kilimanjaro?'' Study this, and we'll talk. (Columbia/Legacy, 70 CDs and one DVD, available only at amazon.com, $364.98) BEN RATLIFF

Television lovers are easy to buy for: more than 100 new TV-on-DVD releases come out every month. Here are a few current selections, from cozy classics to newer and decidedly uncozy shows. MIKE HALE ALLY MCBEAL: THE COMPLETE SERIESCalista Flockhart's winsome lawyer lives out all five seasons of her existence in this 32-disc boxed set. (20th Century Fox, $199.98, not rated) DAVE KEHRANDY BARKER P.I.: THE COMPLETE SERIES The title is the first joke: this cult favorite detective comedy starring Andy Richter lasted just six episodes in the spring of 2007. The theater book of the season is unquestionably FREE FOR ALL: JOE PAPP, THE PUBLIC AND THE GREATEST THEATER STORY EVER TOLD (Doubleday, $39.95). Compiled by Kenneth Turan more than 20 years ago, with Papp's cooperation and input, the book was shelved when the ailing Papp expressed displeasure with the first draft. Emerging from the time capsule today, it is a juicy, exciting read, particularly the first half, which concentrates on Papp's life and career and the founding of the New York Shakespeare Festival and the Public Theater. The voices of more than 100 artists and administrators tell the story as they recall it. Papp emerges as a volatile and mercurial but always energetic figure, driven by a passion both for art and for the idea that theater should not be a pastime for the privileged but a source of joy and inspiration for everybody.

Adrienne Schroeder recently moved to Richmond, Va., from Bozeman, Mont., to care for her aging father. Medical expenses -- not his, but hers -- are a concern. Ms. Schroeder had four pregnancies in the last six years, two ending in miscarriages. She still owes money from those medical costs, despite having had health insurance the whole time.

THOMPSON--David William, 95. Retired executive, business educator, and college professor. Dearly beloved and adored husband of Shirley "Sybil". Born September 3, 1914, in Fort Wayne, Indiana, a son of William Byron and Georgia Louise (Davis) Thompson. Died November 19, 2009 in New York City. David was a quiet and dignified gentleman who brought strength, wisdom, love and a sense of humor to those who knew him. He lived his life with joy, and a generosity that affected everyone around him. He and his famous smile will be greatly missed. Visitation Sunday, November 29, Frank Campbell Funeral Home, 1076 Madison Avenue, New York City, from 2 to 5 and 7 to 9pm. Funeral Service Monday, November 30, 2009, at 11:00am, Park Avenue United Methodist Church, 106 East 86th Street. Burial will be in the family cemetery in Indiana.

Libraries call their bookshelves ''stacks,'' but the only purposeful book stacking most of us do is on our coffee tables, where books are shuffled on and off like favorite playlists on an iPod. Coffee tables are places for odd juxtapositions. Part of the pleasure of gift books -- those chic, jumbo volumes about music and art, history and science, film and fashion -- is watching them rub up against one another and throw off sparks. It's even better, of course, to pull one off the pile. Flipping through these books is like gallerygoing without the gallery; the best of them crack open teeming worlds of color and pageantry and intellect and sometimes even chaos.

ROSENBLATT--Ann, 92, Miami Beach, Florida and New York on November 23, 2009 at her home. We mourn the passing of a beloved wife, mother, aunt, grandmother, and great-grandmother. She was the adored wife of the late Sam Rosenblatt; devoted and loving mother of Gary and Carole, Kenny and Susan; devoted aunt of Marty (Marilyn), Alan (Linda); devoted grandmother of Lisa (Brian), Francie (Evan), Michael (Jane), Dava, Jill (Andrew), Jonathan (Michele), Robert (Jessica), Mitchell (Lauren); and beloved great-grandmother of 19! She will be greatly missed by all who loved her. Contributions in her memory may be made to Alzheimer's Research.

BOB DYLAN Christmas in the Heart (Sony, $13.94) Since Bob Dylan has been calling himself Jack Frost when he produces his own work, and he has made it his business to investigate every nook and cranny of American song, perhaps there should have been inklings that he would make a Christmas album someday. ''Christmas in the Heart'' is that album, with its royalties benefiting antihunger charities, including Feeding America.

Is it a sign of the imminent end of days when Bob Dylan makes a Christmas album? Perhaps it's just further proof of the proposition that sooner or later, a career in music is bound to include something for the holidays. Christmas albums are concept albums, but the concept is supremely flexible: sincere or joshing, worshipful or iconoclastic, modest or bombastic, traditionalist or revisionist, somber or silly, all of which are represented (sometimes on the same album) by this year's releases. Here the pop and jazz critics of The New York Times unwrap some notable seasonal albums. JON PARELES TORI AMOS: MIDWINTER GRACES (Universal Republic; CD/DVD; $19.90) This high priestess of introspection addresses the season through a personal haze, wringing original music from the carols of her childhood. Gorgeously recorded and impeccably produced, ''Midwinter Graces'' includes some characteristic stunners, like ''Star of Wonder,'' inspired by the three kings from the East, and ''Holly, Ivy and Rose,'' with a dramatic Celtic lilt. The album also dwells in hymnlike serenity and diaphanous wonder, with only a few glaringly awkward moments, like ''Pink and Glitter,'' a big-band number that feels neither deft nor genuine. Throughout Ms. Amos shows herself to be right at home with the trappings of nativity, up to and including the frankincense. NATE CHINEN DAVID ARCHULETA: CHRISTMAS FROM THE HEART (Jive, $13.94) Of course: David Archuleta, after all, is basically a lamb, all youth, softness and gratitude. (On the cover of ''Christmas From the Heart'' he cracks an almost preposterous smile, as if you just said something that validated his life.) Aside from the last track, ''Melodies of Christmas,'' this music is not as cynical as his usual romantic dance-pop. Though his light, sweet, note-scooping alto comes unmistakably from the last 20 years of R&B, this record looks toward an older and stodgier tradition of record making, and takes it seriously. A full orchestra drapes itself over nearly every track, and the large-scale arrangements transcend the obvious, even borrowing a little ersatz Andalusian guitar for the climax of ''What Child Is This.'' As for Mr. Archuleta, he sings in a Hebraic-sounding French in ''Pat-a-Pan,'' Spanish in ''Riu Riu Chiu'' and Latin in ''Ave Maria.'' He's reaching. BEN RATLIFF

COSTELLO--Timothy, age 65, of New York City and Shelter Island, NY on November 25th, 2009, beloved husband of Kathryn. Many New Yorkers knew Tim as the former owner of Costello's Restaurant in Midtown Manhattan. His death came after a valiant, l5-year battle against lung disease. The family and friends salute the extraordinary care he received from Dr. Byron Thomashow, Columbia Presbyterian Hospital Lung Transplant Team, and CTICU. As the death watch for the CD continues, so does the flow of classical CDs: no longer a flood but not yet a trickle. The labels that used to be considered major no longer dominate the field, to the extent that they are players at all. But excellent recordings keep coming out from a variety of sources: in some cases the artists or performing institutions themselves. In any case, the classical critics of The New York Times had no difficulty finding a list of worthies to cite as records of the year for 2009. JAMES R. OESTREICH ADÈS: THE TEMPEST Vocal soloists; Orchestra and Chorus of the Royal Opera House, Covent Garden, conducted by Thomas Adès (EMI Classics 6 95234 2; two CDs); $23.98.

Opponents of health care reform periodically argue that legislation is unnecessary because anybody can get medical assistance through the emergency room -- or that those who get in trouble have only themselves for blame by not buying insurance. My Sunday column tells the story of John Brodniak, a young man who had insurance with his job, but lost both when he developed a benign tumor in his brain. Read his story and see if you still think the need for universal coverage isn't urgent. His story seems to me the best rebuttal of the skeptics.

A report in the “Arts, Briefly” column on Nov. 16 about plans by some members of the recently defunct band Oasis to form a new group included several errors. Liam Gallagher was the lead vocalist for Oasis, not guitarist and vocalist. Noel Gallagher, his brother, was the lead guitarist and main songwriter, not lead singer and songwriter. And while Colin Archer, known as Gem, did at times play keyboard, he was primarily the rhythm guitarist and sometimes played lead guitar.

Nothing seems to have gone right for Speech Debelle, below, the British rapper, since she won pop music’s prestigious Mercury Prize in September. On Tuesday, BBC News reported, the hip-hop performer (whose real name is Corynne Elliot) said in a radio interview that she had quit the independent record label Big Dada after her Mercury Prize victory did not significantly increase sales for her debut album, “Speech Therapy.” “I wasn’t disappointed that it didn’t sell well,” she told the BBC. “I was disappointed in the people I was working with.” And on Thursday, BBC News reported, she was booed by audience members at a promotional event honoring the British boy band Take That, when she tried to perform that group’s love ballad “Pray” as a rap. When someone starts talking about a sequel, the last thing you usually want to hear is ''more of the same.'' That is, unless your idea of a good time is mowing down thousands of preternaturally fast, agile and of course ravenous undead as you and three friends try to escape the zombie apocalypse. If that's the case, Left 4 Dead 2 is exactly the game you've been looking for. This is not a game for character development. This is not a game for plot twists. This is not a game for chin-scratching puzzle conquest. This is not a game that will draw you into a rich consideration of the eternal philosophical quandaries of life.

CAWLEY--Florence A.,of Baldwin, NY, on November 24, 2009. Loving daughter of the late Thomas and Jule Cawley. Fond sister of the late Gilbert Cawley. Dear sister-in-law of Margaret Ann Cawley. A native of Archbald, PA, Florence is also survived by several cousins, including Sr. M. Beatrix, I.H.M. The family received friends Friday 2-4 and 7-9pm at Cecere-Pensa Funeral Home, 2283 Grand Ave., Baldwin, NY. 11510. Funeral mass Saturday, 9:45am at St. Christopher's RC Church, Baldwin. Interment Holy Rood Cemetery, Westbury, NY. In lieu of flowers, donations to St. Christopher's RC Church, 11 Gale Ave., Bladwin, NY 11510 or Sisters of I.H.M. retirement Fund, I.H.M. Center, Marywood, Scranton, PA 18509 would be appreciated. Please visit: cecerefamilyfunerals.com

NADLER--David. Passed away on November 26th, 2009 of pancreatic cancer. He was born in Brooklyn on May 16th, 1938. David leaves behind his cherished wife Millie, beloved daughter Laura, stepson Spiros, sister Doris and grandchildren Jason and Olivia. He graduated from Boston University and received his law degree from St. John's University School of Law in 1965. A true advocate, he worked as an attorney and partner of Ballon Stoll Bader and Nadler, LLC in NYC for over 40 years. David was quiet in demeanor, an intellect who loved his work, family and life. Many sought his advice and wise counsel. He created a legacy and will be sorely missed by all. Funeral service will be held at 11:45am on Sunday at Riverside Memorial Chapel, Amsterdam Avenue at 76th Street.

FRANCO--Robert S.,born in Brussels on October 1, 1929 passed away on November 26, 2009. A longtime resident of New York City, Robert was the devoted son of the late Semah and Regine. Beloved husband of Ellie, cherished brother of Rae (Paul) and Lillian. Treasured father of Randi (John), Nancy (Barrett), Andrew (Lynda), Jimmy (Elizabeth) and stepfather of Beth (Joe) and Stephen (Allie). Adored Poppa of Robert, Casey, Maggie, Jake, Matthew, Greta, Dani, Benjamin, Adam, Sophia and William. He was loved by many and will be deeply missed and will live in our hearts forever. Services Sunday, November 29, 11:15am at "The Riverside," 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

An item in the Prescriptions column on Friday reported the financial problems that pregnancy-related medical bills have posed for Adrienne Schroeder, a young mother of two children, despite having had insurance coverage through her husband's employer or, now, under a plan the Schroeders bought on their own. Here is an sampling of readers' replies: The article describes a very common situation for those not in group plans. As a former sales rep for individual health plans, I used a 145-page guide of exclusions for pre-existing conditions, ''hazardous'' activities and occupations, out-of-limit weight, and use of certain medications. Many of my friends who are covered by company group plans just don't understand the high cost exposure potential and the exorbitant premiums of individual plans which still don't provide coverage for many illnesses. Many holders of such plans are covered for the catastrophic costs, but are reluctant to get the colonoscopy or the CT scans recommended by the doctor because of high deductibles. Not much chance for prevention when you can't afford to pay for it.

MALAVE--Ernesto. Brooklyn College and President Karen L. Gould deeply mourn the passing of Ernesto Malave, Vice Chancellor for budget and finances, CUNY. We are grateful for his work on behalf of our students and our institution, and we extend our deepest sympathies to his family.

8 P.M. (Hallmark) THE NATIONAL TREE (2009) A search for a Christmas tree to be planted across from the White House ends at the home of Rock Burdock (Evan Williams, above center), a 17-year-old video blogger, where his father, Corey (Andrew McCarthy, right), planted a Sitka spruce on the day his son was born. With a marketing rep (Kari Matchett, left) in tow, the Burdock men embark on a cross-country drive -- and a potential bonding experience -- to deliver the tree to Washington. But when the tree's significance becomes more about a media frenzy, than about its value as a national symbol, father and son must decide which is more important. 8 P.M. (21) ED SULLIVAN'S ROCK AND ROLL CLASSICS: THE '60s Film footage from ''The Ed Sullivan Show'' from around 1963 to 1968 features the American television debut of the Beatles, a controversial appearance by the Doors and less notorious performances by the Rolling Stones, the Mamas and the Papas and Sly and the Family Stone.

Testimony in the nine-month trial of a former prison chief for the Communist Khmer Rouge ended Friday when the defendant unexpectedly asked to be set free despite his repeated admissions of guilt. ''I would ask the chambers to release me,'' said the defendant, Kaing Guek Eav, 67, known as Duch, as he addressed the panel officially known as the Extraordinary Chambers in the Courts of Cambodia. ''Thank you very much.''

THOMPSON--David William, November 19, 2009, in New York City at age 95. Born in Fort Wayne, Indiana on September 3, 1914, son of William B. And Georgia Louise (Davis) Thompson. He grew up in Fort Wayne. He received his academic degrees from Indiana University - BS 1938, MS 1940. He taught at this institution from 1942-55, becoming a full professor in 1948. Prior to this, he taught at Sanford University in Alabama and at Butler University in Indianapolis. In 1955 Mr. Thompson began a 22 year leave from teaching to work in the private sector joining the General Electric Company as Manager, Financial Training and Education for the company. In 1957 he joined Peat, Marwick, Mitchell & Co. (KPMG) as partner in charge of personnel with firm-wide responsibilities for all personnel activities for the firm. After nearly 20 years, Mr. Thompson retired from PMM & Co. in 1976 and returned to academia, taking a Chair at the University of Virginia in Charlottesville. He retired from UVA in 1985 after 9 years on the faculty there. An expert in financial cost and not-for-profit accounting, Mr. Thompson held Certified Public Accountant certificates in 16 states. He is a past Chairman of the New York State Boards of Certified Public Accountant Examiners and of Certified Public Accounts, and is a member of Beta Gamma Sigma and of its Director's Table. He was a member of the Regents External Degree Program of the State of New York and a member of Dean's Advisory Council of the School of Business at Indiana University. He was a member of the Board of Directors of the Universidad de las Americas, Mexico City, and a member of its foundation. During his careers, Mr. Thompson was very active in many professional and academic organizations, his contributions centering around committee participation and directorships. Outside his professional world, Mr. Thompson enjoyed photography, tennis, deep sea fishing and traveling extensively both domestically and internationally. He was a member of the University Club, New York, India House, New York and the Farmington Country Club In Charlottesville, VA. He married Miriam Vollmer December 21, 1956. She preceded him in death on June 26, 1984. His second wife, Shirley, survives. They maintained residences in Indiana, New York and Virginia. Visitation Sunday, November 29, Frank Campbell Funeral Home, 1076 Madison Ave, 2-5pm and 7-9pm. Funeral Service Monday, November 30 11am, Park Avenue United Methodist Church, 106 East 86th St. Burial in the family cemetery in Indiana.

One quip making the rounds in Athens is that the financial crisis is arriving -- but on Greek time. The Greek economy started to slow down later than those of many of its peers, and it seems that it will be stuck in recession longer.

SCHWAM--Ethel, 80 years, died November 27, 2009. Devoted daughter of the late Fannie and Louis Schwam. Beloved sister of Roslyn and Philip Shipper (deceased), Irene and Sam Kohn (deceased), and Judith and Arthur Goldberg. Cherished aunt of Laura and Marc Vogel, David and Clancy Shipper, Martin and Lisa Kohn, Edward and Sandy Kohn, Jacob and Chari Goldberg, Daniel and Christine Goldberg, Adam and Monica Goldberg. Loving great-aunt of Howard and Stephanie, Andrew, Joshua, Michael, Rebeccah, Zachary, Dena, Benjamin, Jonah, Louis, Hannah, Emma, Lucy, Sadie and Josiah. Before, during and after a distinguished career as the Director of the Department of Dietetics at Long Island Jewish Hospital, Ethel dedicated herself to her family, her friends, the arts and education. She was generous, wise, caring and full of love. Services will be held Sunday, November 29th, 2009, at 11am at Temple Beth Sholom in Roslyn, New York.

BERMAN--Doreen, 85, died unexpectedly on November 26, 2009. Adored wife of the late Joe; beloved mother of Winnie, Robert, Birch and Judy, and mother-in-law of Steve Ingrid, Rhoda and Phil; deeply devoted grandmother of Abby, Rebecca, Gabriella, Tobias, Osho, Tao, Rachel and Adam. Doreen cherished her extended family and friends, sharing herself with generosity and grace, offering love and wise counsel to all who entered her life. She was Professor Emeritus, Dept. of Psychology, Queens College of CUNY, having just retired after 38 years of active teaching and administration. She deeply touched the lives and will be sorely missed by all who knew her. Services Sunday 12noon at "Riverside-Nassau North Chapels", 55 North Station Plaza (Opposite LIRR), Great Neck, NY.

In totalitarian regimes, some people take huge risks for the freedom to be themselves; in this democracy, some people take huge risks for the freedom to be someone else -- a celebrity. Fame has a spellbinding power in American society, the one thing that can trump wealth, talent, breeding and even elected office. Reality shows and social Web sites like Facebook long ago knocked down the barriers that kept ordinary people trapped in obscurity. And instant renown is nothing if not democratic.

ACKERMAN--Muriel, nee Beer, 89, beloved wife of Monroe; mother of Terry; sister of Lynn, Joan; loving aunt and great-aunt. Graveside service 11am, Sunday, Mt. Hebron Cemetery, 130-04 Horace Harding Expwy, Flushing, NY.

Roberto Alomar was a slick-fielding second baseman who was proud of the way he could beat teams with his bat, his glove and his legs. He will soon learn if what he achieved in a 17-year career will be enough to earn him election into the Hall of Fame in his first year of eligibility. When the 2010 ballot was announced Friday, Alomar was the strongest candidate. He had a .300 average, collected 2,724 hits, won 10 Gold Glove awards, made 12 All-Star teams and won two World Series titles with the Toronto Blue Jays.

FRAINT--Lily, 87, of Miami, FL, formerly of New York City, on November 27, 2009. Predeceased by her husband Herman. Survived by her sons Eric and Rabbi Sam Fraint, brother Edward Richman. Services are Sunday, 1pm at Cedar Park Cemetery.

Among the loose ends left after Prime Minister Vladimir V. Putin's visit to Paris was one that has proved particularly difficult to ignore: the 23,700-ton French warship that docked in the middle of St. Petersburg this week as part of an extended sales pitch to the Russian government. For months, Russian officials have been negotiating with France over the purchase of a Mistral-class amphibious assault ship, at an estimated cost of up to $750 million, and a license to build several more in Russia. The high-tech ship would stand out in Russia's aging fleet. Vladimir S. Vysotsky, commander of the Russian Navy, noted this fall that if he had had access to such a ship during the 2008 war with Georgia, it ''would have allowed the Black Sea fleet to complete its mission within 40 minutes, not 26 hours.''

The shuttle Atlantis glided to a flawless Florida landing on Friday, wrapping up an 11-day space station delivery mission and bringing a flight engineer, Nicole P. Stott, back to Earth after 91 days in space. Dropping out of a clear sky, the shuttle was guided to a tire-smoking touchdown at 9:44 a.m. by the commander, Col. Charles O. Hobaugh of the Marines, and the pilot, Capt. Barry E. Wilmore of the Navy -- the final chapter in a 4.4-million-mile voyage that began with blastoff on Nov. 16.

A Yale librarian who cast doubt last year on the origins of the Serenity Prayer, adopted by Alcoholics Anonymous and reprinted on countless knickknacks, says new evidence has persuaded him to retain the famed Protestant theologian Reinhold Niebuhr as the author in the next edition of The Yale Book of Quotations. The provenance of the prayer, which begins, ''God grant me the serenity to accept the things I cannot change,'' became a subject of controversy last year with the publication of an article by the librarian, Fred R. Shapiro, who is also the editor of the book of quotations. Mr. Shapiro had found archival materials that led him to express doubt that Niebuhr was the author.

Stuffed with data and bristling with footnotes, a new report on the federal HealthReform.gov Web site argues ''The Case for Change'' in health insurance. The report includes an interactive map that lets a reader click on any state to see how that state's residents and businesses would benefit -- from the Obama administration's viewpoint, at least -- from an overhaul of the insurance system. The site is operated by the Department of Health and Human Services, whose secretary, Kathleen Sebelius, introduced the report in a conference call this week.

IN New York City, where the unemployment rate remains at 10.3 percent, the jobless have started leaning hard on coffee shops and bookstores to get out of their tiny one-bedrooms and away from their annoying roommates. In these harsh, career-vanishing times, the members of this laptop brigade do everything they can to re-create the office environment they no longer have to complain about. How welcome they are varies. Some small coffeehouses have unplugged the wireless, nailed covers over electrical outlets and posted signs requesting no computer use during lunch. But the New York Public Library has kindly extended its hours at many branches, and behemoths like Starbucks and Barnes & Noble can afford to be more accommodating. At an overcrowded Midtown coffee shop, a barista recently made a woman a cup of coffee, then watched her set up a keyboard, put on headphones and start practicing piano. She's not the only one working in public. Here are portraits of four other New Yorkers trying to get back to the comfort of their offices:

A few weeks ago I had a Dr. Doolittle encounter with the local bear. A solitary two-year old was sitting in the middle of my dirt road as I drove to work. I slowed down, turned off the radio, rolled down the window and had a three-minute conversation with this potential hoodlum. It went something like this: "I hope you have a nice day. I hope you find mushrooms and plenty of grubs and apples. But leave the beehives alone. The bees have their own issues to deal with and don't need any interference from you ."

Although your mailbox may be overflowing with catalogs and a few holiday cards may have started to appear, the United States Postal Service is in crisis. For fiscal year 2009, the Postal Service reported a net loss of $3.8 billion, despite more than $6 billion in cost cuts. Meanwhile, total mail volume fell by nearly 26 billion pieces, or 13 percent.

MONDAY'S PUZZLE - Themes that require a clue like "Word that can follow the ends of ..." are not the most intriguing ones in the crossword construction bag of tricks. However, any puzzle that can weave BLUE-FOOTED BOOBY into its theme is O.K. by me. The other theme phrases are nice as well, and the fill seems especially crisp and interesting, so the arrow on the cruciverbal meter is pointing solidly into the green zone for this Oliver Hill creation.

A 12-man-strong American contingent is headed to Cape Town, South Africa, for Friday's World Cup draw. The United States will be playing in its sixth consecutive World Cup and is regarded as an emerging power, on the field and economically, in the world's game.

There was a full house at Madison Square Garden on Saturday night to watch Boston University, the defending national champions, and Cornell play to a 3-3 draw. For those in the crowd who mainly follow professional hockey, it was indeed a pleasure to see a game end without a penalty shootout, as well as some other advantages of the college game: enthusiastic crowds that don't need prompting from scoreboards, touch-up icing, officials who jump in immediately to stop fights and, of course, pep bands.

Don Nelson, the coach of the Golden State Warriors, has been playing around with his lineup all season, averaging 9.3 players a game, including 11 in a loss to the Kings on Nov. 8. That served to make his absence because of pneumonia all the more noticeable during Tuesday's win over the Dallas Mavericks. Filling in for Nelson, the assistant Keith Smart had only eight healthy players. He apparently considered that two too many; he used just six in beating Dallas, 113-103.

A report on Nov. 15 in the In Transit column, about the new Cruise Terminal 18 at Port Everglades, Fla., misstated the month that the Oasis of the Seas, heading for the terminal on its maiden voyage, departed Finland. It left on Oct. 30, not “earlier this month.”.

A picture on Nov. 15 with a Sports of The Times column, about Andre Agassi’s recent tour to promote his new memoir, “Open,” carried an erroneous credit in some editions. The photograph showing Agassi and his collaborator on the book, J. R. Moehringer, was by Isaac Brekken for The New York Times, not by Stuart Isett for The New York Times.

A listing in the Long Island Calendar in some editions on Nov. 15 and last Sunday misidentified the version of “Miracle on 34th Street” being performed at the John W. Engeman Theater in Northport. It is the musical adaptation by Douglas M. Smith and Vernon L. Stefanic — not the play by Will Severin, Patricia Di Benedetto Snyder and John Vreeke. Both are based on the story by Valentine Davies.

An article last Sunday about Grand Ayatollah Hossein Ali Montazeri of Iran, who has emerged as the spiritual leader of the political opposition, misstated, in some editions, the surname of an Iranian scholar who said Ayatollah Montazeri’s criticisms were especially hurtful to the government because they attacked its assertion of Islamic legitimacy. The scholar, a former seminary student who is now senior fellow at the Washington Institute for Near East Policy, is Mehdi Khalaji, not Khaliji.

The executive director of the Greenwich Tree Conservancy wants town leaders to adopt stricter regulations on the removal of trees on private property.
Some towns have no rules for tree removal on private property, some towns that do have rules take different approaches, and some towns are revising their rules.
The village of Mamaroneck, for example, has no rules for tree removal, but the town of Mamaroneck has regulations that aim to force homeowners to think twice before chopping down trees.
Property owners in New York City generally do not need permits to remove trees, according to a parks department official.
In Madison, for example, a proposed ordinance to protect trees on private property was rejected. But in adjacent Chatham, homeowners require permits.
From aiming to preserve a town’s character to preventing soil erosion and flooding, more local governments are considering limiting homeowners’ ability to remove trees on their property.

The Sandals Emerald Bay resort is in Great Exuma in the Bahamas, not Exhuma. And the Renaissance Aruba Resort & Casino is situated in Oranjestad, Aruba, and has a 40-acre private island. It is not on a 40-acre island.

The government requires the credit bureaus to provide free copies of your credit reports once a year, but not credit scores or monitoring. Yet some companies offer free reports and scores on their Web sites, often to entice customers to sign up for monitoring. And not all scores are created equal – many free scores are meant as a guide for consumers and are not actually used by lenders to assess your creditworthiness.

Dance Student dancers need stage time. Professional choreographers need studio time. In 2004 Barnard College and Dance Theater Workshop realized they could kill two birds with one stone by pairing their constituencies, and the BARNARD PROJECT was born. Choreographers would get residencies and the chance to work with large groups of performers, albeit raw; starry-eyed undergrads would get to step onto a storied stage, for all the world (including many proud moms) to see.

NADLER--David. Passed away on November 26th, 2009 of pancreatic cancer. He was born in Brooklyn on May 16th, 1938. David leaves behind his cherished wife Millie, beloved daughter Laura, stepson Spiros, sister Doris and grandchildren Jason and Olivia. He graduated from Boston University and received his law degree from St. John's University School of Law in 1965. A true advocate, he worked as an attorney and partner of Ballon Stoll Bader and Nadler, LLC in NYC for over 40 years. David was quiet in demeanor, an intellect who loved his work, family and life. Many sought his advice and wise counsel. He created a legacy and will be sorely missed by all. Funeral service will be held at 11:45am on Sunday at Riverside Memorial Chapel, Amsterdam Avenue at 76th Street.

Ben Roethlisberger has spent more time in the neurologist's office than an old copy of Field and Stream. He has survived (and played through) head traumas that would leave most of us wondering where we parked the Batmobile, but the National Football League's new better-safe-than-sorry concussion rules apply even to daredevils. Roethlisberger is out, as is Charlie Batch, leaving the eighth reindeer, Dennis Dixon, as the Steelers' quarterback. Dixon, a star at the University of Oregon before tearing an anterior cruciate ligament in 2007, is best known for establishing a self-promotional Web site before the 2008 draft. The site has not been updated since April 3, 2008; you would think a third-string quarterback would have time to upload a picture of his Super Bowl ring, or something.

Aisling Cuffe of Cornwall-on-Hudson and Brad Miles of Hatfield, Pa., won the Foot Locker Cross Country Championships Northeast Regional at Sunken Meadow State Park in Kings Park. In the girls race, Cuffe took the lead after two miles securing the regional title in 17 minutes 45 seconds over the 5,000 meter course, more than 45 seconds ahead of the second-place finisher Abbey Leonardi of Kennebunkport, Me. (18:31). Chelsea Ley of Clarksboro, N.J., was third in 18:33 and became a three-time national qualifier.

WHAT does the new BMW 5 Series have to do with a new Rolls-Royce Ghost? Each is being built on a modified BMW 7-Series chassis. BMW unveiled the new 5 Series -- the sixth generation of the midrange German luxury car -- last week in Munich. The event was attended by BMW executives and employees, and broadcast on television in Europe.

Pop Formally, jazz and flamenco aren't particularly related beyond deep affinities held by musicians for one style or the other. But improvisers learned long ago that they can push music anywhere they like. CHANO DOMÍNGUEZ, the Spanish jazz pianist born in 1960 in Cadiz -- flamenco's birthplace -- has done a beautiful job of moving jazz and Spanish music together. His sets typically encompass songs by Thelonious Monk and Bill Evans, the Catalan folk art of Frederic Mompou and Cuban boleros. This week he's performing his own takes on the music from Miles Davis's album ''Kind of Blue.'' His excellent band includes the flamenco singer Blas Córdoba, the bassist Mario Rossy, the percussionist Israel (Piraña) Suárez and the dancer and palmero Tomás Moreno Romero, known as Tomasito. Why does a small band in a jazz club need a dancer? Because some kinds of motion qualify as music. Go see him: you'll understand. Thursday to Sunday at 7:30 and 9:30 p.m., with additional 11:30 shows on Friday and Saturday, the Jazz Standard, 116 East 27th Street, Manhattan, (212) 576-2232, jazzstandard.com; $30.

HERZFELD--Henry, on November 26, 2009 at age 95. Beloved husband of Ellen Langner. Father of Alan and Patti of Boise, ID and John of Los Angeles, CA. Grandfather of Amy, Zack and Holland. Lovingly remembered by Virginia, Neal, Caroline and Gregory Luppescu and David, Natalie, Sophia and Geoffrey Langner. Henry was an alumnus of the University of Pennsylvania and Rutgers University Law School. A WWII veteran in the 83rd Infantry Division which liberated Dachau, he was awarded the Bronze Star and was appointed a Military Governor in Bavaria. He was founder and president of Eastern Maintenance Company and a longtime member of Mountain Ridge Country Club. Hank was an elegant gentleman who will be greatly missed by all who knew him.

The top 30 players in the world can earn good livings. But it is considerably more difficult for the players ranked just below them. Their appearance fees are lower, and they rarely are invited to the tournaments that offer the best prize money. For these players, the World Chess Cup now being held in Khanty Mansiysk, Russia, is a great opportunity. With a field of 128 and prize money totaling $1.6 million -- with $120,000 going to the winner -- the tournament is giving some second-tier players a chance to compete against the elite, and perhaps to join them. The winner also will be seeded into the candidates' matches for the world championship.

The Royal Hideaway Playacar, an adults-only all-inclusive resort in Playa del Carmen, on the Yucatán Peninsula of Mexico, is offering 50 percent off stays through Dec. 22. It's every other night free. Stay four nights, for example, and pay for two; stay six and pay for three. Nightly rates start at $300 a person (or $150 a night, if you factor in the discount), based on double occupancy, and includes meals at the resort's restaurants. To reserve, call (800) 999-9182 or visit www.royalhideaway.com.
FISHER--Carol Guthrie. Former purser Pan Am died November 6 after a short illness. Her warmth, humor, and kindness will be missed by her many friends and family.

ROGGE--Carl F.,Jr. (Fred). Age 89. Cherished husband and best friend to wife Julia for 44 years. Beloved father to Fred and Chris and grandfather to Hannah. A Wesleyan grad, he served in the 36th Infantry Division of the US Army throughout WWII and upon discharge was a Captain. He graduated from Virginia Law School and practiced law for 50 years in NYC, retiring as a partner of Lord Day & Lord, Barrett Smith. He had a lively interest in history, music, nature, and sports. He was renowned for his curmudgeonly wit. He will be missed, loved, and remembered by all who knew him. He asked that any memorials in his name to AHRC (Association for the Help of Retarded Children), 83 Maiden Lane, New York, NY 10038. Private family funeral. Memorial service at the Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Ave. at E. 81st St., Tuesday, December 1st at 3pm.

WEIN--Alan. The Board of Governors and Members of Hampshire Country Club are deeply saddened by the passing of our esteemed member and past president, Alan "Scoop" Wein. Our heartfelt sympathy is extended to his children Linda and Mark and to all the members of his family. Stan Brettschneider, President

You don't have to settle for that dreaded middle seat on your next flight. With a new tool from ExpertFlyer.com, you can nab a better one. The site, which caters to frequent fliers in search of upgrades and awards, is offering a service that allows passengers to set up a ''seat alert'' for any aisle or window seat, even if it's occupied. That way, you don't have to waste your time checking in with the airline every free moment before your flight. If the seat you want becomes available, you receive an e-mail message.

FOLEY--Thomas Michael, July 27, 1945 to November 24, 2009, son of the late Lee Foley and actress Barbara Berjer Foley of New York City. Longtime resident of Tanya Towers/UCP, Mike loved travel, camp, Broadway shows. Loved by his friends and family in New York and Seattle. Memorial service, December 3 at 10:30am, Andrett's Funeral Home, 353 2nd Ave. Remembrances: Tanya Towers/UCP 620 E. 13th St. 10009.

Inwood, the northernmost neighborhood in Manhattan, is a place of hills and history. Inwood Hill Park, 196 acres of tree-filled landscape, dominates the scene, and traces of Lenape Indians and Dutch settlers abound. But there are relative newcomers, too, including opera singers and others who are attracted to Inwood's burgeoning arts community. One artist who lives there -- and grew up there -- is Lin-Manuel Miranda, the Grammy- and Tony-winning creator of the Broadway musical ''In the Heights.'' The expedition begins at the 207th Street station, the terminus of the A train. ELISA MALA

POSTHORN--Stanley. 24 December 1915 31 October 2009. Stanley Posthorn was a prominent public relations and marketing executive at Time Inc. who established a marketing presence for Fortune Magazine and was responsible for the innovative celebrity marketing campaigns at the then newly founded People Magazine that featured artists, politicians and celebrities such as Andy Warhol, Paul Newman, Joe Namath, Dinah Shore and many, many others. His efforts were largely responsible for People achieving the premier position in celebrity reporting that it still commands today. He died at the age 93 following a protracted illness according to his nephew Alan Dine. Posty, as he was to become known to his close friends, was born in Cincinnati, Ohio. He served with honor for over four years with the military, rising to the rank of captain. While serving in the conflict in France, he received a medal for bravery in action. After the war, Posty moved to New York and through his love of the theater and the fine arts he befriended artists such as Andy Warhol, Joe Brainard, Jim Dine, Ellsworth Kelly Rex Lau, Diane Mayo and Esteban Vicente, whose early work he collected. His art collection also included the works of Frank Stella, Robert Youngblood, Robert Rauschenberg and others. Over the years, he donated art works from his collection to numerous museums including the Metropolitan Museum of Art, Museum of Modern Art and the Parrish Art Museum in Southampton. His Joe Brainard collection, donated to the Metropolitan Museum of Art, was publicly shown in 2008. In addition to his volunteer leadership and philanthropy in the art world, Stanley actively supported the Weizmann Institute of Science in Israel, where he provided gifts in the memory of his partner Norman Mann, and where his estate will create the Stanley Posthorn-Norman Mann Discovery Endowment Fund to support cutting edge research in perpetuity. His love for "Ojay" a Lakeland terrier, prompted him to include various animal shelters as major beneficiaries of his estate. Posty was also a founding member of the East End Gay Organization (EEGO) which fought back attempts to restrict Gays and Lesbians from congregating at Fowler Beach in Southampton. Posty will be remembered for his innovative and witty mind, for his readiness to share his personal views and opinions, his knowledge and experience in art and theater and for living a life that knew no boundaries. A memorial will be held honoring his life, work and friends. For more information please contact Posty2009@yahoo.com.

As the Senate begins debate this week on health care legislation, the question of whether to keep the bill's provision for a government-run health insurance plan, known as the public option, will be one of the most contentious. The Democrats still have not nailed down the 60 votes they need to pass the provision. Three conservative Democrats and one independent are threatening to scuttle the entire legislation if the public option, as now written, stays in.

VALENCIANO--Robert. Renegade artist Robert Valenciano succumbed to his battle with cancer after a short stay at Cabrini Hospice in NYC, dying on November 13th in the arms of his sister Doris Caceres. Born in Santiago, Cuba on April 4, 1965, Robert and his sister left Cuba with their mother Leila Arrowsmith in 1970 immigrating to Union City, NJ. Robert was five years old. After moving to New York City in the early eighties, Robert became a prominent figure in the downtown gay club and bar scene, working and playing in numerous notorious late night clubs. A long time HIV/AIDS survivor, Robert was a challenging figure, a radical artist self-defined as having "no commercial ambition." His trajectory as an artist was kaleidoscopic, beginning as a self-taught fashion designer making one of a kind pieces for many downtown artists in the late eighties and early nineties. His inspiration and intuitive approach to creating moved him freely from fashion and poetry to composing electronic/computer generated music under the name "Dwarf Colony." For a time he also freelanced as a dresser for numerous Broadway theater productions. Along with drawing, collage and photography, Robert's mature work was punctuated by sculptures of carved wood; sexually aggressive forms encrusted with thousands of jeweled mirrors that are now in the hands of a few private collections. Robert's influential pioneering style, his generous free spirit and unapologetic approach to living life inspired all those who knew him. He is survived by his mother, Leila, his sister, Doris Caceres, her husband, John, and their children Olivia and Gabriel. Memorial services to celebrate and remember Robert's life will be held December 12th at 3pm at Grace and St. Paul's Church, 123 West 71st Street, NYC. Longtime friend Reverend Martin Hauser will be performing services. Instead of flowers, the family is encouraging friends and family to make a donation in Roberts name to the Gay Men's Health Crisis. (www.gmhc.org)

FISHMAN--Ted S.,83, on November 24, 2009. Loving husband of Rita (nee Pock), father of Mark L. Fishman and Aviva, Dr. Glenn I. Fishman and Joanne, and father to Lisa and John Abercrombie, Laura and Gary Lefkowitz, and Jill and Laurent Demesmaeker. Adoring grandfather of Robert, Julia, Adrienne, Adam, Michelle, Rachel, Matthew and Samantha. Brother of Norman and Sheila Fishman, and Norma and the late Edwin Kaminsky. Ted was happiest when surrounded by family and friends. Memorial service at Synagogue for the Arts, Tuesday, December 1, 11am. Donations can be made to VNSNY Hospice Care.

NIGHT AT THE MUSEUM: BATTLE OF THE SMITHSONIAN In the sequel to ''Night at the Museum'' Ben Stiller returns as a museum guard who learns to cope with exhibits that come to life at night. The result is a ''shallow and harmlessly diverting picture,'' A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times last May. ''The conjuring of all these artifacts -- many of them really on display in various parts of Smithsonian -- is delightful and often ingenious.'' Shawn Levy directed; with Amy Adams, Hank Azaria, Robin Williams and Ricky Gervais. (Fox, Blu-ray $39.99, standard definition $29.98, PG) TERMINATOR SALVATIONChristian Bale stars in the fourth ''Terminator'' movie as John Connor, the messianic rebel leader whose fate it is to confront a self-aware computer network with totalitarian ambitions. The mayhem-filled action, Mr. Scott wrote in The Times in May, is ''a symphony of screaming gears, anguished torque and thumping collisions of metal and flesh.'' The director is McG, of ''Charlie's Angels'' fame; the cast includes Sam Worthington and Bryce Dallas Howard. (Warners, Blu-ray $35.99, standard definition $28.98, PG-13)

In theater, Brian was a superb actor, director, designer and writer. In life, he was the ultimate loyal friend, ever calm and cheerful in the face of adversity. We will miss him very much.

KLEIN--Lillian, passed away Friday at her home in New York City, she was 101 years old. She is predeceased by her husband, Charles Klein and daughter, Susan Klauber. A private service will be held Monday at 10am at the Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel.

To the Sports Editor: Re ''Hand of Henry Sends France to South Africa,'' Nov. 19: Thierry Henry's recent game-winning handball for France in a World Cup qualifying match against Ireland raises the question of the degree to which athletes have an ethical obligation to follow the rules of their sport.

SHANGHAI -- A cargo plane crashed shortly after taking off from the Pudong International Airport here on Saturday morning, killing three American crew members and injuring four others, including an American. The plane, which was bound for Kyrgyzstan, caught fire shortly after taking off about 8:10 a.m. Saturday, according to China's state-run news media.

Big Comeback Top-seeded Montana scored the final 40 points, including Severin Campbell's interception return for a touchdown, left, to beat South Dakota State, 61-48, in the F.C.S. playoffs. Bowl Bound Southern Methodist's 26-21 victory over Tulane guaranteed the Mustangs one of Conference USA's six automatic bowl bids. S.M.U. has not played in a bowl game since 1984.

BERNSTEIN--Leon, died November 9 at age 92. Son of the late Sarah and William Bernstein. Beloved husband of the late Harriet Bernstein. A devoted father, grandfather, and great-grandfather, he is survived by daughter Sally Germain and son-in-law Allan Beinhorn, son Iver Bernstein and daughter-in-law Kay Sherman; grandchildren Benjamin Bernstein and Nina Bernstein, Paul Germain and wife Jennifer Germain; and great-grandchildren Sophie Germain and Eli Germain. An institutional food distributor and broker for nearly 70 years, he was a unique entrepreneur. Having successfully sold and rebuilt his food brokerage company Bernco Sales three times rather than retire, he was looking forward to starting it yet again at the age of 90. He will be missed. Donations in his name may be made to Great Neck Public Library, 516-466-8055.

In his long N.B.A. career, Jason Kidd, the Dallas Mavericks point guard, has proved to be among the best rebounding point guards, one of only three players, along with Magic Johnson and Oscar Robertson, to record 100 or more triple-doubles. Kidd has yet to record one this season but has come close on several occasions. Even at his relatively advanced age of 36, Kidd is still a threat, unlike his teammate Drew Gooden, right, who may be the least likely starter in the N.B.A. to record a triple-double.

The cause of the crash of one of Russia's most illustrious trains was identified on Saturday as a homemade bomb that went off on the tracks between Moscow and St. Petersburg, killing more than 25 people, wounding scores of others and raising fears of a new era of terrorism here. Officials called the explosion on Friday night the worst terrorist attack in Russia in years, outside volatile Muslim parts of the North Caucasus region, which includes Chechnya. There were no immediate credible claims of responsibility.
To the Editor: Re: ''Vanished Guideposts.''

Art The week after Thanksgiving brings the cornucopia of art, hedonism and deal making that is Art Basel Miami Beach. Repeat visitors will notice some structural changes to the main event, in addition to the exhibitor turnover induced by the economy. The ''Art Positions'' section of the fair, booths dedicated to newer dealers that were formerly in shipping containers on the beach, has been moved into the exhibition halls. An ''Oceanfront'' area for talks, performances and video has been organized by the artist Pae White and the nonprofit public art group Creative Time. Booths inside the convention center will be larger than in past years, and the layout has been tweaked to create more dining and resting spaces. Thursday through Dec. 6, Miami Beach Convention Center, artbaselmiamibeach.com.

PEPPERDENE--Margaret W.,teacher and scholar died November 20 in Decatur, GA. Emerita Professor of English at Agnes Scott College, she taught there and at The Paideia School for more than 50 years. Her students left her classroom changed by her passion, wit, insight and integrity. She received her Ph.D. in English from Vanderbilt University. She formed close friendships with Eudora Welty, Robert Penn Warren, Reynolds Price, and Richard Wilbur. Amherst College, Sewanee and Yale University gave her awards for teaching excellence. Her academic research, keen intellect and literary contacts were lavished on her students.

BIRNBAUM--Bernard, died November 26 at age 89. CBS News Producer since 1951. He greeted each day with enthusiasm, curiosity and passion and is deeply mourned by family, friends and colleagues. Husband of the late Ronnie Birnbaum, beloved father to daughters Deborah and Amy, sons-in-law John Kocay and Bernard Furnival, and adored grandfather of Sam, Emily, Eloise and Amelia. He was a legend in the news business, producing hundreds of documentaries for CBS while covering the major events of the 20th century. Joined the CBS program Sunday Morning in 1990. Services at 1pm, Tuesday, December 1st, Larchmont Temple, 75 Larchmont Ave, Larchmont, NY.

Thanksgiving week is always exhilarating in the city. This year New Yorkers could show off their autumn finery before the weather called for coats. Extremes of fashion are out, replaced by more functional styles. Celebrated New Yorkers rarely seen by day popped up, including, left, Judith Jamison, the artistic director of Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater; left center, Sanford and Joan Weill, the philanthropists; and right, Carmen Dell'Orefice, the model. Legs, stockinged or in leggings, dictate the look. Winter shorts in corduroy or flannel, top right, were a big surprise. And Macy's Thanksgiving Day Parade was never seen to better advantage, thanks to its new zigzag route.
