MINOR--Emily Brown Chadbourne, died peacefully on October 30, 2009, at the Osborn Home in Rye, New York, aged 94. Mrs. Minor was born in Manhattan on March 7, 1915, only daughter of Frank M. and Lily B. Chadbourne. She graduated from Nightingale-Banford School in 1931, and Barnard College with a degree in chemistry in 1937. In December of 1937 she married Allen H. Minor, a medical student at Columbia University. The Minors moved to Rye in 1946. Mrs. Minor was an active member of Christ Episcopal Church, the League of Women Voters, and a volunteer at Grace Church, White Plains. Mrs. Minor is survived by her four children, John, Kathleen, and Caroline of California, and Jane of Queensland, Australia; fourteen grandchildren, and 23 great-grandchildren. A memorial service will be held on December 3rd at 11am at Christ Church, Rye.

GUGLIELMO--Grace M.,89, Mother, Writer, Gardener and Artist of Life. Died peacefully at home on Thanksgiving surrounded by her family. Beloved wife of Angelo; 11 children, 21 grandchildren, an extraordinary life lived. Memorial December 5, 10:15am at St. Andrew Avellino Church, Flushing.

WASSER--David L. (born David Wasserzug), of New City, NY, died peacefully on November 21, 2009. Born in New York City on December 6, 1917, David recently retired from his attorney/CPA practice. He is survived by his wife of 59 years Shirley (nee Shapiro), children Louis Wasser (Debra-Ann), Joan Heller (Richard) and grandchildren Cara, Jesse, Adam and Elliot. Services were held on November 22, 2009 at Cedar Park Cemetery in Emerson, NJ. Donations may be made to United Hospice of Rockland, New City, NY or to a charity of your choice.

An article last Sunday about developments in the trial in Italy of an American college student, Amanda Knox, and her Italian former boyfriend in the death of her British housemate in 2007 misstated the age of a man convicted in the case last year. The man, Rudy Guede, who is appealing his conviction for murder and sexual assault, is 22, not 30. The article also misstated the name of the chief prosecutor in the case in some copies. He is Giuliano Mignini, not Giuseppe.

REICHERT--Horst D. Doctor of engineering, beloved husband of Luzie Bohmer for 54 years passed on November 21 in Buffalo, New York. Born in Cologne, Germany (1928). Dr. Reichert met his wife in Vienna. He emigrated to Albany, NY founding Reichert Construction specializing in bridge building and road rehabilitation. He is survived by Dr. Andrew and Christina Loik Reichert of Buffalo, Kathryn and Thomas Koenig of Kennett Square, PA and grandchildren Emily Grace, Gabriella and Madeleine. His generosity and wisdom will be greatly missed.

The latest work from that country, as well as some compelling earlier films, will be featured in a festival that begins on Friday at TriBeCa Cinemas, sponsored by the Romanian Cultural Institute.

TOYOTA announced on Wednesday that it would modify about four million vehicles to address a problem with unintended acceleration after some consumers complained that floor mats were interfering with the gas pedal. At a news conference, Toyota said it would instruct dealers to shorten the vehicles' existing pedal by about three-quarters of an inch. The company said it would also start equipping its vehicles with smart pedals, a system that the Center for Auto Safety said should be required for all cars.

ROSENBLATT--Ann, 92, Miami Beach, Florida and New York on November 23, 2009 at her home. We mourn the passing of a beloved wife, mother, aunt, grandmother, and great-grandmother. She was the adored wife of the late Sam Rosenblatt; devoted and loving mother of Gary and Carole, Kenny and Susan; devoted aunt of Marty (Marilyn), Alan (Linda); devoted grandmother of Lisa (Brian), Francie (Evan), Michael (Jane), Dava, Jill (Andrew), Jonathan (Michele), Robert (Jessica), Mitchell (Lauren); and beloved great-grandmother of 19! She will be greatly missed by all who loved her. Contributions in her memory may be made to Alzheimer's Research.

BRESNAN--William J.,a visionary in the cable industry whose 50-year career ranged from the early days of community antenna television to serving as President and CEO of the nation's largest cable company to the founding of his own company, Bresnan Communications, which he led through 25 years of growth and innovation, died Friday at his home in Greenwich, CT from complications of prostate cancer. He was 75. Mr. Bresnan leaves his loving wife, Ann, his six beloved children: Michael, Robert, and Daniel Bresnan, Colleen Shelden, Mary Cashman and Maureen Ward; and grandchildren: Matthew, Peter, Sean, Melanie, Bettina, and Dylan Bresnan, Grace and Teddy Cashman, Katherine, Anna and Will Shelden. He is survived by his much loved sister and brother, Marilyn Berg and Patrick J. Bresnan. He leaves his in-law children; Mary Ann Sherry, Victoria Bresnan, Lauren Versel Bresnan, Brian Cashman, Donald Shelden and Michael Ward, and his step-grandchildren, Donald Jr., Alexa and step-grandchildren Haven Shelden, Emma and Michael Ward and his step-children Jennifer, Kirstie, Lindsay and William Benedict and Courtenay and T.J. Carella and their children Ainsley and Devon Carella. A memorial service will be held at St. Mary's Church in Greenwich, CT on Wednesday December 2nd at 11am and the wake will be held Monday and Tuesday between 4-8pm at the Leo P. Gallagher & Sons funeral home at 31 Arch Street in Greenwich.

C. J. Spiller, left, of Clemson set an N.C.A.A. record with his seventh career kickoff return for a touchdown. Spiller took the opening kickoff 88 yards for a score against South Carolina. Riley Skinner threw for 372 yards and a Wake Forest-record 5 touchdowns in a 45-35 win over Duke. He set team single-season records with 3,160 yards and 26 touchdown passes.

THE artist Richard Phillips, a grown man of 47, admits he is addicted to ''Gossip Girl.'' But then, with reproductions of two of his paintings featured prominently on the show (''Scout'' hangs above Chuck Bass's bed, ''Spectrum'' in the stairway of the van der Woodsen home), it has made him into a pop icon, and his work into true Pop Art. Now the nonprofit Art Production Fund has teamed up with Intermix to sell limited-edition ink-jet canvas prints of the Phillips works (essentially the same ones seen on the show, scaled down a tad). ''It's so wonderful how my work has been able to reach out,'' he said. ''Warhol would never have been able to dream of such a thing.'' Printed canvas reproductions of ''Scout'' (above) and ''Spectrum'' (left), $250 each at

CRAIG--Douglas Broward, 80, resident of Charlottesville, VA, formerly of Briarcliff Manor, NY died of cancer on November 25, 2009. Mr. Craig was born in New York City, Son of the late Dr. Howard R. Craig, executive director of the New York Academy of Medicine and the late Agnes Broward Craig. He was the grandson of Napolean Bonaparte Broward, Governor of Florida from 19051909 for whom Broward County, Florida is named. He was the beloved husband of Joyce Powell Craig, adored father Deborah Soukup, Douglas Craig, Elizabeth Helfman and Robert Craig as well as stepchildren; Douglas Gernert, Catherine Ramsay and ten grandchildren. He graduated from; Trinity School in 1946, from Harvard with an AB in 1950 and a LLB in 1953. He was: an Associate of Debevoise and Plimpton, past President of St. Joe Minerals Corporation, New York President and CEO of Falconbridge Nickel Mines, Ltd. Toronto managing partner of Webster and Sheffield, of council Ceccarelli Weprin, PLLC, President and CEO of Craig Consulting Company. He has served on many Boards including Burke Rehab Center, White Plains, NY, member of the Vestry Trinity Church on Wall Street where he served on the Church Scholarship Committee and was President of the Harvard Club of New York City. He also served on the following Boards; The Century Association, Prentice Cup Committee, Past-President and Chairman of the International Lawn Tennis Club of USA and Ethical Resource Center in D.C. He was a past member of the Pleasantville Tennis Club, the Whippoorwill Club and the Sleepy Hollow Country Club. He was currently a Board Member of Farmington Country Club and a member of the Boar's Head Sports Club. He leaves a strong legacy of wise counsel and leadership in the worlds of his professional, volunteer and his family life that will be cherished by all. A memorial service will be held in Charlottesville, VA early next year, the date as yet to be arranged. Memorial contributions may be made to the Martha Jefferson Hospital Foundation, Palliative Care Service, 459 Locust Avenue, Charlottesville, VA 22902 or Harvard Club of New York Foundation, "Scholarship Fund", 35 w. 44th St., New York, NY 10036. Condolences may be sent to the family at: www.hillandwood.com
JAY LENO Saw a story on TV last night about the Louisiana Purchase. Remember how Congress bought Louisiana? Not the whole state, just Senator Mary Landrieu.

RICE--Charles Francis, of Summit, NJ, loving husband of Nancy, father of Cathy (Gorrell), John, and David, passed away November 23 after a brief illness. Born in Lackawanna, NY on August 12, 1927 to Leslie Hamilton and Gladys Miller Rice, Charlie married Nancy Scarborough Garnaus in 1953. He served in the U.S. Coast Guard, graduated from Hamilton College in 1950 with a BA in history, and graduated from Cornell University Law School in 1955. Charlie joined the Department of Justice as a trial attorney in the Antitrust Division in 1955, worked for Donovan Leisure Newton & Irvine from 1957 to 1961, and joined Mobil Oil Company in 1961 as Counsel in the North American Division. Charlie's career at Mobil spanned 28 years. During the 1970s and 80s, he oversaw Mobil's significant crude oil, gasoline, and acquisition legal matters, including Mobil's acquisition of International Paper. He rose to Assistant General Counsel for Antitrust and Litigation before retiring in 1990, following which "Papa" was promoted to grandfather par excellence by Sarah, Courtney, Tanner, Lucy, Stephen, Michael, and Tyler. Classical TERRY RILEY'S ''IN C'' is celebrating its 45th anniversary this year, but it has been virtually a standard repertory piece in New York for the last decade. Its peculiar magic is that it always sounds both thoroughly familiar and entirely fresh. The score is a sequence of 53 short melodic figures, and once you've heard ''In C,'' you'd know those snippets anywhere. Yet no specific instrumentation or ensemble size is recommended, and though the musicians must play the 53 figures in order, they can do so at any tempo and with any number of repetitions. So no two performances are the same.

The N.F.L. is usually regarded as the industry leader in North American sports, but there is at least one area where it lags well behind the N.H.L.: the medical protocol for clearing players to return from concussion injuries. Previously, the decision on when a player should return was made by team physicians and trainers.

OLIVIA JUDSON The basis of evolutionary potential is clear enough in principle. Whether a population can evolve to cope with new circumstances depends on how much underlying genetic variation there is: do any individuals in the population have the genes to cope, even barely, with the new environment, or not? If not, everybody dies, and it's game over. If yes, evolution may come to the rescue, improving, as time goes by, the ability of individuals to cope in the new environment. What determines the extent of the underlying genetic variation? Factors such as how big the population is (bigger populations usually contain more genetic variation) and how often mutations occur. Let me give an example of how this works. Imagine you have a population of algae that have been living for generations in a comfy freshwater pool. Now suppose there's a ghastly accident and, all of a sudden, the pool becomes super-salty. Whether the algae will be able to survive depends on whether any individuals already have any capacity to survive and reproduce in salty water. If none of them do, they all die, and the population goes extinct. But if some do, then the survivors will reproduce, and over time, beneficial mutations will accumulate such that the algae get better and better at living in a high-salt environment.

BRODY--Frances Lasker, died at home on November 12 at the age of 93. She lived in Los Angeles, California, and had been in ill health for several years. She was born in Chicago, Illinois, and attended Chicago Latin, the Madeira School, and graduated from Vassar College in 1937. During World War II, she was serving in the Ambulance Corp when she met Sidney Brody, whom she married in 1942. She then moved to New York while her husband, a much decorated Lieutenant Colonel in the Army Air Corp, flew missions in Europe and the Pacific. After the war, they moved to Los Angeles in 1949. She was prominent in the Los Angeles community as a long-time advocate and activator of the arts, education and health. She was a Board member of Center Theatre Group, American Red Cross Southern California Chapter, former President of the UCLA Art Council, the UCLA Council of the Humanities, and Advisory Council of UCLA, a board member of The Museum Association of the Los Angeles County Museum of History, Science and Art, and, until a few years ago, served as an Overseer of The Huntington Library, Art Collections and Gardens. She organized and Chaired a number of major exhibitions for the public, including a major Picasso exhibition at UCLA to celebrate his 80th Birthday and the "Henri Matisse Retrospective of 1966", which was exhibited at the UCLA Art Galleries and The Boston Museum of Fine Arts. She was an organizer and director of a pilot program for elementary grade children, supported by the Los Angeles Recreation and Parks Department and UCLA School of Education. For her work, she received numerous Awards including the Boy Scouts of America Annual Award, the UCLA Distinguished Service Award, the Los Angeles Times Best Dressed for Her Life, and the Los Angeles Times Woman of the Year. Mr. Brody, a real estate developer, was also active in community affairs, having served as Chairman of the California Community Foundation and the Los Angeles County Art Museum. Mr. Brody passed away in 1983. Brody is survived by her son, Christopher Brody, and daughter Susan Lasker Brody, a daughter-in-law, two grandchildren, and a great-grandchild. Services will be private. Gifts may be made in her memory to the Lasker Medical Foundation, 110 East 42nd Street, New York, NY, 10017.

For Italians it's old hat, this business of living with your parents until you're, say, double or triple the age of consent. Not coincidentally, Italy has one of the lowest birth rates in the world. But now comes news that more Americans are living with their parents. The recession has sent 10 percent of adults under 35 back home, a Pew survey says. In addition, 15 percent of adults under 35 said they had put off marriage; 14 percent postponed having a baby. Could this lead to the Italian problem? As the British politician David Willetts once observed, ''Living at home with your parents is a very powerful contraception.''

Janeiro I HAD set my umbrella and chair near the water in the early hours of what would soon become a perfect summer day. Like most people, I prefer the beach when it is deserted, and I had the place all to myself, no vendors to be seen, parading their sunglasses and suntan oils; no drinks, sandwiches or sweets offered in singing voices. Above all, no kids kicking balls or sand in my face. I held a book and was intent on doing some serious reading.

von KOSCHEMBAHR--Joan Raible of Manhattan and Watch Hill, RI died on November 24 at the age of 84. She was born in Cleveland, OH and raised in Shaker Heights and Laurel, MS and was predeceased by her daughters Christina and Lisa and their father John. She will be sorely missed by her great friends Hyman Gross and William Gowen; her brothers Michael and Jonathan Raible; her nieces Catherine Allport and Susan Allport Howell and a myriad of great-nieces and nephews, relatives, and friends. Joan vK, as she was known, had a sly wit and a highly original take on life. Maddenly vague, yet sharp as a tack, she sized up a situation as quickly as a general in full battle. She was poetic and stylish, funny and always game, and those who loved her never imagined this life without her. In lieu of flowers, please send contributions to the Lauren Rogers Museum, 5th Ave. Laurel, MS 39440.

8 P.M. (HBO) THE 25TH ANNIVERSARY ROCK AND ROLL HALL OF FAME CONCERT On Oct. 29 and 30, in two concerts at Madison Square Garden, Hall of Fame inductees and hopefuls paid tribute to the organization (which technically began more than 25 years ago, but who's counting?) in evenings that Jon Pareles, writing in The New York Times, called ''the kind of family reunions where distant cousins finally meet.'' Jerry Lee Lewis opens this four-hour condensed presentation with ''Great Balls of Fire''; Crosby, Stills and Nash perform their anthem ''Woodstock'' before merging voices with Bonnie Raitt, Jackson Browne and James Taylor; Stevie Wonder riffs alongside Smokey Robinson, John Legend, Sting and B. B. King; Paul Simon reunites with Art Garfunkel in ''The Sounds of Silence''; and Aretha Franklin and Annie Lennox, above left and right, belt out ''Chain of Fools.'' As the evening progresses, U2 (joined by Mick Jagger and the Black Eyed Peas), Metallica (with Ozzy Osbourne, Lou Reed and Ray Davies), the Jeff Beck Band (with Buddy Guy) and Bruce Springsteen and the E Street Band (with Billy Joel, Darlene Love and John Fogerty) do what comes naturally: they rock on. 10 A.M. (ABC) THIS WEEK WITH GEORGE STEPHANOPOULOS Senator Lindsey Graham, Republican of South Carolina, and Senator Bernard Sanders, independent of Vermont, discuss the possible increase in troops in Afghanistan. Senator Carl Levin, Democrat of Michigan, and Dick Armey, the former Republican House leader, continue the debate on ''Face the Nation,'' at 10:30 on CBS.

THE NEWS A spokesman for Lou Dobbs, the former cable news host known for his tough-talking immigration politics, said Mr. Dobbs was considering challenging Senator Robert Menendez, a New Jersey Democrat and the chamber's only Hispanic member. BEHIND THE NEWS After Mr. Dobbs abruptly resigned from CNN on Nov. 11 rather than put aside his political views while on the air, rumors began that he would try to capitalize on recent Republican gains with a run for the Senate (or even the White House). But party officials in New Jersey worried that he would be a one-note candidate.

THE city's unofficial motto, ''Keep Austin Weird,'' blares from bumper stickers on BMWs and jalopies alike, on T-shirts worn by joggers along Lady Bird Lake and in the windows of independently owned shops and restaurants. It's an exhortation for a city that clings to eccentricity, even in the face of rapid development -- downtown Austin, for one, is being transformed with a fleet of high-rise condos and a W Hotel, scheduled to open late next year. But this funky college town, known for its liberal leanings and rich music scene, has little to worry about -- at least as long as its openhearted citizens, with their colorful bungalows and tattoos, do their part to keep the city endearingly odd. As one local put it: ''As long as Austinites keep decorating their bodies and cars, we're going to be fine.'' Friday

FAUX fur has gotten a bad rap. Synthetic, cheap, on par with pleather, it has never quite found favor in the fashion world, until this fall. Shaggy, Muppet-like furs that are fake and flaunting it are suddenly showing up on some very stylish women: Sienna Miller (far right) was spotted walking her dog in a faux fur jacket from Topshop; the art world fixture Yvonne Force Villareal (right) has hit the town in fuzzy numbers from the Opening Ceremony ''Where the Wild Things Are'' collection. Even Kate Moss, who has been called a ''super tramp'' by PETA, has hopped aboard the trend. Her holiday collection for Topshop has a show-stopping fur jacket that is as fake as a Rolex on Canal Street. But, seen here (inset) on a model during Paris Fashion Week, it looks like a million bucks. From left: ''Where the Wild Things Are'' Judith vest, $415 at Opening

Nearly every day for the past three years, Adam Stoltman, a photojournalist, has captured the scene outside his north-facing window in the Chelsea neighborhood on the West Side of Manhattan. The Empire State Building is at the center of his unchanging yet dynamic view from Eighth Avenue and West 24th Street. IT'S safe to say that no one has ever gone to Art Basel Miami Beach to buy a handbag -- until now, maybe. That's because artfully crafted, limited-edition fashion pieces are among the hot tickets at this year's fair, Dec. 3 to 6. Stuff like a Jil Sander T-shirt printed with work by the French-Japanese painter Tsuguharu Foujita (top, $300) or a pair of hand-drawn Vena Cava slip-ons ($20), both of which were designed for Interview magazine's 40th anniversary and will be sold only in vending machines at the Mondrian hotel. In the Design District, an array of fashion houses will be opening pop-up shops, as part of the Limited Edition Experiences program. Among them are Fendi, which will have Roman artisans and the French graffiti artist André customizing handbags; Gucci, which will offer its Miami-exclusive Mark Ronson-designed sneakers (middle, $540); and the bag designer Katherine Fleming, who asked 16 artists to rework her python Jane clutch (above, a bag by Alejandro Cardenas). Starting Nov. 30, they will be auctioned off in her shop and, for those who don't make it to Miami, on her Web site to benefit Bas Fisher Invitational, a nonprofit gallery that provides space for artists to show their work.

BERNSTEIN--Muriel ("Mitzi") 80, died peacefully in her Manhattan apartment November 18, 2009. Originally from the Bronx, she was married to Eli Bernstein, who predeceased her forty years ago. On Long Island, she then devoted her life to raising her two children, Bruce and Vivian; and got herself promoted from a Girl Friday position at Preco Chemical Corporation (later bought by Fosroc/Maser Builders) becoming Vice President giving speeches across the US and the world to architects, engineers, and college/grad students about exposed aggregate; getting known as "America's First Lady of Precast." She was also predeceased by her two older brothers Alex and Seymour (coincidently also Bernstein); and somehow had enough time and energy left to become First Violinist of the Westbury Symphony Orchestra. Retirement did not slow her down, volunteering for the last twenty-five years in New York City for the Eleanor Roosevelt Democratic Club, USO, NYPD 17th Precinct, Doctors Orchestra, and NY Marathon, amongst others. Her big smile and even bigger heart will be deeply missed by all who knew her. The family wishes any gifts in lieu of flowers or money be given to the Stein Senior Center, 340 E. 24th Street, 2nd Fl., NY, NY 10010; (646)395-8083; www.steinseniorcenter.org.

Boston University scored twice in the third period to tie Cornell, 3-3, and force overtime before a capacity crowd of 18,200 at Madison Square Garden. The overtime period ended without a goal, leaving the defending national champion Terriers with a 4-7-3 record. Cornell, the No. 8 team in the country, is 6-2-2.

Theater It is nearly impossible to get a ticket to the Sydney Theater Company production of ''A Streetcar Named Desire'' at the Brooklyn Academy of Music (through Dec. 20), but that show is not the only foreign production to take up residence in Brooklyn of late. Some buffs are also quite excited about ''BRIEF ENCOUNTER,'' courtesy of the Kneehigh Theater Company of Cornwall, England, which starts this week at St. Ann's Warehouse. In her adaptation, Kneehigh's artistic director, Emma Rice, has drawn on the 1945 film of the same title, and also the original source; Noël Coward's play ''Still Life,'' about the frustrated affair between a man and a woman, both married, who meet at a train station. The production incorporates remade film footage and music -- including songs by Coward -- alongside live characters who sometimes seem to jump in and out of a film screen in what sounds like an intriguing, theatrical interpretation of Coward's tale. Previews begin Wednesday; opens Dec. 6; 38 Water Street, at Dock Street, Dumbo, Brooklyn, (718) 254-8779, stannswarehouse.org; $30 to $80.

LOFGREN--Sophie, Owen, Caroline, and Parker Our hearts and lives have been full of sadness for the past year. We continue to mourn your tragic deaths from Carbon monoxide poisoning while vacationing in Aspen last Thanksgiving. No words can express the emptiness, sense of loss, and anger we feel. Your laughter, love for life, and nurturing of friendships will never be forgotten. You are in our thoughts and prayers each day. The families would like to thank all of those who have helped us through this difficult year. With love, Anna, Leo, Drs Renee and Frederick Feuerbach and all the Families.

LEIGHTON--Jan, died November 16 of stroke-related complications. He is survived by a son, Ross, and daughter, Hallie. Performer and coauthor of Rare Words and Rare Words II from Levenger Press. A creative, vibrant spirit, he will be deeply missed. Family plans to create a documentary about his 60-year performing career; anyone with memories or footage to share, see www.janleighton.com. Memorial date to be announced. In lieu of flowers, donations to Strive International, Inky Blue Sea Animal Rescue Project, and Actors Fund.

THOMPSON--David William, November 19, 2009, in New York City at age 95. Born in Fort Wayne, Indiana on September 3, 1914, son of William B. And Georgia Louise (Davis) Thompson. He grew up in Fort Wayne. He received his academic degrees from Indiana University - BS 1938, MS 1940. He taught at this institution from 1942-55, becoming a full professor in 1948. Prior to this, he taught at Sanford University in Alabama and at Butler University in Indianapolis. In 1955 Mr. Thompson began a 22 year leave from teaching to work in the private sector joining the General Electric Company as Manager, Financial Training and Education for the company. In 1957 he joined Peat, Marwick, Mitchell & Co. (KPMG) as partner in charge of personnel with firm-wide responsibilities for all personnel activities for the firm. After nearly 20 years, Mr. Thompson retired from PMM & Co. in 1976 and returned to academia, taking a Chair at the University of Virginia in Charlottesville. He retired from UVA in 1985 after 9 years on the faculty there. An expert in financial cost and not-for-profit accounting, Mr. Thompson held Certified Public Accountant certificates in 16 states. He is a past Chairman of the New York State Boards of Certified Public Accountant Examiners and of Certified Public Accounts, and is a member of Beta Gamma Sigma and of its Director's Table. He was a member of the Regents External Degree Program of the State of New York and a member of Dean's Advisory Council of the School of Business at Indiana University. He was a member of the Board of Directors of the Universidad de las Americas, Mexico City, and a member of its foundation. During his careers, Mr. Thompson was very active in many professional and academic organizations, his contributions centering around committee participation and directorships. Outside his professional world, Mr. Thompson enjoyed photography, tennis, deep sea fishing and traveling extensively both domestically and internationally. He was a member of the University Club, New York, India House, New York and the Farmington Country Club In Charlottesville, VA. He married Miriam Vollmer December 21, 1956. She preceded him in death on June 26, 1984. His second wife, Shirley, survives. They maintained residences in Indiana, New York and Virginia. Visitation Sunday, November 29, Frank Campbell Funeral Home, 1076 Madison Ave, 2-5pm and 7-9pm. Funeral Service Monday, November 30 11am, Park Avenue United Methodist Church, 106 East 86th St. Burial in the family cemetery in Indiana.

In the opening sentence of a key chapter in his new book on the academy, "No University Is an Island: Saving Academic Freedom," Cary Nelson, president of the American Association of University Professors and a self-identified leftist, makes an important, and conciliatory, point: "Although few students or faculty on American campuses who are on either the right or the left ...are inclined to acknowledge each other's perspective, members of both groups feel beleaguered, isolated, outcast and underrepresented in their higher education environments." Later in the chapter Nelson allows that while political correctness is not the "all defining campus cultural force the right makes it out to be, it does operate, in some contexts absurdly." His own example of absurdity (it occurred in his home department) is a faculty appointment that was derailed when it was discovered that the candidate, then teaching in New Zealand, had written a letter to a newspaper criticizing the practice of going barefoot in public places on the grounds that it promoted the spread of disease. A department member decided that the letter "was an attack on the Maori people and thus racist," and even when it was determined that it is not the Maori, but "white hippies, who go barefoot in New Zealand, the majority voted against pursuing the candidate in order, says Nelson, to prove "themselves to colleagues of color."

The producers of the Off-Broadway play "Made in Heaven" have relented on their claim to the Soho Playhouse, announcing on Monday that they would close down their show so that the theater can host a transfer of the Eugene O'Neill play "The Emperor Jones." Last week, the Irish Repertory Theater said that it planned to bring its production of "The Emperor Jones," starring John Douglas Thompson in the title role, to the Soho Playhouse beginning on Dec. 15 -- an announcement that startled the producers of "Made in Heaven," a comedy about conjoined twins that opened at that theater on Nov. 2. The "Made in Heaven" producers said last Wednesday that their contract with the Soho Playhouse gave them the discretion to close down their show after giving four weeks' notice. But on Monday, they said they would close the show after its Dec. 7 performance. In a statement, Barbara Ligeti, the lead producer of "Made in Heaven," said, "We agonized over this decision," adding: "The Soho Playhouse made us a very favorable offer, and we felt that sparring with them, to the detriment of the Irish Rep's wonderful production, would be counterproductive and mean-spirited."

While Rocco Landesman, the chairman of the National Endowment for the Arts, has grabbed the lion's share of headlines for his travels to Peoria, Ill., his colleague Jim Leach, the chairman of the National Endowment for the Humanities, is planning a road trip of his own. On Monday, the N.E.H. said that Mr. Leach would begin a 50-state civility tour on Tuesday in Concord, N.H., where he plans to address a group of civic, political and academic leaders on the subject of hate speech and its dangers. Mr. Leach, the former Republican congressman from Iowa, mentioned the tour in a speech he delivered on Nov. 6 in Omaha, in which he lamented "a political setting that is bordering on a civility crisis at home and a civilization crisis abroad." Following his appearance Tuesday at the Lincoln Financial Group Insurance Company auditorium, Mr. Leach plans to visit Augusta, Me., on Wednesday, and to visit all 50 states over the next 18 months to discuss civil discourse in American society.

To get a better sense of place, some armchair travelers eat ethnic food or page through coffee-table books of glossy photographs; I have one uncle who likes to read geographical histories of any area before he visits. But I'm a fiction reader, so I was thrilled to learn that Dalkey Archive Press - the Illinois publisher that specializes in (among other things) high-quality translations of challenging fiction - has started a "Best European Fiction" series modeled on the familiar "Best American" books. "Best European Fiction 2010" went on sale last week, featuring 35 stories from 30 countries, and it offers an appealingly diverse look at the Continent's fiction scene: from prominent authors like Hungary's George Konrad and Spain's Julián Ríos to relative newcomers like Croatia's Neven Usumovic and Ireland's Julian Gough. The book was edited by the Bosnian Aleksandar Hemon, who now lives in Chicago and says he considers himself both a European writer and an American one. In an e-mail exchange last week, Paper Cuts asked him about "Best European Fiction 2010."

Was Roger Avary, the incarcerated screenwriter of "Pulp Fiction," moved from a prison work furlough program to a county jail because he was Tweeting about his prison experience? Though it is the prerogative of rock stars to announce that they are breaking up their band and then reconstitute it months (or weeks or days) later, Nine Inch Nails seems to be serious when it says that it will no longer perform as a group. After playing what it said were its final shows in August and September, the hard-core rock group led by Trent Reznor said on its Web site, nin.com, that it was auctioning off its instruments and other touring equipment on eBay, The Guardian reported. "We've been going through the NIN touring and studio rigs and are getting rid of a large selection of gear and equipment the band is no longer in need of," the band said in a statement on its site, adding: "We do not know which (if any) tour these items are from unless specified, nor can we get any items autographed, so please do not ask." Among the pieces that the band has put up for sale are a Gibson banjitar (a half-banjo, half-guitar hybrid) that was selling for more than $1,500, and a guitar decorated with artwork from the Nine Inch Nails album "The Fragile," whose bidding price had passed $2,250.

In the latest round of the continuing dispute known as Artists vs. Critics, a British playwright has suggested that reviewers who gave bad notices to her latest show had spent the afternoon drinking before seeing the play that night. The playwright, Timberlake Wertenbaker, told The Guardian that several of the critics who reviewed her play "The Line," which began performances on Nov. 18 at the Arcola Theater in London, attended an evening performance that followed the presentation of the London Evening Standard theater awards that afternoon -- a four-hour ceremony at the Royal Opera House that included a Champagne reception and wine service at lunch. Ms. Wertenbaker said that the critics "weren't all drunk but it's hard to get through something like that without being tired," adding that "The Line" "is a complicated play, it's difficult, you have to pay attention to it."

Consumer Reports finds that most chickens are still not safe to handle. "In our latest analysis of fresh, whole broilers bought at stores nationwide, two-thirds harbored salmonella and/or campylobacter, the leading bacterial causes of foodborne disease. That's a modest improvement since January 2007, when we found that eight of 10 broilers harbored those pathogens. But the numbers are still far too high, especially for campylobacter. Though the government has been talking about regulating it for years, it has yet to do so.''

In these days of heightened computer security, an average computer user has to manage a hundred passwords in his or her head, or so it seems. Every computer system you use at work, and every Internet site you use regularly (or even once in a blue moon) wants you to create an account with a password. Not only that, the requirements for the passwords are becoming more stringent: mix up letters and numbers they say, and sometimes non-alphanumeric symbols too. Don't include any words that can be found in the dictionary, or the names of your children and pets. Change the password every ninety days. And don't write it down anywhere.

I have a friend who recently told me that, as the recession took hold, he was forced to stop all capital expenditures for his wholesale distribution company, and I mean all. He even put off spending $2,500 to replace the server that runs his entire company. He has been hit hard, and I understand why he stopped all expenditures. He had no choice. But I suggested to him that if the old server went down, it would be the most expensive $2,500 that he ever "saved." Clearly, the damage caused would far exceed the money saved. He agreed, and he's now setting aside cash to get a new one.

What we're reading on Monday morning.Preparing for Polanski: Roman Polanski could be released as soon as Monday from a Swiss prison and be placed under house arrest at his 19,000-square-foot chalet in Gstaad, The Associated Press reports. Mr. Polanski, the 76-year-old filmmaker who is awaiting possible extradition to the United States, still needs to pay $4.5 million in bail; he'll also have to pay a $2,000 installation fee and and a $200 monthly maintenance cost for the security monitoring device he will wear. "He will have no prison regime," a Swiss justice ministry spokesman told The A.P. "He is completely free to determine his daily schedule. It's also up to him to get in food and other supplies." Mr. Polanski fled the United States in 1978 before his sentencing for having sex with a 13-year-old girl.Stephen Gately Is Remembered: Agence France-Presse reports on a tribute concert held in London on Sunday night for Stephen Gately, a member of the Irish pop band Boyzone, who died in October. Among the notables who came to pay tribute to Mr. Gately, 33, who died from natural causes stemming from excess fluid in his lungs, were Cherie Blair, Ian McKellen and Graham Norton, as well as the singer's former bandmates Ronan Keating, Mikey Graham, Keith Duffy and Shane Lynch. "I am just still walking around in a daze really," the British pop singer Chesney Hawkes told Agence France-Presse. "Such a shock, so young, so vibrant, such a lovely guy."Gaga as Theater: Is a Lady Gaga concert a pop-music event or a work of theater? To answer this question, The Guardian enlisted Kelly Nestruck, the theater critic for The Globe and Mail in Canada, to review Lady Gaga's new tour, called the Monster Ball, in Toronto. His verdict? "The Monster Ball ain't 'Gypsy,' " Mr. Nestruck writes. During a performance of her song "Boys, Boys, Boys," he writes that Lady Gaga "removed tufts of her costume until she was down to a thin landing strip of apparel. Not even 'La Cage Aux Folles' and 'Priscilla: Queen of the Desert' could beat this wardrobe."Everyone Wants to Get Into the Act: In The New Yorker, Michael Schulman reports on the resourceful staff members at Orso, a restaurant in Manhattan's theater district, who have joined together to stage a production of the S. N. Behrman comedy "Biography" while they await other acting jobs. (Anita Gates's review of the play for The New York Times can be found here.) "I wish them well," Joe Allen, the restaurant's owner, tells The New Yorker. "And, if they get, as they say, discovered, good for them. There'll be someone else to take their jobs."

The reverberations continue from what the University of East Anglia says was the illegal dissemination of thousands of files from its Climatic Research Unit (CRU). Over the weekend university officials put out an update saying 95 percent of the raw land-surface temperature data in question have been available to scientists and skeptics for several years, although Roger A. Pielke Jr. of the University of Colorado, Boulder, said he was told differently as recently as August. (Realclimate.org posted the locations of various data sets.) He credited the university and climate center for moving now to be clearer about the data archives and to provide more access. "When the data is available in its original form those skeptical of climate science can then do the temperature math themselves out in the open where everyone can see their work," Dr. Pielke wrote on Sunday. "If the global numbers come out as CRU has presented over the years, then it will strike a blow to skepticism about global temperature trend records produced by CRU and restore a good deal of credibility to this area of climate science."

The lighting of the Christmas Tree in Rockefeller Center won’t happen until next Wednesday, but for those of you who can’t wait until then for an extravagant public display of fir and electricity, head to the Upper West Side Monday night for Winter’s Eve at Lincoln Square. The free program along Broadway from Columbus Circle to 68th Street includes music, street performances, food tastings from local restaurants and activities for children. The festivities begin at 5:30 p.m. with a tree lighting, hosted by Joy Behar of “The View,” at Dante Park. Stay to listen to the hot sounds of the Brooklyn Afrobeat band Antibalas, on break from the hit show “Fela!” and the cool jazz of the bassist and composer Ben Allison, who will be holding court at the American Folk Art Museum. Part of the proceeds will benefit City Harvest.

“If this is what a disaster looks like, bring on the apocalypse,” Ben Brantley writes in his review of “The Starry Messenger.” The new play by Kenneth Lonergan was plagued by bad publicity before it opened, with particular scorn directed at Matthew Broderick for his apparent inability to remember his lines. But that’s all just water under the bridge now. Mr. Brantley writes that “the gentle, compassionate comic drama” at the Acorn Theater “has the sweet taste of redemption.” The story about a middle-aged man swept up in a affair with a younger woman, “re-establishes Mr. Lonergan, who hasn’t had a new play on the boards since 2001, as a possessor of all the crucial parts of a good dramatist’s anatomy: a critical mind, an empathetic heart and a musical ear that hears whole lives in sentences. And Mr. Broderick delivers his finest, most affecting performance in years.” Redemption indeed.

Diane Birch’s songs “are retro-leaning in a nonspecific way (think Zooey Deschanel meets Joni Mitchell, with the tiniest dash of Norah Jones),” writes Amanda Petrusich and “her rich, husky vocals go down soft and easy.” Sip slowly while Ms. Birch plays City Winery at 8 Monday night. According to traders, at the close of the New York cash market on Friday, the rate on the outstanding three-month bill was 0.02 percent. Four uniformed police officers were shot to death Sunday morning as they sat in a coffee shop preparing to begin patrol, prompting a widespread search for the gunman, who remained at large. Late Sunday, the authorities said they were seeking a ''person of interest'' in the shootings whom they identified as Maurice Clemmons, 37. They described him as having an ''extensive, violent criminal history'' in Arkansas and said he had recently been arrested in Pierce County and charged with assaulting a police officer and raping a child.

Let's say you're an investor who has followed Hewlett-Packard for ages. The company's slowing printer sales concern you, largely because you think this may be a long-term issue rather than a short-term blip. Meanwhile, you're bullish about H.P.'s services business. Coming up with a financial model to capture your intuitions can prove tricky, especially if you're a philosophy major. A start-up called Trefis has stepped in to fill a void, lending a hand to liberal arts majors and avid investors alike by giving them some easy-to-use modeling tools.

8 P.M. (IFC) TRISTRAM SHANDY: A COCK AND BULL STORY (2006) ''The Life and Opinions of Tristram Shandy, Gentleman'' by Laurence Sterne is widely believed to be unfilmable. The director Michael Winterbottom tries nonetheless in this behind-the-scenes farce about an ill-fated adaptation of an 18th-century classic and its ill-mannered star, Steve Coogan, played, naturally, by Mr. Coogan (above right, with Rob Brydon). In a review in The New York Times, A. O. Scott wrote that Mr. Winterbottom had performed a valuable service by inoculating Sterne's book ''against the depredations of earnest, prestige-minded adapters, while preserving a lot of the book's insouciant, inventive spirit (and some of its best moments),'' adding, ''He has also paid loving, knowing tribute to the crazy enterprise of filmmaking, a torment to those mad enough to pursue it and a delight, at least in this case, for those of us lucky enough to sit and watch.'' 8 P.M. (NBC) HEROES H. R. G. (Jack Coleman) receives visitors, and Samuel (Robert Knepper) sees the realization of his grand scheme. Meanwhile Peter (Milo Ventimiglia) confronts the truth and takes drastic measures. And Claire (Hayden Panettiere) winds up in an unexpected place.

JOSEPH--Frederick H.,of New York City and Andover, MA died on November 27, 2009. Born in Boston, MA in 1937, he was the son of Sara Mostowitz Joseph and the late Edward Morris Joseph. Mr. Joseph received an A.B. from Harvard College in 1959, and subsequently served as an ensign aboard the minesweeper USS Exultant, where he received a letter of commendation for devotion to duty for fighting a fire aboard ship. Upon graduating from Harvard Business School with an M.B.A. in 1963, Mr. Joseph began his career at E.F. Hutton in corporate finance, where he was trained by his friend and mentor John Shad. He joined Shearson Hammill's corporate finance department in 1970, and in 1973, was promoted to Chief Operating Officer. Mr. Joseph joined Drexel Burnham Lambert in 1974 to co-manage the company's corporate finance department, and became Chief Executive Officer in May 1985. Drexel is credited with the commercialization of the high yield bond market, having underwritten more than 1500 issues and raising more than $158 billion from 1978 through 1989. This included many financings of less than $100 million, some of which funded entrepreneurial venture capitalists including Steve Wynn, T. Boone Pickens, and Ted Turner. From January 1994 until May 1998, Mr. Joseph was Chairman of Clovebrook Capital Corp., a boutique investment banking firm. From May 1998 until April 2001, he was a Senior Advisor and Managing Director of ING Barings LLC. Mr. Joseph returned to focus on middle market companies with Morgan Lewis Githens & Ahn, Inc., which was renamed Morgan Joseph & Co. Inc. in October 2002. Morgan Joseph since has developed into a company of more than 140 employees, which has completed more than $29 billion in transactions, including more than 140 M&A transactions and 90 financings. Mr. Joseph was a passionate outdoorsman and hobbyist. Hunting, farming, and horseback riding were an integral part of his life. He traveled through much of the US and Canada on hunting trips, frequently accompanied by friends, sons-in-law and grandchildren. His trophies included a Pope and Young-rated black bear and a Pope and Young rated atypical white-tailed deer. He also participated in numerous Outward Bound and NOLS exploration courses, including one to Africa with his son, Mark, and one to Mexico with his daughter, Tommi Beth, and her husband, Mike. He was often found working in his home blacksmith forge, where he designed and forged his own tools. He is survived by his wife, Linn Anderson of Andover, MA and her son Andrew Prezkop of Washington, DC; his children: Lisa and Bill Schultz of Summit, NJ; Melinda Burke of Brooklyn, NY; Amy and Jon Humphreys of Summit, NJ; Tommi Beth and Mike McHugh of Denver, CO; and Mark and Starry Joseph of Gloucester, MA; and his former wife, Susan Joseph of New Vernon, NJ. He was the beloved grandfather of Billy and Krissy Schultz, Charlotte and Daniel Burke, Molly and Olivia Humphreys and Lucy McHugh. He is also survived by his brother Stephen Joseph and wife Angelique Craney of Chester, CT and New York City; his sister Michelle Joseph Morris and husband Chris of Williamsburg, MA; his mother, Sara Joseph, as well as numerous nieces and nephews. Mr. Joseph was a member of the Board of Directors of several companies, a Trustee of WNET/Channel Thirteen, and a Director of the Multiple Myeloma Research Foundation. He also served as Vice Chairman of the Partners of '63, a group of Harvard Business School classmates dedicated to improving public education in this country. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Multiple Myeloma Research Foundation, Dana Farber Cancer Institute or the charity of your choice. Private interment at West Parish Cemetery in Andover MA. A memorial service will be held in New York City for family and friends. For details on the memorial service please call Morgan Joseph & Co. Inc. 212-218-3700.

As the Nets have become a team in transition, from conference contender to doormat, from established stars to burgeoning ones and from their Meadowlands home toward Brooklyn, they had few constants. One of them was their coach, Lawrence Frank. But even that changed Sunday, when, on the verge of equaling the worst start in N.B.A. history, the Nets fired Frank. The team replaced him with the assistant coach Tom Barrise on an interim basis.

ECONOMIC INDICATORS The Fed's collection of anecdotal evidence on the economy and updates on manufacturing are due this week. Reports will include Chicago purchasing managers' index for November (Monday); the Institute for Supply Management's manufacturing index for November, construction spending for October and pending home sales for October (Tuesday); Automatic Data Processing's employment report for November and the Federal Reserve beige book (Wednesday); revised third-quarter productivity, weekly jobless claims and the I.S.M.'s service index for November (Thursday); and unemployment for November and factory orders for October (Friday).

Office work, filled with overflowing e-mail inboxes and pointless meetings, could be a lot more efficient and productive. One start-up, Asana, is trying to fix the problem. How? Well, that is still a secret. Asana was founded last December by Dustin Moskovitz, above, a co-founder of Facebook, and Justin Rosenstein, an engineering manager at Facebook, after they left the company. Since then, they have built a bare-bones Web site and, they claim, a product that will change the way we work, though they are not yet ready to explain how.

Stress fractures are one of the more pernicious injuries in sports, afflicting the experienced and the aspiring, with no regard for competitive timing. Last year, Tiger Woods managed to win the U.S. Open despite suffering from stress fractures in his left leg (as well as other leg and knee injuries), while the great British marathoner Paula Radcliffe struggled through the Beijing Olympics Marathon on a leg barely recovered from a stress fracture, one of several she's suffered. The International Association of Athletics Federations, the world governing body for track and field, recently described stress fractures, with a kind of grim resignation, as "the curse of athletes."

KABUL - I was one of the hundreds of young photojournalists who came to this distant country in 2001 to photograph my first war; naïve, a little reckless, and mostly unprepared. At the time, the Taliban ruled most of the country. Only a thin slice of mountainous territory in the north, between Tajikistan and the Panjshir Valley, was controlled by the opposition, the Northern Alliance. My travel companions were Matthew McAllester, who was then a foreign correspondent for Newsday, and Tyler Hicks, a photographer for The New York Times.

Thomas Jefferson was homeless for 12 years on the streets of Philadelphia after returning as a combat veteran from the battlefields of Iraq. "When I came home, I was messed up," he said. Mr. Jefferson struggled with substance abuse and had a stroke, ending up in a wheelchair. Now 45, he lives less than a mile from where the man who became the third president drafted the Declaration of Independence. The modern-day Jefferson is pictured in the Assembly Room of Independence Hall, where the document was adopted on July 4, 1776.

If you're planning to talk about President Obama's new military strategy in Afghanistan with your students or children, here are some New York Times and Learning Network resources to help you.

Congressional Republicans offered qualified support Tuesday for President Obama's proposed troop increase in Afghanistan but several senior Democrats took sharp exception to the president's plan, illustrating the deep divide in the party over the conflict.
President Obama announced that he would speed 30,000 additional troops to Afghanistan in coming months, but he vowed to start bringing American forces home in the middle of 2011.

As wartime speeches go, it was a strange and schizophrenic one, laying its emphasis on two not-necessarily-compatible goals - victory, and a swift withdrawal. In one breath Obama was echoing his previous description of Afghanistan as a "war of necessity," referencing our "vital national interests" and describing the conflict's stakes as both "the security of our Allies, and the common security of the world." The next he was offering the Taliban a date to circle on their calendars, and hold out for throughout the American offensive to come - July of 2011, that is, when the Obama administration is now committed to beginning the withdrawal of our forces from Afghanistan. This commitment, of course, was hedged with a substantial caveat: "We will execute this transition responsibly, taking into account conditions on the ground." But still, the date is there: After more than eight years of fighting the United States, our enemies know that we've set ourselves a deadline to win or get out that's only a short eighteen months away.

WEDNESDAY'S PUZZLE - I heeded this puzzle's 62 Across advice before I even knew what it was. If HASTE MAKES WASTE, then my solving performance on this puzzle was pretty frugal. It wasn't that I preferred to plod, it was just the pace the puzzle imposed. Of course that very same HASTE MAKES WASTE entry serves as a hint to the puzzle's theme, the idea being that if you change the H in HASTE, it makes WASTE.

My restaurant review this week is of SD26, which Tony May and his daughter Marisa May recently opened off Madison Square Park in the Flatiron District. Mr. May is a legendary figure in New York restaurant circles. He was for almost 20 years the general manager of the Rainbow Room and later its owner; for almost another 20 years he was the owner and gracious host at San Domenico, on the south end of Central Park. He is worth taking seriously, as is his daughter, who cut her teeth at San Domenico and is an owner and gracious host at the new restaurant. Have you been to SD26? Do you wish to go? Do you recall meals at San Domenico worth sharing with other readers? Or at the old Rainbow Room? This is the place to post your comments, and to bear witness to the civil exchange of ideas.

The Mets did not offer arbitration to their two Type B free agents, Carlos Delgado and Fernando Tatis, and thus will not receive compensatory draft picks if either player signs elsewhere. That is not a surprise; the Mets did not want Delgado to accept an offer and have his 2010 salary, which would be negotiated or decided by an arbitrator, hover near the $12 million he made last season.

Maplewood police were called to a house on Pierson Road on Thursday when its burglar alarm went off. They said they saw that someone had recently broken into the home through a basement window, and called in the Essex County Sheriff's Office's K-9 unit. According to Capt. Paul Conlon, the dog tracked the suspect's scent across the Maplewood Country Club's golf course, losing the trail near 747 Valley Street. The next day, they arrested a suspect, Nicholas Cardone, 18, of South Orange, near his home. The police said he had several pieces of jewelry from the Maplewood robbery with him when he was arrested. He was taken to Essex County Jail and held on $25,000 bail. -- Tina Kelley

Roundabout Theater Company's revival of "Bye Bye Birdie" will be going steady with Broadway a little longer than originally planned. On Tuesday, Roundabout said that its production of the musical will be extended by two weeks, and will play at Henry Miller's Theater through Jan. 24. Though this "Birdie" revival, the first to be performed on Broadway since the original 1960 production, took it on the beak from critics, Roundabout said that the show has sold at over 90 percent capacity each week throughout its run. The musical, which is directed and choreographed by Robert Longbottom, and whose cast includes John Stamos, Gina Gershon and Bill Irwin, will have played 40 previews and 117 regular performances at the time of its closing.

For some people, hunting is a new way to get closer to the food they eat. But it's nothing new for the New Orleans chef John Besh. "Today I hunt with the same group of guys that I've hunted with for the past 20 years,'' he writes in his new book, "My New Orleans, the Cookbook,'' (Andrews McMeel). For those of you who are novice hunters, or have done it for years, Besh will be sharing the wisdom of his years in duck blinds and woods and in the kitchens of his restaurants August, Besh Steak, La Provence and Lüke. My column in the Dining section is on aged rums. It's a somewhat perplexing subject for me as I don't always understand how prolonged aging benefits rum. To my taste, the smoothness and complexity that can come from long-term barrel aging can often rob rum of its character. The effects of aging can be like trading a singular rum-like complexity for a more generic sipping complexity, made up of similar chocolate and caramel flavors that you can find in single malt, Armagnac and Cognac. It's not always the case, as we did find some wonderful aged rums, but it happened often enough.

Susan Katz thought she knew all about caring for old people. Trained as a social worker, she had spent more than 15 years working for home care agencies and for assisted and independent living facilities. So when her own parents began to falter in their mid-80s - her mother had Parkinson's disease, and her father was debilitated by the aftereffects of prostate cancer treatment - she felt prepared to step in and help.

As a new uncertain decade dawns, is rock music ready for a second coming of the Strokes? That vintage early-2000s East Village quintet, which was hailed as the savior of indie rock and then crushed under the weight of unmeetable expectations, said that it would reunite next year to play its first live shows since 2006. Julian Casablancas, the front man of the Strokes, told Billboard that the group would headline the Isle of Wight festival in Britain on June 12, alongside Jay-Z; the performance will likely be followed by other summer concert appearances in Europe and North America. "When we meet with the band and talk and play music, it's just a different level of ease and comfort," Mr. Casablancas told Billboard. "Everyone's more easygoing and everyone feels more confident and just trusts each other a little bit." Mr. Casablancas is promoting a new solo album, "Phrazes for the Young." The Strokes 2001 debut, "Is This It," was critically well received, but the albums "Room on Fire" (in 2003) and "First Impressions of Earth" drew weaker responses.

Starting today, Lufthansa has a three-day Europe sale to 29 cities, with round-trip fares as low as $465. The sale is good for travel from Jan. 8 to March 25. Travelers who act fast can save an additional $100 by downloading a limited-availability promotional code. Book by Dec. 3.

If it's December, this must be Miami. Along with the art world, which flies south for Art Basel (Dec. 3-6), design aficionados head there for Design Miami, which runs from today (the invitation-only opening) to Dec. 5. This year's mood: cautious optimism. For dealers in contemporary design, 2009 has been a bummer, with the sky's-the-limit prices of design art plummeting to earth. But the hardy band of 14 galleries (the smallest number since 2005, the show's first year) that are exhibiting here are banking, for the most part, on more accessible work by younger designers.

A British medical researcher believes she has answered the longstanding question of what killed Jane Austen -- and it isn't the contemporary wave of Austen-horror mashup books. The Guardian reported that Katherine White of the Addison's Disease Self Help Group has written an article for the British Medical Journal's Medical Humanities magazine in which she says that Austen probably died of tuberculosis caught from cattle.

I've never been fully committed to the notion that we're going to have a "double dip" -- that the economy will slide back into recession. But it has been clear for a while that it's a serious possibility, for two reasons. First, a large part of the growth we've had has been driven by the stimulus -- but the stimulus has already had its maximum impact on the growth of GDP, will hit its maximum impact on the level of GDP in the middle of next year, and then will begin to fade out. Second, the rise in manufacturing production is to a large extent an inventory bounce -- and this, too, will fade out in the quarters ahead.

The Washington National Opera said that it plans to mount fewer productions and has cut staff members amid a tightening economy. In a news release, the opera company said that it would produce five main stage operas in its 2010-11 season (compared with six in 2009-10, and seven in 2008-9). The company also said that it had eliminated eight positions within its business and artistic departments and that it has frozen salaries and suspended its retirement-plan contributions for its employees. Additionally, its staff members will take a one-week furlough in the last week of the current calendar year, with additional rolling furloughs expected in the spring. In a statement, the opera's president, Kenneth R. Feinberg, said that the company had achieved balanced budgets for two straight years, in part due to the contributions of "a few exceptionally generous donors." He added that the newly announced cuts "make good sense" because "our patrons have spoken loudly and clearly, telling us that they care more about the quality of productions than the quantity of productions."

In the first comprehensive international report on Antarctica's climate, there was strong agreement that the West Antarctic Ice Sheet will contribute substantially to the ongoing rise in sea levels in a warming world, while increased snowfall in the interior could offset the contribution somewhat. What we're reading (and watching) on Tuesday morning.Couple Denies Crashing White House Party: Tareq and Michaele Salahi, the couple who made their way into President Obama's first state dinner while being followed by a crew for a television reality show, broke their silence in an interview on "The Today Show" Tuesday morning. The Salahis told Matt Lauer that they were not party crashers -- "There isn't anyone who would have the audacity or poor behavior to do that," Ms. Salahi said -- but declined to say who had invited them to the event, citing a Secret Service investigation.No Release Yet for Polanski: Swiss officials said they will not set Roman Polanski free from a prison near Zurich before Friday, Reuters reported. A spokesman for the Swiss Justice Department said it was still waiting for the director to pay his $4.5 million bail and fulfill other security requirements before he is placed under house arrest in his chalet in Gstaad. Mr. Polanski, 76, is awaiting possible extradition to the United States, which he fled in 1978 after pleading guilty to having sex with a 13-year-old girl.'Bar' Dropped, 'Rivers' Ebbs: Here are two more season passes you can erase from your TiVo playlist: TNT has canceled "Raising the Bar," its legal drama created by Steven Bochco of "Hill Street Blues" and "NYPD Blue" fame, citing low ratings, Variety reported. The trade publication also says that CBS has pulled its medical drama "Three Rivers" from its schedule; though the show isn't officially canceled, the network will probably replace it with another medical show, "Miami Trauma."Spoiling the Spoilers: In a comic rant in The Guardian, Grace Dent takes aim at spoilers -- not the people who give away plot details of television shows and movies, but the people who are constantly complaining about having the suspense of these programs and films spoiled for them. Ms. Dent writes, "My general rule of thumb is, if you're old enough to buy a flat screen Sony Bravia TV and a full-speaker Bang & Olufsen wall of sound to complement it, you're officially too old to cry like a girl" if someone reveals a crucial plot detail from "Up" or "The Wire."

We're hardly averse to a compliment at T. After all, we work in fashion. So when you e-mail to say that you like us - that you really, really like us - we'll take it. (You look cute, too, by the way.) But we don't want to get stuck in a style rut, or appear insensitive to criticism. So starting this Friday, we'll unveil a rejuvenated Web site, a daily style magazine that better displays T's jaw-dropping images and seamlessly integrates our popular daily blog. You'll still be able to view all of the content from the 15 annual issues of T, as well as our exclusive celebrity videos and constantly refreshed Web-only features. There's even a new culture section. All this, plus it's easier to navigate and read, and quicker to load. We're pretty proud of our new look, but since we're among friends, don't be afraid to let us know what you think. Seriously. Did we mention how cute you look?

“Would John Darnielle, a guitar-strumming solo songwriter, have found the same dedicated following for his songs if he hadn’t billed himself as the Mountain Goats?” asks Jon Pareles. “It’s impossible to say, but his songs swirl together the mythic and the confessional in metaphorical splendor.” Go to hear that splendor when Mr. Darnielle, whom Mr. Pareles calls, a “literary thinker,” plays at Webster Hall tonight. His set will feature songs off his latest album, “The Life of the World to Come,” based on a literary goldmine rife with deep questions, the Bible.

Mark Twain spent four months in Hawaii when he was just 31 writing “rudely funny” dispatches for The Sacramento Union. Upon his return, the great satirist delivered a lecture at Cooper Union in 1867 on those “Sandwich Islands.” Now that lecture will be read again, this time by radio host and Symphony Space co-founder Isaiah Sheffer as part of “Great Evenings in the Great Hall: Art and Literature,” a celebration of Cooper Union’s 150 anniversary. The free event, which begins at 6:30 p.m., will also feature Tony Kushner, Siri Hustvedt and Salman Rushdie reading from their own works while Olympia Dukakis will read from W. H. Auden. What better way to kick off December than a little Aloha from Mark Twain?

Last year Tina Ramirez, the feisty founder of Ballet Hispanico, retired after leading the company for 40 years, at the age of 80. Over the years, Ms. Ramirez transformed the troupe into one of the leading Hispanic-American dance organizations in the country. Now, it’s the job of the new artistic director Eduardo Vilaro to take Ballet Hispanico into its next phase. He’ll get to show the dance world what he’ s got when the troupe begins its season at the Joyce Theater tonight at 7:30. To start, Mr. Vilaro has chosen three premieres: Andrea Miller’s “Nací,” an exploration of personal identity; Ron De Jesús’ “Tríptico,” in which traditional Latin social-dance rhythms are infused with the power and speed of contemporary dance; and Annabelle López Ochoa’ s “Locked Up Laura,” a wry commentary on what happens when one dancer in a partnership loses focus.

Christopher Walken, a veteran of the spooky and the strange, sure can tell a good body-part story — which he’ll be doing in his return to Broadway this winter after 10 years, as a man searching for his missing hand in the play “A Behanding in Spokane.” Mr. Walken will be joined by Zoe Kazan and Anthony Mackie as two con artists, and Sam Rockwell as a hotel clerk, in the new black comedy by Martin McDonagh, whose plays on Broadway have included “The Lieutenant of Inishmore,” “The Pillowman” and “The Beauty Queen of Leenane.” Mr. Walken last appeared on Broadway as Gabriel Conroy in “James Joyce’s The Dead,” for which he was nominated for a Tony Award for best actor in a musical. “A Behanding in Spokane” is scheduled to run for 16 weeks, with previews beginning on Feb. 15 and the opening scheduled for March 4 at the Schoenfeld Theater. ... The producers of next spring’s revival of “La Cage aux Folles” confirmed that the Emmy Award-winning actor Kelsey Grammer (“Frasier”) would play the nightclub owner Georges opposite the British actor Douglas Hodge as Albin, his partner and the club’s leading drag queen. Mr. Grammer’s last outing on Broadway was as the title character in the 2000 revival of “Macbeth,” which received poor reviews and closed after 8 previews and 13 regular performances. “La Cage aux Folles” is to start previews on April 6 and open on April 18 at the Longacre Theater.

Producers of the Off Broadway play “Made in Heaven” have relented on their claim to the SoHo Playhouse, saying on Monday that they would close their show so the theater could host a transfer of the Eugene O’Neill play “The Emperor Jones.” Last week the Irish Repertory Theater said it planned to bring its production of “The Emperor Jones,” starring John Douglas Thompson, to the SoHo Playhouse beginning on Dec. 15 — an announcement that startled the producers of “Made in Heaven,” a comedy about conjoined twins that opened at that theater on Nov. 2. The “Made in Heaven” producers said that their contract with the theater gave them the discretion to close their show after giving four weeks’ notice. But on Monday they said they would close after the Dec. 7 performance. In a statement, Barbara Ligeti, the lead producer of “Made in Heaven,” said, “The SoHo Playhouse made us a very favorable offer, and we felt that sparring with them, to the detriment of the Irish Rep’s wonderful production, would be counterproductive and mean-spirited.”.

Though it is the prerogative of rock stars to announce that they are breaking up their band and then reconstitute it months (or weeks or days) later, Nine Inch Nails seems to be serious when it says that it will no longer perform as a group. After playing what it said were its final shows in August and September, the hard-core rock group led by Trent Reznor said on its Web site, nin.com, that it was auctioning off its instruments and other touring equipment on eBay, The Guardian reported. Among the pieces put up for sale are a Gibson banjitar (a banjo-guitar hybrid) that was selling for more than $1,500, and a guitar decorated with artwork from the Nine Inch Nails album “The Fragile,” whose bidding price had passed $2,250.

In May the stop-and-start hospital sitcom ''Scrubs'' had what sure looked like its final episode: parade of past characters, teary walk-off, blooper reel, production shots of the lead actors doing their ''series wraps.'' A few weeks later the show got a last-minute reprieve: it was renewed for a ninth season, which begins Tuesday night on ABC with two new episodes. It's still called ''Scrubs'' despite the protests of its creator, Bill Lawrence, who wanted a new title to indicate how drastically he was changing the show. As ''House'' has done over the last season and a half, ''Scrubs'' is significantly remaking its cast, though on a much tighter schedule: scene to scene, you can watch the new show emerging from the old.

The debt crisis in Dubai is about to test one of the fastest-growing areas in banking, Islamic finance, and put the city-state's opaque judicial system on trial, according to bankers and experts in finance. Many loans and bonds that comply with Shariah, or Islamic law, were issued in recent years by Dubai World, the investment arm of Dubai, and other Persian Gulf companies as oil-rich Middle East nations increased spending, and the global credit crisis fed debt investments in emerging markets.

Gloria Macapagal Arroyo, the deeply unpopular Philippine president, announced Monday that she would run for a seat in Congress in elections scheduled for next year, ending months of speculation about her plans when her term ends in June but also raising questions about her long-term intentions. ''I have been mulling different ways to stay involved,'' Mrs. Arroyo said in a taped message that a government radio station broadcast on Monday. ''After much soul-searching, I have decided I will file my certificate of candidacy for Congress in order to serve the hard-working people of my province.''

Like overstretched American homeowners, governments and companies across the globe are groaning under the weight of debts that, some fear, might never be fully paid back. As Dubai, that one-time wonderland in the desert, struggles to pay its bills, a troubling question hangs over the financial world: Is this latest financial crisis an isolated event, or a harbinger of still more debt shocks?

MITCHELL--Jan. The Trustees and staff of The Metropolitan Museum of Art mourn with deep sadness the passing of Jan Mitchell, cherished Honorary Trustee and Benefactor who, for more than four decades, demonstrated his passion for art through wide-ranging support for this institution. His breathtaking donation in 1991 of 70 objects of Precolumbian gold transformed the Museum's Ancient American holdings, and the Jan Mitchell Treasury, which opened in 1993, now houses the most representative display of American gold objects in the world. His interests and collecting extended to a broad range of art, including European paintings and Greek and Roman art, and over the years his benevolence toward the Met touched those and many other areas in significant ways, from important gifts and loans of works of art to support for exhibitions, acquisitions, curatorships, gallery renovations, and other activities. In recent years, he and his sons also endowed a European paintings gallery in memory of his wife Ellin and son Adrian. Jan was a trusted advisor and treasured friend, and he will be greatly missed. We extend our condolences to his entire family. James R. Houghton, Chairman Thomas P. Campbell, Director Emily K. Rafferty, President

John Demjanjuk, a retired American autoworker who has been the subject of more than three decades of legal proceedings over his Nazi-era past, went on trial here on Monday, accused of helping to force 27,900 Jews to their deaths during the Holocaust. Prosecutors charge that Mr. Demjanjuk, 89, listed by the Simon Wiesenthal Center as its most wanted Nazi war criminal, worked as a guard at the Sobibor death camp in Nazi-occupied Poland in 1943. It is the second time Mr. Demjanjuk has been prosecuted, after he was sentenced to death in Israel in 1988 only to have his conviction overturned five years later as a case of mistaken identity.

FOX--Dr. Jack J.,former co-chairman of the developmental therapy and clinical investigation program at the Sloan-Kettering Institute, died Sunday, November 22 in Madison, WI, where he resided after living in White Plains, NY for 40 years. He was 92. Dr. Fox's lab synthesized 5-fluouricil, a cancer drug that is still in used in chemotherapy. He also played a key role in inventing methods to synthesize nucleosides, including the antibiotics gougerotin and blasticidin-S. In 1977 he received the C. S. Hudson Award in Carbohydrate Chemistry from the American Chemical Society. He also received the SKI's Sloan Award in Cancer Research, the Special Member Award from the Pharmaceutical Society of Japan as well as the George Norlin Award from the University of Colorado. Born in 1916 in New York City, he grew up in Brooklyn and studied at a local yeshiva, before going to the University of Colorado, where he graduated in 1938. It was there he became an organizer for the United Cannery, Agricultural and Packing House Workers of America (later merged into the United Packinghouse Workers). In Colorado he met Ruth Inabu, whom he married in 1939. During World War II he served as a navigator in the US Army Air Corps, stationed in England. After the war he finished his Ph.D. in chemistry, also at the University of Colorado. He then did his post-doctoral work in Brussels under Jean Brachet. Dr. Fox came to Sloan-Kettering in 1952. He remained there until 1988, when he retired. During his tenure he was named a professor of biochemistry at the Sloan Kettering Division of Cornell University's the Graduate School of Medical Sciences. In 1995 he established a lecture series at Sloan Kettering to honor developments in synthetic chemistry and biomedicine. Dr. Fox and his wife Ruth remained lifelong supporters of causes for social justice. He is survived by two children, Dolores Emspak of Madison, WI, and John Reed Fox, of Acton, MA, as well as four grandchildren and two great-grandchildren. In lieu of flowers please send contributions to the Ruth Inabu and Jack Fox Foundation, 916 Castle Pl., Madison, WI, 53703.

Readers of the Prescriptions blog had plenty to say on Monday after the Congressional Budget Office released its analysis of the impact that health care legislation would have on insurance premiums in 2016. Here is a sampling of the reader comments: ''Good to have the report in. Maybe it will give some of those on the fence cover to support the bill.'' -- Susan, Western Washington

When Mike Huckabee, a former Southern Baptist minister then serving as governor of Arkansas, granted clemency to Maurice Clemmons nine years ago, he cited his age: Mr. Clemmons was 16 when he began the crime spree for which he was sentenced to more than 100 years in prison. Now, Mr. Clemmons is being sought as the suspect in the killing of four uniformed police officers, execution-style, on Sunday as they sat in a coffee shop near Tacoma, Wash., writing reports.
